Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28 I've recently found a study published by Public Health England that says the risk of dying within 30 days of a chemo treatment is 0.3% in primary breast cancer cases. Here is the link to the press release, which in turn has links to the study. Having said that, I absolutely agree that whether to have chemo is about the likely benefit.
Posts.Title: Decission time!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Emagermain I'm so sorry to hear you're still suffering 3 years after treatment. That must make life really difficult for you. I'm 2 years post diagnosis and still get the occasional bout of fatigue, if I overdo it, but I'm generally pretty well.  Do you take tamoxifen or one of the aromatase inhibitors (letrozole, anastrozole or exemestane)? They can have some nasty side effects like joint and muscle stiffness and a lot of people complain about how old they feel.  If you're not taking one of these hormone blockers, then it might be about time to get your blood checked. You might be anaemic or lacking in one of the basic minerals like potassium or magnesium. All those things can cause excessive tiredness. Bottom line is that it's not "normal" to be fatigued for so long (my docs told me up to 2 years), and you don't need to put up with it. Go to your GP and demand some help. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: 3yrs post cancer... I a man struggling with fatigue and this new life...

Posts.Content: Brilliant news! Long may it continue. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: NED?

Posts.Content: Once again Dreamthief is amazing.
Posts.Title: Histology or Pathology ?

Posts.Content: Hi ronstar Sorry to hear you're having all those issues - BC is just the gift that keeps on giving, isn't it? I didn't have shoulder problems nor tamoxifen so I can't comment on those but I did have PN, mostly in my hands. In fact, my onco stopped my paclitaxel after 9 out of 12 sessions as it was pretty serious. By then I had almost completely numb left hand and all my fingers of the right hand were numb and the palm was tingly. He told me that as long as the numbness doesn't start moving up your arm, the PN should be reversible.  Well, it is now 11 months since I finished T and the PN in my right hand has completely gone. In fact that had gone within 6 months. The left hand is fine too, except for slight tingling in 3 fingers - nothing that interferes with using my hand for anything, including microtasks like threading a needle. I think the hand has been pretty much like that for the last 6 months, so maybe the tingling will always be there but it doesn't matter. So the upshot of that ramble is that you should be more or less back to normal within 6 months, but it will get easier before then.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Being fit and well is such a long way off

Posts.Content: I had no problems with surgery, except I had the drain in for 13 weeks as I kept draining fluid (over 100 ml daily). Anaesthetic and healing were both fine. Best thing about surgery was being given an iced lolly in Recovery - such a great idea!
Posts.Title: Moving from Chemo to Surgery August / Sept 2016 - join me here

Posts.Content: That's great Optimistic Often the first step is the hardest. Have you considered a mindfulness course. I found it quite helpful.
Posts.Title: Stubbornness will get you through

Posts.Content: Hi Nickynoodle. Welcome aboard the roller coaster. Of course you're scared - getting a cancer diagnosis is one of the scariest things that can happen to anyone. I can assure you, however, that once you have a treatment plan in place, things will settle down and soon you'll be an old lag, giving everyone else advice.  It's not easy making a lumpectomy/mastectomy decision, and then if you decide to go for mastectomy whether to have reconstruction. I guess the first step is to be sure you have enough information. There's some really good info on the main Macmillan site about breast surgery. I suggest you read that and make notes of any questions. You can then go back to your BCN or surgeon and ask them. There might be lovely ladies here who can answer some too, but not the medical ones of course. Remember too, you don't need to agree to anything unless and until you're absolutely certain.  I started out having a saved skin mastectomy with implant. However, for a long and complicated reasons, I ended up having to have the implant removed. By then I was so over it all, I told my surgeon to just chop it off. I now live my life as lopsided Lizzie and I couldn't be happier with it. In fact I dislike the floppy boob that's left far more than the side that has no boob. My husband didn't mind what I chose - he's just glad I'm well and happy.  Hope it all goes well for you.

Posts.Content: Great article I just came across in Cure Today a US online mag

Posts.Title: neuropathy cancer

Posts.Content: Hi nazia  Julia is right - I had to learn what the lumps and bumps were in my chest area so that I can tell if there's anything new. I do have lumpy bits of scar tissue which seem odd but are perfectly ok. However, they were all checked by ultrasound. It's important that you go get checked just to be safe.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Is it back ?

Posts.Content: Manuka honey is different from all other honeys because of its antiseptic qualities. To get medicinal value from it, get the highest UMF grade you can (UMF is a grading system see http://www.umf.org.nz/) but at least 10. The UMF mark is also an indication of authenticity ie that it's genuine NZ manuka honey, not Tesco's finest in disguise. Others have previously said you can get it from Holland and Barrett in the UK. Otherwise try health food shops or possibly large pharmacies.  Nothing to do with cancer but my brother had a large (50p piece sized) ulcer on his arm after a serious car accident. It just wouldn't heal for 2 years. But then 6 weeks slathering it every day with manuka honey and it was totally healed.That was enough to convince me. I asked about manuka honey while on chemo and was told it's ok but you may wish to check with your unit.  By the way Aneesa1 - keep a very close eye on that temperature. Some units (including the one I went to) say 37.5 as their go to A&E' cut off point. It's certainly high enough to show that you have an infection. As we know, infection is THE highest risk with chemo, and yes, I do mean to scare you, just a bit. Best
Posts.Title: Wheezing and coughing

Posts.Content: Good for you Jojo4 Sounds like you're coming to terms with what's going on.  Christmas may be a bit harder cos of chemo but as long as you don't try to do too much, there's no reason you can't have a fabbo time. After all, it's the people that count, not the number of side dishes you serve with your turkey lol. Shortcuts rool ok. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: I went to Bali about 6 weeks after finishing radio. I live in Australia so it was about 5.5 hours flying time - not quite long haul, but close. I was fine and all the lazing by the pool did me a lot of good.  I agree that you need good insurance though - especially going to the US! Don't be tempted by any offers of cancer exclusions as they'll no doubt try to bring anything back to cancer if you need to claim.  Hope you have a great time.
Posts.Title: Travelling abroad

Posts.Content: Sorry I missed your post Emily. I'm in Australia so I normally try to do the 'night shift' but I was out all day today. I hope by now you've been seen, treated and reassured. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Currently waiting in out of hours :(

Posts.Content: I avoided the bacteria loaded food - soft cheese (blue and brie style), seafood, raw egg products, etc. We also had bottles of alcohol wash dotted around the house and made good use of them. Didn't avoid my cats - just cleaned my hands a lot. No troubles with infection at all.
Posts.Title: Best food to eat and food to avoid

Posts.Content: Hi Ann. I too had AC, but it was dreadful for me so I found the T part of chemo much much easier. It's impossible to say how you'll react but from reading lost of posts over the last couple of years it seems to me that a lot of people who have a hard time with AC/EC find that T is easier on them but the people who sailed through AC/EC get hit by the tax truck. That is entirely anecdotal of course, with no scientific backing whatsoever! However it turns out for you, it will help that you are fit and active though. There seems to be little doubt that exercise helps with getting through chemo.  Wishing you all the best and keep up the fluids.
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects?

Posts.Content: I had a pretty rough time with chemo - especially the AC part. I had pulmonary embolisms and atrial fibrillation and ended up spending a month in hospital including 2 weeks in ICU. Despite all of that, if I had my time over I would still have chemo. Bottom line is - it works. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: I think ali73 hit the nail on the head - you have to be sure that you can live with the decision you make - no what ifs.  Unlike others, my view is that I'll take whatever treatment is offered (and I have) as I'll to anything to lower the risk of recurrence or mets, even if the treatment only offers a few percentage point reduction in risk. After all, all those percentage points add up. I know that's not for everyone but I would find it hard to cope if I'd refused anything and the cancer came back. Best of luck with making your decision. It's not easy. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Such a shame for you Loolyboo! I have had an achy breaky body ever since chemo. Partly the anastrozole but also partly herceptin. There's no doubt the aches improved a bit when I finished H, but not significantly unfortunately. Sad to say but I've found the only thing that really helps is exercise. I finished H in September and the drippy nose disappeared over the next 4 weeks. JeanieB Sorry to hear you're still suffering. My onco and GP have both told me that it takes 2 years to really get over chemo and I can certainly feel it occasionally especially if I overdo it. Most of the time I'm fine - it took 6 months to get to that point. And of course my seroma is starting to come back boo hiss. Best to all Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hey JeanieB I was told that gentle massage would help with scar tissue. Use something like bio-oil (that's what I use) and rub gently in a circular motion. It'll take quite a while but should do some good eventually. Best Lynn xx
