Posts.Content: Hi Hedgewitch. Welcome aboard! Such a shame your friends didn't support you. I've been lucky and had a few great people to support me through the whole bc journey. However, I did have a similar experience a few years back when my hubbie had mental health issues. One person in particular, who I thought was a friend ended up being so not a friend. I'm better off without her.  I have 3 cats and one stray who is trying desperately to get us to adopt her. They were a blessing when i was really  unwell. Lots of companionship and support here. Be a frequent visitor. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Cake is always good ronstar There's a delightful little bakery about halfway between the hospital and my place and I used to pop in frequently after those appointments. I kinda miss it now.  Sorry to hear that you may have to have further surgery. Never nice but hopefully it's just a tidy up and nothing radical.  Big hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Just so fed up - will it ever end?

Posts.Content: Yep absolutely Helen!!!!! Lynn
Posts.Title: A Fundraising Trip abroad After Treatment ?

Posts.Content: Interesting question wordwifie. I have generally avoided supplements because there's potential for negative interaction with other meds I take. I do take calcium/D3 and magnesium, the former as I am taking anastrozole and the latter because I'm taking diuretics, which reduces the level of magnesium in my blood. Both were 'prescribed' by my oncologist.  I have a generally healthy diet (loads of veggies, some fruit, high quality protein including legumes, low carb), try to abstain from sugary and other junk food, and no alcohol (again cos of other meds). I bought an exercise bike as I hate walking and am religious about my 20 mins per day with intervals.  I finished chemo in January and radio in May but my low point was October 2015 when I spent a month in hospital, including 2 weeks in ICU. Overall I feel fantastic and I think I'm fitter than I have been for at least 15 years if not longer. Probably helps that I lost about 5 stone over my 12 month cancer journey.  So the moral of my story is that you don't need to be extreme but you do need to be consistent and committed. So you need to work out what you'll be able to stick with long term.  Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Advice on recovery from cancer treatments

Posts.Content: So many of the options involve hiking, running or cycling - exhausted me just reading the list lol. Lynn
Posts.Title: A Fundraising Trip abroad After Treatment ?

Posts.Content: Thank you for your kind words WhatHappened I'd forgotten about trigger finger but I haven't had that since.  HClare I did get hot flushes when I started arimidex (Jan 16). They were terrible at first but after about a year they slowed and then eventually stopped. I can't remember the last one. So I can't say if acupuncture would help. I do have heaps of sympathy for you though as it can be quite debilitating.
Posts.Title: AIs and acupuncture

Posts.Content: Hi Trojan50 that all sounds rather overwhelming!  Despite all the negatives, in a funny way you're lucky as you've been monitored so problems have been picked up early. None of these decisions is easy. Some of us have chosen to take every treatment that's offered and some have rejected eg chemo or mastectomy.  It's a bumpy ride and every type of treatment can have its problems but the thing is over 90% of us survive at least 5 years and those that don't were mostly diagnosed too late, were very old or had other health issues.  Have you been told what type of BC you have - hormone positive or negative, HER2 positive or negative? These factors can make a great difference to the agressiveness of the cancer and the type of treatment. It sounds like you're hormone positive as it seems from what you've said that you've been offered long term "tablets".  Long term hormone therapy is designed to reduce the amount of oestrogen in your body to starve the cancer of oestrogen. They're an extremely effective treatment. It'll put you into menopause if you're not already, so you're likely to get some of those symptoms eg achey joints, hot flushes.  If you're HER2+, then herceptin is a very effective treatment but it's only licensed for use in association with chemo. HER2+ cancer is aggressive though, so the docs are strongly in favour of having treatment.  As far as a double mastectomy goes, well surgery is also effective and these days many women opt for reconstruction. Not quite the same but most are pleased with the outcome. I suggest you do a bit of research on the various options, sticking to known and trusted sites like here, the cancer research UK site and the equivalent American ones. If you're into scientific research, the best site is the NIH site from the US. You should also talk to your family and/or close friends - that support is important to your general wellbeing. Finally, I agree you won't be the same but it is possibly to find a happy, balanced and contented new you. Most of us have, even if it was a long journey. Wishing you all the very best with your decisions. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Brca 1 ... the journey .... chemotherapy and more !

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. Haven't been around much recently but I thought you'd be interested to hear about my acupuncture experience.  Last oncologist visit in March, I was whingeing and moaning as usual about the SEs from Arimidex - bone pain, muscle pain, tendon and ligament pain. My onco suggested trying acupuncture. He said there's been some research done in the US and it works for about 40% of people. So, with some cynicism, I have given it a go.  I can happily report that I'm a complete convert. It's made an amazing difference. Hardly any aches or pains any more, unless I really overdo it. The pains I had in my hips has completely disappeared and my lower back is good most days. No more tendonitis in my hands. I can move much more freely and feel about 10 years younger.  Cheers
Posts.Title: AIs and acupuncture

Posts.Content: Hi Regency  Welcome aboard. A cancer diagnosis is one of the scariest things around. But don't despair, breast cancer is very very treatable and if your mum is grade 2, she should be fine.Over 90% of people survive more than 5 years.  It won't be easy. She'll definitely have to have surgery and may have radiotherapy and chemo as well. Chemo will largely depend on the kind of cancer it is. There's one particular kind - HER2+ - where you definitely have to have chemo so you can have a special therapy targeted to that kind of cancer. Chemo isn't always given in other situations. If her cancer is not HER2+ then she needs to have a detailed discussion with her oncologist (when she gets to see him or her) about whether chemo is appropriate given her age. Sometimes chemo offers only a small benefit and it might not be worth having it, as the side effects can be quite severe for some people. The onco can guide you through that particular maze and we're here to try to answer any further questions you or she may have. Wishing you and your mum all the best for successful treatment.
Posts.Title: New to site. very nervous

Posts.Content: I found the test kit very useful to establish what worked for me and what didn't. I hardly ever bother these days though as I go the endocrine clinic every 6 months and have to do a blood test beforehand. The Hb1ac test is a much better indicator of how well controlled your diabetes is.  BTW I was given a test kit when I was in hospital and get cheap supplies (subsidised by the govt here).  It's also been useful to reassure hubby he doesn't have diabetes. He's a bit of a worrier lol.
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Hi Kate2017 Finding a lump is one of the scariest things we can go through and nothing any of us can say will make that fear go away.  However, you can manage the fear/panic/worry whatever you want to call it. Remember worry makes a burden twice as heavy. Keep yourself busy doing things that interest you. Take that worry out every so often, inspect it, then put it away. The main thing is that you have done something about your pains - if either of the lumps turns out to be breast cancer, you're already on the road to recovery simply by having had it diagnosed.  Just one word of warning. Monday isn't the end of it. The samples taken will need to be sent to the pathology lab for analysis. You should be given an appointment to see the doctor to get the results, usually in about two weeks. Do think about taking someone with you to that appointment, as many people have said they didn't hear anything after the word cancer. If it is cancer, you'll be told some details of the pathology at that meeting and you should be given an outline of the treatment being proposed. There's plenty more after that but one step at a time. Don't start worrying about treatment before you even get a diagnosis. Here's hoping your stay with us will be short. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Anxious - is it cancer?

Posts.Content: A friend of mine was prescribed Effexor ( Venlafaxine) for hot flushes before she was diagnosed with BC. Five years after diagnosis, she's still on it - her onco told her to keep taking it to relieve the symptoms of anastrozole. That's the only case I know of. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Fluoxetine (Prozac) to reduce hot flushes...

Posts.Content: Good luck Helen.  I had to have a spine MRI for suspicious areas, just the same. Turned out that one was osteoarthritis and the other is calcifications ie normal ageing. So it can turn out ok.  I hated the MRI but I was offered oxygen, which I gratefully accepted. It made me feel less claustrophobic.  Hope it all goes well for you. Big hugs.
Posts.Title: Spine MRI tomorrow can't eat, sleep, concentrate.

Posts.Content: That's terrible Ronstar. I know that once treatment finishes, you're not a priority, and they're all terribly busy but it's no excuse really. Even if you didn't have lingering issues, you're still entitled to be treated with respect. But don't get too upset by it all. Just try to get another appointment to talk about the dog ear.  Best
Posts.Title: Guess I'm done

Posts.Content: How irritating Ronstar. I expect he's seen so many people distressed by the thought of losing a breast that he can't imagine someone completely accepting it. My surgeon asks me each time I see her whether I've changed my mind but she accepts (and I'm pretty sure agrees with) my decision.  As you know I had an implant at first and, frankly, I found having one pert 16 year old style boob and one floppy middle aged one far more odd than having nothing on that side. Lopsided LIzzies rock!
Posts.Title: Guess I'm done

Posts.Content: Yes it's those bloody steroids. I too had high BGL readings and am left with diabetes. It even has a name - steroid-induced diabetes. I had a lot of health problems after the first part (AC) of chemo, including the BGL issue. When I'd recovered and came to have the T part of chemo and Herceptin, I asked my onco if I could have it without any steroids. He wouldn't agree because of the potential allergic reaction to T. However, he did lower my dose to the absolute minimum - I had 4 mg delivered by infusion just prior to T. Nothing before and no tablets to take home. Even with that small dose, my BGL would shoot up to about 17 from around 7 and take 48 hours to come back down. It made absolutely no difference what I ate. Do speak to your onco about reducing the dose if you still have any chemo treatments to go.  I have been left with diabetes, but it is well controlled with drugs and causes me few issues. I lost a fair bit of weight during the whole cancer treatment experience and I'm hoping that if I lose even more the diabetes situation will improve. The main dietary change I've made is to eat way fewer carbs. That seems to be the only thing that makes any difference to my BGL.
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Yep that happened to me too on the AC part of my chemo. Got so bad that I stopped worrying about it and just told friends chemo made me fart and there was nothing I could do about it. They were all fine, although it did get a bit of a laugh. Didn't get the same with the T part of chemo. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Chemo farts

Posts.Content: I had an 11 week break between the red devil part of chemo and the taxane. In that time all my hair started growing back, including my eyebrows, which grew pretty much at the same rate as everything else. Of course I lost it all when I started the taxane. Personally I don't think any of the snake oils really work - they just make you feel better about yourself, which isn't a bad thing of course.  I'd stick with an eyebrow pencil for the time being.
Posts.Title: Eye brow regrowth.

Posts.Content: The January Chemo Club is now up and running. Please post there rather than here.
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Fantastic news. You must be so pleased. Hope you're going to celebrate. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Surgery results back!

Posts.Content: Lady Penelope - I had the sore red cheeks while I was having doxorubicin (cousin to epirubicin, which is more common in the UK). It's so common the chemo nurses call it the doxy flush. Happens with other chemo drugs too apparently. Worst thing for me was that it made me look healthy - which I wasn't. You've no idea how many people told me I looked great. I used a very expensive Guerlain moisturiser that I'd won a few years beforehand in a store competition. It was so good I even splashed out for another tub when it ran out! I'm sure there are cheaper options though.  Merry Christmas everyone. I hope you survive it all and let others pamper you. You deserve it.
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Hi Rich1984 Don't be afraid to ask about her meds. You can say that you want to understand exactly what's going on so you can help. I'm sure she won't mind. We all know that in this situation, what we're told can go in one ear and straight out the other. I found it very helpful when my hubby (who I admit is a bit of a science nerd) did all the internet research so I knew what questions to ask my onco. Doesn't matter if you're not a science nerd though - it's still important for you to know and understand. There's plenty of very clear info on this site about all the different drugs. And as for only being together a year - what does that matter, it's how you feel about her that counts.  I'd say you need to take her dad down the pub and have a few beers. Apart from anything else, I'm sure he'd be pleased to know you care. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Books on breast cancer

Posts.Content: Not food but have you tried the bicarb mouthwash? Using it several times a day really eases your mouth and throat. I used to wash out my mouth before and after eating as it gave me some taste. There are plenty of recipes on the internet. I was given bottles by my chemo unit but when I ran out I used 1 tsp bicarb in a cup of water.
Posts.Title: Oh my mouth...

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey Tray41 I pretty much agree with what's been said already - my nails are still crap and I finished chemo 11 months ago (sigh). I've now started using manuka honey hand cream on hands and feet and that's made a real difference within a few days. Have to keep it up though as if I forget, my nails go straight back to being flaky.  As for sore feet, yep mine were sore and peeled two or three times during and after T. Quite frankly, I found the absolute best help was to wear my Crocs - wildly unfashionable and very naff but they work so well to cushion your feet. Trouble is I now don't want to wear anything else. My husband also started wearing slightly posher loafer style crocs all the time as he had plantar fasciitis - it's completely gone away! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Side effects of fec-t on feet and body

Posts.Content: I found The Breast Book by Dr Susan Love to be the most helpful. It's clear and detailed. Just ignore the bits about the US health insurance system lol. It's free online. Thank you for being supportive. Your girlfriend may not say so (we get very self-absorbed) but I have no doubt that she fully appreciates your support. I wouldn't have got through without my wonderful husband.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Books on breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi JaneyS47. Unfortunately, while most people say that their treatment has been fantastic, you're not the first to complain about less than perfect treatment. I'm so pleased for you though that you've now found someone and somewhere that is meeting your needs. You always have the option of contacting the PALS unit at the hospital where you're being treated. A little complaint can go a long way as PALS units can put a rocket under the treating team.  Hope everything goes well for you from now on.
Posts.Title: Different hospital=different quality of treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Rich1984 I feel for you. This disease is emotionally as hard on loved ones as it is on the person who has it. I've recently come out the other end of 18 months of treatment, including one really rough patch. My husband was by my side all the time. He cried, he had temper tantrums and he had his foul moods but he was there. That's the important thing. No one can or should keep up a brave face all the time - how can you when awful things are happening to someone you love? And showing emotion is not weak.  My husband has said that the hardest bit was dealing with the 'blokes are supposed to fix things' part of his brain when on this occasion he couldn't fix it for me. Once I realised this was an issue for him, I gave him jobs to do and he turned into my chauffeur, bed maker, chief researcher and wielder of the vacuum cleaner.  So be there for her, do stuff around the house, ask her if there's anything she wants and most importantly love her. Little surprise presents won't go astray either.  To end on a positive note, I can definitely say that me having breast cancer treatment has brought us closer together. Life is good. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Books on breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy. This time of uncertainty is the hardest part; once your biopsy results are in and if it is indeed BC, you'll find things move quite quickly to give you a treatment plan. Once you have that and the treatment starts, everything somehow seems easier or at least all your coping mechanisms swing into action. Sadly, I find it hard to believe that the consultant would've told you it's BC if he had doubts. Usually they're pretty closed-mouthed until they're sure. More likely the biopsy is for confirmation and to identify the kind of BC ie whether it's hormone or HER2 positive. That will determine the treatment you are prescribed. i guess there's always room for a miracle though! I have found this site so helpful - being able to check things with people who have been through it, learn from them and yes rant if necessary. Everyone here understands and the community champions are great.  Wishing you all the very best, be kind to yourself. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: New diagnosis but already knew

Posts.Content: bougiecat thanks - I'd completely forgotten orange juice, especially freshly squeezed. Tasted like sunshine in my mouth. Also cherry tomatoes and grapes. I lived on them plus scrambled egg and tinned tomato soup. Mind you most of these are quite acid (which I liked cos it cut through the mouth goop) but may not be so good if you've got a sore mouth.
Posts.Title: Oh my mouth...

Posts.Content: I was given Cephalex when I had both surgeries and told to take them as a precaution so I guess that's ok for wound infections, not that I got one. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: what is the best Antibiotic for wound infection after mastectomy....

Posts.Content: Hi I'm so sorry to hear you're worrying about your lymph node and rash. I'm sure you can appreciate that no one can diagnose over the internet and anyway, I have no medical training whatsoever lol. I do know though that lymph nodes can misbehave for all sorts of reasons - their sole function is to trap nasties (eg bacteria, viruses, and yes cancer cells) to stop them spreading round the body, and this entrapment often causes swelling. When I was a kid, my mother and grandmothers were for ever  checking for "swollen glands" if I had a cold or sore throat - I expect yours were too! So don't panic but do mention it to your onco at your appointment.  Do you have any antiseptic cream especially an iodine based one? If so, try putting some of that on your rash. That's what my GP advised when I had a rash on my leg (although not related to cancer treatment). It worked. If it gets really bad then I'd suggest ringing the NHS 111 helpline (if you're in England). Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Swollen lymph node in neck

Posts.Content: Great news! That'll make the rest of it easier to bear. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Hi Winebelly I had a mixed reaction to chemo. AC was terrible but paclitaxel and herceptin were both much easier. I did still have considerable fatigue during paclitaxel and also got quite bad peripheral neuropathy, mainly in my hands. So much so that I stopped after 9 of the 12 treatments. There's research that suggests that exercise makes chemo easier to get through, with fewer side effects, but don't push yourself too hard! I was able to use my exercise bike during paclitaxel, but only about 15 mins before I'd be knackered. Absolutely the most important thing is to keep your fluids up - I did 3 litres in the 24 hours post treatment and 2 litres every other day.  I don't know about working as I didn't have to. However, I don't think I could have managed to hold down a job during that period. I was far too tired. You get a better result with a taxane plus herceptin than either on its own. I too wondered why bother with the T but I was convinced by the research results.  Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: "Dribble" chemo and getting back on track

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza10. Welcome back. It's great to hear that you are recovering. This cancer business isn't easy and you're absolutely right, not enough focus is placed on our mental health. To me that's a big part of the value of this group - we can help each other along, as we REALLY understand. Always remember you're a strong woman. With lots of love and a big hug.
Posts.Title: Mental Health side effects

Posts.Content: We're all on your team Sal. Hope you're doing OK
Posts.Title: London Lass

Posts.Content: You will start to feel better physically very soon. It took me about 3-4 weeks to really notice a difference and 6 weeks to get back some energy and start to feel like me.  Why not make enquiries about counselling - I can't see how that would be a bad thing? It may be that you have to wait a few weeks to see someone anyway. You can always make it a short course if you feel you don't need it any more. And just to reassure you again, chemo is tough and it does take its toll on both your body and your mind. You are not abnormal and not alone. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Moving on, counselling?

Posts.Content: Hi mossom2 Yep chemo is probably the hardest thing I've ever done - came within a whisker of killing me. I went into respiratory arrest but fortunately I was already in a large teaching hospital and they were able to keep me alive and get me to ICU immediately. I was a code blue just like on telly lol. Despite that, I went on to have the second tranche of chemo - paclitaxel plus 12 months of herceptin. I never for a moment thought of quitting because I knew that HER2+ breast cancer is sneaky, aggressive and likely to recur.  Rather than talking to your onco with a predetermined idea that you'll stop after 4 rather than 6 treatments, why not tell him that you know people are often given 4 treatments and ask him to explain why he thinks you should have 6. I think that might be a better approach to an open discussion. It's still up to you of course but you do need to make a decision armed with all possible information.  T can be very hard on some people. There might be an option to reduce the dose or, if it works for you, to switch from the 3 weekly docetaxel to the weekly paclitaxel. The SEs are not so heavy but the outcomes are the same.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: 4 vs 6 TCH

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar. I didn't get to this quickly enough to wish you luck but I do hope your day went well. It is all about confidence, and I hope that doing just that one day has boosted yours. You've still got it old girl lol. Best
Posts.Title: Hand holding and advice needed

Posts.Content: You have my total sympathy. It does seem to go on FOR EVER. I've had a completely different set of problems but let me just say I started treatment with surgery on 2 June and am now about half way through chemo with 6 weeks radio to follow. That's going to be about 11 months of my life being a professional patient grrr.  We normally do the whole fancy meal thing at Xmas but this year I'm just going to get a ham, a stollen and a shop pudding (especially as I have chemo scheduled for the 24th). That's plenty. Main thing is not to stress. I wish you the very best of luck - in particular that your wound heals quickly - and have a good Christmas.
Posts.Title: Feels Neverending....

Posts.Content: That sounds crap peachesxxx - such bad timing!!! Are you type 1 or type 2? Either way, you'll need to be pretty careful during chemo as the steroid they give you (dexmethasone) plays havoc with your blood sugar levels. For me the dex actually caused me to become diabetic and at the worst point my BGL was up in the 30s. This was only discovered half way through chemo (when I had finished the AC part). When I came to have the T part, I argued long and hard with my oncologist as I didn't want to have any steroids at all. In the end we compromised and he gave me the minimum dose - 4mg infused prior to the chemo infusion and no tablets before or afterwards. It might be worth having a chat to your onco before you start chemo.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: So fed up

Posts.Content: Worrying for you Crystal kitty. Just remember though that you're being very sensible and getting it checked out. That's always the most necessary step. Hope it all goes well for you. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Painful neck after bad cold ....

Posts.Content: I take magnesium simply because my blood tests have shown I was deficient. I now have no cramps or restless leg syndrome. My flushes have disappeared to the point of just feeling a bit hot now and then but I don't know if that's down to the magnesium or not.  Are you still having blood tests? If so then ask the doc to order a Mg level test on the next one. BTW I think I read that a massive proportion of the population doesn't get enough Mg - I think it was 3/4 or 80% or something like that.
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: I'm no expert but I just can't see any logic in fasting. Chemo puts your body under a huge amount of stress so why would you want to put it under more stress? As Carolyn said, you do drop nutrients fast so you need to replace them or you could get really ill.  My oncologist was very clear that he thought moderation was important. I think he said something along the lines of don't even think of dieting... but he did encourage me to avoid junk food. I'm not sure I managed that though as hot chips were one of the few foods I could tolerate and enjoy.  I guess my best advice is to listen to your body. It's highly likely you will fancy some foods that you don't normally eat - for one person on this forum it was milk shakes (a person that doesn't normally like milk) and for me it was fresh orange juice. I firmly believe that I needed the nutrients in it.  Hope it all goes well for you.
Posts.Title: Fasting along side Chemo - Advice/Thoughts

Posts.Content: And PS I'm off the grog too as I'm on Warfarin. That alone is depressing.
Posts.Title: Feels Neverending....

Posts.Content: Actually Lamonsea I think you're more likely to die from delaying treatment than from either stress or infection (provided you take appropriate precautions like handwashing, temp monitoring etc). However, it's clear that you've made up your mind and nothing anyone can say will change it. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Delaying chemo

Posts.Content: I found those when I went to M&S in Singapore. I was so excited. They're great and really comfortable. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Bras again!

Posts.Content: Most of my adult life I've not worn underwired bras as I never liked the wire digging in. Then about 3 years before I was diagnosed, I happened upon a style that was comfortable and converted. Coincidence? Probably. Mind you this style is still the most comfortable for me, except I've now taken the underwires out - doesn't make any difference in support.
Posts.Title: Bras again!

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky SpicedTea Yep it's way too hot here for me. I was in Adelaide last week, where it hit 41. Fortunately here in Canberra we've only made it to 37.  I'm really well except I got shingles just before Christmas, which dragged me down a bit. These days though, they give you anti-virals which clears it up pretty quickly.  Hope you're doing OK. Happy 2017 and a healthy one too of course. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Bras again!

Posts.Content: I have the same. The surgeon says it's swelling from the op and not to worry as it'll go over a few weeks. Suggest you speak to your surgeon or BCN
Posts.Title: Panicking another lump

Posts.Content: There is this site Riprap.org which is affiliated to Macmillan for teenagers. It might help your children. Best
Posts.Title: Delaying chemo

Posts.Content: I was told by my onco to have the flu jab before I started chemo, because it reduces the risk of infection. He said he would NOT recommend anyone have it during chemo. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: Excellent news. Time to celebrate (another C word lol). Lynn xx
Posts.Title: The results are in!

Posts.Content: Hi Lamonsea. It sounds like you've had a pretty rough time of it so far but it also sounds like you are a bit confused about some elements of your treatment and have little faith in your treating doctors. I think you need to take a deep breath, unpick the different bits and then take it one step at a time. Firstly, if you're not satisfied with your treatment, you're entitled to ask for a second opinion (see info here) or complain to the PALS unit. Are there other hospitals nearby where you could be treated. Do you have a BCN right now? If not, ask for one. If you do then talk to her about all these issues. Secondly, if you've had your surgery, the cancer is gone. Chemo, hormone therapy and radiation are about making sure it doesn't come back. Thirdly, if you're waiting for an oncotype test, then it's not certain that you'll need chemo. When you get those results then it's time to talk to the oncologist about chemo and/or hormone treatment. I would be massively surprised if they agreed to give you palbociclib as that's only been approved for metastatic cancer treatment at this stage. Chemo can be horrible but it isn't dreadful for everyone. Some people sail through - who's to say you can't be one of those people? And even those that find it tough think it's doable. You are of course entitled to refuse chemo but I strongly urge you to have a detailed conversation about the risks and benefits with your oncologist before you make any decision. Fourthly, the longer you delay treatment, the more likely it is that your cancer will return. You say there has already been several months delay. Why would you delay further? Your children will need you in their lives for a long time yet. All your children are of an age where they can help you and take some responsibility for themselves. It's time for them to step up.  Finally, over 90% of people who get breast cancer survive for at least 5 years. That's the only statistic you need to focus on.  People here are very kind and happy to support you. Please do hang around. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Delaying chemo

Posts.Content: I take magnesium simply because my blood tests have shown I was deficient. I now have no cramps or restless leg syndrome. My flushes have disappeared to the point of just feeling a bit hot now and then but I don't know if that's down to the magnesium or not.  Are you still having blood tests? If so then ask the doc to order a Mg level test on the next one. BTW I think I read that a massive proportion of the population doesn't get enough Mg - I think it was 3/4 or 80% or something like that.
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass Reiterating what others have said, this is simply not good enough. Pain control is so important in managing any medical condition long term, let alone metastatic cancer. Your overall level of health is likely to deteriorate if you're in pain and that's the last thing you need.  My response would be to find another GP who is more sympathetic and on the ball. Failing that then I would suggest asking either the GP or your onco for a referral to a pain clinic. Unfortunately, you may need to be rather assertive! Mind you I think I'd be having a total tantrum. Wishing you all the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hi to all those having hot flushes and night sweats. It will diminish as it's your body adjusting to lower oestrogen levels.  George (Dreamthief) posted a really clear explanation of what's going on a few weeks back. Unfortunately I can't recall the detail but I've tagged him so he can repeat it if he's around. Thanks George. And to suzie02 So sorry to hear you're feeling so down. Deal with the sleep problem and things may well start looking up as the world always looks darker when you're not sleeping. Time for a visit to the GP. As far as the kids go, I agree with whoever said to say no. If necessary make up reasons why you can't have them. Don't let him control your life.  And as for housework, who cares? Don't put that stress on yourself.  Who's going to say you're a bad person  if you don't vacuum or the shelves are dusty? And if anyone did, you simply don't need to have them in your life. As long as the kitchen and bathroom are reasonably hygenic then say bollocks to all of it. I've been practising that wilful blindness for years and I'm getting very good at it lol. What about your kids? Why can't they help? When mine were at home, we all pitched in (hey I've hated housework for ever) and whilst they grumbled, they did do their bit, and of course learned valuable life lessons too.  Finally, please try not to obsess about dying. If you had no lymph node involvement and the onco didn't even feel the need for you to have chemo, then your cancer was caught early and there's a high likelihood that you've been cured. Of course none of us ever knows for sure but the stats are so good, there's no point in wasting your emotional energy on that particular worry.  Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: So glad you're doing ok Jojo. Hope you continue that way.  Big but gentle hug
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Thank you Dolina I very much appreciate the thought. Life's better if you can laugh a bit! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: That was it, thanks George
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear your news. The cancer treatment roller coaster is bad enough without doctors making it worse! Everyone worries and stresses waiting for results, and I've heard many complaints on here that doctors won't tell you, but somehow I think that's probably better than what you've just gone through. I do wonder though how so many surgeons and oncos can be oblivious to the impact this has on people. Grrr . Off my soapbox now Have they told you whether you need further surgery to get proper clearance or do an axillary clearance? Chemo? Radio? I hope your resilient spirit reasserts itself after a night's sleep. Let us know how you're feeling tomorrow
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: So glad to hear you're on the mend. Hope the new job works out well for you. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: Hi Lil. I have quite severe breast lymphoedema and it's improving very slowly. Apart from the physiotherapy, the best thing I've found is a compression garment called Expandaband from the USA. Comfortable and easy to wear, even in bed; bonus is they're even relatively attractive, not medical looking at all. You can find them by googling. They don't ship outside the US but you may find a UK supplier or you can use an intermediate address. You can send me a private message if you want more information or assistance. Lynn
Posts.Title: waiting times

Posts.Content: PS I haven't been able to find that much info about breast lymphoedema. Seems that it's not an area where much research has been done.
Posts.Title: waiting times

Posts.Content: That's such a shame for you and must be quite distressing. I presume you're now in the situation of just having had a mastectomy. If so, you should get given a temporary foob (fake boob) known as a softie, before you leave hospital. Check with the BCN. On a longer term basis, you can get a silicon prosthesis. I think on the NHS in the UK but I'm in Australia so I'm not sure. (ronstar ???) Otherwise, you can continue to use the softie.  My personal preference is for knitted knockers. Knitted foobs stuffed with fibrefill, or shower scrunchy for swimming. I've made several in different colours and to my exact size to match the other side. The other bonus is that you can just pin them (with safety pins) inside a normal bra. I wear padded/preformed bras to make it easier to get and keep the right shape. If you can't knit there is a group in the UK that will send you KKs free. You may be able to have a reconstruction later, probably with an implant I'd imagine if you have blood supply issues. However, as far as I know surgeons would want to wait at least 6 months from your last treatment, especially if you have radiotherapy. Suggest you speak to your surgeon as soon as you see him/her so you can find out what might be possible. DO NOT DESPAIR Life with one boob is absolutely fine. Great even. Hugs
Posts.Title: failed deep flap

Posts.Content: I use normal bathers with a knitted knocker (one filled with shower scrunchie) PINNED inside the cup, so there's no chance of a wardrobe malfunction. I've never been one for bikinis - don't have the belly for it - but I think KKs would work just as well as long as the top wasn't too tiny.
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Swimwear

Posts.Content: Completely understand wombat.23 I am married to a master negaholic.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: I could have driven home but the parking station for the hospital was nearly a kilometre away - I couldn't have walked that far. So my partner dropped me off and collected me. I had a friend come with me for the first chemo but I felt stressed by that - I kept worrying that she was bored etc etc so from then I preferred to be by myself with my puzzle book, kindle and knitting. But then I'm a person that likes alone time.  As for food ... I lived mainly on tomato soup, scrambled eggs and fruit. They were all i could tolerate, which in itself was unusual as i'm no fruit bat and rarely eat eggies. I found grapes particularly good as you can just have 2or 3 and they're really refreshing in the mouth. My worst craving was hot chips with gravy. I tried to not give in more than once a week lol. Bottom line is eat what you can tolerate but try to keep it as varied and healthy as you can. Best of luck - it seems scary now but soon you'll be an old lag!
Posts.Title: CHEMO TO START

Posts.Content: One of the reasons a taxane is given with the Herceptin is that studies have shown that H is more effective when given in conjunction with a taxane. Currently the approval licence for Herceptin is only with T. So I don't think you're going to be able to avoid T unfortunately.  Are you going to be given pertuzumab as well as herceptin? Those two, along with T, seem to be the new gold standard treatment for primary HER2+ cancers. It might be worth asking about it.
Posts.Title: New Drug for HER2+ive called KADCYLA

Posts.Content: I started out with a skin sparing mastectomy and implant. It was a lovely implant but while on chemo I got really ill and took on loads of fluid. Eventually the fluid went from everywhere except my new boob. Think walking round with a football on your chest. Tried several strategies to get rid of the fluid but none worked so surgery was the only option. By then I was so sick of the football that I asked the surgeon to just cut it off.  Since then I've worn knitted knockers inside ordinary non-underwire bras. They work perfectly well and best is that you can fix them in with a safety pin so no possibility of a wardrobe malfunction. I'm very happy as lop-sided Lizzie and I doubt I'll consider reconstruction in the future.  It's not an easy decision but you do need to be happy with it. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Struggling to decide about reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Lee. You should have a look at the monthly Chemo Club thread. It's designed for people going through chemo to chat to each other and share their experiences. Attached to the first post in that thread (by Crystaljuju) is a list of helpful hints for chemo. Hope it all goes well for you and may your side effects be minimal.
Posts.Title: Due to start chemo 24th May

Posts.Content: When I swapped from letrozole to anastrozole, my onco told me to take a 10 day break in between the two. I don't know why. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Can I change back from Anastrazole to Letrozole ?

Posts.Content: Well done Jojo. It will be lovely to catch up with your friends - kinda makes the effort worthwhile. Big hug
Posts.Title: Due to start chemo 24th May

Posts.Content: Hi wombat.23 so sorry to hear you're having a rough time. My back gave me grief for several months after diagnosis and surgery - I put it down to all those uncomfortable scan beds and a bit of rough handling while I was under. I did have an MRI of my chest area as I had calcifications on my spine. Turned out to be just that - calcifications. It may well be related to your surgery but as it seems to be persisting, you should contact your doctor and get a scan, even if only for your peace of mind. Now as for your husband ... My hubby was very supportive but we did have some rocky moments. He's neurotic and anxious and has had depression (still on the happy pills). Mostly he tends to overreact, which wasn't a great deal of fun. We've talked about it since in calmer moments so here's what he said was going on. Firstly, he felt left out because I was getting all the attention. Secondly, I was only interested in me. Thirdly, he's a bloke and he's supposed to fix things, but he couldn't fix this and felt really helpless. Now I think the third one is entirely understandable but the other two really pissed me off - very selfish I thought. However, I didn't say so. I too had always been the strong one and I think he was genuinely flopping around when I was no longer able to be his rock. And I know I had less tolerance for his wobbles. I was very self-absorbed, as I think everyone on chemo is, but I hadn't realised I'd reached the point where I wouldn't eg say thank you if he made me a cup of tea or say hello when he got home. So I started making more effort to be nice to him and also I gave him particular tasks to do so he wouldn't feel left out. He became my chauffeur, bedmaker and chief researcher. This all worked and the path was much smoother later on.  Try to take a dispassionate look at what's going on between you. There may be some things you can adjust that will make life better for both of you. However, don't be a martyr - you have a right to expect support from him. Happy to chat further - let me know how it goes. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: That's very good news for you Violets day. I'm not surprised you're feeling very positive.  I found radiotherapy not too bad. The worst bit was having to go to the hospital every day. For me it was 5 weeks, which is normal here in Australia, but I think in the UK they do it for 3 weeks. It felt like a life sentence at first but in the end passed fairly quickly. We have a monthly Radiotherapy club where you can chat to people going through radio at the same time as you. The first post in that thread contains a link to tips posted by members. You might find that helpful. Tamoxifen may be easy for you or you may get some side effects. It's often a subject of discussion in the breast group but don't be put off as only those that have SEs tend to post about them.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Today’s Results from my lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Yes it's a scary time. Don't beat yourself up for not finding the lump sooner. They can come on very quickly. You have already done the most important thing - take action. I read somewhere the other day that breast cancer is now more of a chronic disease to be managed than a killer. It's true, survival rates are high. And anyway you don't have a diagnosis yet. The best advice I can give is not to try to be superwoman. If you need treatment, you will feel rotten at times so ask for help and don't sweat the small stuff - your kids will survive wearing unironed clothes or eating frozen pizza for example.
Posts.Title: Im scared

Posts.Content: Hi redkite I too am a bit surprised your hairdresser is suggesting perming solution as the new hair is quite fragile (which is why we're told to wait).  It takes about 18 months apparently for the chemo curls to go. I found that after about 6 months I could see my normal hair growing at the base so I've been keeping it short (about 3 cm long) and getting the curls gradually cut off. I reckon I've got one or two more haircuts to go. Now you can see it's normal hair but there's a pale grey twist at the end. The colour has also gone back to what it was before - a mix of brown and dark grey, rather than the almost white that came through first. I used  kms shampoo and conditioner for frizzy hair (orange pack) and then leave-in conditioner mixed with a bit of evo moulding paste. That combo plasters it down enough for it to dry wavy rather than curly.
Posts.Title: Curly Hair!

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty-ann. It's definitely do-able. You may forget that at times, but every day you're a step closer to the end. The only advice I'll offer is be kind to yourself, rest when you need to rest, accept the help offered (people really do want to help) and try to take a bit of light exercise whenever you can. It really does help. Best of luck for your treatment. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Chemo consult

Posts.Content: Hi Katymay. You've certainly drawn more than your share of short straws! Some of the chemotherapy drugs can be toxic to the heart - the most well-known are doxorubicin and epirubicin but there are others. If you are offered chemotherapy, think very carefully about it and make sure you have a full consultation with your cardiologist and that the drugs selected are the ones least likely to impact the heart. I have a healthy heart yet doxorubicin put me into atrial fibrillation, which in turn led to pulmonary embolisms - I came pretty close to dying! I would decline these two if I had to go through chemo again. Radiotherapy can also impact the heart, in cases where the radiation beam hits the edge of the heart. It is rare and there are various techniques to minimise the chance of the beam hitting the heart but again, I would want a full consultation with the cardiologist before agreeing to go ahead.  There may be other impacts for both chemo and radio - these are just the two I know of. Hopefully, given your history of heart disease, the MDT will bring in your cardiologist to make him/her part of the decision making process. But even if not, do insist.   Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: Heart disease and cancer

Posts.Content: I found that if I used the bicarb mouthwash just before eating, it cleared the horrid taste long enough for me to get some food in. Very limited range of foods though - for me it was mostly acidy foods that I enjoyed - cherry tomatoes, tomato soup, fresh orange juice, grapes and to a lesser extent pineapple. Pretty much lived on them plus scrambled eggs which tasted of nothing but didn't taste bad. One piece of advice I was given, which I mostly followed, was not to eat my favourite food as it could put me off it forever. The only ones I tried were baked beans and mashed potatoes, both of which I love, but they did taste gross so I didn't go there again.
Posts.Title: Taste

Posts.Content: They don't like to do surgery while your immune system is still compromised, because there's an increased risk of problems with healing. I have to have a hernia fixed but my surgeon said she doesn't want to do it for 6 months after I finished herceptin. It's a minor procedure so I don't mind waiting.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction after treatment

Posts.Content: As far as I know Herceptin doesn't have a direct effect on your immune system in the same way as regular chemo. My surgeon's view, however, is that you're still giving your body a nasty to deal with, which increases the risk of surgery so if not urgent, it's better to wait.  Having BC and a mastectomy has in a strange way made me feel more feminine - along the lines of 'you can take my boob, you can take my hair, but I'm still a woman'. Interesting isn't it how we all react differently. Lots of love Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Caz48 I love love love manuka honey hand cream. It's so good I use it all over my body. You do have to be a bit careful as there are lots of fakes out there but if you get one made in New Zealand then it should be fine. I use Wild Ferns brand and buy it online but I imagine health food shops would carry it and I believe Holland and Barrett have some manuka honey preparations (I'm in Australia so can't say for sure).
Posts.Title: Hand Cream

Posts.Content: Lucky you Helen mistymoley. Mine is the exact opposite. My natural hair is thick and curly and the longer it is the harder it is to manage. It just knots up and then takes an age to brush out. After having short hair all my adult life, I grew it when I retired 6 years ago, because I wondered if it would be better once it got properly long. By the time I was diagnosed, I was pretty sick of the work and pain involved in keeping it looking ok and was wearing it in a bun the entire time. I'll never go back to long hair I think - I look too much like an old witch.
Posts.Title: Curly Hair!

Posts.Content: Hi volvox Welcome aboard. It's a scary time isn't it? You will find things settle down as your treatment progresses. Depending on the treatment offered, mainly whether the docs suggest chemo, you'll be out for a few to several months. Most people will get back to their previous levels of fitness some months after treatment finishes but it can take up to 2 years if you have chemo.  As far as reconstruction goes, I chose not to have one for long and complicated reasons but I'm quite happy as lop-sided Lizzie. It really doesn't bother me at all. Because I decided not to go for reconstruction I'm not really up with the different types. However, I do know that there's one type where they use muscle from your back. Seems to me that might not be a good idea if you're a rower. I'd suggest that you ask for an appointment with your surgeon to discuss the pros and cons of different kinds of reconstruction, including recovery periods and the likelihood of long term problems. Here's a good article from the Cancer Research UK site on different options for reconstruction.  Good luck for your surgery.
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Hi Wilson81 - yes it's a worrying time. I think we'd all say that the period between finding a lump and diagnosis is the worst as there's so much uncertainty. Things will settle down - either you'll get the all clear (and let's hope so) or you'll have a treatment plan and will start following it.   Will you get any results on Wed or have to wait? I went through the same process and I have to say as soon as the radiologist walked in and said he wanted to do a biopsy, I was pretty certain it was cancer. Of course that meant when my GP rang to tell me the results a couple of days later, I wasn't at all surprised and didn't fall apart. Still we all react differently. Wishing you all the very best for Wednesday.
Posts.Title: Got my referral - Wednesday morning

Posts.Content: Hi Shirl3. Chemo is awful, or it was for me at least. As others have said, RT is much easier for most people.  I understand you wanting to stop now and not have radiotherapy but do talk it through with your oncologist first. Radiotherapy is very successful with a 15% absolute reduction in risk of recurrence over 10 years. The risk reduces from around 30% to about 15%. Worth it? I thought so.
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Ouch Lilian, that looks so sore. You poor thing, you must've thought you were through all the nonsense and out the other side and then this! Thank you so much for sharing your story. I'm sure that will help others, even if not providing a solution for you. The only suggestion I can offer is manuka honey, which is amazing - does wonders for the skin and has antibacterial action. Just make sure you get the real thing though as there are loads of fakes out there.
Posts.Title: Lymphangitis

Posts.Content: I'm very unusual JoDec - ER-, PR+ but still get the hormone treatment unfortunately. I had a single mx. I worry more about spread elsewhere than to the other boob, as that's fixable whereas mets elsewhere aren't. How are you doing on Herceptin? I thought I was fine on it until I finished and then I realised  that I felt a bit crap the entire way through. Not enough to say I was ill but enough to notice the difference once it was finished. I hated the drippy nose too and my nails were very flaky - they've really only recovered in the last few months.
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear about your dad. It's never easy, even if expected. I do hope you can get to the funeral but please don't beat yourself up if you can't. And do take time to grieve - that's very important. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Fifth day of radiotherapy, and my sister rings me ...

Posts.Content: I have ordered some R1 and R2 online in preparation for my radio as I don't think it's widely available here in Oz. I'm going to ask the radio nurses and/or the radio oncologist for their views but I think I'm going to use it anyway as I don't fancy the steroid cream that you are given automatically here.
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Just to add a bit of humour to this discussion. I saw this today - just how I feel sometimes.
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz15. I had similar lumps and pain. Turned out to be a septated seroma (fibrous tissue growing in the seroma), capsular contracture (where fibres grow round the implant and squeeze it) and a bit of cording for good measure. All very uncomfortable but not "nasty". In the end mine was so severe, I chose to have everything chopped off - instant relief, I feel great now.
Posts.Title: Hard lumpy area in reconstructed breast

Posts.Content: Congratulations Maisymoo. Have a fantastic day on Sunday and a wonderful future together.
Posts.Title: Good News Story for a cold Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi millie63 Is your elbow pain on the side you had surgery? If so, it's quite possible it's related to nerve damage from surgery, which is not uncommon. If so, it will clear up but nerve healing is a slow process. The other thing is that during surgery (ie when you're out) they do contort your body into strange positions to make it easier to access and often people have strange pains.  Having said that, as with any persistent pain, I'd suggest you mention it to the doc next time you go. You never know, it might be something else quite unrelated to the surgery.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Random aches and pains

Posts.Content: Yes I do have the ultimate tenacious seroma thanks ronstar. Mine has been there since my mastectomy surgery in March 2016. I had it drained several times in the first few months but it always came back. I also had some compression garments, both light and heavy. The heavy one did squish it but it returned if I didn't wear the wretched thing. And boy did I hate wearing that - I could hardly breathe. So now it just sits there and hasn't expanded or contracted. It doesn't hurt and isn't infected. I have spoken to my surgeon about it at my last check up. She thinks there's no point in draining it as it will refill. She also said that the pressure of the seroma prevents further leakage and will eventually enable healing. Once all the tissues are healed it should go away by itself. Waiting, waiting...  I figure that while it's not causing any problems I'll just leave it. As someone said the next step is surgery but I have also heard (from one of my chemo nurses) that they can inject an irritant, like talc, into the space and that helps the two sides adhere together.  Best of luck with it
Posts.Title: I still have a large seroma 5 months after my surgery

Posts.Content: Hi JoDec My diagnosis was very similar to yours. Onco said it was a very aggressive type - stage 3c, HER2+++, 14/30 lymph nodes infected. I too decided to take everything on offer. TBH I found radio the easiest of all. It was a bit of a pain going for 5 weeks (here they do 50 Gray in 25 fractions whereas in the UK it's usually 45 Gray in 15 fractions) but it passed quite quickly. As I had a full mastectomy I didn't have to have the booster doses. Now I take arimidex and have denusomab shots every 6 months. It's worked so far. Best of luck with radio. It'll be easy compared to what you went through with chemo. Hugs
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I have read the reports of 2 controlled trials, including one published by the NIH in the US, and both say results are significantly better.
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: How interesting - I've not heard of stopping H for surgery. I was about 5 months in when I had my mastectomy. I can understand you being concerned about radiation. Imaging has improved significantly over the years!
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: JoDec. It's not a small reduction in risk - it's an 18% reduction in relative risk, if I remember correctly (but I haven't looked it up again).
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: And now for something completely different. I had my drain in for 13 weeks and then it only got removed cos I cheated. (I was told it couldn't come out till I was draining 20ml a day or less so I used to empty the drain bag before the district nurse came). Are you sure it's blood? For several weeks, my wound drained a sort of pink liquid - a bit like Red Bull. It was only in the last couple of weeks it drained straw coloured fluid.  Anyway, it may or may not be "normal" but it would be rather worrying if your doctors are puzzled. I think the time has come to be assertive and get a different opinion. Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Still Bleeding .....

Posts.Content: No spread sounds like good news to me CathyPJ! Never forget that the 5 year survival rate is over 90%. I think BC does change you mentally. We've come face to face with our own mortality and sometimes it's not a pretty sight. Hard to erase the experience so we have to learn from it and grow instead. Wishing you the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Update; Pathological (or How I feel about my Pathology Report after...

Posts.Content: Hi Bijou So sorry to hear you're having a rough time of it. I know how it is - I felt all the way through treatment that I had to look after my husband's emotional well-being! It got to me sometimes as I felt that I should be able to be entirely selfish but in the end it wasn't worth the hassle.  Have you ever thought that all the people in your cancer support group are thinking exactly the same as you. I wonder whether it would be worth trying to start a gentle conversation with one or two people, perhaps by asking them how they are really feeling? It could potentially take the group to a much more helpful place.  Anyway, there are plenty of people here to chat to and the best bit is that everyone's been there, either as a patient or a carer. I take a lot of strength from some people's stories and how they've managed to weather terrible storms but come out the other end.  Lots of love  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Hi Sillypen The reality is you can wear whatever you like after 6 months. Whether underwires suit you is a matter of comfort. To a great extent it'll probably depend on where your scar is located as it's mostly the scar tissue that rubs that causes discomfort. Try out stuff you already have and you'll know within an hour whether they're going to be suitable. I've never really liked underwire bras but used to buy them as they're mostly better designs and less stuff than non-underwire. Now I wear my old underwires but I've taken the wire out. Works perfectly for me.  Enjoy your holiday Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Underwired bras

Posts.Content: My smile is real too because I'm happy and healthy. It may not last forever, but I'll deal with that if it happens. Regardless, I'm having a great time and really enjoying life. I'm blessed with a wonderful spouse, a few truly fantastic friends, a beautiful garden and 4 loving cats. I can do just about everything I could before I was sick (and in some ways more) and I have enough money not to have to worry about having the heating or aircon on for an extra hour. What's not to be happy about?
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Yep I've had shingles. It was well after my chemo but did show 24 hours after my 6 monthly denusomab injection. So close I thought it was a reaction to the denusomab and didn't go to the doc for 3 days. Mine was pretty conventional though - starting at my sternum and spreading horizontally to my armpit (good side thank heavens). I don't think they test for shingles in your pre-chemo bloods but you could ask them if it's possible. I managed to get an occasional extra test done by persuading the nurse, who then persuaded the registrar who had to authorise it.  Hope it clears up soon for you as it must be very uncomfortable, not to mention having to cope with that on top of chemo.
Posts.Title: Shingles?

Posts.Content: Good days, bad days - I rather suspect that goes with the secondary territory. I think you're travelling remarkably well - managing a full time job, moving towns (or is it cities), coping with the pain, re-establishing relationships, getting mucked around by various members of the medical profession (or people that think they are). It's no wonder that sometimes it seems all a bit too much. You are resilient, so remember this too will pass and in the meantime, there are plenty of people here to offer a virtual hug, some sympathy and a kind word. With a huge virtual hug from Australia, where we're expecting 40 Degrees today. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Everyone's mileage varies! I have never lived alone. We lived with my grandparents and uncles and aunt when I was little and finally when my parents managed to get a house, my two brothers came along. I went from that to group houses and when I left Adelaide and moved to Canberra, I moved into a hostel where I met my first husband. We moved out together. I met my second husband when I was in the throes of separating from the first but for a while lived with a friend. Then of course my current husband.  I think because of that, I love to be alone. I have a pretty good circle of friends but still value time by myself. When I retired, I immediately started doing volunteer work as I was worried about filling my days. I've made half a dozen really good friends from that.  Interestingly, I haven't made any friends through cancer treatment. The 4 other people I know who've had BC all made chemo buddies that they stay in touch with. Maybe it's because my treatment followed an irregular pattern but I didn't seem to see the same people very often at all. Not that I mind as I suspect it would be too much of a reminder of a bad time.  Bottom line is that life is what we make it. I'm not the sort of person that can sit home and mope, more likely to sit home and relish it. But we are all different. Lots of love to all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Happiness vs Meaningfulness - an interesting article

Posts.Content: Settle back Mazza. Herceptin takes a year. I think having the chemo first is great. I wish I had. It means you can actually see how well the drugs have worked. Your lump should shrink in that time, meaning less invasive surgery. Great news that there's no spread to the lymph nodes - you're a bit of an advertisement for screening, I think.  Hope you're coping ok with the chemo. Have a look at the monthly chemo club, if you haven't already. Attached to mistymoley's initial post there's a document full of tips from people on how to get through chemo.
Posts.Title: Diagnosis.. what does it mean?

Posts.Content: Hi Resilent Welcome aboard. One of the fab things about this site is that there's always someone who's been or going through a similar situation to you. I find it very reassuring to know I'm not the only one.  I did post above but thought it might help to give you an update. I STILL have my seroma - that's 3 years after surgery. It just feels like a hard lump about the size of a satsuma where my boob used to be. I had it drained regularly at first but gave up on that. Now it just sits there. It's never been infected (guess I'm lucky) and doesn't really cause me any trouble. I've also tried compression with an elasticised corset thingy but I gave up on that as it squashed my other boob and also I could hardly breathe.  I do have mild lymphoedema as I had axilliary clearance on that side. The lymphoedema physio that I go to thinks part of the reason the seroma won't drain is the presence of all that fluid - it's got to go somewhere. Physio does seem to be helping a bit and I think the seroma is a little bit smaller than 12 months ago.  The good news is that I've had annual ultrasounds which just show a large pocket of fluid - nothing else and nothing wrong. I've just learned to live with it.  My advice, if you can, is to just live with it for the time being if it's not infected. The more often you have it drained, the more likely it is to get infected. However, you need to get on to the first signs of infection (any or all of red, itchy, swollen, painful) and get some antibiotics into you. My surgeon gave me a prescription for a fairly strong antibiotic to keep at home and take at the first sign.  I think it's another case of breast cancer, the gift that keeps giving. Wishing you luck with it.
Posts.Title: I still have a large seroma 5 months after my surgery

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016 Whoa, time to take a deep breath! Yes, cancer is scary and the most scary and worrying part is when you're first diagnosed. Loads of hospital appointments, lots of language you don't really understand, thinking the worst and so on. Sounds like you're completely normal. I can assure you it does settle down. BC is very very treatable with over a 90% 5 year survival rate.  For you right now it's all about the surgery so just focus on that. Firstly keep remembering that the surgeons are very experienced with this so you'll be in good hands. A lumpectomy shouldn't be too painful but they'll give you proper pain relief if needed. Don't be afraid to take it.  I'd start by buying a notebook and writing down things as you remember them or as you have appointments. I used to write everything down as my mind was all over the place. And in the back of the notebook, I wrote down every question as I thought of it, because I knew once I walked into a doctor's room all the questions would go straight out of my head.  You should also take this time before surgery to get help for your Dad. You can't bear the burden of his care as well as yourself and your children. I'm in Australia so I'm not sure how these things work in the UK, but I imagine the local council provides lots of services. Do you have siblings? Perhaps it's time for one of them to step up and take responsibility for him for a while.  As soon as you get a surgery date, the first thing you should do is make arrangements for your children for when you're in hospital and the first few days afterwards. Once you've settled them, you'll worry less. Their father?  It will settle, but if you find you're still in a state of high anxiety after a couple of weeks, then you might want to think about getting some counselling help. Many people on here have found it very useful. You could ask your BCN about available options. Finally remember that we're here. There are loads of lovely people on this site who have all either been through what you're going through or have cared for someone who has.  Big hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016 Whoa, time to take a deep breath! Yes, cancer is scary and the most scary and worrying part is when you're first diagnosed.
