Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: I haven't changed my diet except I do try to eat less junk food than I used to. I gave up alcohol as I'm on warfarin and it really is a bad combo. The trouble with that is that my sweet tooth has increased and I find it hard to resist cakes and desserts.  We eat a pretty good diet anyway - loads of veggies, complex carbs and small amounts of meat. I will not eat margarine so it's only butter in our house. There are so many fads out there (quinoa with chia seeds anyone?) and so much contradictory information. The only consistent theme seems to be to eat lots of veggies, which I always do.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Changes to diet

Posts.Content: The January Radiotherapy club is now live. Please carry on posting there.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ December Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza Welcome aboard. It can be hard to remember everything you're told by the docs - information overload. That's why it's good to receive all the pathology etc written down.  Ki 67 is a cell protein. It's presence is a way of measuring the aggressiveness of the cancer so the higher %, the more aggressive. 80% is aggressive, but that's not surprising as you are HER2+, which is an aggressive kind of breast cancer. Have you received a treatment plan? As you are HER2+ you will be offered (and probably pressured into accepting) chemo as that's the pathway to the key treatment for HER2 cancers - Herceptin and likely pertuzumab as well. If you're not offered pertuzumab, ask why not as these 2 are the gold standard now for HER2+ cancer and are getting very good results. ER 7/8 means the cancer is strongly hormone receptor positive as well, so you are likely to be offered long term (10 years) hormone therapy as well. Are you having surgery or chemo first?  They were right to tell you not to google everything - much of the info and stats on the internet are wrong or out of date and can scare you unnecessarily.  Do stick around. There are lots of lovely knowledgeable people here who will provide you with plenty of support and tips for getting through treatment. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Diagnosis.. what does it mean?

Posts.Content: I drove myself to radio every day but it wasn't nearly that far - just a 15 minute drive. Radio made me a bit tired but not exhausted so I'd have a nanna nap when I got home. That was enough, I felt otherwise completely normal. I also started local driving 3 days after my surgery (both times) but only in quiet times at first and never on the freeway. Best Lynn xx EDIT I didn't drive to chemo initially as there's very little parking nearby and later because I was basically too ill to drive. My hubby used to drop me off and then pick me up a couple of hours later. Luckily his work is only 15 mins away and they were very flexible and understanding.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: Interestingly, here in Australia, I have been given aqueous cream by the Cancer Centre and told not to use anything else! I ignored that and am using R1 and R2 which are fabulous.  I just looked at the tube of aqueous cream and it seems we have a different recipe. The contents are water, white soft paraffin, emulsifying wax BP, liquid paraffin and phenoxyethanol. Not a mention of sodium lauryl sulfate. I do recall seeing on this site that they've recently changed the recipe in the UK. Fortunately it seems we haven't caught up yet. Going to research it though.
Posts.Title: Aqueous cream and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Littlesusie In all honesty it's not something it would expect my oncologist to know. After all I wouldn't expect my radiographer to know what effect chemotherapy would have on my body. Mmm not sure about that. My medical oncologist seems to know quite a lot about everything that's happened to me. We've had in-depth conversations about radiotherapy and surgery and also, when I was in hospital for a month, he was my main treating doctor so was across all my issues, although other specialists did pop up from time to time. For example, he was the one who spotted that I was being given the wrong dose of one of my heart meds.
Posts.Title: Aqueous cream and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: There is a lifetime dose limit for the anthracyclines (including epirubicin and doxorubicin) because of cardio-toxicity but there are plenty of other drugs that could be used in future.  What's the point in holding back treatment for yourself. You're 3 times more likely to die if you don't have chemo. None of us would say that chemo is fun but it does work and we all had to pull up our big girl panties and get on with it.
Posts.Title: Chemo - long term implications for treatment

Posts.Content: I wasn't given a choice - surgery, chemo, herceptin, radio, AIs - all because of the type of cancer. However, I would have opted for all of it, even if each individual percentage is low. Together they add up to the best possible chance in my view. Overtreatment - bring it on!
Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: Sleepy Mushroom Thanks for sharing, Kacang.  May I ask whether you have chemo before surgery or surgery before chemo? Hi - I had surgery first. That seems to be the norm here in Oz. I don't know anyone who had chemo first. Cheers Lynn
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: I wasn't told but I was sent for "mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy if warranted". So the moment the dr walked in and said he was going to do a biopsy, I knew.
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results

Posts.Content: Femara made by Novartis is the original patent medicine. All other brands are so called generics. Perhaps see if you can get your doctor to prescribe Femara.
Posts.Title: supply of letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi - I had all lymph nodes removed and am glad I did as 16/30 showed evidence of cancer. My approach is to do anything that might contribute to the cancer not coming back. Mastectomy, lymph node clearance, chemo, radio, herceptin, aromatase inhibitor, biphosponate injection and anything else they might offer me.
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Well now I know. The so-called emulsifying wax BP contains sodium lauryl sulfate. It will give me great pleasure to raise this with the nurses.
Posts.Title: Aqueous cream and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi all.  I think it sucks when you can't get the patent brand medicine if that's what you want. I have to pay a little more to get Arimidex (about $5 more) but it's available to me. The system here is slightly different - there's a check box on the prescription form that says 'no substitutions'. If my doc ticks that, I get Arimidex. The job was convincing my onco that there was a difference. I'm pretty sure he thinks it's placebo effect, but his view is that if it makes me feel better, placebo or not, then he'll prescribe it. Thank goodness.  Best to all
Posts.Title: supply of letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Bev. I didn't mention that the wretched steroids caused me to put on about 10kg of fluid, which then caused other health problems. It was severe enough for the docs to give me diuretics and the fluid gradually disappeared. Seeing you mention a bloated belly made me think that possibly part of your weight gain is fluid. I know others in the UK have had great difficulty getting fluid tablets but it might be worth mentioning it to your consultant next time you see him/her.
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: Great post Fiona. Good luck with the last chemo. It took me about 4 weeks after that to really get my mojo back - just in time for radio lol. All the best for next week. Lynn
Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Yep I had a port too. Best thing ever. I didn't have a moment's problem and you can shower/swim etc without a problem as it's entirely under your skin. Everyone should have one! Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: You poor thing! It will settle down eventually. I had drain in for 14 weeks and it wasn't till that was gone that I really started to settle. Most important is to keep doing the exercises.
Posts.Title: 18 days post surgery and very sore / tender

Posts.Content: Hi Bev. I lost weight during chemo - particularly the T part, as I couldn't eat very much. However a friend of mine put on 10 kg (about one and a half stone I think). I wouldn't recommend dieting during chemo as your body is messed around enough. Just try to eat some healthy things. I survived on tomato soup, fruit and hot chips. It was all I could stomach. I had minimal steroids for the second half of chemo as they'd caused me loads of health issues. No doubt that's part of the reason for not putting on weight.  And as for exercise - I barely had the energy to get up and go to the toilet, let alone anything else lol. Trying to now though, although I have never been one for regular exercise.
Posts.Title: Weight gain on chemo

Posts.Content: Slightly disagree mistymoley I had a mastectomy and then radio, even though my tumour wasn't near the chest wall. The radio oncologist said it was to mop up any cells hanging around. I also had radio to the supra clavicular fossa (near the collarbone) as I had stage 3, HER2+ (and therefore aggressive) BC.  I absolutely agree with you on the possible damage to the skin from radio. I was told by my surgeon that she wouldn't consider reconstruction till at least a year after finishing radio, to give the skin a proper chance to heal. I'm not going to have recon though.  Violet blue  You might be interested in this article re chemo http://www.healthcentral.com/breast-cancer/c/78/181139/chemotherapy-decision?ap=brca I guess I'm adding more stuff into the mix too - sorry about that. None of us can really advise you as it's a personal decision. The main thing is that you have to be able to live with whatever you decide. Best
Posts.Title: Immediate reconstruction or staged?

Posts.Content: Hi Jemily. Yes chemo sucks big time but thing is, it works! If the docs are suggesting chemo, they must think it's necessary/worthwhile.  Yes we all lost our hair but there are plenty of wigs, scarves, hats and bandanna options. Or, like me, you can be out and proud. It's not the end of the world.  I had my op before chemo because I was HER2+ but if possible, I think the chemo first option is good for two reasons - first you might only end up needing a lumpectomy, rather than a full mastectomy. Secondly, you can "see" the chemo working as the lump shrinks. The downside is that lumps don't always shrink as much as expected. As for vomiting. Not everyone gets bad nausea and vomiting - I didn't (I didn't throw up at all and only felt mildly nauseous a couple of times) - but if your mum does, there's a wide range of anti-nausea meds to help. The docs don't actually want people to throw up.  Wishing your mum all the best and sending hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Scared about my mums chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi Kerry Violet blue    Great news that your nodes are clear. It's not an easy decision and the options seem confusing. You haven't said whether you have the detailed pathology results yet, nor whether the surgeon has confirmed that s/he will want to do a mastectomy or lumpectomy, nor whether you will or will not need chemo or radio.  It is becoming more common for chemo to come before surgery, especially if there's no spread, with the goal of shrinking the lump so surgery is less invasive (possibly a wle instead of a mastectomy). Has that option been discussed with you?  As far as I know, doctors tend to discourage you from having an implant if you are to have radio as it makes the radio more complicated and there is a risk of damaging the implant and therefore needing to have it removed. It sounds like this has been made clear to you but you do need to have a good idea of whether the docs will recommend radio before you can make a decision on that basis.  I can understand that you want to minimise surgery but do bear in mind that follow up surgery is often needed anyway for various reasons.  Can I be of any further help? Best Best
Posts.Title: Immediate reconstruction or staged?

Posts.Content: Yeah Jen white Not sleeping really sucks, but it's very common. Have you got a book or a movie to watch? Better that than lying there worrying. Or you could get up and do the washing lol.  If you have to have a biopsy, then you'll have to wait a couple of weeks for the result. It might at that point be worth asking your doc for something to help you sleep. Keep on keeping on
Posts.Title: Lump in my armpit.

Posts.Content: Sounds like denial to me! He's probably extremely scared You have to look after yourself and do what's right for you - involve friends and other family for support. Try not to stress about his attitude (impossible I know). Stay strong xxx
Posts.Title: Husband remark to cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Jen white Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I hope your stay with us is short. There's nothing quite so scary as finding a lump. And then plucking up the courage to go to the doctors. Well done you for doing something about it.  None of us on here can tell you if it's cancer - you need to have a scan and biopsy to confirm that, but remember the vast majority of breast lumps don't turn out to be cancer. When you go to the hospital you'll be given a mammogram and ultrasound. If there's anything suspicious, or even if your hospital is ultra-cautious, you'll have a biopsy. Then you'll have to wait a couple of weeks for the results. That's a scary time too. You could try over the counter pain meds like paracetamol or ibuprofen, if you can take these. Otherwise I'm afraid it's a case of grin and bear it. Often the pain is magnified by the worry. Try to keep busy - treat yourself or do one one of your favourite things. Shopping therapy works too lol. Have you talked to any of your family about this? Support from a family member is really helpful, and if possible you should get someone to go with you to the appointment. I hope it turns out to be nothing to worry about.  Big hugs
Posts.Title: Lump in my armpit.

Posts.Content: Hi Matthew (mattyg) I had a nasty flare up in my back after radio, which both my radio oncologist and medical oncologist, as well as my GP, put down to lying in an awkward position every day. It settled down eventually but took about 3 months. Sigh - middle aged back - sigh! However, I'd say if it doesn't resolve soon then get another opinion or go back to the onco. Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Back Pain Post Radio?

Posts.Content: Great news. It must be such a relief for you. Hugs
Posts.Title: So worried - 2 new lumps in my other breast

Posts.Content: Don't worry everyone. You soon get used to being bald as a coot! And the feeling of water on your scalp in the shower is fantastic - quite luxurious. Oh and you never have a bad hair day.  Whether you choose a wig, hats, scarves or nothing, it'll soon be over and your hair will be back.  I was out and proud ie I never wore anything on my head except occasionally I wore a sunhat when out in the Aussie summer sun, just as I always do. I found I had no problems - no staring, no weird looks. I know that's not for everyone but always, when I saw people wearing scarves or hats, I had thought that if I were in that situation, I'd like to be open enough to go commando. I figure the more open we can be, the less scary cancer will become.  Love to all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Here's the link Cords  https://www.knittedknockers.org/make-a-knocker/ Scroll down past all the video tutorials and the pattern you need is the fourth one "our original pattern". It's American so the conversions are  4 ply yarn, No 10 or 3.25mm needles Double knit/8 ply yarn, no 8 or 4 mm needles (the instructions for this are in brackets). I find using 4 ply acrylic gives the best result. I have used cotton but it's heavy and takes ages to dry. Also, tell your mum that it works perfectly well if you start with 3 stitches on each needle and just sew up the tiny hole. It's also much less fiddly. Don't worry, this should all make sense to her lol.
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: Hi JMC04 Mine basically all came out about 2 weeks after my first chemo. I lost everything - head, pubes, all body hair, eyebrows and lashes and best of all the nasty hairs that grow out of my chin. They of course were the first to return - and at full strength!  The tell tale sign that it's happening is when your scalp starts to hurt - like you've had a too tight ponytail all day. When that happens you'll be so ready to shave it off, just to get rid of the pain.  Of course much depends on the type of chemo you're having. If it's AC or EC, hair loss is guaranteed. Some people lose less with T, and other chemo drugs generally have less of an impact.
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: I too have found it difficult to by bras. Seems you can have pretty or comfortable but not both at the same time. I was also in a bit of a quandary as I'm losing weight so not wanting to spend excessively on any clothing - I've already bought and discarded 2 pairs of jeans! In the end I went through my pre-mastectomy bras, found 4 that aren't too bad and took the underwire out. They're all slightly padded, pre-formed style so work really well. Once I pin my knitted knocker in, it's impossible to tell the difference between the two sides.  Lord knows what I'll do when they wear out!!! Cheers all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Coastal-lady Sorry to hear you're having trouble with Arimidex, especially that rib pain, which sounds horrid.  I'm not sure I can add much to what Dreamthief has already told you. I've found Arimidex to be the best of the anastrozole options, with way lighter SEs than the generics. It does get easier over time as your body gets used to the lack of oestrogen.  I have found that my body doesn't deal as well with unusual movement as it did once upon a time. Not putting that very well so here's an example: I recently joined a strength and balance exercise class, with many exercises I've not done before. I was in agony for several days afterwards, mostly in tendons and cartilage  and especially in my lower back and one hip. Same again last  week but not quite so bad. I've also found that an old (1980s) repetitive strain injury has flared up and my arm can get quite sore if I hang out on the computer for too long. I can only attribute these to the Arimidex. So, similar but not identical, problems to yours.   Don't rush to quit the Arimidex but I do agree with George that the best thing to do is to ring your BCN. Good luck with it.
Posts.Title: Rib Pain - Arimidex

Posts.Content: Exercise - I hate it and have done since I was at school. I tried running at one point in my 40s. Both my girls and my then husband assured me that it would stop hurting and I'd get the endorphin rush. I ran a structured program for 6 months and got to the point where I could run for 30 mins plus warm up/down. It never stopped hurting and I never got an endorphin rush so I gave up and I've never run again.  These days I force myself to do 20 mins on the exercise bike. I've managed to keep it up for over a year cos I know it's good for me but I hate it. Every. Single. Second. However, I will keep doing it as I can feel that it's doing me some good.  I think I wasn't born to exercise sigh. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Hi MoMo2626 I completely agree a rethink on pain is needed. I didn't have actual pain but for several months I did have weird twinges and the sense that not all was normal. Couldn't feel any lump or anything though and dismissed it as age, gardening etc and wasn't at all worried. When I finally found a lump, I also by then had a swollen lymph node, which I hadn't noticed. Once it was pointed out though it was bleeding obvious. 20:20 hindsight is a wonderful thing of course but I certainly encourage anyone who asks to get any pain or weird feelings checked out. After all, being wrong would be a wonderful thing.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Hi Wynneth. Welcome aboard the roller coaster! It's rotten that you've been passed round different consultants - it doesn't help in building trust! It seems to me that the main benefits of having chemo first are a) shrinking the tumour so a WLE instead of a mastectomy becomes possible; and b) you can see whether and how well the chemo is working. Of course, it would be more disheartening if you didn't get significant shrinkage. On the other hand, the main benefit of surgery first is that the cancer is gone and everything else is belt and braces to try to make sure it doesn't come back.  I had surgery first - chemo first wasn't offered and I didn't know enough then to ask about it. However, I don't regret it in the least as I was glad it was gone.  Best of luck with your surgery. Have you got a date yet?
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: Hi Gay wombat.23 I started after a lengthy spell in hospital as I had to do something as rehab. I started at 2 mins on the lowest resistance and gradually worked up to 20 mins with intervals. I was lucky enough to be guided by a cycling coach (my cleaner actually who also coaches teenagers in competitive cycling). His view is that you don't need to do more than 20 mins for fitness, as long as you do intervals. I vary these but always do a  period at the highest resistance.  I have the bike in front of my computer so I can watch TV lol. I'm working my way through old episodes of The Bill. I started with the very first episode and now I'm up to Series 7, which was about 1991 I think. It's great. Even that is an encouragement to keep at it lol.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: I don't know much about dogs but they are vaccinated for several things aren't they? Why don't you get all the non-live ones and leave live ones till you finish. In addition, there might be alternative vaccines for some diseases. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and my dog

Posts.Content: PS My chemo unit doesn't use the cold cap and the oncology practice I go to doesn't recommend it. Their view is that it's mostly unsuccessful but heightens the risk of cancer cells remaining near the skin of the head. The overall risk assessment is that it's not worth it.  I guess this illustrates differences in treatment around the world - I'm in Australia.
Posts.Title: Hair still falling out 4 weeks after chemo

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear you're not looking forward to going back to work. I've retired so it didn't happen to me and I'm sure someone will be along who has been through a similar experience recently. We've had a few teachers on here in the last year so highly likely someone will have something to say.  I'm sure it won't be as bad as you think. My husband has a saying "nothing is ever as good or as bad as you think it's going to be".  Take it as slow and steady as you can and be prepared to be exhausted by the end of the first week, so don't plan anything but relaxing for the first weekend after starting.  I hope it goes really well for you.
Posts.Title: Back to work anxiety

Posts.Content: Hi Ruthie63 As Carolyn28 said, I do have a different view from her! The approach I've taken is that all those little percentages add up - radio, AIs, chemo and so on all reduce your risk of recurrence by a bit so I want to do anything that will reduce the risk of recurrence. This is, however, in the context that I had a "nasty aggressive cancer" as my onco called it. In the end it's up to each individual to decide how much risk they can bear and how much treatment they can bear. You do, however, have to be comfortable that, if it were to recur, you could live with the fact that you had refused a kind of treatment ie no 'what ifs'.  To LJB234 HER2+ breast cancer  the cancer cells make an excess of the HER2 protein - it's about 20% of breast cancers. If you are HER2+ then you would be offered Herceptin, a treatment which is directly targeted at the HER2 protein. If you're HER2- then Herceptin has no effect.  Love to all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and should I have chemo?

Posts.Content: Docetaxel is the drug where you really need to paint your nails. I'm having paclitaxel which isn't quite as fierce on nails. I painted mine for a couple of weeks but decided to stop so I could rub cream into the actual nail. It seems to have worked - they look horrid, bruised and with the white patches, as well as ridged, but at least they've stopped flaking and they are still there. I'm keeping them very short at the moment so they don't catch on anything. I figure that if they're not adhering to the flesh as much as usual, then there's a risk of pulling one off. Don't want to even think about it. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Nails!!!!!

Posts.Content: JMC04 Hi my mother has mid-stage dementia so I know what you're going through with your dad. She lives in a different city. 12 months ago I was very ill in ICU and my husband was told to call the family. Mum came (although she worried more about the dog being in kennels than about me). She has very clear memories of that time but not of the times (4) I've seen her since I recovered. So this means she thinks I'm very ill and won't believe me when I tell her on the phone that I'm very healthy. Not much I can do of course except reassure her as much as possible and visit when I can. Sigh! And as for scans - the waiting time is pants. It's impossible not to worry and we all let our imaginations run riot. No way to avoid it. Just go for as many distractions as you can - friends, hobbies, exercise, shopping - they all help. Best to everyone Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Hi Skye01 Sorry to hear they're at it again. Some great responses here and all I can add is to tell them to get stuffed lol. As Julia said, it's time for you to look after your own mental health not theirs.  Love and hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha Well done you for getting through the mastectomy. Did you have full node clearance or just the sentinel nodes removed?  I'm not sure what you mean by margins of 4 and 8. Normally docs talk in terms of a margin of x mm when someone has a WLE rather than a mastectomy, so I don't know what it could mean in your case.  Chemo is usually offered when there is significant presence of cancer in the lymph nodes. The aim is to catch any stray cancer cells that may have migrated around your body and stop them growing into secondaries. It is also offered if your cancer was HER2+, as you can't have Herceptin and pertuzumab without at least having a taxane. Chemo is also usually offered to people who had triple negative breast cancer, mainly as there are no other follow up treatments for TNBC.  No oncologist would offer chemo if they didn't think there was a benefit to the patient. However, it's up to the patient ultimately to decide if the benefit outweighs the risk for them personally. For some people the reduction in risk is small, for others it's significant. You need to make sure that your oncologist explains everything, including the benefits and risks, to you very carefully. Keep pestering until you are satisfied with the answers. Some people do decline chemo. There is a thread on here from about 6 months ago that goes into this in a fair bit of detail. This is the link. Do have a read, you'll find it interesting. Best
Posts.Title: Margins and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Cords. Glad you like your knitted knocker. The best bit is that you can pin it to your bra - no chance of a wardrobe malfunction. Great in swimmers for the same reason. I have knitted several to match different bras and also a couple for swimming that are filled with shower scrunchies rather than poly-fill. Can you knit or crochet? If so, I can give you the link to the patterns.
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: Before I was diagnosed, I was a C-D cup but I lost a lot of weight during chemo and went down to a B-C. Now putting it on again unfortunately so I'd say I'm firmly a C cup these days.
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: You are so right KerryCake you do learn a lot about people and about yourself. I am blessed to have had several wonderful people who have supported me (and my husband) through the whole journey and some whom I've let fall by the wayside. And as for family ... I've posted before about my self-centred mother but my brother came good. He was here when I was very ill and in ICU and was wonderful, particularly with my husband. They've never really gotten on but there's a new closeness now. Cancer does bring some positives, although it's hard to see it at the time.  And huge respect to you for having the courage to stand up to your "friend". I too had one like that but I junked her about 3 years ago. Couldn't stand it any longer. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Hi Skye - you sure will feel better once you're past chemo. I found that I'd forgotten what feeling even moderately normal felt like. It was wonderful from about 3 weeks after the last chemo and when I started feeling better and better each day. Finishing also lifted me mentally as I could do more stuff and didn't feel like a dreary invalid sitting home all the time. Here for you Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Hi again Wynneth. I just wanted to let you know that I've had a mastectomy with no reconstruction and I'm a very happy lop-sided Lizzie. My scar is clean and neat and it really doesn't bother me at all. I use knitted knockers pinned into an ordinary bra (or my swimmers) when I go out and I defy anyone to tell the difference. At home I go round with no bra and I don't care. I've even been known to sneak down to the shops like that - providing I"m wearing a loose sweatshirt. Frankly I really don't care - the ghouls can look all they like but I'm healthy and happy and that's all that matters. Best
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: My hair fell out during my 1st set of treatments (4 doses of AC). I was then given 4 weeks off as I wasn't well and then spent 4 weeks in hospital. My hair didn't start growing at all till I was in hospital ie at least 6 weeks and it was only peach fluff. I have now moved on to 12 weekly doses of paclitaxel and I still have the peach fluff but nothing else. I think 4 weeks is a little early to expect real hair, and your peach fluff should be hidden by the hair you have left. Relax - you should have some by the end of the year.
Posts.Title: Hair still falling out 4 weeks after chemo

Posts.Content: Great news Val. Sounds like you're on the up. Hope everything else has worked out too.  Have a great Christmas and a happy and healthy 2017 Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Feeling so happy

Posts.Content: This must all be very upsetting for you Rubix. I'm afraid I don't have any real answers for you but like George this doesn't make much sense to me. A couple of positive things that might help ease your mind or at least give you ammo to ask more questions: - if you're stage IIIA that means the cancer has spread to local lymph nodes but not through the rest of your body; - I had cancer in 16/30 lymph nodes but they were all removed - you are HER2 positive. Herceptin is a very effective treatment.  Finally, I was diagnosed as stage IIIB but my onco is confident that I'll recover. Don't despair, just remember you are entitled to a clear explanation of everything. Frankly your consultant sounds like an a**hole - perhaps you could talk to your GP about getting a second opinion.  It will be a rocky road for a few months but best of luck Lynn
Posts.Title: Confused after unhelpful consultant appointment

Posts.Content: Here's a terribly unfashionable suggestion - buy a pair of crocs. I found the cushioning from the spongy sole to be a godsend. My hubby took to crocs after he got plantar fasciitis - that's completely fixed now. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Sore Feet/ peripheral neuropathy

Posts.Content: How frustrating and worrying for you Daisylou but please don't get too upset. Letrozole is used to shrink tumours before surgery, to control tumours in the absence of surgery, to help prevent recurrence and to stabilise and control metastatic cancer so it should be fine for you. The other important thing to bear in mind is that cancers develop quite slowing so a week or two here or there doesn't make much difference. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Surgery delay

Posts.Content: As I said on the other thread, I use knitted knockers. I decided against getting a proper silicon prosthesis for the time being as a) I still have a small seroma so the sizing wouldn't be quite accurate; b) I might still go for a reconstruction; c) prostheses here cost hundreds of dollars and any subsidy is strictly means tested (I wouldn't pass). I also made myself an aqua knocker, filled with the nylon stuff from a shower scrunchy so it dries easily after swimming (actually I squeeze it out when no one's looking lol). Both work really well.  Best of luck  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Protheses problems?

Posts.Content: Hi Bramblefarm. Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I'm so sorry to hear about your diagnosis but you'll find plenty of support here.  Whether or not you need chemo will depend on the pathology of the cancer, how advanced it is (the stage) and how aggressive it is. If yours has been diagnosed as grade 3, chances are it's an aggressive one. The docs may not be able to do final staging until after your surgery as they'll take a lymph node to check for any spread to the nodes. As far as the pathology goes if the cancer is HER2 + or triple negative then a chemo recommendation is pretty much guaranteed, unless you're too frail otherwise to be able to cope with chemo. If it's hormone positive but HER2- then chemo may not be the right treatment. There are tests to help determine that - but let's not get too far ahead. Losing your hair is traumatic for some people but you can try the cold cap. And in the end, it does grow back.  One piece of advice I was given is to take it one step at a time and focus on that. So for you at the moment it's diagnosis and getting the full information. Then the medics will develop a treatment plan for you.  Do keep in touch and feel free to ask any questions you like, or just come here for a rant if you need to.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Grade 3

Posts.Content: Sooooo upsetting for you. I fear I wouldn't be nearly as restrained as others have suggested - I'd be more likely to tell them to go to hell.  That might not work for you but do think about telling them where to go at some level.  I moved away from my family because of my mother and have never regretted it. I have some good close friends who've absolutely been there for me in the last 12 months. That warms my heart!  I was very sick and in ICU during chemo. The family was summoned and unfortunately my mother came.  From when I woke up until she went home she only had two topics of conversation - how exhausting the walk from the car park was and how she worried about her dog (who was in a very posh kennels that he loves). I've accepted she'll never change. Wishing you the best of luck with them all. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Oh Skye how horrid for you. I guess it confirmed all you suspected about their selfishness. Quite frankly, you can't afford to live in their shadow at this time. You need all available emotional energy to get through this and keep your daughter happy. Focus on the main game - getting well - and not their silly games.  I'm sure your friends will come through for you. I have never ceased to wonder at how fab my friends have been. And the bonus is that the whole thing has brought me closer to some lovely people. Wishing you the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: What crappy news franm_1962! Are they saying it's definitely a recurrence of breast cancer? The reason I ask is because you've had your lymph nodes removed, so it can't be in them. Perhaps there was some residual breast tissue there. As far as recovery is concerned, I guess you mean recovery from surgery. I don't think it should take that long if they just cut out the lump and a margin but it really does depend on what surgery is planned. Time to ask a few questions maybe. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer 2nd time around

Posts.Content: Hi tammj The waiting sucks! It really is the worst part of the whole thing as your mind just goes crazy imagining the worst. While you are fretting (and you will - no one can tell you not to worry cos it's a worrying situation) just remember that if it is cancer, you have already taken the first step towards getting yourself fixed up and also that breast cancer is immensely survivable. In my home town the 5 year survival rate for all breast cancers is 96% - that's virtually normal. Of course it varies by sub-type of cancer, how advanced it is when diagnosed and to some extent your location but overall it is very very survivable, so don't start planning your funeral.  I agree that random googling isn't helpful but some of us need to know and understand what's going on. I did. However, I found that if I stuck to sensible well-informed sites like this one, cancer research UK and the equivalent American ones, you can get the facts without the emotive stories.  Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: awaiting results for a breast core biopsy

Posts.Content: In your position, I would definitely get myself tested - knowledge is power. Also it might help with your mother, especially if you do have either 1 or 2. However, in the end your mum is a grown up and entitled to decide what suits her best.
Posts.Title: Talking to family

Posts.Content: PS a quick scan of Dr Google would suggest that the BRCA 1 mutation also elevates the risk of bladder cancer. You might want to check that out.
Posts.Title: Talking to family

Posts.Content: Found this on Facebook and immediately thought of you Skye01
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Jones 75 Hi Ann, I am having left breast Mastectomy and back flap recon, I think? I can't decide whether to have the reconstruction, would you recommend it, can you offer any advice? Thank you xx Hi Ann. You might want to start a new thread with this question as people may not find it as this is 5 years old and on a different topic. I had a saved skin mastectomy and immediate reconstruction (with implant). However, I got very ill in the middle of chemo and ended up putting on about 10kg worth of fluid. Eventually that went everywhere but my reconstructed boob. So I ended up with a septated (fibrous) seroma looking like a football on my chest. I had to have it surgically removed - effectively a full mastectomy. I wish I'd had a regular full mastectomy from the outset and I don't know whether I'll ever want to have a reconstruction. I don't at the moment but it's early days.  Best of luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Hair falling out.

Posts.Content: I am 9 weeks post chemo. I have about a centimetre of hair all over, although it's a bit thin on the top of my head. I was told by one of the nurses that it's like babies - apparently their hair grows from back to front. Have to say it's lovely having a bit of hair back, although my partner thinks I look too butch lol.
Posts.Title: Question about hair growth

Posts.Content: Hi Sammy2017 I'm sure you're concerned about what's going on and it's a worrying time for you. However, I can assure you that you've done the right thing. The majority of breast lumps turn out not to be cancer, but if it is then you'll be scheduled for treatment. Remember breast cancer is very treatable.  Don't fret too much about the look of the lump - lumps come in all shapes and sizes. It sounds like your doctors are being thorough and that's the most important thing. Please keep in touch Big hugs
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Hi Maxine Sorry to hear your toenails are misbehaving, but it does sound like you'll lose them. Don't worry too much though, when they eventually drop off  there will be a nice new nail already growing underneath.  As for your feet, it may be the start of peripheral neuropathy so make sure you report this to your onco. He may decide to reduce the dose of T. I was told PN is normally temporary but is more likely to be  permanent if it starts moving beyond your hands and feet ie up your arms and legs. My T was stopped early because of PN. My best advice is to wear crocs, no matter how naff, as they cushion your feet.  Best
Posts.Title: Tips for a black toenail

Posts.Content: Brilliant news Sammy2017. It's the kind we love to hear. I hope you're going to celebrate.
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Hi StuTea. Welcome aboard the roller coaster. Let's hope your stay isn't very long and you get good news from your tests. I'm not surprised you're worried - facing a cancer diagnosis is one of the scariest things that can happen to you. Please bear in mind though that 90% of breast lumps turn out not to be cancer and, even if yours is, breast cancer is very treatable especially as it looks like you caught the problem quickly.  I know it's hard that the docs and technicians won't tell you anything but the technicians aren't authorised to say much as they're the experts in the machines, not the lumps. Secondly, generally doctors don't like to say anything because imagine how you'd feel if they said it looked ok and then turned out to be cancer?  So now you have to face the weekend. Remember that no amount of worrying is going to change a single thing between now and Tuesday. I know you won't stop worrying, but don't let it take over. Do something fun with your children and husband, spoil yourself, keep busy - whatever it takes to distract you. I hope you get good news on Tuesday but if not we'll all be here to help you through.  Best
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Hi Myfairlady Welcome aboard the roller coaster. Let's hope your stay with us is short!  Sounds crazy but I think you're pretty fortunate that the lump has been found. If it is breast cancer then early diagnosis gives the best chance of a cure. However, that won't stop you worrying until you get the results. Please do remember that 90% of breast lumps turn out not to be cancerous and even if it is, BC is very treatable.  Now, as to the worrying ... Nothing I can say will stop you worrying - it's natural and normal. We've all been there. The main thing is to try to not let the worrying take over. Keep busy, treat yourself, try a new craft, do lots of exercise, perhaps a bit of shopping therapy - whatever it takes to keep your mind active on other things. Some people set aside a time for worrying eg half an hour in the morning and for the rest of the day tell themselves to park the worrying until the next "worry time". It seems to work and the more you practise it, the better you get at it. Also remember that there's nothing you can do now to change the outcome.  I could give you a heap more advice but I'll stick to one piece. Please try to avoid Dr Google. He'll just scare the pants off you and so much of the information out there is out of date or inaccurate. If you absolutely can't resist doing the research, then stick to trusted sites like Macmillan and Cancer Research UK. If they don't satisfy you, let me know and I'll point you in the direction of other good reliable sites.  Please do hang around this forum and post if you wish. There are some very supportive and knowledgeable people here who will hold your hand through this. Feel free to just have a rant if you need to, or ask questions. Do let us know how you get on Thursday. Wishing you all the very best.
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: If they've told you you will have tamoxifen, it means the cancer must be hormone positive. If you're not HER2+ (when chemo is always recommended) then chemo isn't necessarily the best treatment. I suggest you ask your team about the oncotype test. This is a test to see how much you'd benefit from chemo. For some people it's really low, like 2 or 3%. If you then consider the risks associated with having chemo, it may not be worth it. But  you can't make that decision unless you know. As far as losing your hair goes, it's not that bad. I went commando the entire time - I think I wore a sunhat a couple of times and that's all. Frankly I was more bothered by losing body hair (skin on skin friction) and my pubes - I thought that was a bit creepy. People were really kind to me and I got great service!  Hope it all goes well for you. Do keep in touch and let us know how you're doing.
Posts.Title: My left breast has been removed

Posts.Content: You could try cutting what's there to 1 cm long. That way it wouldn't look quite so tufty.
Posts.Title: hair regrowth ahhhh what to do with it ?

Posts.Content: Lucky you Amanda! I used to have thick and misbehaving curly hair. Hope mine grows back finer and semi curled like yours.  I too went bald and was entirely comfortable going out in public - I wore a hat for the cold and a sun hat when out in the heat but nothing otherwise. I found people were very kind and I'm sure I got better service in cafes and restaurants! I like to think of it as out and proud - I didn't see any reason to hide what was happening to me. Maybe it's people who have lived with crap hair that are not so worried about losing it. Cheers Lynn
Posts.Title: hair regrowth ahhhh what to do with it ?

Posts.Content: What bad luck but it does sound like you were overdoing it Dee!!! Your body does take longer to heal while on chemo so take it easy.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Twisted ankle and feeling miserable

Posts.Content: I started using bio-oil as soon as my scabs fell off. Both the oil itself and massaging the area really helped. Good luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Stopping Scars From Drying Out

Posts.Content: Normally they try to leave about 4 weeks between the two (or at least they do here in Oz) to allow time for some recovery from chemo. I had to have further surgery so my gap ended up being about 12 weeks. I was told anything up to 4 months is ok ie with no increase in the risk of recurrence. Best of luck - radio is much easier than chemo Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Times between chemo and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Alison. I had hubby shave me to a no 4 the weekend before I started chemo and started to get the sore scalp about 2 weeks after first treatment. I'd already made up my mind to be out and proud and not worry about being bald, so I got him to shave it that weekend. Even going from No 4 to No 0 was a great relief! Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Sore/Tender Scalp

Posts.Content: Hi all. I started on letrozole exactly 12 months ago. It was awful - achy, sweaty etc etc so after 3 months my onco switched me to anastrozole. I had a generic for a couple of months, which was significantly better than letrozole but still not great. Then my pharmacist gave me some real Arimidex as that's all they had in stock. I couldn't believe the difference it made. Hardly any SEs at all. I mentioned the difference to my onco who was skeptical but he agreed to keep prescribing Arimidex only. I think that it was on that basis that if the placebo effect is working, then that's good. I really believe there's a difference though.  Now, one year later, I have very few side effects. I occasionally have trouble sleeping and I get stiff if I sit for a long period, such as watching a movie or on a flight. However, it only takes a couple of minutes to loosen up.  There is of course also the option of exemestane, which is also an AI but has a different mechanism of action. It suits some people better. I'm avoiding it though as it's steroid-based and steroids and I do not agree. As for night sweats, I found that taking the tablet in the morning was better. I'd wake up in a pool of sweat when I was taking them at night. However, the sweats do reduce over time anyway as your body gets used to the lower oestrogen level.
Posts.Title: Femara ( Letrozole) V Arimidex ( Anastrozole) advice please !!!

Posts.Content: Oh Loulou it's not good getting that feeling from your medical team. It's highly unlikely they're giving up on you. I suspect it's more that BC is so common and so routine for many doctors that they lose the ability to explain things properly! There's also quite a few pompous asses out there who have no bedside manner and act as though they think all patients are stupid. Mind you I'd rather have a doctor with no bedside manner who was competent than a lovely person who was hopeless! Make a list of all your questions for your oncologist and don't let him/her get away with not answering. Most important don't let them intimidate you. Take notes (or have a relative/friend take notes for you) as you probably won't remember everything you're told.  Stay strong. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Hi Seapebbles Welcome aboard. Let's hope your checks are clear and it's only a short stay! I think most people would say the waiting is the worst part as your mind naturally thinks the worst. Please keep in mind that the vast majority of breast lumps do not turn out to be cancer (I think I've heard 90% but I can't remember where from and can't verify that) but also, if it did turn out to be breast cancer, you've already taken the first step in getting treated - seeing a doctor about it. You won't stop worrying, but you can control it - keep busy, treat yourself, focus on positive things.  Some breast clinics will carefully avoid saying anything, while others will give some indication. The trouble with that is there have been people on this forum who have had the doc say it looks ok and then once the pathology is in, told they have breast cancer. Personally I think that would be worse than not being told anything in the first place.  I was sent for the standard mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy "if indicated". Although the radiologist didn't say anything, I knew I had BC the moment he walked in and said he was going to do a biopsy.  The only caution I would add is that for about a year or so (I can't really remember how long) before I was diagnosed, I had a strong feeling that I was facing a health train wreck. No real symptoms, just knowing I wasn't quite right - in fact I thought I'd have a heart attack as heart disease runs strongly in my family. There was never enough to actually go to a doctor about until I found the lump of course. Of course I can't say whether you have BC or any other illness, but don't dismiss those feelings. Wishing you all the very best and hoping your checks turn out fine.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer referral after my nans passed away from cancer the same...

Posts.Content: Oh Loulou it's not good getting that feeling from your medical team. It's highly unlikely they're giving up on you. Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: As others have said, it's perfectly normal. My GP sent me for the scans right at the start as he said the surgeon would order them anyway and it would save time. I think at that point I was so spun out by the whole thing I didn't really even think of the cancer having spread - it was more a case of bumbling from appointment to appointment.
Posts.Title: Scans to check if bc has spread

Posts.Content: I had AC then weekly paclitaxel but with a two month break in between. In that break, my hair started growing back, including eyelashes and eyebrows. It ALL fell out again 3 weeks after starting T. Back now :) Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 12 weekly Taxol hair loss

Posts.Content: Crocs rock Maxine lol. I wore mine everywhere when my feet were sore. Trouble is now I have difficulty remembering to wear anything else. I hope this dose of T is kinder to you.
Posts.Title: Tips for a black toenail

Posts.Content: Wow GaryN1 - you have been through rather a lot. However, keep remembering that breast cancer is very treatable.  It sounds like your team hasn't yet decided whether to remove all your lymph nodes on the affected side or to give you chemo. Just make sure you're comfortable with their recommendations before agreeing to anything.  Just one bit of advice. If you are to have chemo, then ask for a portacath or, if they won't agree to that, then a PICC or Hickman line. The portacath is the best as it's under your skin so doesn't cause any problems day-to-day, but any of them will be better for you than having chemo by a cannula if your veins are already shot.  BTW the operating theatres I've been in are just like on tele. What freaked me out the first time was having to get on the operating table by myself. I don't know why - it was unexpected I suppose.  Do keep in touch and let us know how you're progressing.
Posts.Title: My left breast has been removed

Posts.Content: You could try the Daniel Field natural hair colouring products. No peroxide, alcohol etc etc. I haven't tried them but will as soon as I have enough hair!
Posts.Title: Hair lightening products

Posts.Content: Hi Fireopal welcome aboard.  Apart from lying awkwardly and the possibility of tension, it's also true that surgery can give you weird pains as nerves get bruised and sometimes cut, plus you get put in some very strange positions when you're on the operating table. Did the hospital give you exercises? If so, are you doing them? I'd suggest trying some gentle stretching or yoga, or even a bit of swimming, especially breast stroke. It should all settle down and it's good that you're getting your other lump checked out.  Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: pain in front and back of body

Posts.Content: I would imagine so - H&B have a reputation to protect. Cheers Lynn
Posts.Title: Neuts/Pacletaxo and hair loss

Posts.Content: Well loupielou - you're still here and from the sound of it, likely to be for a long while to come. It does just keep going doesn't it - we're on the medical roundabout now and no signs of being able to get off it! Still, I'm happy with all the checking on me the docs seem to want to do - it's kind of a security blanket, even though I'm forever having medical appointments.  So glad you feel positive. Stay strong. Lots of love Lynn xx
Posts.Title: One year on !!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007 and peachesxxx  I was diagnosed as Type 2 diabetic after the first half of my chemo (AC). For a while there, my BGL was up in the 30s and I was put directly on insulin injections. Turns out it was brought on by the steroid I was given to help with nausea - dexmethasone. It's pretty standard treatment and you get it infused prior to the chemo infusion and tablets to take home. No one mentioned anything like diabetes before I started.  When I had my second set of chemo (T) I argued with my oncologist as I didn't want to have any steroids at all. In the end we compromised and I had the minimum dose for my size (4mg) and no take home tablets. My BGL was usually around 15 the next morning (usually sits at around 6.5 or 7 with drugs of course) and took a couple of days to drop back down. I would strongly recommend a discussion with the onco about steroid use prior to starting chemo.  Loulou, if I were you I would ask the onco for a serious discussion about the risks and benefits of chemo for you personally. As someone else has already said, we were all at the risk of sepsis and these days most people are given filgastrim or pegfilgastrim (Neulasta) to bring your white blood cell count up quickly. It may be that s/he has made an assessment that the benefit you might derive from chemo is outweighed by the risks but you don't know that unless it's explained fully to you. Chemo is standard here in Australia for just about everyone who has BC (except for the earliest of early cases) but there are plenty of people in the UK who post here who haven't had chemo so I think it's not quite so standard for you. You should ask for the oncotype test to get an idea of the level of benefit chemo might give you.  One other tip. If you have to have further surgery, ask to be put early on the list. My surgeon (without being asked) scheduled me for first in the day so I only had to fast for the minimum period. And then in Recovery, I was given an iced lolly (never tasted anything more delicious in my life lol). One thing I've learned through all of this is that you have to be an assertive patient! Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: Hi Mama55 Just to reassure you, I went to all my appointments and my chemo by myself, except for the first chemo when a friend, who had been treated at the same centre, insisted on coming along. I think it was more about catching up with the chemo nurses than anything else as she got bored and went shopping lol. I still love her though.  All through I wanted to be by myself so I could process things mentally in my own time, without other people wanting to discuss and dissect everything before I was ready to. My husband dropped me off and picked me up, which was great but that's all. In fact, until I was hospitalised, I don't think my onco realised I had a hubby! As it turns out, they got on really well (both being nerdy science boys) so I'd never have got a word in edgewise if I'd had my hubby at the appointments.  Your daughter will need plenty of other support during chemo as it really knocks you around. Be ready to drive her places, get shopping, look after kids, cook food etc etc and that will be appreciated I guarantee. Best Lynn xx PS She's not being "stubborn". It's just that you feel the need to do things a certain way and become more assertive about saying what you want. I know I did. Best to just respect her choices and go along with it. It doesn't mean she doesn't need and love you.
Posts.Title: Daughters 1st chemo

Posts.Content: I don't think the expander should need more than two surgeries - the mastectomy where the expander would be inserted and then a further surgery several months later to replace the expander with a permanent implant. In between the expander would be inflated with saline (I think) but this is done through a valve in the expander and should be no worse than an injection. There are also permanent expanders which they insert and then leave permanently.  Here's a link to the Macmillan explanation of implants and here's a more detailed explanation from breastcancer.org. There might be slight variations in practice as it's a US site but the general procedure would be similar. As for LD flaps - here's the Macmillan page and here's the link to the breastcancer.org information. Hope this helps
Posts.Title: Options for reconstruction

Posts.Content: I agree with mistymoley There's a lot of fake manuka honey out there. Pointers to the real stuff are that it's called manuka honey and it says made in New Zealand. The jar should also have a hexagonal UMF mark with a number. This is a grading system for quality - see umf.org.nz  I don't know about helping with low neutrophils but I do know that it's magic stuff!  Best  Lynn xx
