Posts.Title: I don't know what to do

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear this. Not the kind of news anyone wants. Hopefully it will turn out to be a localised recurrence only. Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Another Lump Update

Posts.Content: Hi Rosie Welcome aboard. I come at this from the opposite point of view to yours. I'm a "throw everything at it" person as I don't want to ever be in the position of saying "I wish I had ...". As far as I'm concerned, all those different treatments contribute percentage points to reducing the risk of recurrence. Hopefully the aggregate will be enough. This is partly because I know mine was a "nasty, aggressive cancer" (the words of my oncologist) so I feel a need to do everything I can.  I'm currently taking anastrozole as the AI and apart from a little stiffness after sitting for a long time eg a flight or watching a movie, I have no noticeable side effects and it doesn't interfere with my quality of life at all. I also found radiotherapy very easy to get through, with a little redness on my chest area but that's all. Chemo was a different story, with dreadful side effects but if I had a recurrence, I'd go through it all again willingly.  I understand having a phobia about medication - I did for many years and wouldn't take anything. My view has completely changed and now I am glad to have drugs that keep me alive and in good health.  Do make sure you get your oncologist to go through the risk figures with you as they're really important. For some people, taking an aromatase inhibitor can dramatically reduce the risk of recurrence. Finally, I understand that this is a really tough decision. Most importantly, you must be happy in yourself whichever way you go and prepared to accept the outcomes.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Declining further treatment after breast surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Val. Glad to hear you and your grandson are doing well. You'll probably be a bit anxious when you go for your mammogram - we all are! Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Breast clinic (mammogram )

Posts.Content: Excellent. Now you need to take it easy to maximise your healing. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: more surgery

Posts.Content: Nice one!
Posts.Title: A little bit of encouragement

Posts.Content: Not the news you wanted peaches but at least it's been found and you're getting treatment, which means you're already on the road to recovery! It's all a bit of a whirl at the moment I expect but things will settle down.  Interesting that you were told up to 15 years hormone therapy - I've only heard of 10 years and that's been relatively recent. Personally I'd stay on it as long as it's offered because it works!  Do keep in touch  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Results are back

Posts.Content: I didn't really have skin problems during chemo but I've just had shingles. It doesn't sound like shingles at all - with that you get cold sore like blisters that last for ages unless you get anti-viral meds. The classic feature of shingles too is that it only occurs on one side of your body.  I would give your BCN a call as they might be able to give you something to ease the pain and swelling.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Upper body skin sensitivity

Posts.Content: I had a node clearance 2.5 years ago. It was a long op but pretty easy. I didn't need the painkillers I was given. I'd agree with toxophilite and say start doing the exercises and keep doing them, especially if you're likely to have radio, as you need good shoulder movement for that.  I'm still numb around the armpit area and I expect I always will be but it doesn't interfere with my life and I don't really notice it. I've had some mild lymphoedema but the exercises and manual lymph drainage (sort of self-massage) keep it at bay. You need to try to avoid infections in that arm as they can bring on lymphoedema (or cellulitis if you already have it) so attend to any cuts quickly and carefully. Rose thorns are particularly bad so wear leather gloves if you have roses. All in all it's not so bad. Best of luck with it.
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Chick. I didn't have a reconstruction so can't help I'm afraid. I'm replying so you know someone's listening, to bump this post up the list and most of all to wish you all the best for your further surgery.  Is your tummy just untidy or is there an open wound? I had my belly button fixed recently (after 63 years of an outie, I now have a beautiful innie). I've always healed really fast with not much scarring but this time part of the wound took ages ie a couple of months to heal over. I still have a bit of scabbing. I think it's because there's a poor blood supply in that area, especially as I have a bit of belly fat. Fortunately that part is inside my bb so there's not much to see. Hope it goes well for you and that someone is along soon who has had a similar experience.
Posts.Title: more surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I had what the nurses called the 'doxy flush', where my cheeks became really red and itchy/sore. It's called that because I had doxorubicin (the A part of AC, which is a close cousin to epirubicin, the E part of EC). I just used posh moisturiser which soothed it but the splotches didn't go until I'd finished that part of chemo. Best
Posts.Title: Itchy rashes

Posts.Content: DL - just to clarify - "awaiting Herceptin results" actually means they're testing to see whether you're HER2 + or -. That test takes longer than the other pathology for some reason.  Jacmatholmad - Your team may decide to offer chemo as an option but it's not a given. It partially depends on how many lymph nodes were infected. If it's a lot then chemo is more likely to be offered. If they don't mention it, ask about the oncotype test. This tests the cancer to determine how much benefit chemo would be. There's some really good information about the test here on the breastcancercare site.
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Great news! It's all up from here on.  Lynn xxxx
Posts.Title: Gene test result :-)

Posts.Content: Hi DL. I'm not sure what percentages you're talking about. Is it the % benefit of chemo or the % chance of surviving 5 years? On the first one, if the cancer is HER2+ then the % is irrelevant as Herceptin is only licensed to be given in conjunction with chemo so everyone gets it. If the cancer turns out to be HER2-, then it's worth asking about percentage benefit and possibly the oncotype test. Some people may only get a 3-4% advantage from chemo, which you may not consider worthwhile as there's a risk in chemo itself. BUT some people do get a significant benefit, which is why it's worth the test.  If it's the latter, then my advice is to assume you will survive and put it out of your mind. Deal with a recurrence only if it occurs.  As far as diet goes, I confess I'm not a great believer in the organic thing. The science doesn't make sense to me. Some of it is truly absurd - for example buying a jar of pasta sauce that says made with organic tomatoes: yes but think of all the preservatives and other things in the sauce. Not sure about the sugar thing either. I prefer a good, well-balanced diet incorporating plenty of fresh food, especially fruit and vegetables, with moderate exercise and limited alcohol. I am, however, a firm believer that stress is a big factor and I have tried as far as possible to de-stress my life.
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: It does sound rather like a seroma but it's worth getting it checked. If it is, most disappear within a few weeks either with drainage or without. Some persist but they're not dangerous. Do keep doing the arm and shoulder exercises as they help to get the lymph moving - it has to be encouraged to find new routes to drain away.  Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Lump under arm after op

Posts.Content: I have been to every appointment by myself except my first chemo. A friend who has had BC insisted on coming with me (mainly so she could catch up with a couple of the chemo nurses I think). I have never wanted my husband or anyone else there and I didn't find any problem with not hearing stuff. Took copious notes however.  I guess all I'm saying is that everyone's journey is different and you need to do exactly what is right for you.  Hope it all works out well for you. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Waiting is nearly over

Posts.Content: Thanks collies. I can more confidently answer your question now. You might want to repost in the breast group too to get more responses. I had all my lymph nodes removed at the same time as having a saved skin mastectomy with implant. The whole procedure was pretty straightforward for me - I was driving within a week and I'm confident I would have been ready to go back to work after a fortnight at most, but glad I'm retired lol. Not everyone finds it that easy though. I had very little pain - I was given some panadeine forte to take home but only used a couple of them and that was more to get to sleep than for the pain.  As for side effects, the possible immediate side effects are seroma (build up of fluid) and failure of the wound to heal. That's much rarer but it does happen. Seromas tend to go away in a few weeks and often people have them drained a couple of times and they go away. I have had a seroma for 18 months, which is very rare. It won't go but it doesn't bother me so I've stopped worrying about it. The long term side effect that's more common is lymphoedema, which I've read can affect up to 25% of people. If you get any arm swelling, it's important to jump on it quickly and get treatment - that gives you the best chance of getting it under control.  Overall, most people find axillary clearance not perfect but not too bad. Better than having cancer remaining in the nodes of course.  There is an alternative to node clearance and that's to have radiotherapy on the nodes. Some people do very well with that. There's a big trial going on at the moment called the POSNOC trial to look at the value of radiotherapy. It might be worth asking your surgeon about whether RT is a possible alternative for you, or at least participation in the trial. The other option that might be available is to have a partial node clearance. Some people just have the next layer of nodes removed and tested, leaving some behind and thus reducing the risk of lymphoedema. Of course I've no idea whether either might be suitable for you but it could be worth doing a bit of research and then discussing with your surgeon.  Hope it all goes well for you.
Posts.Title: LYMPH NODES BEING REMOVED SOON

Posts.Content: No worries Rosie. The coughing thing wasn't aimed at you. I was just a bit concerned that the thread seemed to be developing into a lot of mutual reassurance that a cough was nothing to worry about, when it can be.
Posts.Title: Coughing with no other symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi Laura. It's good to know that your Mum is getting through chemo ok, although of course I'm sure she has good and bad days. I'm afraid low blood counts are par for the course with FEC-T chemo. Chemo kills all types of fast growing cells, not just cancer cells - that's why we lose our hair, our taste goes weird and so on. Blood cells are also fast growing so get knocked out by the chemo, making the risk of infection greater. Some people are given injections of Neupogen (filgastrim) or Neulasta (pegfilgastrim) to stimulate the production of white blood cells. Has your Mum had either of these?  It's hard to say how your mum will react to the taxotere. Some people say it's easier than FEC, but others find it quite hard - I've seen people refer to it as being hit by the tax truck. If she finds it really difficult, then it is possible to switch to the weekly paclitaxel, which has less difficult side effects. I had that and to be honest found it a breeze by comparison to my earlier chemo.  Wishing you and your mum all the very best
Posts.Title: Mum starts Docetaxel soon for stage 3 breast cancer. Any advice ladies...

Posts.Content: Hi Rosie I can't comment about your cough but it does seem that your GP is taking it seriously and looking after you properly, for which you should be eternally grateful as not everyone gets that I fear.  I just wanted to clarify, for everyone, your comment about radiation rays going right through the body. You make it sound like they go in through your breast and pop out on your back  somewhere near your shoulder blade. That is not so. Firstly, the intensity of the radiation beam, and thus how far it penetrates into the body, is variable. Secondly, the angles used mean that much of the radiation goes across the breast rather than directly into it. Part of the radiotherapy planning process is to work all these angles out, with the aim of missing the heart and lungs so far as is possible. As for unexplained coughing, coughing can be a side effect of letrozole. However, I would caution everyone not to immediately assume an unexplained cough is a letrozole SE. You should always get a cough checked if it persists for more than a week or two.
Posts.Title: Coughing with no other symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi Boudicca. I had a port - they're more or less automatic here in Australia. I think everyone should be offered one, or if not that a PICC line, as chemo is very tough on your veins and there's greater risk of leakage. Do you have "good" veins or rubbish ones? You can tell by how easy it is for them to find a vein to take blood. If they're rubbish, that's all the more reason to opt for a port/PICC. As someone else said, in the UK it seems to vary between NHS trusts but if you're offered either I'd recommend taking it.  To me the port is the rolls-royce option as it's inserted under the skin so you can go about your life without worrying - showers, baths, exercise etc etc, and they only access it when needed for chemo or to take blood. They usually insert the port just above the breast on the good side so you'd have a small scar there, although I've also seen them placed under the breast where a scar is less obvious. Mind you, I had mine removed about 6 months ago and the scar has virtually disappeared. The PICC line is also good but does dangle outside your body so there are some restrictions such as needing to wear a waterproof sleeve when showering. Some ladies have complained about bits digging into your arm but I think that can be sorted with it being taped down adequately.  Best of luck
Posts.Title: Cannula vs PICC vs Port??

Posts.Content: Hi Nanajanet From comments I've seen on here, whether or not you get offered a PICC line, Hickman or portacath seems to vary from place to place, even within the UK.  I'd suggest you do a bit of research on the options then ask your oncologist. You might need to be a bit assertive about it lol. Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: I think the most important thing is to avoid lifting or putting any other strain on that part of your body. That means no lugging of groceries. Perhaps you could get someone to shop for you or with you and lift the bags in and out of the car. Also don't stretch up too much (as in putting things on high shelves). You probably won't feel much like cooking either - I didn't for about a week so hubby did it.  I don't know if it's the same in the UK, but here in Australia they keep you in hospital extra time if you live alone - they like someone to be with you for at least 24 hours.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Post-Op care

Posts.Content: Hi Poohbear44 I totally sympathise, having been overweight most of my adult life. I'm taking anastrozole rather than tamoxifen but they have the same outcome, reduction of oestrogen, so have the same weight effects.  I lost 38kg (about 5 stone) during and shortly after chemo as I was very ill (the only positive side effect as far as I'm concerned). I have managed to keep it off so far but only by being very vigilant and not indulging much at all. Haven't managed to lose any more though grrr. The only way I've been able to hold my weight is by cutting down to 2 meals a day - breakfast about 10 am and then dinner about 6pm. This works for me as I'm retired and also my husband has always liked an early dinner. That used to drive me mad as I was more used to eating at 7.30 or 8 pm but is perfect now. I make sure I have a high protein breakfast and only a small amount of carbs eg 1 slice of toast or some baked beans. Dinner is meat and veg in various forms with loads of non-starchy veggies (ie no potato, few peas and so on) and no carbs. I have also stopped drinking alcohol for other reasons but I'm sure that helps. I do use butter, full fat yogurt, coconut cream and so on so it's not too Spartan. Occasionally I have fish but I don't really like it that much and I allow myself a treat once a fortnight. Treat might be hot chips, roast potatoes or cake.  It's pretty strict, although my cooking has become very creative. I'm spurred on though by having been told by my onco that fat produces oestrogen so losing weight (or at least not gaining) has an anti-cancer effect. That's enough to motivate me. Wishing you all the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Weight gain with Tamixifen

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah. Axillary nodes are in clusters going down towards your arm. Think little bunches of  grapes. Some people have had only the first (of three) levels removed. That might be an option for you to consider. The benefit is that you have some lymph nodes left, so the risk of lymphoedema is reduced. Suggest you ask your team about the possibility before agreeing to go ahead with full clearance.
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Ah seromas, the bane of my life! I have had a seroma since March last year, following a full mastectomy with no reconstruction. Initially it was tight and painful and I had it drained several times. Each time it came back quite quickly ie within a day or two. The last time I had it drained was just after Christmas and it seems to have stopped increasing and isn't at all painful. When I had my routine followup with my surgeon a couple of weeks ago, she said she would prefer to leave it as long as it's not causing discomfort as the pressure within the seroma stops further fluid leaking from the tissues, giving them a chance to heal properly. When healed the fluid will gradually dissipate.  So what have I learned? Firstly, while seromas can be caused by vigorous exercise, exercise doesn't seem to make much difference. I have continued with the arm/shoulder exercises as I wanted total movement in my shoulder and no cording. I have that. Secondly, I was told that compression wouldn't help. I did have fluid in my reconstructed breast before the mastectomy and had all sorts of physio, compression and massage but nothing helped.  I'm sorry but I don't have a magic solution. Mine is unusually long lived as they mostly disappear within weeks. Let's hope yours is one of those.  In summary, I'd say if you aren't in any discomfort then carry on as normal but at the first sign of any pain, redness or further swelling contact your medical team.  Best
Posts.Title: Seroma advice please

Posts.Content: I've always been exercise averse but started using a stationary bike (sounds so much better than exercise bike) for rehab purposes when I was halfway through chemo. That was about this time in 2015. I'm still using it regularly, have no problems and am definitely fitter than I've ever been. Still hate it though lol.
Posts.Title: Axillary Node Clearence

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona. I finished my chemo at the end of January so I'm slightly ahead of you. I think I really started to feel well at about the end of March so you were probably beaten down by your cold. I have slightly more hair than you - but I'm still sporting the Judi Dench look. In fact it was a very popular hairstyle at the radiotherapy clinic! I had several conversations, all good natured, about hair re-growth but remained satisfied that mine was above average. There was one poor woman whose hair was about 6 or 7 cm long. Trouble is she only had one hair every half cm or so. She was very upset - there's always someone worse off! I lost 33 kg (about 3 stone) during chemo cos I was fairly ill. Mind you I had plenty of reserves. When I had my radio planning, they told me not to lose any more while I was having radio so I managed to make sure I didn't with the help of donuts and hot chips lol. Have to stop eating them now! I've finished radio but my breast area is still red with a couple of sore spots. Not too bad but it doesn't yet really feel like my treatment is finished. I used the R1 and R2 creams and think that they were pretty effective. My radio-oncologist said my skin was in really good condition for someone so fair-skinned. (I never told them what I was using as I didn't want to be told not to).  Anyway, apart from the slight discomfort, I'm getting my life back to normal and enjoying every minute of it.  Radio is a pain because of the need to go every day but it doesn't hurt and those few weeks will pass quite quickly for you. Continue to be kind to yourself and thank you for your cheerful presence here. Wishing you all the best  Lynn
Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: DL - you could try massaging the cord and please keep doing the exercises you were given. If the cord hasn't loosened by the time everyone's back working from the Christmas break, I'd suggest you contact your BCN as she should be able to arrange physio for you. Physios can usually deal with cording very swiftly. Merry Christmas

Posts.Content: Excellent idea Fiona but make sure you buy fun and funky tops to reflect the new you. Nothing frumpy allowed. You shouldn't feel at all guilty - it's all a part of who you are and what's been happening to you.  I just polished off a box of 8 gourmet truffles I was given - now that's guilt! xxx

Posts.Content: Too funny ronstar I'm afraid it's too close to bedtime for me to have any ideas. I'll dream on it.
Posts.Title: What do you call yours?

Posts.Content: Hi boneyem1 I feel for you. You're not stupid, just scared. We all have some fear that the cancer will return, and I suspect that fear never goes away completely. All we do is try to keep it under control as best we can and live a normal life as far as possible. Remember that tamoxifen is very effective in keeping cancer away.  As others have said, mastectomy is no guarantee that it won't come back. Even around the breast area, it's possible for cancer to recur on the chest wall, not to mention spread to other parts of your body.  I agree that it might be wise to seek some counselling. After all, right now you're a healthy woman and counselling may help you to accept and understand that and get on with enjoying life.  Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Thinking of breast removal

Posts.Content: I agree. The portacath is definitely the rolls-royce. I still have mine as I'm having herceptin by infusion. It has been brilliant and not a moment's trouble. It sits like a little drum about the size of a pound coin just under my skin on my chest area (good side). It's accessed whenever needed with a needle. 10 seconds of discomfort when it goes in (although I believe some places will even give you a local for that) and then they can give or take whatever necessary. You can shower, swim, whatever cos there's nothing sticking out and it only needs to be flushed every 6-8 weeks if it's not being used. If that's not on offer then a PICC or Hickman is better than using cannulas in your arm.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: I took all my hats (which I never wore anyway) to the chemo unit. They have a big box of them there for people to pick from. It's a lovely direct way of helping.  I threw out the clothes I wore at home when I was having chemo - tights, track bottoms, sweatshirts, T shirts - because they reminded me of being ill. This was a significant move for a hoarder lol.
Posts.Title: Squeezing some good out of this nasty disease

Posts.Content: Hi Pam squajygirl Congratulations. You are an inspiration. You must've been one of the early beneficiaries of tamoxifen!  Why not try the exercises we are given? They're very gentle and do loosen up your whole shoulder area. I''m 17 months down the track from 1st surgery and I still do them twice a day. If I don't, I find my shoulder starts stiffening quite quickly. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Weight gain with Tamixifen

Posts.Content: Hi Doglady I had a pretty rough time with AC chemo and ended up in hospital with atrial fibrillation and pulmonary embolisms. Not nice but it's very rare I was told. Apart from that I had shocking fatigue but little nausea. The UTIs I got later when I was on paclitaxel. It's important to remember that however vile, chemo actually works! If I had my time over I would do it all again, just perhaps be a bit more assertive about being breathless. Keep ploughing on Doglady, you'll get there. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Hi Paddypup. I'm sorry to hear about your daughter's diagnosis. It sounds like you're very worried about her. She's lucky to have such a supportive mother. Firstly can I just say that the only silly question is the one you don't ask. None of us know it all (and the docs don't either for that matter) so asking anything is fine. No one will judge you here.  As for inserting a marker. From what little I know about it, I think most surgeons can spot different kinds of tissue and tell cancerous tissue from normal tissue. For example, a work colleague of my hubby went for a delayed reconstruction. During the surgery, the surgeon spotted a small (3mm) cancer recurrence. He did of course remove it. She considers herself very lucky that it was found very early.  It's uncommon but not unknown for tumours to have different characteristics. In very general terms it means there are separate cancers, rather than branches of the same one. They offer all the treatments that might help get rid of any of the tumours so if one is HER2+ and one is HER2- then Herceptin will be offered. Similarly, if one is hormone positive then hormone treatment is likely to be offered.
Posts.Title: Overthinking - random questions

Posts.Content: Hi Kirsteen78 Sounds like you're having a bit of a hard time there! I agree that it looks like you're being drip fed information, which is hard to handle. Adjuvant therapy just means therapy (mostly chemo) after surgery, as opposed to neo-adjuvant therapy, which is chemo prior to surgery. The majority of people have their surgery first so have adjuvant therapy, so it's not clear what you're being asked to participate in.  I hope I'm not telling you how to suck eggs but I thought I'd lay out the basics so you can think about what to ask.  Firstly, the pathology. The key points are whether your cancer was oestrogen and/or progesterone positive or negative and whether it was HER2 positive or negative. If it was HER2 positive then you will definitely need to have chemo as the HER2 targeted drugs (Herceptin and Pertuzumab) are only given in combination with traditional chemo. If you are negative for all three, most likely you will have chemo as that's the only real treatment available for triple negative BC. Not everybody that is hormone positive has chemo - the doctors look at the expected benefit to you, other aspects of the cancer and the level of node involvement. Often you will be offered what's called the oncotype test which makes an assessment of the chances of cancer recurring. Obviously I can't say which way your doctors are likely to go, although node involvement makes chemo more likely.  Secondly, node involvement. It would be unusual to leave nodes if there are strong signs of spread so it's not clear what's going on. Perhaps they intend to offer you further surgery to remove more or all of your lymph nodes or maybe there were only  a few stray cancer cells, in which case they may offer radiotherapy in the axilla (armpit) area. I'm just speculating really.  You are also likely to be offered radiotherapy of the breast area and possibly the axilla and the supra-clavicular fossa (near the collar bone). Radio is an effective way of killing off stray cancer cells in the area around your breast and seems to be offered to the majority of people with anything more than the earliest stage BC. Most people also have a CT scan of their head to pelvis area to check for spread and to make sure there's nothing undiagnosed that might affect your treatment. A lot of people are given a bone scan too. These scans don't mean that the docs think that the cancer has spread, more that they want to confirm that it hasn't.  As you can see there's quite a lot you need to clarify before your treatment.  I'd suggest you compile a list of all the questions to ask your onco/surgeon (whoever you see next) and make it clear that you want the full story. One thing I've learned through this whole BC experience is that you need to be an assertive patient and make sure you're satisfied and comfortable with everything that's happening to you. You might also want to think about taking someone with you to the appointment to make notes or recording the conversation (with permission of course). I guarantee you won't remember everything you're told without some kind of aide memoire. This is a worrying and uncertain time for you no doubt but as things become clearer and your treatment plan is organised, it will settle and soon you'll be on the way to the other end. Always remember BC is very treatable. Best wishes for your journey and do keep coming back to this forum. People here are really kind, supportive and knowledgeable.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Pathology results

Posts.Content: Hi Sally Lou. I've nothing really to add to the other posts but just wanted to give you a virtual hug. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Lovely post Heather. You must feel such relief - I can't wait. 20 months seems like ages to be a professional patient (cos that's what we all are). I'm expecting to be done in half that time!  Hope all continues to go well for you.
Posts.Title: Four weeks post radiation and my thoughts

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass Rather than worrying about what they want, think about what you want out of the appointment. Seems to me that you have a great opportunity to go in on the front foot and control the conversation. Be assertive. Perhaps start out by saying 'my current issues are ..." . As we tell the newbies, make some notes, ask the questions, and so on.  I haven't had to change hospitals but my medical oncologist, surgeon and radio oncologist do operate out of different practices. They do seem to want to do their own examinations and come to their own conclusions on everything. They were all trying to see me every 3 months until I jacked up and got the surgeon and the medical onco to agree to alternate 3 month appointments. This is a roundabout way of saying they might want to re-scan you. I think it's perfectly reasonably for you to say no, even if only on the basis of additional unnecessary radiation.  Hope it all goes well and you can form a good relationship with this team.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Appointment at New Hospital...

Posts.Content: I'm still doing Herceptin but finished the other chemo at end Jan. I get my bloods done with the Herceptin. Both my GP and onco said that it can take up to 12 months to normalise and both are monitoring me. I usually end up seeing the GP once a month and the onco every 6 weeks. Surgeon and radio-oncologist both do 6 monthly follow-ups.
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: I have my bloods done through the portacath but one nurse did tell me "some will give blood and some won't". I've had no trouble. Good luck Dee KiwiCardi
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Sounds good Wiggins218 It's true that an MRI might show something that the mammo and ultrasound don't but it might not.  Best
Posts.Title: Had my breast clinic appointment today

Posts.Content: Hi Always Baking  If one doesn't get you, the other will lol. I don't want to be a doomsayer but do try to keep moving. If you can't get up and walk around, at least do some of those aeroplane exercises to keep your blood moving and do drink loads of water. There's a risk of clots if you don't and believe me that's no fun at all! Apart from that, paradoxically, gentle exercise makes you feel better.  As for something under your bottom. I have a fleece electric blanket which is wonderful - both soft and warm. Or possibly a sheepskin, either real or fake. They're used a lot for bedridden people here so they don't get bedsores. Here in Australia IKEA have quite nice fake ones for less than 20 pounds equivalent. But make sure you get a long haired one not a curly one.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Advise re being more comfortable propped up in bed !

Posts.Content: Hi Peartree I hate to admit it but I'm pretty certain it was exercise that got me back to normal. I do 20 mins daily interval riding on the exercise bike. I have forced myself to do it even if I don't want to (and I never do lol) and it really has helped. My energy levels are pretty much back to normal and I'm probably fitter than I was 15 years ago. It took me a while to work up to 20 mins and I started at 2 mins on the easiest level but I've reached the optimum now.  I finished chemo end Jan and radio mid May. Very fatigued right up to about mid-June but have really come good in the last few weeks. Good luck Lynn xxz
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Hannah. I was out and proud the entire time I had no hair (about 8 months in the end). I knew I wouldn't be able to cope with a wig so bought a whole bunch of hats and scarves, plus had some given to me by a friend who's been through the same thing. Didn't like them either so I went out bald. I just wore a beanie a couple of times when it was really cold.  I never felt that people stared and certainly no one made any comments. I got really good service in cafes and restaurants and people were generally very kind. I know it's not for everyone but it worked for me.  My hair is now growing back and I'm rocking the Judi Dench look. Trouble is I'd like to keep it that way lol. Best of luck with whatever you decide. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Rage at the Wigs!

Posts.Content: Wow what an interesting thread - so many sub-threads going on.  On whether or not to have chemo ... As Carolyn28 said, I do have a different view to her. I will do anything to reduce the risk of cancer coming back and I'll take all those little percentage gains - they all add up in the end. As a result, I've had surgery, chemo, radio, herceptin, denusomab and anastrozole so far and will take anything further that the oncologist offers. I should also say that chemo knocked me around pretty badly - I got quite ill - but given my time over, I'd do exactly the same again. On husbands ... my husband has been great but I know how hard it has been for him. He has said things like "can you imagine how hard it is watching the one you love suffer so much and know there's nothing you can do" and "I feel completely useless and on the outside". I'm a pretty independent person and throughout have kept trying to do as much as I can but when he said these things, it made me re-think. People on the outside do feel useless and do genuinely want to help/ease the burden for you. I decided to make sure that I did ask for help and make him feel involved as much as I could. There were plenty of things I struggled with, mostly involving strength tasks so I got him changing the sheets, taking out the rubbish, vacuuming etc, as well as driving me to chemo and other appointments where parking was crap. Also, as he's a bit of a science nerd, I put him in charge of research - he loves reading all those scientific papers about some new drug or the benefits of weekly vs 3 weekly taxanes. Each to his own lol. The same would apply to adult or almost-adult children - let them in and let them help. It will make them feel better in themselves, make life easier for you and hopefully bring you all closer. Wishing everybody the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Hi puzzler - alendronic acid is one of the biphosphonates so everyone is right! Looks like you're already getting the advantage!
Posts.Title: biphosphonates

Posts.Content: For all you ladies who're having to wait months for a dexa scan, it might be worth considering taking a calcium/D3 supplement. I have been told to take it even though my bones are fine atm, because of the risk. Apparently it's harder to improve your bone density than it is to maintain it.  I take tablets with 250mg calcium equivalent plus vitamin D3 (which aids calcium absorption) - 1 tablet twice a day. NB I haven't done a lot of research on it because it seems pretty harmless for me.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: That's exactly how I feel Lainy r. I don't think calcium supplements are harmful. They are available over the counter here in Oz but I'm not sure about the UK. I got a very big bottle for a very cheap price in Costco (just like everything in Costco lol). Just checked - looks like Holland and Barrett sell them in the UK online. Best Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hi lililou72 It's what we all dread isn't it? I can completely understand you having a moment! However, you know as well as I do that it's better to know and get it dealt with. Sounds like your consultant is being very thorough, which is great.  Please try to park the worrying. No amount of worrying will change the outcome.  Hope it all turns out well for you

More about deciding how best to treat that rather than the yes/no of primary.  Are you coming up for your 5 years? I'm turn 4 in May. No matter, I'd still love to see you - it'll be 4.5 years by the time it warms up again here at the end of the year. xxxx
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Yes of course Carolyn28 Try hard xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: A 9-12 month wait is outrageous. I was p*ssed that I had to wait a week. Just sayin' Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Well Loulou99 , you're ahead of the pack already as you've had a portacath fitted. They make chemo so much easier than having chemo by cannula in your hand. I had a port for 18 months and had no problems with it at all.  I didn't do the cold cap but I understand the most important thing is to make sure it fits tight all over your head. lynnwad cold capped very successfully so I've tagged her in case she's around to offer you any tips.  I think the most important thing is to be kind to yourself. Rest when you need to, exercise as much as you can as it really does help and drink at least 2 litres of water every day. I actually did 3 litres in the 24 hours following treatment to flush it round and out.  I didn't have much trouble with nausea but I did find it was better if I had something in my stomach. I used to carry a little pack of ritz type biscuits around in my handbag, and had them by my bed, as nibbling one or two really settled my stomach.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Fidst chemo session tomorrow

Posts.Content: Linkj - How can you possibly be a wimp when you're still receiving treatment!!!!! Herceptin isn't as fierce as the old fashioned chemo but it still takes a toll on your body. I thought I'd sort of recovered a couple of months after finishing T but about a month after finishing H I got a huge rise in my energy levels and really started to feel well. It was at that point that I fully appreciated how much H had been knocking me around. Not enough to say I was ill, but definitely a bit crap. Also, my onco told me to expect to get bouts of fatigue for up to 2 years after finishing all treatment. I actually finished in Sept 16 and, while I'm ok most of the time, I do hit that brick wall of fatigue if I overdo it or get dehydrated or don't sleep well.  Stay strong - you'll get there.
Posts.Title: You must be nearly better now!!! What a whimp!

Posts.Content: I don't have biphosphonates but I do have Denusomab injections which do the same job. I've only had one so far but didn't notice any side effects at all. I'll take anything on offer to reduce the risk of recurrence. Best wishes Lynn xx
Posts.Title: biphosphonates

Posts.Content: Carolyn28 and I have always been on different sides of the chemo argument. My view is throw everything you can at the nasty beast to maximise your chances of it not coming back. 8% uplift is pretty good I think. Also ask yourself how you would feel if you don't have chemo and it comes back.  I had chemo and had a terrible time (check my profile if you're interested) but despite that, I'd make the same decision again. But really it's an individual thing, even though the decision may be difficult. Some people do sail through and don't have a hard time like I did.  Best of luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: There's a really interesting article on HER2 and herceptin at http://www.cancer.gov/research/progress/discovery/HER2 And now I'll stop harassing you lol.
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: Good outcome for you Pollydog. you must be relieved. Radiotherapy is a doddle by comparison. Best of luck
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Great news simba4me - you must be so pleased. As for letrozole, many of us are on that or one of the other hormone reducing drugs. Some people have few side effects, some have lots and most of us are somewhere in the middle. Try searching the group for letrozole or aromatase inhibitor and you'll find lots of threads. Have a read and then come back and someone will be able to answer any questions you may have. Radiotherapy isn't too bad for most people. We have a monthly radiotherapy club for you to chat to people going through it at the same time and perhaps pick up some useful tips.  Best
Posts.Title: My results so pleased

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona. In response to your latest post ... Scans and mets - my onco told me that mets are never symptom-free (pain, cough, breathless, headache, tummy ache depending on where they pop up) so the best way of detecting mets is the patient themselves. His view is that scans are pointless cos they are taken at a single point in time and don't deal with the year or so in between. For my annual review, however, I did get both a mammo on my good breast and an ultrasound of that and the chest area where I had a mastectomy - these to check for local recurrence. All this means that we all need to be vigilant about any changes in our bodies and get it checked asap.  As for the aching. I have it too but I am on AIs. However, both my onco and my GP have told me that it can take up to a year from finishing chemo to completely recover. So early days yet for you. Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi George. Yep I'm perfectly happy with infusion of herceptin. It only takes 30 mins and I get tea and cheese and biccies! Not even enough time to get my knitting out. I usually feel a bit cr*p afterwards so go home and drink a litre of water then have a nanna nap for an hour. By then I'm absolutely fine and ready to go. I don't even have a runny nose lol. Thanks for asking Lynn
Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: I won't bore you with the story but there was a question as to whether I should have surgery before or after radio. My surgeon was absolutely insistent that I have the op before radio. She says that wounds don't heal as well afterwards and she doesn't like to operate for at least 12 months after radiotherapy, unless it's an emergency of course.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy before mastectomy ?

Posts.Content: cycling_girl You can,t have an implant if you are having radiotherapy.  Not quite accurate. You can have an implant, the issue is that radiotherapy increases the risk of capsular contracture (ie the implant capsule hardening necessitating removal). Some people choose not to take that risk.
Posts.Title: DIEP flap or Implants... How to choose?

Posts.Content: Hi wynne. Keep nagging the docs about the breathlessness!!!!!!!!! I had breathlessness during chemo and kept mentioning it only to be told it was a SE and just to take it easy. Turned out I had pulmonary embolisms, fortunately picked up by my wonderful GP (not any of the experts at the hospital lol). He basically saved my life. Leg pain can of course possibly mean a clot, even without much swelling.  I have had 7 months worth of Herceptin and have had no SEs, apart from feeling a bit cr*p afterwards and that's easily fixed with a nanna nap. However, I do have it by infusion which I understand is easier on the body. Best of luck and make sure you get to the bottom of the breathlessness thingy. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: biphosphonates

Posts.Content: PS Just as an example, the sister of my partner's colleague visited here from Bangladesh. She had been treated there but the family decided to get a second opinion in Australia. The onco here said she'd received exactly the treatment he would have ordered. A world-wide practice!!!
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: I'm in Australia and have had a slightly different experience to the UK ladies. Here they tend to go for surgery first, unless the tumour is close to the chest wall (which makes surgery more difficult, leaves a greater disfigurement and isn't always as successful). I was happy to have surgery first as I just wanted the thing gone.  I am HER2+ and have had both chemo and herceptin. Actually I'll go for anything that makes the prognosis better.  I have found that oncologists here are just as competent as anywhere else - it's a world wide practice and they all seem to be in touch with colleagues overseas and also read the scholarly journals.  If your s-i-l feels the need for a second opinion, I think you don't need to look beyond Canada at this stage. Her cancer isn't so rare that it's only handled in the top 3 places in the world. The most important thing is for your s-i-l to have confidence in whoever is treating her as she'll have a long-term relationship with that doctor.
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: Sorry but no. I think I've had the standard BC chemo treatment. 4 fortnightly doses of AC and then 12 weekly doses of paclitaxel. All to be followed by continuing herceptin for a year (started that when I started the paclitaxel). Unfortunately it seems the effectiveness is reduced if you have fewer treatments.
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: My hubby was the same, to the point of driving me mad over it. The most useful steps we've taken are: 1 have bottles of the alcohol hand cleanser around the place - especially for the kids 2 clean your kitchen work bench before you start cooking  3 follow the so-called pregnancy diet - no shellfish, no blue or soft cheese, no food that's been sitting around eg in a deli.  4 Use the dishwasher if you have one. If not, make sure you dry the washing up straight away. It's actually not that difficult - I'm 5 months along and have had no problems at all. Good luck with it!!!
Posts.Title: Risk of infection

Posts.Content: I should also share that my cancer was hormone negative and HER 2 positive. My oncologist says this is a particularly nasty aggressive form of BC, hence the intense chemo. I am grateful that I was HER 2 positive so I can have Herceptin, although I'm led to believe that Herceptin is most effective in conjunction with a taxane (hence the paclitaxel). I do hope your s-i-l works it all out and finds a recipe that suits her - every journey is different but none is pleasant. My good wishes to her.
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: Yes I found water started tasting awful so I switched to very weak Ribena. That actually tasted quite good.  Ginger tea is good too for nausea and doesn't have any calories lol. Just slice some root ginger and steep it in boiling water. I used to do big batches and then microwave a cupful when I wanted it. Tastes good. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Fidst chemo session tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea. I found that if I woke in the night I'd feel nauseous. I ended up having a few savoury biscuits by the bed (Ritz style) and nibbling on a couple. I then took another maxillon and was fine for the rest of the night.
Posts.Title: Controlling nausea overnight

Posts.Content: I used bicarb mouthwash all the way through chemo and found that did a lot to clear the bad mouth taste. I didn't eat a lot and just about lived on tomato soup, scrambled egg, grapes, cherry tomatoes and freshly squeezed orange juice. The acid tastes were great for me although others have said they couldn't bear them. Water tasted pretty awful but I found weak Ribena ok and also lemon squeezed in to the water.  I was told not to eat my favourite foods as it could ruin them for you for ever. I did try baked beans once but they weren't very nice so avoided them after that. Now I'm back to that particular addiction lol. Overall I think it's just trial and error really.  Best of luck  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi. I thought radio was a breeze compared to chemo. I had 50 Gray in 25 sessions (5 weeks), which is standard here in Australia.  I used the R1 and R2 creams, which were absolutely fantastic for me. My skin reddened (like a mild sunburn) and I ended up with one small spot (about the size of a pound coin) where the skin broke down. However, I was given silicon dressings (Mepilex) which stick without any adhesive and peel off without any sticking or pain. Kept that area covered for a few days and it was fine. The redness disappeared about a week after I'd finished.  The only advice I'd give is to wear a bra as little as you possibly can to avoid rubbing and wear old cotton Tshirts or shirts next to your skin. The more you can avoid any irritation, the better your skin will be.  I thought it was going to be a real pain having to go every day for so long (ruin my social life and all that) but it went very quickly. I did find I was tired afterwards but a nanna nap sorted that out. Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Rads - Panic?

Posts.Content: As long as you feel comfortable with your decision Sophie. That's the main thing. We'll all be here to support you and offer gratuitous advice about anything. Please don't hesitate to ask.
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz I used the R1 and R2 creams, which I had to order online as they're not available in Australia. I don't regret spending the money at all - they were fabulous. They didn't arrive till a week after I'd started radio by which time my skin was already reddening. There was an immediate improvement once I started the R1/R2.  I used to apply the R1 cream in the change room after treatment and then go home without a bra (loose tops all round lol) ie I didn't sit around for 20 mins waiting. I don't think it's necessary. I'd then put the R2 on once I got home, then again at night.  Karen is absolutely right - you need to have your treatment with absolutely nothing on your skin. This is particularly to ensure that there are no metals like zinc or aluminium hanging around. We were recommended to use Dove ultra sensitive soap - horrid greasy stuff but it worked. Make sure you have no deodorant or perfume either. A friend of mine, who couldn't stand that, used to spray perfume on her top; I didn't bother.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: I should also have mentioned that the worst part is clothing rubbing against the treated area. I wore old loose cotton Tshirts next to my skin which seemed to do the trick. Also, I finished mid-May and there is now nothing to show I had radio - my scar is just a thin white line and my skin has gone back to its normal pale colour. I still occasionally rub some R2 on the area, mainly to keep the skin soft and supple. I guess I'll do that until it runs out. L
Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Are you going to have radiotherapy? I had a skin saving mastectomy and then implant but have now been told by the radiooncologist that there is a 50% chance of "capsular contracture" which leads to implant failure. Also because the skin becomes less supple with radiotherapy, it's unlikely they can replace the implant. I would have made a different choice had i known. Chicken fillet is sounding good right now lol.
Posts.Title: DIEP flap or Implants... How to choose?

Posts.Content: I'm very happy with the implant, although I have some lymphoedema in the breast. That relates to the fact that I had 30 lymph nodes removed ie nothing to do with the implant itself.  I'm unlikely to need further surgery. However I'm 62. I believe some people need implants replaced eventually. The only other point I'd add is that you should look up 'capsular contracture' as this can happen to anyone.
Posts.Title: DIEP flap or Implants... How to choose?

Posts.Content: Hi again Pollydog Just a couple of things. Firstly - taste. I had no taste, or at least altered taste, and no appetite during chemo. They say (who's they?) not to eat your favourite food during chemo as it might put you off it for life. Anyway I survived on scrambled egg, canned tomato soup, grapes, cherry tomatoes and fresh orange juice. The last three tasted really good, better than they do normally, and the other two I ate because I had to eat something. My taste normalised pretty quickly after chemo. The only problem was that it took me a while to get used to chili again so hubby was always moaning about mild curries. Solved that problem by making some chili pickle for him. He's now addicted lol. Secondly, Macmillan has some really helpful financial advisers who support people through financial problems during treatment. You might like to call them on the number at the bottom of the page.  Best of luck
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: I too was below par for a few years. I had a busy stressful job for most of them, my husband had mental health issues and my brother killed himself so I put it my feeling not quite well down to all that. Mostly, I had a constant feeling that a health "train wreck" was coming. I thought it was going to be a heart attack as heart disease runs in both sides of my family. Nevertheless I didn't feel ill enough to actually go to a doctor and only went when I found the lump. Ironically, my heart is strong, as my cardiologist says.  Also, despite the rigours of treatment and what happened to me, once I'd recovered and since I feel much healthier than I did before I was diagnosed.
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Hi 4paws So sorry to hear you're suffering with docetaxel (and it will be that as H is relatively easy on you). I had the weekly paclitaxel and had similar side effects, but possibly at a lower level. I wasn't nauseous either but I'm not one to throw up ever. Most food tasted foul. I lived on cherry tomatoes, grapes, fresh orange juice, tinned tomato soup and scrambled egg. Couldn't take anything else. Even water was tough so I used to squeeze lemon or orange into it and eventually found weak Ribena was ok.  I was given a bicarb mouthwash by my chemo unit. It worked really well on the bad mouth taste. There are plenty of recipes on the Internet - 1/2 tsp bicarb in a cup of water is the simplest. I found that using the mouth wash just before I ate really helped. You might also find an anti-histamine helps with the pains - suggest you discuss that with your oncologist. I used clarytine as that was given to me as a premed before each dose. As for Herceptin, the main side effect I had was the drippy nose, where suddenly water just pours out of your nose with no real warning. I used more tissues in that 12 months than in the rest of my life! Stay strong - you're nearly at the end. Best
Posts.Title: Docetaxel & Herceptin side affects

Posts.Content: Yes it can be upsetting Karin. Trouble is that as a society we don't deal well with critical illnesses like cancer and people often don't know what to say or how to react. This means that instead of saying 'that's crap, but how can I help' or something like that, they pussyfoot around or say inappropriate things. Even worse are those who you though were your friends who conveniently disappear. On the plus side, you will find that the vast majority of people are incredibly helpful and supportive and that some people who you thought were just acquaintances turn out to be real friends. So don't dismiss people too early for saying the wrong thing. On the other hand, if people are messing with your head then drop them like hot potatoes - you need to be able to focus on getting well, not on dealing with other people's issues. Don't worry it will become very clear who the good people are! I was very blessed with half a dozen incredibly supportive friends who helped both me and my husband physically and mentally. Wishing you all the very best. Make sure you keep coming back to this forum - it's invaluable. Hugs  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Hi im newly diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, scared and looking...

Posts.Content: I had a portacath fitted, which I believe is the rolls royce but I think you should grab anything that's on offer to avoid cannulas in your veins. I've seen enough poor people with vein problems from chemo to now believe that everyone should be offered a PICC, Hickman or portacath. I was given a portacath because here in Australia we still get herceptin by infusion (not the case in the UK I think) so I'm committed to infusions for a year! The benefits of a portacath ahead of the others are that it's completely under the skin and it only needs to be flushed every 6 - 8 weeks so flushing only becomes an issue if you decide to keep it after chemo is finished. The downside is that there's quite a sharp pain each time they need to access the port - but it's momentary. Anyway, if a PICC line is what's on offer for you, you should take it to save your veins. Best wishes for your treatment Lynn xx
Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: I was told by the chemo nurse who did my chemo education that I should get a digital thermometer and use it in my mouth, keeping my mouth closed during the reading. I was also told not to take my temp straight after hot food/drink or a cold drink.
Posts.Title: Which thermometer? Ear, mouth or forehead?

Posts.Content: Hi Karakeys. I understand where you're at. I had more scans and tests in the first month than I've had in my entire life. It's a bewildering new world with info being pushed at you, terms you don't understand and umpteen doctors, nurses, technicians. I've never really been ill before getting BC so it was very hard at first. Things do become clearer once you have the full details of your diagnosis and have a treatment plan. You do settle into a routine - mostly being a professional patient! A lot of people take someone with them to their appointments, for emotional support and also to listen, as you never remember everything you're told. I preferred not to, but I did take a notebook and wrote everything down so I could think about it later, or look up terms I didn't understand. I also made a note of questions as they came to me, which I could then ask the oncologist when I saw him. Sure as anything, you'll forget your questions during your actual appointments. If you're having surgery first, is there someone who you could stay with, or could stay with you? They won't let you out of hospital early if you're going home to an empty house but if there's someone there you'll be in overnight only, unless there are problems of course. If you have stage 1 - 3 cancer, then the surgery is to get rid of it. Chemo and radio and other treatments are to stop it coming back.  Chemo justifiably has a bad rep. It's not nice but you will get through it. Not everyone gets terrible side effects and the chemo unit will have loads of drugs etc to help with them. People on here will have plenty of advice and assistance too.   Anyway welcome to the club. Sorry you're here but we are a friendly bunch so don't be shy in asking questions or just ranting or having a moan. We all understand and have been there one way or another. Big hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Hi im newly diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, scared and looking...

Posts.Content: Wow that's great news Angie. You must both be so pleased.  As for tamoxifen... I don't take that but it does a similar job to the drug I take ie strip oestrogen from the body. I'm not sure of the consequences for men but I know for women it often results in stiff and painful joints, as well as menopausal symptoms. I had a bit of a look and the main side effects for men seem to be headaches, nausea, hot flushes, skin rash, fatigue, sexual dysfunction, and weight and mood changes. Sounds dreadful doesn't it but I've not found mine that bad and many people manage to persevere with it. There seems to be quite a bit of info on US sites and it's pretty easy to tell which are the reliable ones - breastcare.org and cancercare.org are both fine. One tip: despite what doctors say, many of us have found that your body reacts differently to different brands of drugs. It's not the active ingredient but the fillers that are used. So if your husband finds it heavy going then it's worth trying a different brand for a couple of months to see if it makes any difference. It does for me! And finally, I hope they've taken him off the Dutasteride. Has he asked about the consequences for his prostate with tamoxifen? Hope you're going to celebrate! Best
Posts.Title: Decisions to make, all so overwhelming

Posts.Content: Yes, amongst everything else! I started on letrozole but was terribly achy so switched to anastrozole. Better, but still some aches and the headache and feeling a bit below par all the time. However, a couple of months ago, I got my pharmacist to give me the original Arimidex. Aches etc disappeared within a couple of days and I'm travelling well now. Moral of the story, if it continues try swapping brands. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Anastrozole - side effects

Posts.Content: Cramps? I had terrible cramps until I started taking a magnesium supplement. My Mg level was actually measured in one of the many thousand blood tests and I was found to be deficient. My onco suggested the supplement.
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: It never ceases to amaze me just how mean people can be. If I were you, I'd drop her from my life right now and (as I just said elsewhere in a different context) don't waste a moment's emotional energy on her. Don't bother to engage with her, don't try to explain - something like that can never be unsaid and she doesn't deserve anything from you. If she ever makes contact just say no thanks. Big hugs from me too.
Posts.Title: Really bloody angry !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jillyp1210 I'm sorry to tell you that "gut issues" (diarrhea, constipation, reflux, indigestion) may continue for a while. Like our hair and nails, the cells that line the GI tract are the fast growing ones that get knocked out by chemo and the bacteria that populate our GI tract also suffer. It takes a while for everything to settle back down so when your hair's back, then your gut should be ok. Mine took about 8 months to really settle down. I didn't use the wine remedy but at one point I did take a course of probiotics, which seemed to help. Best
Posts.Title: Digestive issues

Posts.Content: Hi iwannaliveforever. My portacath scar is just over 1 cm long, crescent moon shaped and barely visible. I have seen some people have their port inserted around their midriff area ie under their good boob. One young woman told me her surgeon put it there so it wouldnt show. Just a thought ...
Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: I'm not surprised he was exhausted! One chap on here calls BC treatment the Hotel California, as it never seems to stop. I prefer to think of it as a medical roundabout that you can't get off once your on. I too have other issues and forever seem to be going to the doctors. I was diagnosed 2 years ago but before that I hadn't been to a doctor in 20 years. I wasn't actually sure where to go when I found the lump lol, and had to settle for a walk-in clinic (or doctor factory as we call them here). I must've been blessed though that day as I got the most wonderful Irish GP, who fled the GFC and is now practising here in Australia permanently. Good luck with the tamoxifen issue. I don't think there's a clear answer for him but I know I'd make sure I'd checked out the interactions thoroughly. Who monitors his PD? Can you get an urgent appointment with them - that seems to be the most significant to me.
Posts.Title: Decisions to make, all so overwhelming

Posts.Content: Hi Tukis. I think we all dread finding that lump and being so close to your treatment finishing would be very worrying. I'm sure you realise that it could well be something other than a recurrence, like scar tissue or perhaps a bit of cording. I'm glad you're doing something about it and I wish you the best of luck.
Posts.Title: Found lump under arm 5 months after double mastectomy and lymph node...

Posts.Content: Just a little story to let you know you're not Robinson Crusoe ... I was hospitalised in September - in ICU "get the family" kind of stuff and in a coma for 4 days. My mother turned up fluttering around but within 24 hours of me waking up, she just kept on and on about her poor dog and how worried she was about him. The dog that was in a luxury kennels place that he loves!!!! I couldn't wait to see the back of her.
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: Remember you can't choose your family, but you can choose your friends. Stick with the people who have loved and supported you and distance yourself from those that haven't. I had a same same but different experience with my mother many years ago. She sided with my former husband when we separated. It hurt but it broke the mother/daughter dependency thing so in the end I'm grateful. I now have a wonderful group of half a dozen close friends who I regard as my family. And you know what - they've all been right there for me through my BC journey! Don't try to ingratiate yourself with your family - it'll only end up hurting you. Let them make the next move - perhaps at least one of your siblings with wake up. If not, you have a husband and kids that are there for you.
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: That metal taste is horrid isn't it JMarlene! I had it too. I used the bicarb mouthwash right through chemo and found that swilling my mouth just before eating held that taste at bay just long enough to get some food into me. I also found that freshly squeezed oj and cherry tomatoes cut through the taste. At least you're close to the end. Keep up the good work.
Posts.Title: Metal taste in the mouth.

Posts.Content: Hi Rachmeister I originally had an implant, which was very pretty and healed really well. However, during chemo I got really sick and put on about 10kg of fluid. Eventually that all went, except in my new boob, so I was left with a football on my chest. I had physio, lymph massage and compression but nothing worked. The fluid in my boob septated ie grew fibres in it, so it was a sponge rather than a balloon, and these compressed the implant. At that point I had to have the implant removed. My surgeon offered me a new one but by then (6 months later) I was so sick of the whole business that I opted for a mastectomy. I don't regret it one little bit. It healed really fast - within 2 weeks there was a full scar and no scab. I do have a seroma which won't go away but that makes me think I've made the right decision. Yes I only have one boob but honestly it doesn't bother me. I use knitted knockers and they suit me perfectly. I doubt I'll bother with a reconstruction as I don't want to risk more fluid problems but my surgeon has said she'll do it if I change my mind. The best thing is no more chopping me up, waiting to heal etc etc Hope it all works out for you
Posts.Title: Fed up due to failed implant. Next steps help please?

Posts.Content: Hi Andi3. I feel for you as I also developed clots during the AC part of chemo and spent a month in hospital, including a fortnight in intensive care. I'm now on warfarin, probably for the rest of my life as the doctors discovered that I am lacking in a protein that prevents clotting. Awful while I was going through it but now I'm quite glad as i was at high risk of stroke.  You probably feel really unfit and quite terrible. I know I did when I first got out of hospital - couldn't walk more than 20 metres and was pretty breathless, as well as bald and fatigued from chemo. That was in October 2015. Now I'm as fit as a flea, have lost weight, doing enough exercise, off the grog, and completed chemo and radio. I had to work at it but I can assure you there is a road back to good health. Also, I have had a portacath right from the start. Wonderful! It hasn't been a moment's trouble and I have decided to keep it till I finish Herceptin in September. I absolutely agree with KiwiCardi that it's worth asking about. Wishing you all the best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Why is my PICC a Pain...???

Posts.Content: Oh Cannon. How the mind plays tricks on us! I'm pretty much OK but a couple of months ago I watched a show about Great Ormond St. One episode was about the ICU. As soon as I heard the beeping noises of all those monitors, I was right back in ICU! Horrible. My hubby is even worse - every time he drives me to a hospital appointment, he gets flashbacks relating to my treatment. So bad for him that I try not to cadge a ride any more, even though parking is virtually impossible.  I think all we can do is acknowledge the feelings, have a good cry or a good old worry or whatever, and then get on with life till the next time. I'm sure these things will always pop up but as time passes, hopefully our reactions will lessen. I hope your results are all ok.
Posts.Title: Feelings

Posts.Content: I had my drain for 13 weeks and it was still draining more than 30 ml per day. I ended up cheating just so I could be rid of the wretched thing. But I have paid the price - I still have a seroma 18 months later. Guess I'm a fluidy person lol. I ended up pinning the bag to my top so I could move around without catching it. Very annoying all round so I sympathise.
Posts.Title: My Drain and I

Posts.Content: Hi Welshie. Sorry to hear you're having a rough time of it. I have to say I've not heard of that kind of reaction to radio before. I used to be a little light-headed afterwards but that was cos I'd been lying still for a while. Cleared in a couple of minutes. Do mention it to the nurses next time you go to radio. Hope it sorts itself out soon.
Posts.Title: Headache / dizzy & radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4 Well at least you're on the way. I tried to drink 3 litres of water in the 24 hrs following chemo and 2 litres every other day. It really does help. I too found it hard to keep track of how much I'd drunk so I got 3 x 750 ml bottles that I filled every morning and gradually worked my way through them. Don't forget other liquids also count, except for coffee and tea.  As for BP, my chemo nurses only looked at the systolic and didn't blink an eyelid until it was over 150. After that they'd get the registrar to check you, not that it happened to me (one of the few problems I didn't have). They said up to 150 is nothing to worry about. It's mostly fear but add in a touch of white coat syndrome and the effect of prior chemo doses.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: When I went to Osaka, the shops were full of panda tat. Bags, socks, napkins, soft toys and so on. The Japanese love their cutsie tat but this was OTT even for them. A couple of days later, I worked it out ... the Osaka zoo had just received 2 pandas and  everyone was going panda mad. I remember the Adelaide Zoo got a couple and the same thing happened. Sigh.  Personally I prefer meerkats, which is a good thing as Canberra Zoo has plenty of meerkats and no pandas.
Posts.Title: Pandas

Posts.Content: Hi LL Don't even think about giving up your job!!!!!!!! There is a long way to go before that is even on the horizon. You should talk to the oncologist and get him to refer you for proper pain management. Seems to me the GP is only recommending everyday drugs,none of the good stuff. But you don't have an everyday problem. I'd also suggest that you have a really critical look at how you do your job: how you lift the child, how much you bend over, do you go up and down stairs a lot, standing or sitting and so on. Look for efficiencies and energy saving ways of doing things. A few new habits may help a lot. Finally, on the question of poo ... my bowels have never really recovered from chemo - I have the same problem as you. I can fill myself  with lentils veggies hot curry and everything else that's supposed to work = nothing. Particularly irritating is that my husband is a poo machine. I've found the best thing is a product  called coloxyl with senna. A district nurse put me on to it. After day 2 of no poo, I take 2 at night and am usually right the next day.  If not,  I take 2 again at night and am definitely ok the following day. I don't know if it's available in the UK but the active ingredient is docusate sodium. I've always had a tendency this way though - first time I went to India I was constipated for 8 days -I think I was so scared of getting the runs, my bowels locked up lol.  I  hope you've had a lovely day and that there are many more to come.  Big birthday hugs  Lynn xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Hi Val. Don't be too nervous - radio is a breeze and the technicians are all very kind. How is your breathing? Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy. Hair is growing

Posts.Content: Hi 4paws welcome aboard, although I'm sure you'd rather not be here. You can do it. It might get tough at times but in the end you'll get there.  I can't help on the work front as I'm lucky enough to be retired. Carolyn28 may be able to help on that as she's self-employed too. As far as your dog is concerned you should try to keep her with you as much as possible as I'm sure you'll want the companionship. Nothing like a pet to keep you sane and happy.  How much difficulty you have with walking her mostly will depend on how big a dog she is. You should be able to manage a short walk with a small dog even if you have to have chemo but if she's a bigger dog needing lots of exercise you might need a bit of help. Do you have dog-walking buddies - my mum's buddies had a roster when she broke her hip. Alternatively is there a teenager nearby that would walk her regularly for a small fee? If everything goes well, you'll only be in hospital for one or possibly two nights when you have your surgery and gentle exercise is very good for you during chemo. Don't be afraid to let people help you. I felt blessed, especially during chemo, with how some of my friends rallied round my husband and I. It has definitely drawn me closer to several people and I'm very thankful for that. If the tables were turned, wouldn't you want to help them? Happy to try to answer any questions you have. Best Lynnxx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi @pussycatgirl It's a shame they didn't get it all first time round, but it's not the end of the world! First up I had a skin saving mastectomy and reconstruction with implant. It was a very pretty boob but a few months later I got really ill and was carrying a lot of fluid, including in my new breast. Eventually all the fluid went, except in the breast. I had physio, massage, binding, drainage but nothing worked so I had to have surgery. By then I was so sick of having a football on my chest that I decided to go for a mastectomy and no reconstruction.  Now, 18 months later, I have absolutely no regrets. Being lopsided Lizzie doesn't worry me at all and I don't feel any less feminine. In fact, in a strange way I feel more feminine - you can take my boob, you can take my hair but I'm still a woman! My husband doesn't care - he's just glad I'm healthy.  I have always used knitted knockers as they're soft and comfortable and, if you pin them in your bra with a couple of safety pins, you can wear regular bras. I use slightly padded bras that are preformed (actually my old bras with the underwire removed). The padding helps with the shape - I can't tell any difference once I have a top on. I just have to be a little careful with low cut tops. I also have a knitted knocker filled with shower scrunchie material for swimming. I just pin it in my bathers. I'm not a bikini person but others have said that balconette bikinis are fine.  I have even been known to go down to the shops without a bra/knocker, provided I'm wearing a loose sweatshirt. I'm more embarrassed about the droopy boob on the other side than I am about the flat side.  So to sum up. I've completely adapted to having one boob. My surgeon offers me a reconstruction every time I see her but I won't have one. I don't need to and I've had so many fluid problems that I don't want to expose myself to more.  I know it's not easy but as everything, it's about the attitude you go into it with. Wishing you the best of luck with it.
Posts.Title: Having a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Here's the link to the knitted knocker pattern.  https://www.knittedknockers.org/make-a-knocker/  Scroll down past all the video tutorials and the pattern you need is the fourth one "our original pattern". It's American so the conversions are  4 ply yarn (what the Americans call Sport), No 10 or 3.25mm needles  Double knit/8 ply yarn, no 8 or 4 mm needles (the instructions for this are in brackets).  I find using 4 ply acrylic gives the best result. I have used cotton but it's heavy and takes ages to dry. It works perfectly well if you start with 3 stitches on each needle and just sew up the tiny hole. It's also much less fiddly. That probably doesn't make much sense to you but it will to a knitter lol.  Best
Posts.Title: Having a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Rachmeister Welcome aboard, but sorry you had to find yourself here.  The post surgery bras are ugly very elasticated things that your grandma would've worn but they do work to hold everything in place after an implant reconstruction. I totally agree about the front opening tops as it's quite hard to manoeuvre your arms initially. I wore hubby's holiday shirts. Not fashion forward but they worked. As for the drain, I was given a drain bag but I found it was a lot easier to pin the drain to my shirt with a safety pin as I didn't then forget it and leave it behind when I got up.  The main thing I'd add to the list is facial moisturiser as your skin can get very dry. I also like to take my own soap/cleanser as the soap offered is usually horrid. What about underpants?
