If you're wearing a gown, it's nice to be covered up.  Also, make sure you do the arm exercises they'll give you very religiously. You need to get your shoulder working again, especially if you're going to have radiotherapy.  Interesting to hear you have AF. I developed it and pulmonary embolisms during chemo. Have you been offered a cardioversion yet? It revolutionised my life - I felt instantly better, even walking out of the hospital was easier. Interesting that you've been told not to use nsaids. I can't but that's because I now have to take warfarin forever. Are you on blood thinners? Also, make sure you follow instructions exactly re wound care. Fortunately my surgeon used the stick on dressing that stays there until you peel it off, so my whole wound area was sealed for the first 11 days ie until I peeled it off. That meant I was able to shower right from the beginning. If you don't get one of those, there should be all sorts of instructions re not getting the wound area wet, changing the dressing and so on.  Hope it all goes well for you. Big hugs in anticipation.
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Thanks Rachmeister It's really interesting how treatment varies around the world. I'm in Australia so I've had the advantage of being able to switch to private medicine quite easily. I seem to have been given the traditional medicines - digoxin and sotalol for the heart and warfarin as the blood thinner. I'm still on the heart meds as I have a thyroid problem too. Once that's fixed they'll take me off the heart meds apparently, although I don't mind taking them. Fixing the thyroid means drinking something radioactive I'm not rushing. They say that warfarin is outdated because you have to have your INR checked every month or so. I don't mind that and I quite like the fact that its effects can be easily reversed with a shot of Vitamin K. That means if I'm ever in a car accident or similar, something can be done to stop me bleeding out.  Sorry to hear the cardioversion hasn't worked for you. My cardiologist told me that they can do it 5 or 6 times but I'm so glad it worked first time. It was January last year so I'm pretty confident it's settled down now, although permanent is a big call. The crosses we bear ...
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4 Well at least you're on the way. I tried to drink 3 litres of water in the 24 hrs following chemo and 2 litres every other day. It really does help. I too found it hard to keep track of how much I'd drunk so I got 3 x 750 ml bottles that I filled every morning and gradually worked my way through them. Don't forget other liquids also count, except for coffee and tea.  As for BP, my chemo nurses only looked at the systolic and didn't blink an eyelid until it was over 150. After that they'd get the registrar to check you, not that it happened to me (one of the few problems I didn't have). They said up to 150 is nothing to worry about. It's mostly fear but add in a touch of white coat syndrome and the effect of prior chemo doses.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hi Kitkat59 Well done you for getting to the end of radiotherapy! For me, the soreness and burning lasted almost exactly 2 weeks, although I've heard others say it lasted a week or two longer.  Be very careful how you wash - just pat, not rub, and only use aqueous cream or a very mild soap like Dove sensitive - to give yourself the best chance of healing quickly. I had just one sore spot but oh boy was it painful. My radio unit gave me Mepilex silicon dressings which were magical. They are peel on, peel off with no adhesive and just protect the sore area. My sore spot healed in a few days with them.  I was using R2 over the area but avoided the sore spot. I've never heard of flamazime cream but I wouldn't recommend using any creams without checking with your radio unit first. Best
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy burns & blisters

Posts.Content: Hi AngieD Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I'm so sorry to hear that your husband has joined the club that no one wants to be a member of. However, let me reassure you that breast cancer is very treatable.  I think the thing I learned most of all from my BC treatment is that you have to be an assertive patient. You need to ask the questions and make sure you're satisfied with the answers. In your husband's case, the issue of drug interaction will be very important as he takes important regular medication. He'll need to keep at it until he's satisfied with the answers - the days of doing as the doctor tells you are long gone.  Turning first to chemo. Chemo isn't always necessary for ER+ BC. It can be treated effectively with tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor. However, I don't know exactly how the oncologists decide as the oncotype test isn't used in every case as far as I know. He may wish to ask what percentage benefit is expected from chemo and then weigh that against the risks of chemo. I think it would be wise to ask for an oncotype test if it's not mentioned by the doc, or at least ask why s/he isn't proposing it. You both also need to bear in mind that while some people have nasty side effects from chemo, others sail through, with many people in this forum having been able to work some or all of the time. There are also very good drugs these days to help with the side effects, such as nausea and vomiting.  As far as radiotherapy is concerned, the vast majority of people find that much easier than chemo. Again, I don't know how radio might affect someone with Parkinson's so that needs to be raised with the oncologist. As someone has already said, make sure to write down all your questions as it's very easy to forget them once you're in the consulting room. Wishing you both the very best.
Posts.Title: Decisions to make, all so overwhelming

Posts.Content: Cramps? I had terrible cramps until I started taking a magnesium supplement. My Mg level was actually measured in one of the many thousand blood tests and I was found to be deficient. My onco suggested the supplement.
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Not the worst news you could have been given Jojo4! If you've had your bloods done it would probably only have been about weighing you, checking BP and so on. No doubt you'd have been given a chat but likely to cover much the same info as you've picked up from here. They should give you anti-sickness meds and instructions.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Just to reassure you ... I feel really sorry for Carolyn28 and what she's encountered with other people's attitudes. I have found other people to be exceptionally kind and caring as I wandered around town with my bald head. We even got given an extra course in a posh restaurant! My husband did call me a dyke a couple of weeks ago but we had a good laugh about it - cos I do look a bit butch. Don't care though. He has been loving and supportive all the way through and I think we've grown closer. The only time he had an issue was when I had to use one of those toilet seat raisers after I came out of hospital. He hated that and kept on about it. It did make me give it up quickly though. Lots of love Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: I actually knit my own linsw and have several in different colours to match my bras. You can get them from https://www.kkukciowix.com/  free of charge.  If you knit, or know someone that does, I can give you the link to the patterns. Best
Posts.Title: Having a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Not the worst news you could have been given Jojo4! If you've had your bloods done it would probably only have been about weighing you, checking BP and so on. No doubt you'd have been given a chat but likely to cover much the same info as you've picked up from here. They should give you anti-sickness meds and instructions.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: You're looking great Ann. And I've huge admiration for you running 10k, let alone racing.  I noticed a couple of people behind you with the same hairdo. I wonder if anyone 'didn't look' at them? I never had that problem - or maybe I was just oblivious to them all lol.
Posts.Title: No headscarf

Posts.Content: The waiting is the worst but yours does seem to be going on rather long. Time to get assertive - remember that you more than anyone has your best interests at heart!
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: It's all a bit of a murky drug-laden soup isn't it tropicof? I by no means have all the answers but hopefully this will help you.  Anastrozole, letrozole and exemestane are pretty much the same in effect ie they strip oestrogen from your body. Side effects can happen with each of them and it varies immensely from person to person. I expect you've seen the various threads about different brands having different effects so it pays to change brands before giving up or asking for a different AI. Zoledronic acid, or an alternative like denusomab, are often prescribed with an AI as the AI can strip calcium from your bones. They do also help to prevent bone mets. You should also be prescribed a calcium supplement. As for the teeth thing. A rare side effect of ZA etc is osteochronosis of the jaw, where basically the jaw starts to disintegrate. It's usually started with a tooth problem so it's best to ensure your teeth are in good nick before you start.  I'm not a believer in giving up dairy or anything else for that matter. I'm more for eating a balanced sensible diet and minimising junk food. My onco gently suggested that I should try to lose some weight, as oestrogen is produced in fat cells in post-menopausal women, so the less fat the better. Can't say I'm excelling in that department.  Best
Posts.Title: anastrozole and similar

Posts.Content: My usual perfectly behaved blood pressure was always elevated when it was taken just prior to chemo and then Herceptin. It used to worry me, as I always thought my BP was one thing that was ok. However, the nurses in the chemo unit were completely unconcerned. They said they only refer you to the dr if the systolic goes above 160.  We do have a BP machine at home (hubby is a hypochondriac lol) and it always reverted to normal within 24 hours. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Blood Pressure

Posts.Content: PS I had a terrible time with my GI tract right throughout chemo - alternating between constipation and diarrhoea, including the memorable Christmas Day 2015 when I didn't make it to the toilet from my bed. Cleaning up when you feel rubbish is not fun - what a Christmas present.  In fact, I don't think my GI tract has ever fully recovered. It's much more sensitive these days, despite filling myself with probiotics and being a year and a half past chemo. I used to have a cast iron belly but not any more. Lord knows what'll happen next time we go to India or somewhere like that lol.
Posts.Title: Scared to last Chemo

Posts.Content: I got pulmonary embolisms as a result of the first lot of chemo (I had doxirubicin and cyclophosphamide - equivalent to the EC part they give you in the UK). I've been on warfarin for 6 months and have a review in a couple of weeks time. To be honest, it's no trouble apart from the blood test every fortnight, and someone comes to my house to get the blood, so I don't care if I'm on it for ever. At least it gives you significant protection against stroke! I think my clots must be pretty much cleared up as I no longer get any breathlessness.
Posts.Title: Blood clots after chemo

Posts.Content: I was prescribed denusomab rather than biphosphonates as my onco is of the opinion that it has a stronger anti-cancer effect (he cited a paper given at the San Antonio cancer conference in 2015, which my hubbie has read but I haven't). However, I only have the injection every six months.  I'm not sure why we're all on different regimes but I do know that this is an area of current research so perhaps the best way isn't yet settled. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Bisphosphonate side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou1007  good plan - I found it very reassuring, although I don't use it much now.  Advice from the hypochondriac himself - always take your BP first thing in the morning, as soon as you get up and before you have coffee/tea. Set it up, put it on your arm and then sit quietly for 5 mins before taking it. That's how you get reliable readings, as your BP will fluctuate quite a lot during the day. Record the readings so you can track any pattern and then you can work out what might be causing changes eg anticipation of doctor's visit, what you had for dinner, how you slept and so on. I also recorded pulse rate but I was having trouble with atrial fibrillation so heart rate was a big issue for me. Thankfully that's fixed now by my hero cardiologist lol. I have occasionally taken it when either I felt lightheaded (possibly low BP) or stressed (higher) just to see what happened. I never got consistent readings, although the fluctuations weren't wild. Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Blood Pressure

Posts.Content: I'd definitely take body lotion. I found my skin got very dry and had to get hubby to find some at home (hahahahahaha) and bring it in. The other thing I'd do if I had my time over is find a decent post-op bra to take with me. I was given one by the breast nurse but it was too small (she said they didn't have bigger) so I ended up taking the wire out of my normal bra and using that. It wasn't the best solution but I needed something.  I took some of his cotton summer shirts ie big and loose with buttons all the way down the front. I wore leggings with them and was very comfortable.  Wishing you all the best.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: What to take to hospital?

Posts.Content: Hi silvercloud. Seems the decision was taken out of your hands. Try not to worry too much about chemo - it's definitely do-able and there's plenty of advice available on this site. Try to get the docs to give you a portacath, Hickman or PICC line as they make the infusion process much easier. I have a portacath and haven't had a moment's problem with it.  Being HER2+ isn't such a bad thing as Herceptin is pretty effective and there are other drugs newer to the market or under trial that are specifically targetted at HER2+. Hope it all goes really well and you sail through. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: I finished chemo end January 2016 and I've only just (earlier this week) had the last of the chemo curls cut out. Before chemo, my hair was curly and quite unmanageable, the regrowth was also curly but the hairs were harsher and thicker. Now my hair is just slightly wavy and silky as anything. I love it and hope this is how it will stay - an unexpected positive outcome from chemo.
Posts.Title: Hair after chemo

Posts.Content: That was me toxophilite! I had a terrible time with steroids during AC - caused diabetes. When I was ready to start the T part of my chemo, I asked my oncologist if I could have it without any steroids at all. He declined because of the potential allergic reaction but he cut them right back - I just had 4mg by infusion immediately prior to each T treatment, no pills beforehand or afterwards. Mind you my blood glucose level still shot up and stayed that way for about 48 hours, so the wretched dex was still having an effect. I think by the time you've had a couple of T and H treatments, they know whether you're going to have an allergic reaction at all. I ended up having 9/12 paclitaxel as I got peripheral neuropathy. That didn't stop me having a full 1 year course of Herceptin. I also remember someone else on here only having one T treatment I think but still having H.  Bottom line is that it's probably best if you can manage the final treatment Jo but if you really think you can't then you need to discuss the way forward with your onco. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Scared to last Chemo

Posts.Content: Great news Jo. You must be so relieved. Won't be long before you're feeling much better.
Posts.Title: Scared to last Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi ScaredofPN  There was a thread about  hair loss a week or so ago. I'm not sure if this is relevant to you - let's hope not.
Posts.Title: Hair loss again 4 weeks after finishing chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Kitkat59 Well done you for getting to the end of radiotherapy! For me, the soreness and burning lasted almost exactly 2 weeks, although I've heard others say it lasted a week or two longer.  Be very careful how you wash - just pat, not rub, and only use aqueous cream or a very mild soap like Dove sensitive - to give yourself the best chance of healing quickly. I had just one sore spot but oh boy was it painful. My radio unit gave me Mepilex silicon dressings which were magical. They are peel on, peel off with no adhesive and just protect the sore area. My sore spot healed in a few days with them.  I was using R2 over the area but avoided the sore spot. I've never heard of flamazime cream but I wouldn't recommend using any creams without checking with your radio unit first. Best
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy burns & blisters

Posts.Content: There are other options than codeine. Carolyn28 was prescribed something but I can't recall what it was, so I've tagged her.
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie84. I don't have an answer for you. There's a bit about ovarian suppression (which is what Zoladex does) and tamoxifen in the NICE guidelines (from Page 54 - there's a link below my signature) but I read it twice and I still can't work out why ovarian suppression is recommended in some cases and not others. The only distinguishing feature seems to be whether or not you refused chemo, but that doesn't really make sense to me.  Have a read anyway and maybe someone will be along soon who knows more about it than I do.  Sorry I couldn't be more help.
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi Silvercloud Firstly, I think the oncotype test must be based on statistics at its heart so it's not an either or situation!  We all have to face this kind of decision at some point in the journey - mastectomy or lumpectomy, chemo or not, will we put up with the side effects of AI and so on. Not helping much but you'll know in your heart what's right for you.  I had a dreadful time with chemo, ending up in hospital for a month with clots which resulted in respiratory failure and 2 weeks in ICU. I had to have a second op cos I had a septated seroma and I find Letrozole horrid with hot flushes and insomnia. Radio is ok so far! Despite all of that I would go through everything again. I want to give myself the best possible chance and each of those percentage points adds up. Best of luck with your decision and further treatment. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: A friend of mine has lichen sclerosus around her vulva, which is also dreadfully itchy. Her doc gives her cortisone cream, which she says works very well.  And as for medi-honey - I'd recommend it for any skin condition. You need to make sure that you get genuine medicinal quality manuka honey though - not Tesco's finest!
Posts.Title: Letrazole side effect

Posts.Content: Interesting Loulou1007, my chemo nurses always worried about the upper figure, never bothered about the lower one. 132/80 isn't too bad. My husband's doctor is satisfied when he's at 140/90 with BP meds! Of course, you've been doing yours during the day so it will fluctuate depending on what you've been doing and eating, that's why the first one in the morning is the most important. I had mine taken in Bali a couple of months back and it was 115/75. The doctor and nurse (both Indonesian of course) were really worried that it was too high. I managed to calm them down by insisting that was a very good BP for a fat white Australian! Indonesians are generally much shorter and wirier than westerners so I guess their normal is much lower because of that. Just shows how variable it all is. Good luck with it. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Blood Pressure

Posts.Content: Here's to the bald ladies. I went commando all through chemo. I knew I'd never cope with a wig and hated the hats and scarves - they label you just as much as being bald. I found that people were really nice and I got great service in restaurants and cafes. Also, I loved the feeling of hot shower water directly onto my scalp.  I know it's not for everyone but I agree we have nothing to hide and should be proud that we are getting treatment. I think that every time someone steps out without their wig/scarf/hat, it's normalising cancer treatment and baldness just that little bit more.  Oh by the way, there were quite a few people at the cancer treatment centre I went to who had chosen the bald look.  Hope everybody's treatment goes really well.
Posts.Title: No headscarf

Posts.Content: Oh and I forgot to add that I didn't need any painkillers at all, but I did have axillary clearance as well so had virtually no nerves in that area. I'd talk to the surgeon or anaethetist about pain relief before you have the surgery. They ought to prescribe something suitable. I found them very obliging with the panadeine forte (do you have that in the UK?) and now have a nice little stash for emergencies lol.
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: Hi Jemima. So sorry to hear your mum has breast cancer - it's a scary time for her, you and the rest of the family. Lots of good info has already been posted which I won't repeat. I'll just give a few suggestions of practical things you can do to help, in no particular order. You don't say whether you have siblings but if you do, and they're younger than you, take some responsibility for them. It will be especially important for them to have someone to talk to. Make some freezer meals for when you're busy studying and your mum doesn't feel like cooking. Do the shopping. Help with housework.  Make sure you both have some treats - even if it's only something like a coffee out, or an ice cream.  Shave her head for her if she has to have chemo. Arrange to be home for the 24 hours after she has surgery (they mostly let you out of hospital earlier if there's someone going to be at home). When you go to appointments with her, take notes as neither of you will remember everything. It's also helpful to write down questions for the doctors when you think of them, as you often forget during the appointment. But don't give up your life. I'm sure this is the last thing your mum would want. Just a few adjustments ... Wishing you and your mum all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Mum diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Lovely that you have found a partner you want to be with. If s/he's a good person, then they'll understand and support you through this, especially with you needing to give more time and attention to your mum and brother. If not, well it's better to find out now.  Please keep visiting this site, we're a friendly bunch and try to support each other. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Mum diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Forza Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I'm so sorry to hear about your father. A cancer diagnosis is always shocking and upsetting but I suspect that a diagnosis of breast cancer is particularly tough for men. We have a few male contributors here who might be able to offer some useful support to you and your father. I'm tagging Buddha7 as he's been treated relatively recently. Puzzler is correct. The main treatment for breast cancer is surgery to remove the cancer and often the lymph nodes under the arm. Up to stage 3, that means the cancer is gone. Chemo and radio are extra treatments to try to make sure it doesn't come back.  You're probably aware that there are several forms of breast cancer. For triple negative (negative for receptors for oestrogen, progesterone and HER2) breast cancer, there are no additional treatments at this stage, although I believe they're close.  It will be important for your father to have regular checkups and also to self-monitor ie feeling for any changes or new lumps and he should check both sides regularly, as well as his armpits.  Always remember that breast cancer is very treatable and over 90% of people survive more than 5 years. So once his radio is finished, then your father should get out there and live his life. Walking out of the hospital door for the last time can be scary and many people feel sort of abandoned and a bit lost without the regular schedule of scans, treatments and doctors' visits. Tell him to give himself time, and as someone put it a week or so ago, let life come to him. He'll still feel below par for some months but will gradually get back to normal, or at least a new normal. Don't expect him to be completely fit immediately. Do stay on board and feel free to ask any further questions you have. There are plenty of knowledgeable people around here.  Wishing you and your family all the best
Posts.Title: Male Breast Cancer- chemo then what?!

Posts.Content: And just to give you a bit of a laugh Loulou1007 . He went to the doc for prescription renewal. The doc took his BP (which was massive as he gets severe white coat) and then gave him the lecture - you know the one: lose weight, drink less, exercise more, less stress - and decided to do blood tests. Well, in the 3 days he waited for the results he was diabetic, had prostate cancer and cirrhosis of the liver, his kidneys were failing, and he was about to have a heart attack - quite unbearable with the foul mood he was in. And the results came back - slightly elevated blood sugar, slightly off liver numbers and everything else fine - exactly what you'd expect from a 50 year old who is overweight and drinks too much.  Sigh - that's my karma. To his credit though he has got back on his exercise machine and is doing the 5/2 diet, plus he's really cut back on the alcohol. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Blood Pressure

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28. i think doctors find it difficult to understand a decision to refuse treatment - after that's what they're trained to give. I saw a terrible example of that when I was in hospital.  As for treatment for advanced disease. My husband, who is a total nerd, has done heaps of research on pipeline treatments for HER2+ and reckons there are at least 3 new drugs that are very effective - lapatinib, neratinib and another I can't remember. I like you hope it doesn't happen to me, but if it does then I'll try anything that's going! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie84. I don't have an answer for you. There's a bit about ovarian suppression (which is what Zoladex does) and tamoxifen in the NICE guidelines (from Page 54 - there's a link below my signature) but I read it twice and I still can't work out why ovarian suppression is recommended in some cases and not others. The only distinguishing feature seems to be whether or not you refused chemo, but that doesn't really make sense to me.  Have a read anyway and maybe someone will be along soon who knows more about it than I do.  Sorry I couldn't be more help.
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: No need to cry for me Dee. I'm doing really well! I have been a complicated case and I like to think that both my surgeon and my onco have learned from me. I have also learned a new skill - how to make a knitted knocker. They are so much more comfortable and convenient than the silicon chicken fillets and you can pin them in place! I've made them in all my bra colours and my bathers also - that way if a bit peeks out it won't be noticeable. We're alive - that's what's important. Hugs Lynn
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: I agree - go with what you feel comfortable with. My only question is whether you tend to fiddle with your headcovering. If you do, then I'd leave it off as it will be a distraction and will draw the interviewers' attention to it. Here in Australia, no interviewer would dare ask about it as it would be viewed as discriminatory but if there's a possibility you could be asked, even indirectly, make sure you have a good positive answer at the ready that you've practised. Best of luck with it Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Job interview

Posts.Content: Hi Peaches. I'm sure you didn't want to have chemo (none of us did). However, you are now on that train journey and will eventually reach the destination. It always feels better once you have a plan!  Chemo will be tough but as everyone says it's "do-able". Get prepared (see the links at the beginning of the chemo club thread), be kind to yourself and take it one day at a time. It's good that you'll be off work as working is tough when you have chemo brain and fatigue. I guess that working in a school would expose you to plenty of infection.  Try and get your teeth checked before you start chemo. The teeth/gum area is where you're most susceptible to infection so best if it's in good working order beforehand. You should also think about getting a flu shot if this coming winter's shot is available.  Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: AC chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I didn't lose any on either the AC or the Taxol but they definitely went flaky. Right from the start I massaged them with bio-oil every day and always wore rubber gloves when doing wet tasks. I don't know if that helped but it made me feel better. Best of luck for your treatment.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Nail damage from AC Chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Louby123 I had terrible swelling all over my body but  in my legs and feet in particular. I put on 10kg in 3 weeks. I ended up being really ill with pulmonary embolisms and spent a month in hospital. The docs told me it was a combination of chemo, the steroids and an overactive thyroid. They were particularly scathing about the steroids, saying that was what tipped the balance. I don't know whether the swelling was a cause or a symptom of PEs. Make sure you mention it to your onco next time you see him and keep a close eye on your BP and temp. Also be alert to any breathlessness. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Swollen legs and feet??

Posts.Content: Hi Unoxx  Welcome aboard. The waiting is the scariest part of the entire BC experience. Once you get a treatment plan, somehow everything settles down and, while it's not easy, you just keep pushing on till you finish. I presume the CT scan you had is the normal check to make sure the cancer hasn't spread. It's not that the docs think it has, just that they need to check. The vast majority of cases show no spread but if you're unlucky and it has, then at least you know and there are plenty of treatment options available. Doesn't make the waiting easier though! As for not getting lumps checked. I had a couple of lumps about 15 years ago and never got them looked at. When I found my latest lump (in May 2015), I was pretty sure it was cancer and went to the doc immediately. I was right and had a diagnosis that week. I don't know why I behaved differently this time. Older maybe ?? Do keep looking in on this forum. There's a great bunch of people here with a wealth of knowledge and experience and sympathetic ears to help you through this journey. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Waited to have lump checked

Posts.Content: Hi Baki Sorry you're having a tough time of it right now. Is it an all or nothing thing? Would it be possible for you to try this drug for a reasonable period eg 3 or 6 months (being guided by your onco) and then have another scan to see if it's working? If it's working then great, continue; if it's not or only a little bit then talk to the onco about changing meds? I know it's a hard call, but like others have said, I'm sure your family would rather have you around than not.  Big hug from Australia Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Guilt and Self loathing

Posts.Content: Hi Baki, you seem to be feeling a bit better which is a GOOD THING xxx. I know it seems that the price of new drugs is a serious ripoff but think of the billions they invest in research. That can only be recouped from the few that are successful. If not for that research, ground breaking drugs like Herceptin would never have been developed. I personally think the real problem is governments that won't pay for new drugs because of the cost to the budget. I get why but it seems desperately unfair that treatment is available but not available to ordinary folks. Not just the UK - it's the same here in Australia. I have to pay full price for 6 monthly denusomab injections and a friend spent tens of thousands of dollars on a drug for his prostate cancer. What about those who can't afford it? Would you be prepared to share the name of the drug you've been prescribed. I'm really interested in new developments. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Guilt and Self loathing

Posts.Content: Hi Skymoonflower It sounds like you're having rather a hard time with it.  I'm rather concerned about your arm. Chemo can do dreadful things to veins but the worst of all is causing clots. If you haven't already, contact your chemo unit and get it checked.  As for the indigestion, I had all sorts of GI tract problems throughout chemo including acid indigestion. In fact, it must be pretty common as my chemo unit gave me ranatidine (Zantac) as part of the pre-chemo infusion cocktail. I took that at other times too.  Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: Pain in wrist and arm and restricted movement from elbow after chemo...

Posts.Content: I had a 12 week gap between surgery and chemo starting, mainly cos I still had the wretched drain. In the end my onco decided to go ahead with chemo anyway. I wouldn't worry too much about a bit of a wait. It's far better to heal first, as you're really susceptible to infection once you start chemo. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: It worries me that my chemo is delayed because of Diep flap infec...

Posts.Content: Wow Dee you've certainly had a hard time.  but thanks for sharing. I had all mine removed in June 15 but haven't had any arm trouble at all. I will be extra vigilant now i've heard your story as I live in a place where life without driving would be impossible!  Best of course is that you're ok after 5 years. Don't lose sight of that. All the best. Lynn
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: I had a saved skin mastectomy with immediate implant plus 30 lymph nodes removed, 16 of which had cancer cells! Midway through chemo (in Oct 15) I became very ill and accumulated a lot of fluid all over my body. It eventually went from everywhere except my affected breast, which is now like a football on my chest. Docs kept telling me it would go but it didn't. I thought I had a seroma plus some lymphoedema. Turns out I was right but in the intervening period the seroma has septated (ie grown fibrous). Now my only option is a full mastectomy with removal of implant. I'm going ahead cos that'll be better than the current football. However, I'm told the lymphoedema may return. Moral of the story - don't take no for an answer. If you have any swelling that the docs or nurses try to pass of as post-operative or temporary for other reasons, just keep on at them!  On the positive side, I have been religious about the arm exercises and have no sign of lymphoedema in my arm. Let's hope it stays that way!
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Hi MoMo2626 It is of course quite natural for you to worry but do try to not let it take over. After all, you know as well as I do that it's better to get these things checked out and not ignore them.  Try to keep going about your normal routines and pack the worry away for later. The weeks will roll round! Best
Posts.Title: Just when I was trying to get back to normal

Posts.Content: Hi Batfinkcaz. That's a new one on me, but there seem to be endless variations to what we have to go through once we're diagnosed with breast cancer. Of course it might be totally unrelated to the BC.  From a quick look, it seems there are plenty of possible causes of an enlarged thymus, so don't go panicking just yet! The main thing, regardless of what's going on, is that it's been found. Instinct suggests they don't think it's super urgent but I suspect though that they may want to do more tests. I do feel for you being back in the waiting space. All you can do is keep busy and try to confine the worrying and not let it take over.  Do let us know how you go on the 23rd.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Enlarged thymus gland.

Posts.Content: I retired 6 years ago at aged 57. I was lucky enough to get a payout big enough to pay off our mortgage and I do have a reasonable monthly pension. Nowhere near what I was earning though. Most important thing I think is to go into retirement debt-free. I've found I don't spend nearly as much as I did when I was working and always seem to have plenty of spare cash on 1/4 of what I used to earn. I have a much better, richer life too and enjoy simpler things. I wouldn't swap it for the world. My husband is still working, which keeps him out of my hair lol. He doesn't earn nearly as much as i used to but we have plenty. I simply don't want the new furniture, new car, new clothes etc like I used to.  Best of luck with your decision Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Retiring but scared...

Posts.Content: Best of luck for tomorrow. If they do take all your lymph nodes be sure to read some of the threads about lymphodema. The main thing is to get on top of it early and be fanatical about it. Particularly, be fanatical about the exercises - it pays off. It's not the end of the world though, it just means your lymph nodes have been doing what they're supposed to ie trapping those nasties.
Posts.Title: Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: I had a lump in a similar spot - turned out to be internal scar tissue - but it was worrying until it was checked.
Posts.Title: A bit of reassurance please

Posts.Content: Brilliant news Karen. I bet you're jumping for joy. Now go out and celebrate. Best
Posts.Title: Mammogram recall

Posts.Content: I don't think you're being over-sensitive at all. No one expects your GP to be your best friend but we all have a right to expect professionalism, and not paying attention is hardly professional. It's also really stupid on his part as he could miss something vital and end up misdiagnosing!  We all need to be assertive patients but that doesn't necessarily mean confrontation. Perhaps you could go armed with a list of queries and then you can just keep pulling him back to the list. It's a prop I guess but it might make it easier for you. Above all, don't be fobbed off with substandard care.  I've had some pretty ordinary GPs in the past, some that I would never use again and some who I'd only ask for an antibiotic. I'm very fortunate that by pure luck I landed a fab GP when I went to the clinic to get my lump checked. He has been wonderful all the way through.
Posts.Title: GP support ?

Posts.Content: You are definitely not silly!!! It's a scary and worrying time for you so don't undersell yourself. I can understand you isolating yourself as no one seems to understand, but do remember they have your welfare at heart and will want to support you if that turns out to be needed. Best
Posts.Title: Mammogram recall

Posts.Content: I have the hot and cold thing happening too but I put it down to the letrozole I'm condemned to for the next 5 years. Not really hot flushes, I just get so hot during the night it wakes me up. And again and again. Last night was really cold though - about 5 degrees C and I had the best sleep I've had for a couple of months with only one wee break. I'm hoping with the onset of winter, this problem will resolve itself.  More generally, when I finished chemo (10 weeks ago) I found my body doing all sorts of crazy things - lightheaded, very tired moments, lots of weeing, shivering, bursts of great energy, insomnia and so on. I put it down to readjusting now I'm no longer being poisoned. It's all settled now except for the heat during the night.
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Great news Karen. Relax and enjoy it.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Positive point 6!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you've been sick Always Baking  and I hope you're feeling better now.  Seems to me that if AC/EC knocks you around then T will be easy but if you sail through AC/EC then T will hit you on the head. I was in the former group.  I was told that they start out on the max dose for your size but can reduce it up to 25% without it losing its effect so I doubt you'll have an extra treatment. Don't ignore those temps. Hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Oh Boy ! Fell At The First Taxotere Hurdle !!

Posts.Content: Most people on here say they are glad they had someone with them. I'm the opposite. I went to every appointment except two by myself and I'm glad I did, as it gave me time to process the information before sharing it. I know if I'd taken my hubby, he would have taken over as he's a bit of a loudmouth. The only appt he came to was my chemo education session and guess what - he took over. I could hardly get a word in edgewise grrr. A friend insisted on taking me to my first chemo. She had chemo a few years back and I think she was more interested in catching up with the nurses. She had a few chats with them and then went shopping lol. Best of luck with your appointment today. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: biopsy results on Wednesday 2nd nov 2016

Posts.Content: Not the news you wanted masquerade2010. You probably don't think so right now but there are some positives - hormone positive is better than hormone negative as they'll give you either tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor (AI) depending on whether you are pre or post menopause; you don't have to have chemo = big bonus; and it's still early stage which means you can be successfully treated and it may never come back.  I can understand you just wanting it out. I did. The reality is though that a few weeks makes little difference so don't panic.  You'll find plenty of support here so just ask away if you have questions or feel free to rant without judgement.  How old are your children? I'm sure it'll be tough for them whatever their age but if they're a bit older, then make sure you keep them involved in the process.  Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: biopsy results on Wednesday 2nd nov 2016

Posts.Content: Some great advice here Wendy. The only thing I'd add is that it might be useful to ring the Macmillan hotline (number and hours of operation at the bottom of the page). They have experts on workplace issues and cancer so they would be able to give you advice on how to proceed, Including both your rights and responsibilities in your current workplace and what you do or don't need to tell a prospective employer. Having said that, it sounds to me like there's going to be a ringleader who is whipping up the others. What can you do to win him/her over?  Hope it all works out for you.
Posts.Title: need some advice regarding my job

Posts.Content: This sounds familiar! For me it turned out to be the dexmethsone (steroid) that I reacted REALLY badly to (ended up in ICU with respiratory failure). When it came time for the taxol, the onco said I couldn't have it without dex but he cut down the i/v dose to 4mg and told me not to take the pills afterwards. I've done this and am doing ok. I put on 2kg of fluid each week and my blood glucose level goes up to 25 or so from about 8 but it only takes a couple of days to normalise. I can put up with that. My advice to you would be to monitor your bloodwork reports very carefully for anything out of the ordinary and ask the docs immediately if you see anything.
Posts.Title: Anxiety/restlessness

Posts.Content: Hi Eden121 Welcome aboard the roller coaster that is cancer treatment. As others have said you'll find plenty of support here.  I just thought I'd point you, and others about to start radiotherapy, to the monthly Radiotherapy club, where you'll find plenty of tips to help you get through radio and where you can chat to others going through it at the same time as you. Best
Posts.Title: Hello, I am new, anyone there?

Posts.Content: Looks like you need the chemo club not the radiotherapy club lol. This is a thread for people going through chemo. There are some very helpful tips and plenty of people to chat to (unfortunately far too many).  I finished my treatment last year and am fighting fit now. Hopefully that's where you'll be at this time next year. Best
Posts.Title: Hello, I am new, anyone there?

Posts.Content: Hi LittleWren. This is always a scary time. I was pretty convinced it was cancer from the moment they said I needed a biopsy but the waiting is the hardest part. My best suggestion for you would be to talk to one or more of your friends - I found mine wanted to help and be part of the whole journey. Frankly I needed them as much as I needed my husband. Best of luck and stay in touch Lynn
Posts.Title: Waiting for diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4 I didn't have pps but I did have peripheral neuropathy. That didn't cause any delay in treatments but my onco did stop my paclitaxel after 9 of the planned 12 treatments.  I know Lacomtekp had problems with her feet so I've tagged her, in case she's got any suggestions. Best
Posts.Title: Palmer Planter Syndrome

Posts.Content: I had paclitaxel for 9 weeks. It was supposed to be 12 but stopped early cos I got neuropathy. My other SEs were pretty mild, just a little nausea in the first 12 hrs (fixed with metoclopramide) and some fatigue, but not nearly as bad as the AC part of my treatment.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Weekly Paclitaxol & 3 weekly Carboplatin

Posts.Content: The Australian Government has just released new guidelines for best practice in breast cancer care. The information is very accessible - easy to read, supported by videos and with scientific references given for each of the 12 guidelines.  This may be of interest to those at the beginning of their journey to give them some idea of what it's reasonable to expect and to ask about. https://thestatement.canceraustralia.gov.au/ Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Best practice in breast cancer care

Posts.Content: Easiest way to eat liver that I know of is to eat pate. Even the cheap stuff from Aldi or similar will do the trick, and if it's supermarket packaged (rather than artisan, freshly made blah blah) then you won't fall foul of the dietary infection guidelines.  And on the gap. I was recommended to have surgery between chemo and radio and did a lot of research at the time. I didn't keep a record of the research papers I read but basically they say that there is no increase in risk with a gap of up to 4 months between finishing chemo and starting radio, so you've got plenty of time.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Waiting for emotions to catch up with brain!

Posts.Content: Hi Karenelizabeth. Welcome aboard. Let's hope it's a short stay and you get good results from the recall. I know the waiting is very scary - we've all been there and I don't think one person would say they weren't worried. However, a recall isn't a diagnosis of breast cancer. It may be as simple as them not getting good pictures, or there may be one area that they think needs more detail, or there may be a lump, which might or might not turn out to be breast cancer. Remember 90% of breast lumps are not cancer. Even if there is a lump that does turn out to be cancerous, breast cancer is very treatable and as you've had recent clear mammos, they will have caught anything relatively early. Nothing I can say will stop you worrying, but do try not to let the worry take over. Keep busy, try new things, perhaps a little shopping therapy and actively tell yourself to stop worrying for the time being. You can't change anything right now! Finally, try as best you can to stay away from Dr Google. So much of the information is wrong or out of date and you'll frighten the pants off yourself. If you must, then stick to reliable sites like Macmillan or Cancer Research UK. Also anything that has .gov in the URL is likely to be ok.  Wishing you all the very best
Posts.Title: Mammogram recall

Posts.Content: I was told by one of the chemo nurses that hair always regrows from back to front - like a baby's hair.
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Great cartoon. Fits the bill exactly!
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: BRILLIANT Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Retiring but scared...

Posts.Content: Hi Always Baking  Don't over-stress about the something on the x-ray. I had "calcifications" on my spine that some random radiologist in my local public hospital thought were bone mets (the radiology dept doesn't have a great rep) when I was an in-patient last year. Worried my hubby stupid but no one thought to mention it to me as they all thought I was too ill to cope! Anyway, it had been picked up when I was first diagnosed and I'd had an MRI and it had been found to be calcification!!!! This was all done privately so wasn't in the hospital's records and I hadn't even mentioned it to my hubby as there was so much going on at that time plus I hadn't yet met my medical onco who was looking after me in hospital. That early work also found that I have arthritis in my lower spine (middle aged back lol). Moral of the story - plenty of blobs can show up on the scans that aren't mets. Obviously we all need to get them checked but not go overboard with worry before getting the results. On the T. I can't remember if you're HER2+ but if so, T plus Herceptin gives the best result. Either way, there are a couple of options that don't require you to stop. One is to reduce the dose and the other is to switch to weekly paclitaxel, which is just as effective, but with much easier side effects. Probably worth discussing with your onco on Tuesday. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Oh Boy ! Fell At The First Taxotere Hurdle !!

Posts.Content: So glad you went to see your family. I'm sure it was worth it. Hope you had a lovely day. Stay strong. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Hoping everyone is enjoying the holiday.

Posts.Content: I consider myself to be something of a drain expert, or perhaps a drain victim, as I had mine for 13 weeks! The best thing I found was to tape more of the tubing (probably about 20 cm) to my body at a comfortable angle, so if it started pulling, it wasn't pulling at the exit site. Within about a week, I was sleeping normally on that side. Good luck with it.
Posts.Title: 5 Days post op - tips on sleeping with drain!

Posts.Content: Lovely comments Lorraine. I absolutely agree that breast cancer removes all vanities. I've given up worrying about the hair thing and happily go around bald - out and proud. I've no eyebrows or lashes either and am very reluctant to wear any makeup as it makes my eyes itch (b/c no brows or lashes to protect them). So all the world gets is the real me and it's not so bad.
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: Hi Jump123 I used R1 and R2 and found it fabulous. I'd highly recommend it. I had to buy it online as it's not available in Australia yet - I think it was only approved for use in the UK in late 2015. I was also given fantastic silicone dressings (called Mepilex) for the one small area where I lost the skin. It self-adheres and peels off easily.  So there are solutions out there - you've just got to be aware of them.  Best of luck with your treatment. Lynn xx

Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: I was told by one of the chemo nurses that hair always regrows from back to front - like a baby's hair.
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Hi purplediva R1 is a cooling gel that you smooth on straight after treatment - I used to put it on in the change room at the hospital before I got dressed. You don't need to use it at other times, although if your treated area feels hot and burny then you can smooth some on.  I originally stopped using the R2 about 2 weeks after I finished radio. However, after about a month I felt my skin in the treated area starting to go a bit leathery so I started again. I'm still using it. Also, I'm quite big and found I needed to use 2 sachets at once to thoroughly moisturise the area.  I have seen people offer leftovers through this site but I decided to keep mine. As I said I'm using the moisturiser and I think the R1 might be useful for household burns. (I'm always burning myself in the kitchen lol). It's proved very good for that too. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: R1 sachets are quite big. I never needed more than one. R2 on the other hand comes in smaller sachets. I always used 2, sometimes 3, but I'm not a small person. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Sounds awful you poor thing. May I suggest that you ask for a portacath. I've not had a moment's trouble and mine's been in for 8 months so far with another few to go. My onco suggested it right at the start as I'm having Herceptin and here in Oz we still get that by infusion. Best of luckPost Lynn
Posts.Title: Picc line infection , surgery cancelled.

Posts.Content: Oh bougiecat None of us champs to my knowledge have any medical training. We're just like you - people who've been through it, learned from the experience and happy to share with others to help them on the way. Best
Posts.Title: Waiting on scan for lump in left breast, worried sick.

Posts.Content: Brilliant news. Long may it continue.
Posts.Title: Whoop whoop ... mammogram results

Posts.Content: I sympathise too! Mine is much the same 6 months after finishing chemo. Worst part is that it's still short on top - about 1cm only and is showing little inclination to grow. I've had to get my husband to cut the back neckline several times, or else I'd have the world's worst mullet. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Amused by my hair

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn Best of luck for your treatment. After the first one it won't seem nearly so scary.  I agree with others that you have to drink a lot of water. I did 3 litres in the first 24 hours after chemo and 2 litres a day after that. When I couldn't face the taste of water I drank very weak Ribena. That did the trick. I didn't have much appetite so tried to make sure that whatever I ate was ok nutritionally. I basically lived on tomato soup, tinned pineapple, cherry tomatoes, grapes and small pieces of cheese. Oh and the dry biscuits I kept to keep the nausea at bay. Occasionally I had fresh orange juice at a local cafe - that was delicious!  Initially I put on weight - mostly fluid from the steroids - but then I got ill and have since lost a net 33kg (about 3 stone I think). A friend of mine, however, ended up a stone heavier so you can't really tell.  Wishing you all the very best - may your SEs be mild and may you sail through it like a pro. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Chemo Starts Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Soursops are a complete pest here in Australia. It really does taste like apples and custard - just like one of its alternative names. Tasty fruit yes, cancer cure no.  It makes me really really angry when people try to peddle snake oil cures to vulnerable people who doing their best in difficult circumstances. Time to cease and desist LongDrive Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Soursop

Posts.Content: Welcome aboard MRSORANGECAT - plenty of support and helpful tips here if you need it. We've all either been there or cared for someone who has. I too have an orange cat. He's 2 and named Kacang (pronounced ka-chang in the Indonesian way), which in Indonesian means bean or peanut. He was a very sick kitten, to the point where we had to feed him water with a syringe every hour, but he's recovered well and is a perfectly healthy and energetic young man. My husband said that, when I was very ill in hospital from chemo, he'd look at Kacang for inspiration. If he could get well, then so could I. I have and Kacang is a very special cat. Do stay in touch - we'll help you through. Best Lynn xx

Best thing is to either shave your head or cut it really short, and I mean short like half a cm. My GP suggested getting a bottle of champagne and drinking it while hubby shaved. Posts.Content: Hi Zanib. I'm sorry to see you back here with new worries. Unfortunately biopsies can be rather uncomfortable and can result in bruising. Hopefully it will settle down in a couple of days but if you're worried, or if it gets worse, you should contact your BCN.
Posts.Title: Pains in both shoulders and mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi I was totally ok with going bald, so my husband shaved my hair at the first sign of it dropping out. However, the painful feeling did continue for a while but not as bad. I think it was probably until all the stubble had dropped out. I appreciate that not everyone is as relaxed as I was about losing your hair, but it does feel so much better once you shave it.
Posts.Title: Scalp pain and impending hair loss

Posts.Content: Brilliant post Silverglades
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hahahahaha - no don't forget I'm in Australia Always Baking  so it's afternoon for me. I always try to look at this site during the day to pick up anyone who is sleepless and distressed. Stay strong, lots of love Lynn xxx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I think I'm a bit different to other contributors to this thread. Losing my hair didn't bother me in the slightest. In fact, I rather enjoyed being bald - no bad hair days and I've had 60+ years of them. I was also surprised that I didn't and don't feel any less feminine for having no hair (well I have a bit now) and only one boob. In a perverse way I feel more feminine - sort of 'you can do all this to me but I'm still a woman'.  Having said that, I do not like shave the head events. Mostly because everyone I've known who has done it (about 12 ppl so small sample) thought they were some kind of hero or martyr for doing so. That seems to me to mock the seriousness of a cancer diagnosis and the effect it has on those going through it. I also recognise that many if not most fellow BC travellers have more issues with their hair loss than I did. In my view Macmillan, of all organisations, should respect their client group and if even one person finds it objectionable, it shouldn't happen.  Best to all Lynn
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Thank you Judy. That is exactly what I was going to say - off the shelf statement, no empathy, patronising.  I used to work for the government and their response sounds EXACTLY like the fob off letters ministers used to write to backbenchers to get rid of a constituent complaint - thanks for your inquiry, let me give you some irrelevant facts, hope this helped, bye. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I don't think anyone should shave their hair for charity, and acknowledge this campaign has upset a lot of people here. I commented to that effect last year. However, I haven't and don't intend to engage further as I'm in Australia and of course haven't seen any of the ads, so I think it would by hypocritical of me to criticise something I can't possibly really know about.  I'm only posting now because of the comment about community champions not getting engaged. TBH this upset me a bit as I don't think on this issue we are any different to other members of the community - people who have/had cancer or cared for someone who has. We have our various opinions on issues but like everyone choose to comment or not comment depending on the issue. Our role is to help people of the community not to herd sheep.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Congratulations Karen Lacomtekp on reaching the finish line. It's a wonderful feeling isn't it? Like you, I feel that all the discomfort (and that's a bit of a euphemism) was worth it. I'm trying very hard lol to get living - managing to organise a bit of travel between now and the end of the year. Apart from little trips within Australia we're planning a long weekend in NZ, a couple of weeks in Japan in September and then in December we're taking my niece to India for 3 weeks. All this to make up for the year that I was stuck at home.  Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Thanks Dozyfiend - that's really interesting. Like you, I accept that pharmaceutical companies need to recoup the costs of research and development, even if the drug comes from a natural product (as the taxanes do). It's not simply a question of turning a plant into a pill. For this reason, I don't accept any of the big pharma conspiracy theories that do the rounds from time to time. That said, I do wonder sometimes at the price they set on new drugs. Countries like the UK via the NHS and here in Australia via the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, negotiate the price of supply and I'm sure other countries do too. The prices vary enormously, which I guess is down to the various governments' ability to negotiate. Pity the poor folk in the USA who don't have a government run system for the supply of drugs. I am of course a beneficiary of the system. My hubbie calculated the total cost of my treatment over the last 14 months as close to A$1 million (almost 600,000 pounds). This includes GP visits, scans, radiotherapy and hospitalisation, as well as the various drugs I've been given. Of this I've paid about $1000. Makes you think doesn't it. Cheers Lynn xx PS My daughter works in medical research in the UK, but with devices not drugs. She's always moaning about compliance issues, both with the FDA and the EU regulators.
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: I too did better on T than on AC Flopsyuk but I did have a long break between the two as the AC made me very very ill. T was a breeze by comparison. Interestingly I didn't have much nausea with either but then I've never been a chucker - I've probably thrown up less than 10 times in my life, other than one awful bout of delhi belly in India.  I have absolutely no evidence to support this theory but I have noticed on here that people who suffer with AC/EC seem to have a better time with T and vice versa. Not sure why this should be.  Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Funny that Judyr58, my fabbo (Irish) GP told me I looked like Sinead O'Connor. I was very flattered as I'm certainly not the sylph-like creature she was when she was sporting that hairdo. I went bald the entire time through chemo - couldn't stand hats or scarves and didn't bother to get a wig as I wouldn't have liked that either. I found people, without exception, to be very pleasant and kind. And no staring or making me feel uncomfortable. There should be more of it so everyone can feel that it's completely unexceptional to be bald. After all, no one takes any notice of a person with a cast on their arm. I do, however, hate the brave the shave thing, mostly as for me no hair is symbolic of an awful time, not being brave nor being a martyr, as some participants behave. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: PS Always Baking  try ranatidine (Zantac) for the indigestion. It's what I was given before each chemo infusion. Worked for me lol. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear this DizzyD I hope you're travelling ok apart from the puffiness. I'm not a medic but I do have experience of what you're talking about - horrible puffiness. When I was on chemo, I started getting really puffy after 2 AC treatments. This continued for another 2 treatments and I was like a balloon by then. It was all fluid - I put on 10 kg in 3 weeks (about 1.5 stones). If it had just been that I'd have been able to cope but I did get other problems especially shortness of breath to the point where I could hardly walk from the front door to the car.  It turned out that my body doesn't deal well with steroids, especially dexmethasone and that adverse reaction plus chemo caused all sorts of problems, the worst being pulmonary embolisms and steroid-induced diabetes.  I'm not saying that you'll get those problems but I do think that you should see your GP and not get fobbed off. It does need to be taken seriously, not because of the fluid itself, but other possible consequences.  Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Struggling.....

Posts.Content: Thanks Judy

There was someone on here recently who developed one about 4 months after surgery. She broke her arm on the good side and thought that caused the seroma to form. I just can't remember who it was. Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28 Not quite the wedding dress level of service but my surgeon was wonderful. My GP selected her after asking numerous colleagues, as he's only lived here a couple of years. She was great at explaining everything and did show me pictures of her work. I asked her if she is an artist, to which she replied "no, I'm a sculptor". She made me a perfect new boob and then when I had to have my implant removed months later, she did a very neat mastectomy. I can't fault the level of care and I still see her. Guess that's the benefit of private medicine! Cheers Lynn xx

Posts.Title: Normal MRI scan

Posts.Content: 2015 Christmas I was in the middle of paclitaxel treatments, including having one on Christmas Eve. I had terrible diarrhoea and didn't make it to the ensuite so I spent 2 hours Christmas morning cleaning up the floor, the bed, the rug, the ensuite.  This year I'm healthy, fit, happy and raring to go. Full traditional lunch here - turkey, ham, sprouts, roast veg, gravy, pudding, custard, cream, even though it's going to be 40 degrees (thank goodness for aircon). Why - because we're celebrating the fact that I can. To everyone going through chemo - it will pass.  To all those worrying about the future - there is one.  To everyone, thank you for just being there.  Wishing everybody a very happy Christmas, with lots of love. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Merry Christmas Everyone :)

Posts.Content: Oh Maxine how strange. It must've felt really weird.  PN is a common side effect of the taxanes but it generally affects the hands and feet. I've not heard of it affecting your nose. Please don't rely on Dr Google and do contact your BCN.

Posts.Title: Light at the end of the tunnel

Posts.Content: For those of you who don't know, I have a long lasting seroma from surgery in early March last year. I had it drained a few times, the last being just after Christmas. Then I decided to see what happened if I didn't get it drained. It has stabilised and definitely isn't getting bigger. Sometimes I think it's a little smaller, and then I think I'm kidding myself. It's hard to the touch but doesn't hurt and isn't inflamed.  Anyway, today I had my 6 monthly checkup with my surgeon. Her view is that it's better left alone if it's not getting bigger and isn't infected. She said that eventually the amount of pressure in the seroma stops any further leakage from the small vessels and then they're able to heal properly. After that the body gradually absorbs the fluid.  It seems like a logical explanation, but unfortunately she wouldn't or couldn't say how long it will take. Guess I'll just plod on with it.
Posts.Title: Seroma update

Posts.Content: Hi Andysis  My mum also has Alzheimer's and lives in a care home as she wouldn't be safe in her own home. Nothing about dealing with her is easy as she just doesn't remember anything you tell her. She hasn't had cancer but did fall and break her hip, necessitating a hip replacement. She found the stay in hospital very confusing and disturbing so one of the family had to be with her as much of the time as possible. Now she's healthy again but doesn't remember the minor changes in lifestyle that she's supposed to do, in order to stop her falling eg wearing sensible shoes all the time (she still likes to go out in her slippers or barefoot), not walking over rough ground and using her walker if she's going more than 10 metres. As a result she's already had another fall.  So, not as bad as being diagnosed with cancer, but I do understand where you're coming from. I'm pretty sure I would have made the same decision as you have if that's any reassurance. I wouldn't subject my mother to surgery again unless absolutely essential. I presume your mum is having hormone therapy ie letrozole or one of the other aromatase inhibitors. They do a good job of controlling the spread of hormone positive BC and for that reason are used extensively in the treatment of secondary BC. I have also read somewhere (although ironically I can't remember where) that often with elderly people, the cancer is slow growing and something else is likely to get them first, so to speak.  The other important thing is to be mindful of the possibility of pain. Usually primary BC doesn't cause much, if any, pain but secondaries often do. Additionally, the aromatase inhibitors can cause achiness in the joints and muscles. Your mother deserves to be pain-free but may not complain about any symptoms. I'd suggest asking her on a regular basis as there are plenty of pain meds out there.  Wishing you and your mum all the best.

Posts.Title: Seroma update

Posts.Content: Hi scared66 Welcome aboard the roller coaster. Firstly, you are absolutely normal!!! Any cancer diagnosis takes a massive  toll on your emotions and we all recover at different rates. Some good suggestions already to help you and I'll add one - how about a Moving On  course. A lot of people have found them very helpful. In the meantime I'd suggest reading a fantastic article by Dr Peter Harvey called After the treatment finishes then what? Ifound it really helpful. Sorry I can't link it, but it's easy to find.  As far as the tiredness and hard breast are concerned, it does take quite some time to recover fully. Just eat well,don't push yourself and try to get some exercise. Of course, see your doctor if you think you're getting worse. Finally never forget it's great that your BC was picked up early and there's every chance you're fixed.  Wishing you all the best

Posts.Content: As regulars on here would know I'm a complete knitted knocker convert. I love mine and wouldn't think of using anything else. I've had a full mastectomy, but I don't see any reason why you couldn't use a partly stuffed knocker to even up your boobs. You can order from knitted knockers UK and then just take some of the stuffing out or knit for yourself. The pattern is easy to find on the internet but I can give it to you if you can't locate it.  Importantly, you can pin the knocker inside your bra so you don't get any wardrobe malfunctions.

Posts.Content: When I first met my oncologist, he made it very clear to me that speculating about how and why I got cancer is pointless. His view is that, other than specific identified links (like asbestos and lung cancer), they simply don't know enough to be able to say anything for certain. His view is that you can waste a lot of emotional energy and indeed your life beating yourself up about it. It was a refreshing and very heartening conversation with a very good sympatico doctor.

Posts.Title: Breast Tissue

Posts.Content: Hi Sue. I had a port for about 18 months. It was no trouble at all and I was able to do anything I wanted - no dangly bits hanging around to look after. I had mine inserted on my chest on the good side just above my boob, but a number of people had them inserted underneath the boob on their good side, so the scar didn't show. That seemed to work fine too.  The only issue is that some ports won't give ie you can have any infusion through the port but it won't give blood. That happened to a few people I came across. Then they had to have their bloods done using a vein - I did that mostly anyway as I have good veins and it was quicker than accessing the port.  I highly recommend a port if it's on offer.

Posts.Title: Bleeding on tamoxifen and Zolodex

Posts.Content: Oh I had the same problem with T and took loperamide on the advice of my onco. In fact he told me also to take a couple of tablets as a prophylactic on the morning of my T. I did that and then took 2 the following morning after each treatment. Solved the problem, although I would occasionally take another if I felt my stomach "grumbling".  I think the serious risk  of dehydration is a worse problem than the possibility of damaging your gut so make sure you drink as much as you can. Two litres a day and 3 litres in the first 24 hours after treatment or if you have diarrhea. I had 3 x 750ml bottles which I'd fill each morning. That way I could keep track of how much I'd managed to drink.  And just to give you a laugh - I'll never forget spending Christmas morning cleaning up cos I didn't make it to the loo in time. Not my finest moment!!!! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: overactive bowel

Posts.Content: I have to say I'm not really a believer in alternative therapies. I do think that you need to give yourself the best chance by creating an internal environment that isn't conducive to the cancer cells - all that blah blah we've been told forever: healthy diet, low alcohol consumption, moderate exercise, no smoking and so on - but beyond that I'm not a fan! In fact I get really cross with some of the stuff promoted on places like facebook cos as far as I can see they're taking advantage of people who are in a bad place and often fleecing them.  The pseudo-science makes me mad too. I mean articles that use scientific language but if you read carefully, it's actually bullsh*t with little adherence to real scientific principles. And of course, if coconut oil or turmeric or whatever the latest fad might be really cured cancer, wouldn't scientists have worked it out and big pharma made money out of it??? Conventional treatment: surgery, chemo, radio, AIs, targeted therapies,actually works; maybe not in every case, but in the vast majority of BC cases. That's why they're conventional. And as my onco said - they're trying to fix you up, not kill you.  Anyway, rant over. I know a lot of people feel strongly about alternatives and good luck to them, but not for this little black duck. Best to all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you Carolyn28 The article seems to confirm my earlier fears about what Professor Plant is advocating! I knew already that soy isn't the best thing for women who've had ER+ BC, as it contains high levels of a plant-based oestrogen type hormone. The jury's still out on whether that affects women in the same way as their own oestrogen but why not avoid it. Mind you I still drink soy sauce lol, especially the sweet Indonesian one kecap manis.  Karen Lacomtekp - maybe you should switch to lentil burgers! I make them regularly using brown or puys lentils. Delicious.  I was the poster girl for bad living - high responsibility, high stress job, too much alcohol, smoking, way overweight, too much fat and sugar (both yummy of course, especially cake and cheese, not necessarily together), love my red meat, zero exercise. I always thought I'd have a health train wreck at some point. Funny thing is, I thought I'd probably have a heart attack as bad hearts run in the family but my heart is perfectly healthy! And there's no cancer on either side so who can tell. Unlike you though, Carolyn, I've always loved my food - good, bad or indifferent. I loved school dinners as it was a chance for an extra meal lol.  So now, I'm being well-behaved. I have mostly cut out the junk food (except I allow myself chips once a month and a cake on alternate fortnights). We have always eaten a lot of veggies as my husband is a former vegetarian. He grew up as a vegetarian but started eating meat after he met me. I think that has more to do with living in Australia than anything else as the meat here is good quality and relatively cheap. Now though, I make far more purely veggie meals and we eat a lot of pulses. I still eat meat and dairy, but I limit the amount of cheese and I haven't had alcohol for over a year. I've also started exercising every day.This was more for rehab after my period of great unwellness but I've managed to keep it going since November 2015.  I still love my food and I've found my slightly revised diet a fascinating challenge - all those different delicious meals to cook. My current favourite cookbook is Jerusalem by Yotam Ottolenghi and another chap. Brilliant, slightly different and out there food and full of healthy pulses and vegetables. Highly recommend.  All in all, I am fit, I've lost 38kg (5 stone), I'm healthy and I'm happy with that. I don't feel a need to become more rigorous with any of those boring diet or exercise thingys and as ronstar said, I'd prefer to focus on the positives - what I want and need to do and be, rather than restricting myself and focusing on negatives. Love to all Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hi Vonnie - sorry to hear you're struggling with osteo. I have a bit in my spine but none of the supplements do any good. I tried glucosamine for several months but apparently it only works on about 40% of people. Frankly, the best thing for me has been regular paracetamol.  And as for nails, mine have been delaminating and flaking ever since I had chemo (Aug 15 to Jan 16). I bought some IBX treatment a couple of weeks ago to use at home, but haven't yet found the time to do it as you basically can't use your hands for 2 hours. However, I've noticed in the last week that my nails have suddenly stopped flaking. I don't know why as I've not used any different creams or anything. Maybe just maybe they're finally recovering. If so, it means you've only got a couple of months to go. Unused IBX kit anyone?

Posts.Content: At one of my very early appointments, my onco told the story of one of his patients who, 10 years after diagnosis and successful treatment, is still obsessed with why she got cancer. He was essentially telling me not to waste energy on wondering why or how I got it but to get on with my life. He said that, apart from some specific causes of certain cancers, they don't know the exact causes. All they can look at is risk factors. He has also been very strong on not becoming extreme in my diet but rather concentrate on eating reasonably healthily and avoiding junk food.  Best Lynn xx

And here she is going about her life, happily married, adult kids, successful career and so on.
