Posts.Title: Back to work - another box ticked

Posts.Content: Hi Mirabo I'm so glad to hear your infection has cleared up and hopefully your next surgery will sort you out.  As toxophilite said, you're very welcome here. There are people from all round the world, apart from me in Australia - France, Ireland, South Africa to name a few. I agree about the different terminology - I had the same problem at first. I think we use some British terminology and some American (probably not surprising). You do get used to it eventually but if there's anything that's not quite clear, just ask - someone will know. Yes radiation = radiotherapy and my favourite - in the US and Aust we say lumpectomy, but in the UK they say WLE, which stands for wide local excision; it took me ages to work that one out as it's not obvious.  I looked at various groups in the US and in Australia but none matches up to Macmillan in my opinion. Mainly because there's a real culture of friendliness and empathy in this group. People won't be able to help you with issues relating to things like health insurance but then I can't help people with their National Health Service issues. I haven't found that to be a problem. So hey you're a valued member of our community. Please don't think you need to leave. Best

Posts.Content: Definitely get yourself checked out JackieHK. Shortness of breath may be low red blood cell count, which if really bad means you'll be given a transfusion. Worse is that it's a pulmonary embolism. I had them and ended up in ICU for a fortnight and in the oncology ward for a further two weeks!  Please ring your team or go to A&E as soon as you can.
Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: There are several different chemo drugs they can use, so a frank conversation is needed with your oncologist as soon as possible. I too had terrible problems with dexmethasone and had the dose reduced significantly so as flopsy said, it may not be the paclitaxel.  If you can, I'd suggest reading up a bit about paclitaxel, docetaxel, allergic reactions and alternative drug regimes. If the technical stuff doesn't float your boat, perhaps you have a friend or family member who you can get to do the reading for you. My husband read all the scientific papers during my chemo which was enormously helpful. And just in case you continue with the paclitaxel ... I only had 9 doses, because of peripheral neuropathy. My onco was quite satisfied that this was sufficient. I never got a week off either! All the best Lynn xx

Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: Hi Jen. First of all, don't apologise for being here. You are very welcome. It's a tough question you've asked! The only guaranteed diagnostic tool is a biopsy and even that can be wrong if the sample is taken from a part of a lump that only has benign tissue. However, ultrasounds and MRIs give very good pictures and radiologists and oncologists look at hundreds of these pictures so I'm pretty sure they know what they're looking at the majority of the time. There are of course rare cases where they get it wrong, but usually if they have any suspicion they will order a biopsy.  However, if you remain concerned then you should push for a biopsy. I do know at least one person Carolyn28 whose cancer was missed during scans. I've tagged her in case she has something to add. Could you afford to go private just for this bit? If not, then I'd ask for a second opinion. Apart from anything else, you'll just keep worrying unless you have a definitive answer.

Posts.Title: Milk Thistle

Posts.Content: Hi Baki As I understand it, hydration is different for everyone. If your wee is pale silvery green then your drinking enough, if it's yellow or brown, you're not. Simple as that. As for specific rules for chemo ... I was told to drink 3 litres in the 24 hours following chemo and 2 litres every other day. This included soup and herbal teas but not regular tea or coffee. I used to go get my bloods done early in the morning (about 7.30) so I'd drink about 500 ml beforehand to make sure my veins were plump. To make the counting easier I had 2 x 750 ml bottles which I'd fill each morning and made sure to drink them during the day. The balance came from OJ, soup and fruit tea. My creatine level was out of whack during chemo (I can't remember whether it was high or low lol) but neither my onco nor my GP were concerned as they expected it to settle in the months following chemo and herceptin. My GP will do a blood test 12 months after I finished H and check it then.  Hugs

Posts.Content: The only foods I avoided while on chemo were blue cheese, soft cheese, seafood, raw egg products and anything that tends to sit around for a while eg sushi. Posts.Content: I was told by my radio oncologist and my surgeon that as long as you start radio within 4 months of finishing chemo there is no appreciable increase in risk of recurrence.  My delay was caused by needing further surgery so I had to also wait for that to heal. In the end it was a gap of 11 weeks, which the docs were very happy with.  I'm pretty sure that I read some literature that supported the docs' view - probably on the NIH site as that's basically all I read.

In fact I might ask him next time if I can resume taking it ...
Posts.Title: Milk Thistle

Posts.Content: Sounds very familiar but my breast swelling started when I was carrying a lot of fluid from chemo. Docs told me it would settle but it hasn't. 3 months later, I'm now told I had a seroma which has septated (ie developed a lot of fibrous tissue), meaning they can't drain it. Unfortunately I now have to have surgery to clean it all out. So the moral of the story is get on to it as soon as you can and don't take no for an answer.  What I really wanted to tell the lovely ladies is that I've found a couple of really helpful items online. Firstly a gentle compression garment that looks like a shirred sun top - not medical at all. Secondly a pad that goes underneath it with thin and thick bits to get the lymph moving. Both have helped, especially to keep my skin in good nick. Happy to share details if anyone's interested.

Posts.Content: Hi Baduki1. It's not easy is it, having to make this decision when you know not a lot about the consequences of the different options. I know that when I had my first surgery, I was still bewildered by the diagnosis and found it really difficult to analyse anything objectively.  I started out with a saved skin mastectomy and immediate reconstruction with implant. I had a lovely perky breast and healed quickly and all in all I was very happy with it. However, I got really ill during chemo and put on a lot of fluid (about 10kg). Eventually it all went, except in my reconstructed breast, which was like a football on my chest. Lots of things were tried but eventually I had to have it sorted out with surgery as the implant had distorted. By that time, I was so sick of the whole business that I told my surgeon to just chop it off. She did so, but did try to persuade me to have another reconstruction, both then and when I've seen her since.  I'm quite happy with one breast and I doubt I'll ever bother with reconstruction. I don't feel any less feminine; rather in a peculiar way, I feel more feminine - along the lines of they can take my boob but I'm still a woman. So overall, I'm pretty happy with life right now and just grateful to be healthy.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Choices....Any Thoughts?

Posts.Content: Love those bears Snowys Mum and the baby blanket Over70. Still haven't managed to get round to taking photos of my efforts. As for knitted knockers, I don't wear anything else. I love that they mean I can wear ordinary bras. I've made several, including a couple filled with shower scrunchies for swimming. I always pin them inside my bra/swimmers so no chance of a wardrobe malfunction. Through trial and error, I've found that a good quality acrylic is the best yarn to use. Wool can be a bit scratchy, especially on my radiated side, and cotton (which I used for my first swimming knocker) takes too long to dry. I have also found that DK/8 ply wool is easier than 4ply and I start with 3 stitches on each needle and sew the little hole up to make a "nipple". Much less fiddly than dealing with 1 stitch on each needle and just as effective.  Happy crafting everyone.

Posts.Content: Problems with tendons are a know SE of arimidex and the other AIs unfortunately. I developed what's called de Quervain's tenosynovitis at the base of my thumb - basically an inflammation of the tendon sheath. Had to stop crafting for a while. I wore a thumb splint for about 6 weeks and that has basically fixed it up. I was offered a steroid injection which apparently fixes it in a few days but steroids and I don't get on so I declined as it wasn't essential treatment. I now wear an elasticised wrist support with a loop over the thumb for my craft activities and similar, just for protection.

Posts.Content: Hi Jacster The stats always seem depressing so I tend to ignore them. As Carolyn28 once said, for each individual it's either 0 or 100 anyway. We just do what we can to lower the risk. I had stage 3, grade 3, HER2+ with 14/30 lymph nodes involved. The onco said it was a "nasty aggressive cancer" so I decided to take whatever they offered - surgery, node clearance, ACT chemo, Herceptin, AIs, and denusomab injections for the bones so far. And I'll take anything else he suggests too. Plus I take metformin for diabetes and statins for cholesterol - both supposedly have anti-cancer properties. However, here I am 18 months from diagnosis and fit and healthy. Long may it continue! Best Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hi Bjez - sounds like you're feeling pretty rough. If you had all those drugs at the same time it's no wonder! Hard to know whether it's just side effects or something more serious - I didn't have the same combo so I've no direct experience.  The most important thing though is are you checking your temperature regularly? Please don't hesitate to go to A&E if you're running a temp (some places say 38 and some 37.5C). If you have an infection it's really important to get antibiotics into you quickly as your white blood cell count will be low by now.  Let us know how you get on in the next day or so and in the meantime, look after yourself. Best Lynn xx

Posts.Content: HI Frances kumihimo I just use the 4 needle one on the US knitted knocker site.  All the patterns (knit and crochet) are on this page: www.knittedknockers.org/.../  Scroll down past all the video tutorials and the pattern you need is the fourth one "our original pattern". The conversions are  4 ply yarn, No 10 or 3.25mm needles  Double knit/8 ply yarn, no 8 or 4 mm needles (the instructions for this are in brackets).   I find using DK/8 ply acrylic gives the best result. I have used cotton but it's heavy and takes ages to dry. It works perfectly well if you start with 3 stitches on each needle and just sew up the tiny hole. It's also much less fiddly.

Posts.Title: One stop breast clinic

Posts.Content: Yes Katedw32 it was rough there for a while but I'm completely fine now (although I still get tired if I overdo it). I've chosen to confront all the nasties that happened to me head on and deal with it that way. It's much the same as choosing to go commando when I had no hair. I'm even thinking of volunteering at the ICU as I reckon I'd be a shining example of how someone can recover and might give some hope to some of the poor people whose loved ones are where I was.  I'm in Australia so I had a choice of public or private treatment more or less automatically. I ended up having a mix of both - I had radio in the public system as that's all that's offered here in Canberra, presumably because of the cost of the machines. And when I had my period of great unwellness, my onco wanted me to be in the big public teaching hospital so the full range of specialists was instantly available. Fortunately he practises there and privately so he was in charge of my treatment in both systems.  As someone wise once said worry about the things you can control and don't worry about those you can't.  I know you're not quite finished with treatment but do read this article by Peter Harvey. I found it extremely helpful After The Treatment Finishes - Then What ? Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: One stop breast clinic

Posts.Content: Yep chemo is horrible Felen! I had horrible side effects, both from the chemo and the steroids - so severe I ended up in ICU for 2 weeks, followed by another 2 weeks on the ward. Everyone's journey is different though as I didn't get most of the standard SEs - no nausea, mouth ulcers, infection so I'm thankful for that. The good news is that I finished chemo 8 weeks ago and now feel terrific, although I'm slightly anaemic still. The body has a marvellous capacity to recover!  Careful with the internet - there's a lot of rubbish out there. I suggest you stick with the reliable sites like here, the cancer research one, a couple of American sites like cancer.org and the Mayo clinic. They won't lead you astray but remember not to rely on Dr Google - he's very scary. And as for your hubbie - don't feel guilty. For better for worse and all that. Truly, as George said, most men are glad to help rather than feel useless - I know mine is. And if he's not then that's his problem.  Wishing you well for the rest of your journey. Lynn

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz - I bet a day after your first chemo you'll be thinking 'what was I worried about'. I certainly did. You sound rather like me - I hadn't been to a doctor for about 20 years until I found my lump nor to the dentist for about 15 years! Mainly cos I don't like either! I really struck lucky though. I went to a walk in clinic and waited in the queue only to get a fabulous Irish doctor who'd come to Oz because of the GFC. He's been my best friend through all of this - including saving my life by recognising that I had an embolism. The only point I'd add in relation to teeth/dentists is that the mouth is one of the easiest ways to get an infection when your immune system is low. If not going to the dentist, make sure you have a rigorous mouth washing routine right from day 1 - several times a day, esp after eating. I was given bicarb soda mouthwash by the cancer centre and it was fantastic. No mouth problems all the way through. I don't know if you can buy it in France or whether they'll give it to you but there are plenty of recipes on the Internet.  I have a portacath and haven't regretted it for a minute. No trouble at all and you can do anything - shower, swim etc cos it's completely under your skin. There's a sharp sting from the needle when they access the port but it's momentary. I've heard that some people are given anasthetic patches to put on beforehand so if you're worried, perhaps ask for them. Best of luck Lynn xxx
Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Tansi. I'm so sorry to hear about your mum's diagnosis. It must be a worrying time for her, you and the rest of the family. I also apologise for not replying sooner. My only excuse is that there has been a bit of difficulty recently with the notifications (computers, sigh) and somehow your post slipped through the net.  I had spread to the axillary nodes but not further.I did have radiotherapy to the supraclavicular fossa area in addition to the usual chest RT as the docs were concerned about possible spread to the lymph nodes there. No one mentioned the chest nodes though! I don't know whether that counts as local spread or distant metastases.  Let me say first that I have no medical training whatsoever, and only know what I've picked up from being a patient and from long conversations with my oncologist. I do know though that the most likely places BC will spread to are the bones, lungs, liver and brain. Occasionally you hear of spread somewhere else eg someone was talking about eye metastases a few months back, but that's very rare. What I also know is that, while metastatic breast cancer is considered incurable, it is not untreatable. There are many ladies with metastatic BC on this forum who have been living with good quality of life for several years.  Radiotherapy does deliver good results in preventing further spread. It's also not as tough on the body as chemo so it may well be a good option for your mum. I sailed through radio but nearly died during chemo!  I'm sorry I can't give you more info about chest node involvement.   I'm tagging Dreamthief, a very experienced champion in the breast group, in case he is able to give you more information.  You could also post a question in the Ask a Nurse section of this site as there are some pretty experienced nurses looking after that section.  Please do stick around. We're actually a friendly bunch and happy to provide ongoing support to both patients and their carers. Wishing your mum and the rest of the family all the best.

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz. It's a tough call for you and I won't be telling you what to do, just what my thinking has been. I decided early on that I would do everything  I could to reduce the risk of the BC returning - that's meant surgery, chemo, radio, herceptin, AIs and Denusomab injections so far - and I'll take whatever else is on offer. My view is that each of these treatments reduces your risk by a few percentage points and all those percentage points add up. I would hate myself if I didn't do something and the cancer came back. I was 61 at diagnosis and want as many years as possible. Also very importantly, I took into account my husband's point of view. I believe that it's not just my decision, it's about our life together. I had a very horrible time with chemo - nearly died from atrial fibrillation and pulmonary embolisms which caused respiratory arrest and other nasties. Despite that I would do it all over again in a flash. Finally for Carolyn - Here in Australia the cops will happily book you for doing a couple of km over the limit and so do the speed cameras lol. Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hi Fatpuffin The basic answer to your question is that yes it is completely normal to feel grotty 7 months after chemo etc. I was told it can take up to 2 years to recover fully.  All of these drugs (tamoxifen, Zoladex and the three aromatase inhibitors) will also make you feel below par in some way, at least initially, as the oestrogen is stripped out of your body. Different people find different ones better though and it's a question of working with your onco to find what works best for you.  I don't know much about tamoxifen as it's usually used for pre-menopausal women, and I definitely wasn't pre-menopausal. If you're pre-menopausal or peri-menopausal, the docs (I think) are probably considering something in addition to letrozole for you, perhaps Zoladex? It's all a bit complicated so you need to have a full discussion with your onco before agreeing to anything. As for the AIs (letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane) at least the first two can cause bone thinning (I don't know about exemestane). Normal practice is for you to have a bone density scan before you start to get a baseline on the condition of your bones. Many women are also prescribed a bone strengthening drug at the same time, often a biphosphonate like zoledronic acid. I have been having denusomab injections instead as that apparently reduces the risk of bone mets more than biphosphonates. However, I read in the 'Ask the Expert' section a few months back that it's not available for this purpose in the UK, except if you're on a trial. I'm in Australia where it's not available either in the sense that the government won't pay for it, but I chose to pay!  The upside is that the AIs have less risk of other serious side effects like heart attack or stroke than Tamoxifen so it's swings and roundabouts.  I found letrozole difficult - I was very achy and sometimes could hardly move. I switched to anastrozole which was better but I was still a bit achy. Then I managed to get the pharmacist to give me the real Arimidex rather than a generic and I've been fine ever since.  So the bottom line is that it takes a bit of trial and error to find the right drug, but it's worth persevering as the benefits are huge for hormone positive cancer.  Wishing you all the best Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hi Croxley I understand your dilemma but I'm not a shining example. I had issues with my bad boob and the implant and ultimately chose to have a mastectomy, which I don't regret.  Reading your post though my main question is why do you have to decide straight away? Often the answer becomes clearer over time. One option might be to tell yourself that you'll live with it for 3 or 6 months, or even a year, and then make a decision. Then shut the door on it and go live your life for a while.  I believe Carolyn28 had implant problems too so I've tagged her.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Need help with decision

Posts.Content: Hi vera68 It's horrid for you that the goalposts have moved. I think that much of the way we cope with treatment is due to having a clear treatment plan that we accept and can plod our way through. Any changes are emotionally very tough and I feel for you.  I can't explain why you may not need radio as most people seem to have it. Is your cancer very early eg Stage 1 with no node spread or DCIS? Have you had a good result from chemo? I imagine these issues will factor into your team's recommendation. Definitely something to discuss with your onco - and keep pushing until you get clear answers that you're satisfied with.  I've not seen many people ask about the pros and cons of radio - people are generally less worried about that than about chemo. However, I think my response is the same as with chemo. I'm a believer in throwing everything at it to minimise the chances of recurrence. Every little percentage point adds up.  I don't think delaying surgery is a good idea, even if your son is coming up for exams. Your team wouldn't recommend it if it wasn't necessary. A mastectomy these days is pretty straightforward and people don't stay in hospital for very long. Much of the complication comes from the type of reconstruction you choose as some are more complex than others and take longer to recover from. I was only in hospital overnight and my drain was in for 3 days but I didn't have reconstruction. Others will be able to tell you how long they were in hospital for different kinds of reconstruction and how long the recovery period was. Are you planning to have immediate reconstruction? Is there any chance that, if you've had a good response to chemo, they might only recommend a WLE - this might be something else to raise with your onco? Wishing you all the best.

Posts.Title: Need help with decision

Posts.Content: Hi zizza Welcome aboard the roller coaster. Let's hope your stay here is really short, in the best possible way of course. It's no surprise that you are worried - facing a possible cancer diagnosis is probably one of the scariest things we have to face, and the waiting for results is awful. I won't tell you not to worry as obviously you will but try not to let it take over.  You're right - about 90% of breast lumps aren't cancer and even if it does turn out to be, it is very treatable despite you having lost a couple of friends. Where I live, over 96% of people survive at least 5 years and those that don't mostly had something else wrong with them or were very old. (It's a compact bijou community of about 400 000 people and the researchers have been tracking all BC patients for 15 years).  Take things one step at a time. Wait for your results, then you can either celebrate or deal with the next phase. Do come back and let us know either way. You'll find plenty of help and support here if you need it. Hoping it all goes well.

Posts.Content: Radio is a breeze compared to chemo. Only one person I've come across in the forum has had difficulties. It's annoying having to go every day but the time soon passes.  Let me know what your onco says. Best
Posts.Title: Possibly no Radiotherapy but surgery very soon..Yikes I'm not ready...

Posts.Content: Hi zizza Welcome aboard the roller coaster. Let's hope your stay here is really short, in the best possible way of course. It's no surprise that you are worried - facing a possible cancer diagnosis is probably one of the scariest things we have to face, and the waiting for results is awful. I won't tell you not to worry as obviously you will but try not to let it take over.  You're right - about 90% of breast lumps aren't cancer and even if it does turn out to be, it is very treatable despite you having lost a couple of friends. Where I live, over 96% of people survive at least 5 years and those that don't mostly had something else wrong with them or were very old. (It's a compact bijou community of about 400 000 people and the researchers have been tracking all BC patients for 15 years).  Take things one step at a time. Wait for your results, then you can either celebrate or deal with the next phase. Do come back and let us know either way. You'll find plenty of help and support here if you need it. Hoping it all goes well.
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy result - just need to vent

Posts.Content: The best news Zizza. I'm so happy for you.
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy result - just need to vent

Posts.Content: The best news Zizza. I'm so happy for you.
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy result - just need to vent

Posts.Content: I suffered quite a lot with indigestion while I was on doxirubicin (equivalent to the epirubicin or the E in FEC). I was very gassy and had a lot of cramping. I found a mix of indigestion remedies and ginger tea helped a lot. I just about lived on canned tomato soup for that period as that was all I could stomach. Pretty much stopped as soon as I finished the doxi treatments.
Posts.Title: sickness and indigestion

Posts.Content: *ranitidine
Posts.Title: sickness and indigestion

Posts.Content: Hi mistyblue I hope that you feel a bit more settled now that things have been explained to you. Of course any cancer is bad news, but as it goes this is pretty ok. 2 cm is small and most importantly it hasn't spread. This means your chances of getting rid of it and it not coming back are very good.  I'm not sure why you want a double mastectomy and no reconstruction. Do think carefully about it. They can do a pretty good job with recon these days as I'm sure many ladies on here will tell you. I had a mastectomy eventually (long story) but would have loved to keep my fake boob really. And why the double? Is that what the docs are recommending or are you just thinking that it will prevent the cancer coming back? It won't. It'll prevent cancer in that boob obviously but BC can potentially spread to many parts of the body. Now try to enjoy yourself until you see the consultant and not too much checking of Dr Google - he can be very frightening. Oh and by the way, our current favourite cake isn't a cake but peach pie, made with sweet pastry and lovely fresh peaches, which are abundant here in Australia at the moment, flavoured with cardamom. Mmmmm delicious. Best
Posts.Title: What type of breast cancer

Posts.Content: And on the subject of heart attacks, my father died of one and my mother and two brothers all had heart attacks at 48,47 and 51. I always thought that would be my fate but I got breast cancer instead (no cancer of any kind on either side of the family). I did have one heart issue during chemo but that was fixed pretty easily. I also had regular echocardiograms and monitoring by the cardiologist because I was HER2+. Last time I saw the cardiologist he told me that my heart is strong and I've got nothing to worry about. Can't tell with genetics! May I suggest that if you're really concerned about heart issues then you ask for a cardiology consult before starting chemo. That should put your mind at rest.

Posts.Content: Good news Bedy. I too was having breathing problems and just got worse and worse so keep pushing! All the best. Lynn

Posts.Content: Hi Tiger. Do check out the monthly chemo club thread. Included in dreamthief's first post is a link to a blog with tips and suggestions from members. The chemo club is also a place where you can share/commiserate with others going through chemo at the same time as you. Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: New chemo starter

Posts.Content: Hi mistyblue I completely understand you worrying - it's perfectly normal. A diagnosis of breast cancer is probably the most scary thing that's ever happened to you. I can't tell you to stop worrying cos you won't but do try not to let it take over. Take out the worry daily, have a good look at it for a short while and then put it away till tomorrow. Keep yourself busy and do some of your favourite things.  It's hard to speculate what not normal breast cancer means. There are several different kinds so I'm not sure which one is the "normal" one. The main things to remember are that breast cancer is very very treatable and over 90% of people survive it. Those that don't are normally old, had other things wrong with them or were diagnosed too late. It doesn't sound like you fit in any of those categories.  Wishing you all the best

Posts.Title: Sore mouth

Posts.Content: I too have indoor cats and managed to look after them and their litter trays all the way through chemo. I was extremely careful with hygiene and like jacks77 I had alcohol handwash everywhere and I made everyone use it. I also always made sure to wipe the kitchen bench down with spray and wipe just before any meal prep. I still patted and played with my cats and they still slept on my bed. I had plenty of issues during chemo but thankfully infection wasn't one of them.  To chemo or not to chemo is difficult. No one loves chemo but it isn't awful for everyone. There are plenty of people who get through it relatively unscathed and I suspect that we don't hear as much from them.  I agree with whoever suggested getting your pathology report. Having all the facts will help make a sensible decision.

As for the moving prosthesis, I use knitted knockers, which I love as they're so comfortable and I just pin them in place with a couple of safety pins. I never get any movement, including in swimmers.
Posts.Title: Bra problem

Posts.Content: tiger-777 Hi, I just googled knitted knockers, they look great, thanks for telling us about them, can you get them in the UK? Yes. This is the site. https://www.kkukciowix.com/ If you can knit or crochet, or someone you know can, then the patterns are on the US website.
Posts.Title: Bra problem

Posts.Content: Well I got to the point where I hated water but I don't think it was anywhere near as bad as your situation Jo. I couldn't stomach any milk or milk product so that restricted me a bit! What worked for me were freshly squeezed orange juice (or rather blended to within an inch of it's life in the Vitamix); ginger tea - cold, kept in fridge, helped with the minor feelings of nausea that I"d occasionally get too; and surprisingly Ribena, which I normally can't stand; coffee and tea both awful so I got a selection of herbal teas the best of which had rose hip in them.  I pretty much lived on tomato soup but as you can't bear that, it might be worth trying a few other soups as it's such an easy meal to prepare, eat and digest. Chicken broth would be both nourishing and hydrating.  Best of luck with it. I remember how hard it can be.
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: Oh mine's a pretty sad tale really Jo. I had pulmonary embolisms, atrial fibrillation, steroid-induced diabetes, ischemic liver, overactive thyroid. In other words, pretty much a system crash. Docs weren't sure which came first but were certain that chemo exaggerated every symptom causing me to crash. This all happened from treatment 3 of 4 of AC (like EC). And crash I did - respiratory failure, 3 days in a coma, 2 weeks in ICU and 2 weeks on the general ward. When I left hospital, I couldn't walk more than about 10 metres ie struggled to get from the car to the house. But hey I'm fine now - fitter than I've been for 20 years. It was nearly two years ago though. You should be allowed home soon I'd imagine. They'll probably wait till you have a big wee!
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: My hubby, who suffers from depression and anxiety anyway, was indeed beside himself. He's English and doesn't have any family here in Oz but fortunately a couple of my friends and my brother stepped up and looked after him. We're indebted to them. The only thing I probably had beforehand was an overactive thyroid. The steroids caused diabetes, the chemo caused atrial fibrillation, which in turn caused pulmonary embolisms. I was having dose dense AC (doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide, every 2 weeks) at the time, which is a pretty tough chemo regime. (Doxorubicin is a close cousin of epirubicin, which is more commonly used in the UK).  I did find out though as a result of all the tests that I'm deficient in something called Protein C. This means that I'm more prone than normal to blood clots. It means I'm on warfarin for the rest of my life but the good thing is that I'm less likely to have a stroke or get DVT from eg flying so every cloud has a silver lining as that wouldn't have been picked up otherwise. I remember when I was a kid one of my dad's party tricks was that he didn't bleed when he was cut. We all thought it was amazing at the time but now I realise that's where I got the Protein C deficiency from! The whole episode has made me much more aware of shortness of breath, which I had for weeks before I crashed. I and my onco and the chemo nurses thought it was a pretty normal SE, as a lot of shortness of breath in chemo patients is caused by low red blood cell count. I'm on to it immediately if anyone in this forum complains of shortness of breath. It might be low red blood cells but it could be a pulmonary embolism and needs to be checked. I'm also very aware of steroids and diabetes. My glucose level went up to 30+ at the worst time, when it should be 5 or less. Even after this period when I had my T chemo and had to have a minimal steroid dose, my blood glucose would go up to about 15 for 48 hours. I don't think we're told enough about this before chemo starts. I should also say that I wouldn't hesitate to have chemo again if I got a recurrence, although I'd probably ask the onco to design a regime that didn't include doxorubicin. And, I'd certainly be much more aware of symptoms/side effects.  Sorry that was probably far too long and boring but it's hard to tell part of the story.  Best
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi Chaffinch17 It took me pretty close to 6 months to really get over the PEs, so your dad has a way to go! I can understand your mum worrying and I guess it's possibly you have inherited a clotting problem from your dad, like I did. Still, at least you're alert to it. Make sure you drink loads and try to keep exercising a bit (one of my mistakes was that I became far too sedentary). Also be very alert to breathlessness and report it to the onco and nurses immediately. You may need to be quite insistent as they'll probably say it's just a usual SE, as they did for me (and of course it may be) and do tell them you have a family history of PEs. It might be worth mentioning that to the onco anyway, as it may be preferable for you to have a PICC line or portacath, rather than having to have chemo through the veins in your arm, as that brings a risk of clots too.  Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi flopsyuk. Can't say I've got the same - no nipple lol. It does sound like scar tissue though. Does it hurt?  I used medihoney and biooil on my scar. Worked a treat. Now all I have is a white line. For some reason I got keloid scarring where my portacath was inserted. That took about 6 months to disappear with the bio-oil but it wasn't sore at all  Best
Posts.Title: Misshapen nipple after Rads - anyone else?

Posts.Content: Hi dl99 I had achiness (is that a word?) and tiredness all through Herceptin. At the time I put it down to anastrozole but I definitely improved once H finished. I still have achy joints if I sit for too long but otherwise I'm ok.  Are you taking an AI or tamoxifen as well?
Posts.Title: Aches n pains

Posts.Content: Hi Bedy. Sorry to hear you've had nasty side effects. But remember everyone's journey is different. I had terrible side effects from the red devil (up to and including respiratory failure and 2 weeks in ICU) but on the taxane I had virtually none! Same goes for the hormone inhibitors. It varies enormously between people and between drugs but I've not heard that any cause hair loss like chemo. My onco told me he'd start me on letrozole cos it's the best for my situation but if I get awful side effects he'll try different ones till I find something I'm happy with.  Best advice I can give you is to be assertive - look out for your own interests and ask for a change if the tamoxifen isn't good for you. Wishing you all the best.

Posts.Content: That's a shame Bedy - how irritating. I don't know why they're being so thingy about it.

Posts.Content: Yep unfortunately. The doxi/epirubicin makes your hair go faster than you can say bald. However, I was ill for a couple of months after that so my weekly paclitaxel was delayed and my hair started to grow back. 3 treatments in and I still have it (pathetic though it is).
Posts.Title: Different chemo regime options - any advice?

Posts.Content: Great news Anne. Time to celebrate.
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: HI Mom74 Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I'm sorry to hear you're feeling rough. It's hard to know how you'll deal with chemo - everyone seems to be different. For some they have a few bad days and are then ok for the rest of the cycle while others just get worse as time goes on. I was in the latter category during AC and in fact got really ill, but then the T part was comparatively easy and I felt not too bad. It can be the other way round too.  The most important thing is to drink loads of water - I was told to drink 3 litres in the 24 hours following a chemo treatment and then 2 litres every other day. Tea and coffee don't count but herbal teas, soup, soft drink all do. I found very diluted orange squash or Ribena was the easiest to get down. I had 3 x 750 ml bottles that I'd fill each morning so I could keep track of how much I was drinking. The second most important thing is to try to exercise, even if it's just a walk round the block. The more you can move the better you'll feel. I hate any kind of exercise but even I admit that's true.  Thirdly, be kind to yourself and don't struggle to do things. In the end it doesn't matter if the house isn't vacuumed or the kids occasionally get takeaway for dinner. Also, your husband is probably struggling too - it can be very tough on the blokes. My husband said that he struggled because he felt useless. As he put it, blokes are brought up to fix things but he couldn't fix this. I'm sure he's doing the best he can and be grateful that he's standing by you and being supportive - many aren't.  Lastly, it seems like a terrible mountain to climb right now but it does pass. You will get through it.  Wishing you all the very best
Posts.Title: Post Chemo - when will I start feeling better?

Posts.Content: Bedy I have two water tablets. Furosamide (which is quite strong and dramatic in terms of needing to wee) and Spiractin (spironolactone is the chemical) which is much more slow and steady. Spiractin is used to treat heart and kidney disease and doesn't decrease your potassium levels.  I don't have kidney problems (about the only thing I haven't had lol) but I did have heart and lung problems.Part of the reason why I was given water  tablets is because the docs were worried that I would develop fluid on the lung. Ironic isn't it!
Posts.Title: Tablets

Posts.Content: I got very ill from Dexmethazone while I was having my AC treatment. To cut a long story short the result has been atrial fibrillation, clots and steroid induced diabetes.  I'm now on the weekly paclitaxel phase of my treatment and have to have the wretched dex again (altho' I'm having 4mg rather than 20mg). I'm 3 weeks in but still very wary.  I'd be really interested to hear from anyone who has had problems with steroids,
Posts.Title: Steroids - adverse reaction

Posts.Content: I've never come across this before LondonLass but remember the advice we've all been given ie  that we should get any changes checked out ... Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Odd coloured breast?!

Posts.Content: I don't think being well-established is a bad thing. On the contrary, it probably means they know more about it - effectiveness, SEs and so on. I think they tend to save the newest, more experimental stuff in case the others don't work.  I'm in Australia but my daughter lives in Farnham so I know that part of Surrey reasonably well. toxophilite is from that part of the world too.
Posts.Title: Jumped to breast cancer secondary forum and had no responses to my...

Posts.Content: The third option sounds like what I am having. It was 4 treatments of doxirubicin and cyclophosphomide followed by 12 weekly treatments of paclitaxel. I found the Doxy/cyclo bit very punishing and got quite ill, but that was just me. However, it looks like doxi or epirubicin (very similar) are included in all 3 options. The weekly paclitaxel is pretty good. I tend to get random side effects occasionally (perhaps diahorrea for a day is the worst) but also achey bones and runny nose. Other than that, I have enough energy to do things like cook dinner, do the washing, go out for a coffee. Not 100% energy though. In terms of the drugs, there's not much difference between the three options.
Posts.Title: Different chemo regime options - any advice?

Posts.Content: Hi Mistia - as you can see we've all had meltdowns and it's ok. Don't worry, your mojo will be back - just be kind to yourself. As for blood sugars, it's mostly the steroids that cause blood sugar problems. I've had my dose of dexmethasone reduced to the minimum - just 4mg IV before infusion and no tablets. Seems to be controlling the problem although my BGL still spikes for 24 hrs. But to 15 not 25+ as it was doing before.
Posts.Title: Had a wobbly and almost lost it!

Posts.Content: Blimey Sophie you've got a keeper! My hubby was great throughout but he never did the litter trays, except when I was in hospital. So there I was with a mask and rubber gloves, nearly catatonic from fatigue during chemo, cleaning the wretched things.
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: My onco went through the images with me - mammo and ultrasound - and explained exactly what each blob was, both good and bad.  Also, I really didn't think I felt ill when I was diagnosed. However, now that I've been out the other side for several months, I realise that I wasn't really well for quite some time before diagnosis. Tired, listless, slightly breathless, lacking the mental energy to engage with anything. I'd put all the symptoms down to "getting old"; now I know there's no such thing and I feel at least 10 years younger.  Ask at your next appointment to see the scans. Best
Posts.Title: Tumour shrinkage and scan images

Posts.Content: Fantastic news. Makes the treatment all worthwhile. Big hug Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Good morning all it happend, I'm a grandma.

Posts.Content: Before finding my lump I thought I was perfectly ok, totally normal for an overweight, non-exercising 61 year old. Now that I've finished treatment and fully recovered, I realise that I wasn't ok at all. I was tired and lethargic all the time. I had just gotten used to coping with being that way. Now I have so much more energy and can do so many more things. I believe the cancer was sapping my energy and my spirit, without me realising.  Best
Posts.Title: Tiredness and aches.....

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear about your mini-stroke Chloecat. If it's any comfort, I know 3 people who've had them and they're all fine and living full and energetic lives with no permanent effects from the stroke. As for statins, I was never as anti them as some people are and took them when I was given them. . My total cholesterol was 6.something and at last test a couple of months back has gone down to 3.2. However, apparently they have a protective effect in relation to cancer, reducing the risk of recurrence quite a bit, according to recent research. That's made me decide to keep taking them. I don't know if it also applies to your situation, but they'd be neutral at least if not helpful.  Keep powering on.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Sounds good Sarah. You'll soon be an old lag at the chemo thing. You do get quite used to it. Hope it all goes really well for you. Lynn
Posts.Title: Treatment plan at long last

Posts.Content: Make sure you check the interactions between milk thistle and any drugs you're taking patrb as it's known to have quite a few interactions. My onco told me not to take it.  There is a US website that documents interactions but I can't remember the url or name. Perhaps Dreamthief can, as he was the person who led me to it initially.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi again CARDBOND I hadn't realised you are in that horrible twilight zone of waiting for results of tests. I think most people on here would agree it's the worst part, mentally at least, of diagnosis and treatment.  I think I knew as soon as I found my lump that it was BC. I'd had lumps previously and knew in my heart they were nothing to worry about. This time it was different - I just knew. My lovely GP immediately referred me for "mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy if indicated". Then when the radiologist walked into the room and said he was going to do a biopsy, I was absolutely certain it was cancer. All of this meant that I wasn't surprised, shocked or scared when I finally got the diagnosis. I'd done some research, talked to others and even decided which surgeon I was going to ask for. I also had an oncologist in mind but my surgeon (who is fabulous) strongly recommended someone else. I'm glad she did as he's been just the best.  Anyway, stay strong. The best advice I can give you right now is to take it all one step at a time and be kind to yourself. Wishing you all the very best
Posts.Title: Tiredness and aches.....

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you're having pain with RT chloecat45 It's not the most pleasant treatment but it clears up reasonably quickly once you finish (about a week for me). I had a bolus for every treatment (25 over 5 weeks) but it was quite heavy and they just laid it over the area to be radiated. Mind you I'd had a mastectomy so it was lying reasonably flat - nowhere for air pockets lol. I was told the purpose of it was to intensify the dose near the skin. They are also used to even out the dose if a lumpy or uneven area is being irradiated (think nose lol). So I doubt you're being told hogwash - not that I'm the big expert lol. You could always ask in the Ask an Expert section - they've got a radiographer at the moment.  Are the "plasters" Mepilex dressings? If not, kick up a fuss as they're what you need. I only had one small area, about the size of a pound coin, where the skin disintegrated due to skin on skin rubbing. It was very painful but once I got Mepilex dressings on it, no pain at all. The one I was given was Mepilex lite, which is for wounds that aren't oozing much. It's just like a very thin layer of foam but has a silicon coating so it adheres but doesn't stick. There are other Mepilex dressings for oozy wounds.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Good to hear you're ok Jo. Hope they let you out soon. My best hospital tip: in your hospital bag, pack tomato sauce or salad cream or whatever condiment floats your boat - makes hospital food taste so much better (I had both tomato sauce and balsamic salad dressing in my stash when I was hospitalised during chemo)
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: My dad passed away in 2004 at age 74, probably too young but he never ever went to a doctor. He just died sitting in front of his computer. The ambos said it was absolutely peaceful and he'd been healthy right up to that point, so we all think it was a good death, especially as he would have made a dreadful invalid. My mum is still alive but she has mid-stage dementia so she's living in an aged care facility and not really with it, although she does still know who we are and what's going on around her. Just very confused and forgetful. We live in Canberra. It's a great small city of about 400k people, very political as it's the seat of our parliament. Also beautiful - lots of trees and rules about not building on hill tops. Hubby is originally from Stourbridge in the Midlands, went to university in Coventry and lived in London before coming to Australia. His mum lives in Cornwall, right down the end between Penzance and Land's End. Always a great place to visit. I have an aunt living near Inverness and my foster-daughter lives in Surrey so when we visit next month we'll be travelling the length of the country. Keep an eye out for those PEs, although apparently it's a very rare SE thank goodness. Off to bed now.
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi Lavendergirl I'm really pleased that you have had successful treatment and that you have such faith in the NHS. It must be very comforting for you. As an outsider (I live in Australia) what I observe is that the majority of people on here who are in the UK are very happy with their treatment but there is a significant proportion who are not. I'm not saying this to diss the NHS but rather to say that it's important to understand what's happening to you and the treatments being offered, so that, if necessary, you can challenge what you are told or the treatment being offered (or not offered).  It's not that those of us who have read research papers (many many in my case) think that we know better than the scientists, or the doctors for that matter, it's more that knowledge gives us power, especially power over what's happening to us. And I have to say, the doctors and scientists are not gods - they don't necessarily get it right every time. One thing I've found throughout my cancer treatment is that it's important to be an assertive patient - after all, ultimately you are the person who has your best interests at heart and only you can know what's right for you.  Finally, to be honest (to use your words deliberately), I don't think it was particularly nice of you to fire a shot at we who study the research. If you don't like a post then move right along, no need to be offensive.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: My apologies. When I wrote my first comment, I thought this was a new thread. (I have issues with reading things thoroughly - comes from having an overbusy job for years). I now realise that it's been going for years and is really interesting. Thanks everyone for sharing your experiences.  Just one comment in response to someone who said that AC treatment isn't used in the UK as it kills people. AC is the gold standard here in Australia (and I think the USA), so it can't be killing too many people! Where I live there is a documented 93% 10 year survival rate with breast cancer. BTW I still don't regret opting for conventional treatment.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Great comment George
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat45 Good to hear you're still doing well. More power to you. I was 62 when I started AIs (first letrozole, then anastrozole) and hadn't had a period at all for about 5 or 6 years. I still got hot flushes/night sweats for the first few months, which was really annoying as I didn't get any when I went through the menopause. I understand it's because the AI strips out even more oestrogen from your body (the oestrogen produced other than by your ovaries) so it's like another menopause. I'm now a year into it and don't have any more. The only symptoms I have are that I find I need lighter bedcovers and I get quite stiff if I sit for an extended period eg a flight or going to the movies. However, I loosen up within a couple of minutes and am ok. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: That must be so upsetting for you Gail. Believe you can beat it again, as you have done before. All you can do is take it one step at a time and get through each stage before you start worrying about the next.  Mastectomy isn't that bad. I had a saved skin mastectomy and then a few months later (because of various problem but not failure of the implant) I had a full mastectomy by choice. Best decision ever and I am lopsided Lizzie with pride. I use a knitted knocker inside a preformed ordinary bra and it's impossible to tell when I'm dressed.  Best of luck

Posts.Content: I agree with you re pincushion. I have a Portacath rather than a PICC line but I'm so glad I do, especially only being able to use one arm/hand for bloods etc.

Posts.Content: Blimey Sophie you've got a keeper! My hubby was great throughout but he never did the litter trays, except when I was in hospital. So there I was with a mask and rubber gloves, nearly catatonic from fatigue during chemo, cleaning the wretched things.
Posts.Title: Support tips for men on how to support their partners the best way...

Posts.Content: I'm in Australia so the "cost-effective" NHS isn't an issue for me. I chose conventional treatment because I want to stay alive and that's the best chance I have. Over 90% chance of survival is good enough for me. Yes chemo is horrid, yes radio is tiring and yes surgery doesn't look the best at first but together they'll give you the best chance of survival.  I can understand that you felt pressured. The worst part of the journey for me was the loss of control - I have always been a leader not a follower and also never liked doctors (didn't go to a dr for over 20 years other than for travel vaccinations). That's all changed - my life is dominated by medical appointments. I don't like it but I accept it.  Please please opt for the conventional route. Even if your immune system has issues to deal with, at least you'll be alive to deal with them.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: mistymoley I call bullshit on Johanna Budwig. Flax oil and quark ffs!!! I particularly liked the testimonial from the Stage 4 BC patient, who said she was an holistic health counsellor before diagnosis. Fat lot of good that did her.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: You're very lucky your clot was found early chloecat45 I ended up spending 4 weeks in hospital because of PEs, including 2 weeks in ICU. It was apparently a mix of causes, including hyperthyroidism, diabetes (caused by the steroids) and atrial fibrillation (caused by the chemo doxorubicin). So my advice is keep a strict eye on your heart rate. If it goes over 100 resting, or you get palpitations, or get breathless, or feel that your pulse is uneven or thready then get checked out as soon as you can.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Oops I forgot to add that when I had AF, I couldn't really count the pulse in my wrist. I could feel it was there but there wasn't a regular beat.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Don't rush to two weekly epirubicin. I had 2 weekly doxorubicin and it was REALLY punishing -almost killed  me. However, I did then have weekly paclitaxel and was fine, except for peripheral neuropathy.  When I was given heparin, the doc told me to press down on the injection site  for a minute. Didn't get any bruises. You can also ice the site for 5 mins before and after. I've had 2 surgeries since starting blood thinners. The first I was just told not to take the blood thinner the evening after the surgery. The second, no change ie kept taking them as usual.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Lou I'm so sorry no one has responded to your request. Gemcetabine and carboplatin seems to be a well established combination for BC treatment (I saw articles about trials in 2004 - 2008). However, it doesn't appear to be used that often. I don't know why and there don't seem to be any articles dealing with its ongoing use.  That doesn't mean it's a bad treatment. From the little I know, the docs tend to try one drug or combo until that stops working, then try another and so on. Anyway, it maybe just that few forum members have been offered that combo.  May I ask where you're being treated? I hope it goes well for you.
Posts.Title: Jumped to breast cancer secondary forum and had no responses to my...

Posts.Content: Well intravenous fluid certainly solves your problem lol. The weight loss is of course fluid unfortunately. If you don't like tea or coffee then do try either ginger tea (just slice fresh ginger and steep it in boiling water) either hot or cold, or some of the herbals. Warm might be easier for you to swallow. And send hubby out for 200 packets of chicken noodle soup hahahahaha.  Things should settle down as you get into a routine. Can't say the rest will necessarily be a breeze though.  Take care

Posts.Content: Hi kdoohan7  I feel for you. This is what we all secretly, or not so secretly, worry about. At least your team seems to be on to it pretty promptly. I know the waiting for results is the worst bit but keep your pecker up.  Wishing you the best Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Thanks George. I knew I could rely on you to remember.

Posts.Content: Hi Chloecat. Have you tried making no-knead bread? It's the easiest ever bread and you can make it without salt and with any kind of flour. Turns out like Italian pane de casa. I got on to it through a friend of mine who has, from time to time, to go on a low iodine diet, but we love it anyway.  https://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/no-knead-bread-56389453 is one version but there are plenty.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: It's very common here for people to retire to a coastal town. But so many find themselves lonely and cut off from their networks and support systems. I don't think we'll move. I'm retired but hubby is still working so the decision isn't one we have to make yet. I never thought I'd say this but I do actually like being right near excellent health care and am not sure I'd want to move away.  I would have loved to meet you but I'm afraid we're flying between destinations as time is too short to do otherwise. Amazingly, it's also much cheaper when you factor in the cost of petrol and staying overnight in different places.  Hope you have a good day and get a release promise, even if you don't get to go home today.
Posts.Title: Aversion to liquid! Help!

Posts.Content: Necrosis in a tumour that's just been diagnosed and not yet treated is a sign that the cancer is aggressive. Necrosis in a tumour that's been/being treated is a very good thing - it means the tumour is dying and that's what we  all want.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Sounds like a really scary incident chloecat45 The trouble is you never know whether a side effect is so-called normal or whether an emergency is happening to you. Makes you feel that it's a big call to go to A&E. I didn't have anything like your experience so I can't help there. However, I do take paracetamol all day every day for arthritis and have had no ill effects so far (been taking it about 2 years). My liver numbers are perfectly normal. Both doctors and nurses have told me that it's more effective if you take it continuously. Of course there's a maximum dose per day that mustn't be exceeded under any circumstances or else you get bad liver effects. It doesn't actually take that many paracetamol tablets to kill you if you take them all at once.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: A very interesting post chloecat45 - you don't do things by halves! I had never heard of radiation recall. I had a quick look and will read some more but I agree, it's yet another significant side effect that no one warns you about. I saw one article about a woman in Japan who got it 6 years and 4 months after her radiotherapy - sigh! I'm very glad to hear you're coping ok with paclitaxel. I certainly didn't find it as harsh as doxorubicin but I was still fatigued. I'm particularly glad for you that you haven't (yet) got any PN symptoms. With any luck you'll avoid that altogether.  Stay strong xxxxx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Sorry to tell you but losing all your hair is virtually guaranteed with epirubicin (and its cousin doxorubicin).  I agree with leolady - it's time to take control. My GP suggested that we buy a bottle of champagne and drink it while hubby shaved my head. We did and it was great fun - made an awful time into a pretty happy memory.  I chose to go commando all the time as I knew I wouldn't be able to stand wearing a wig, I've always hated hats and the scarf thing just identifies you as a cancer patient. I remember seeing a woman with a shockingly bad wig some years back and hoping then that if it happened to me, I'd be strong enough to go out bald. Honestly, I never felt stared at or made uncomfortable and in fact people were quite lovely. I also got exceedingly good service in cafes and restaurants.  Good luck with it all.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat45 A couple of things that might extend your understanding ... I'm not saying this is the case for you but I had terrible cramps during chemo but before the period of great unwellness. Turned out to be low magnesium levels, which the docs only identified when I was so ill they were testing everything. Problem is that Mg testing isn't usually included in a full blood count. Might I suggest that the next time you have a scheduled blood test, you ask them to check your Mg levels too. And on radiotherapy. It's not the number of sessions but the number of Grays you're given overall. Different places give RT in different fractions but the total is usually somewhere between 45 and 60 grays. There have been various trials testing different levels but I confess I haven't been following them.  If you're already having skin problems, you'll need to pay even more attention than most to your skin during radio. I used R1 and R2 cream and they were wonderful but there are others. Make sure you avoid cream containing sodium lauryl sulfate. If you do get lesions, then I highly recommend mepilex dressings. They self stick and peel off easily but protect the skin really well. They're quite expensive so you might have to fight for them (I didn't but some people have had to) but it's worth it.  It sounds like you're going through a rough patch right now so here's another big hug for you from me.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Gosh chloecat45 You have been having a rough time of it. Hopefully your skin will settle a bit now the RT is finished. I know you think you're being "managed" but EC (or AC) plus paclitaxel are pretty standard and quite effective treatments for BC. Personally I found the paclitaxel much much easier than the AC I had, although for some people it's the other way round. Are you having weekly paclitaxel? I did and managed 9/12 before my onco stopped them because I had peripheral neuropathy.  I can understand that you hate having different oncologists see you. I went private so had the same chap from the outset, and I still see him for checkups. I don't think I'd like to see different people all the time - I'd feel the need to explain each time - how tiresome. Anyway, keep plugging on with it, stay strong and maintain the vigilance. Big hugs Lynn
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Great news - you must feel like dancing in the streets. Long may it continue.  Best  Lynn xxx
Posts.Title: 1st Annual mammo clear.....I am so happy

Posts.Content: Lizz. I would take the emend just before you leave home. I think the 1 hour before is because it takes one hour to take effect. It must then last several hours or it would be pointless. I didn't have this drug but was told by the chemo nurses that the plan with all anti-nausea treatment is to fix it before it gets bad (and especially to fix nausea before you throw up, cos then it's quite difficult to sort out).
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: Hi - best of luck with chemo. It's not so scary after the first one! My tips are: - pack a hospital bag as well as an entertainment bag - nighties, toiletries etc. If you're feverish and having to go to the emergency dept, last thing you want is to be worrying about finding suitable nighties! I had one ready all the time (bit like pregnancy) but fortunately never needed it. - drink heaps in the 24hrs after chemo to flush it out. I'd do about 3 litres. Makes you feel much better. - get on to any nasty side effects or health issues immediately - you don't want to end up really ill - keep asking questions and checking - after all, you're the person who's most interested in your health. Don't let any dr or nurse brush you off!
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: Oh and I forgot to say that if you can get a PICC line or portacath fitted, do so. It'll save your veins and be much less uncomfortable.
Posts.Title: start of chemo

Posts.Content: Can't be as bad as asparagus wee lol
Posts.Title: Smelly urine! (Sorry!)

Posts.Content: Hi Ann. You poor thing - must make chemo even worse! I don't suffer migraines but I am prone to headaches and I found I got a terrible 24 hour headache after every chemo treatment. Only codeine (with neurofen) helped. Best wishes Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Migraine and Fec

Posts.Content: My hair hurt too so I shaved it off. Difference is I'm out and proud. I couldn't bear the thought of a wig, especially during the Aussie summer. I wore hats when I was cold in winter but am otherwise bald. It's liberating and people are so nice. Get good service too! My nails are crap half way through my weekly paclitaxel treatment but I haven't done the polish thing as I prefer to rub oils and cream into them to keep them from completely drying out.  Good luck. It will eventually be over and done with.
Posts.Title: Hello Newbie Here

Posts.Content: Hi JustLittleMe I can understand you worrying, although it's not a problem I've ever had - plenty of flesh here for the docs to use lol. I assume zoladex is a sub-cut injection. If so, then they should be able to inject you in your thigh, or possibly even your bum. I suggest you talk to the doctor/nurse ie whoever is going to do the injection and ask about alternatives.  Best of luck with it.
Posts.Title: Zoladex after diep

Posts.Content: Hi Jane. I confess I did become rather addicted to hot chips and gravy during chemo. Donuts were pretty good too especially ones filled with caramel and iced.
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: Chemo hits us all differently - some people put on quite a bit of weight (a friend of mine put on 2 stone) and some lose it. I lost a lot of weight as I just didn't want to eat. Mind you I have plenty of reserves so it wasn't a problem. It is mostly the steroids that cause weight gain - both from carb cravings and fluid retention. I ended up having very lose doses of steroids, which probably partly explains why I lost weight. The most important thing at the moment is, I think, to eat good food - lean protein, salads, fruit to give your body as much ammo as possible for the onslaught. During chemo I found that I didn't want to eat many of the foods I'd normally eat and lived on eggs, tomato soup, cherry tomatoes and grapes. The last two tasted fabulous - much better than normal. And even other fruit was good.  Wishing you all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty-ann. Just to clarify. It's perfectly normal for a PICC to go in the arm but not a portacath. In fact PICC stands for Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter. Ports are much more commonly placed in the chest area Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: Ports are pretty common here in Australia too. I agree with the others. I have had no trouble with mine at all, chemo and herceptin have been painless. I'm still having infused herceptin so will keep it till I finish. It's so easy - they just access the port with a needle, flush it, take blood, start a saline infusion and then the chemo drugs. Pull the needle out at the end and you're back to normal. However, putting it in the arm seems a bit odd. Mine feeds directly into the superior vena cava, one of your main veins. I thought that's how they were meant to work. Also it does make a lump under your skin, which could rub if it's on your arm. Mine is placed like Karen's - about 6cm below my collarbone on the unaffected side of my chest. I have also seen a few people with them placed against the ribs under the boob on the good side - on the theory that any scar (or indeed the lump itself) won't show if you wear a lowish cut top.  Highly recommend it!!!! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: It can take up to 2 years to return to complete fitness. However, I started feeling significantly better after 6 weeks and got another real bounce after finishing Herceptin. It's now 15 months since I finished chemo and 8 months since I finished H and I have to say I'm pretty close to normal. The only thing is that if I overdo it, I really crash, and if I'm going out at night I try to have a nap in the afternoon as I don't last beyond about 9.30 normally (although I've always been an early to bed, early to rise person). Just don't push yourself too hard - it will come.
Posts.Title: Getting hair back to normal after chemo

Posts.Content: Try baking soda mouthwash. I was given that for chemo and had no mouth problems. I still use it. There's plenty of recipes on the internet. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Mouth ulcers taking anastrozol

Posts.Content: Hi Shepherdess. Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I like to think of it as that, because cancer treatment is never straightforward - we all have our particular problems. Firstly congratulations on getting a good outcome from chemo.  Have you spoken to the surgeon about your fear of needles? If your biopsy was done with gas, then can the marker be done the same way? Alternatively, he might be able to offer you valium or some other drug to put you in the twilight zone. I'm sure you're not the first person to have this sort of issue so they must have a way of dealing with it.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Scared of needles

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy. I'm guessing you're in London from your name and because you have a choice of hospitals.  You might find this assessment useful. It's getting a bit stale now but I've not seen anything more recent. It is organised by trust rather than individual hospital but should give you some idea about standards. In addition, is it possible for you to ask your GP? S/he should have some idea of which hospitals are performing well at the moment. My GP went to some lengths to find me the best breast surgeon around (although I'm in Australia which seems better endowed with GPs at the moment - I can always get a same day appointment, unless he's not working of course and then I can see a colleague).
Posts.Title: Selecting hospital

Posts.Content: Hi. My hair was all grey when it first came back but now (18 months later) it's completely back to normal - still basic brown with some grey bits. Do try to hold off for a while on colouring your hair, as it and your skin will still be sensitive. When you do colour it, make sure to do a test patch 48 hours beforehand.  Best
Posts.Title: Colouring hair post chemo

Posts.Content: Flouracil was never suggested to me. I had doxirubicin (closely related to epirubicin) and cyclophospamide, followed by 12 weekly treatments of paclitaxel. That's a pretty standard treatment, although some have docetaxel instead of paclitaxel (similar taxane drugs).  The more important question is why you aren't being considered for one of the taxanes.
Posts.Title: Confused about type of chemotherapy for Breast cancer

Posts.Content: Congratulations. May there be many more!
Posts.Title: Celebration today ...

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy woo69 Lovely to hear you're looking after your sister. We all need close supportive people - it makes the journey much more bearable. I had terrible trouble with steroids during my first lot of chemo (AC). When I came to have the T part I asked the onco if I could have none. He said it was essential to have some but gave me the minimum dose just prior to the T infusion. I didn't have any before or after that and I was much better for it. I wouldn't recommend though that your sister just stop them. It might be a good idea though for her to have a discussion about steroids with her onco or the chemo nurses.  I had a lot of trouble sleeping during chemo but was completely back to normal within a couple of months of finishing chemo.  Best Lynn xx
