Posts.Title: More Good News...

Posts.Content: Hi Martika. Not surprisingly, colouring hair is a frequent topic of discussion in this group. The most recent thread is here  but you can find others by searching for 'hair colour' in the search box at the top of the page. The short answer is that advice varies between 6 weeks and 6 months, but definitely that your hairdresser should do a patch test first as it's the scalp that is sensitive. Some people recommend the Daniel Field range of natural dyes. But do check out the threads to see the full range of the discussion.  Best wishes
Posts.Title: Getting hair back to normal after chemo

Posts.Content: It's very simple Jojo4, just half a teaspoon of bicarb in a cup of warm water. You can add a drop or two of peppermint or lemon oil if you fancy a flavour but it isn't necessary. I used bicarb mouthwash several times a day throughout chemo. I had no problems at all and I found swilling before I ate was good to get rid of the nasty taste in my mouth.  I was told that the bicarb mouth wash is better for you than the commercial mouthwashes as it's much gentler on sensitive tissue. Good luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Recipe for mouthwask

Posts.Content: Hi cehfin I had no choice about having chemo as my cancer was HER2+. I actually had a really bad time during chemo and ended up spending a month in hospital. However, I'm a "throw everything at it" person and will have whatever treatment might be available to try to stop it coming back. I can also say that if I had to go through it all again.  As for long term side effects, I don't really have any. I finished the hard core chemo in January last year and it did take several months to get back to normal but now I feel great.  It is a tough decision and you just have to be sure inside yourself that you can live with whatever decision you make. Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: Should I or Should I not have Chemotherapy?

Posts.Content: Udderly cream is great if you can get hold of it. I couldn't but used zinc and castor oil creme (sold here in Australia for babies' bums). That was lovely and soothing. My feet still peeled though.
Posts.Title: Hot and sore soles of feet

Posts.Content: Strange you were given Letrozole. The info in the pack suggests it's for post-menopausal women ...
Posts.Title: Zoladex & Letrozole : When will periods stop?

Posts.Content: Hi berren. I had a 7cm lump plus active disease in 14 out of 30 lymph nodes. I've had chemo and am in the middle of radio. I also have another 6 months of herceptin and 4.5 years of letrozole to go. It's been a rough ride but now I feel better than I have for about 15 years - I'm exercising, eating healthily most of the time and have lost 3 stone. I have way more energy and am ready to get on with my life.  Cancer in the lymph nodes means they've been doing their job ie stopping the cancer cells from travelling to the rest of your body.  Don't lose hope - you've got a lot of living still to do. Best wishes Lynn
Posts.Title: Feel there is no hope

Posts.Content: Try not to think about it Jo, just enjoy your holiday, you lucky thing.  Hugs
Posts.Title: Start FEC-T May 10th

Posts.Content: I had my first surgery in June 15 and my first seroma appeared in October 15, my second surgery in March 16 and the seroma appeared a couple of months later. I doubt increased use of the arm caused the first, as I was laid low by chemo. I'm pretty sure it did cause the second one though as I was improving rapidly at that time.
Posts.Title: Firm swelling of 'breast'

Posts.Content: My bloods bounced around for at least 18 months. Sometimes one was out, sometimes another. I had my first one with everything in normal range just last month. Interestingly, that's coincided with my nails finally deciding to grow properly and not delaminate.  I finished T in Jan 16 and Herceptin in Sept 16 so it's nearly 2 years since chemo proper. It's the gift that keeps on giving.
Posts.Title: Low neutrophils months after chemo

Posts.Content: Sounds as if you, like me, are fully on the medical roundabout now. Maybe we should have a competition to see how many specialists we can collect lol.
Posts.Title: Low neutrophils months after chemo

Posts.Content: I had my first surgery (saved skin mastectomy, implant, node clearance) in June 2015, and my second (mastectomy as the implant failed and I had fluid) in March 2016. I'm still quite numb in that area, although I've noticed a small improvement. From having had shingles recently, I suspect that the itching is the nerves healing, although I couldn't say for sure.  As far as activity is concerned, I agree to avoid swimming till chemo is well and truly out of your system. I tried it once but my skin felt horribly tight and uncomfortable afterwards.  I was dreadfully ill during chemo and was seriously unfit (struggling to walk the hospital corridor). I live in a very hilly area and wasn't up to walking it and I knew if I had to drive somewhere to walk on the flat, I wouldn't keep at it. So I bought an exercise bike and started with 2 mins per day, with no resistance. I now do 20 mins with intervals, including some on the highest resistance. A friend who's a cycling coach told me that's enough for general fitness.  Also, I've found it very important to keep going with the arm and shoulder exercises that I was given straight after my first surgery. It definitely helps to keep my shoulder area loose and without pain.  The most important thing is to do a little bit and gradually build up. You'll find that your strength and fitness will return. Best
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: How interesting. I never thought of reading cancer books. I've read plenty of scientific articles and a few blogs with personal stories but I just might check out some books now to expand my understanding. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Books you recommend

Posts.Content: Hi silkpainter31 This sounds like just what you don't want, and yep of course you'll worry. Do try to park the worry for some of the time over Christmas though - no amount of worrying will change the outcome. Actually I think you're incredibly lucky. You've lucked on to a thorough consultant who spotted something early. If it's nothing all well and good, if it is a recurrence then you should thank your lucky stars he found it.  Do have a good Christmas  Love Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Ever so slightly stunned ! Please not again.

Posts.Content: Great JJ - just what you need! I hope you have a fabulous time.  I'd recommend Medihoney or another manuka honey cream for healing. Works a treat. Lynn xxx
Posts.Title: I've done it - booked flight

Posts.Content: Hahahaha Helen mistymoley - that's exactly how my husband has been, that is after he staged the world's biggest temper tantrum (he managed to break a ladder, the vacuum cleaner and the granite benchtop in the process). However, I've found his ability to research very useful - he knows as much about cancer as my onco I think lol.
Posts.Title: Tried and scared

Posts.Content: Finally, 17 months after finding the lump, I've finished treatment woo hoo!!!!!!! That's 2 surgeries, 4 hospital stays, 1 cardioversion, 2 mammograms, 3 CT scans, 1 MRI, 2 bone scans, 1 bone density scan, 4 AC, 9 paclitaxel, 17 Herceptin, 1 MUGA scan, 3 echocardiograms, more than 10 ultrasounds, 4 x seroma drained, plus countless doctor and physio appointments.  It's great to have my life back. A special thank you to everyone on here. The support has been wonderful.  Love to all Lynn xx Added: PS I forgot to mention the drain I carried round for 13 long weeks after my first op. Lx
Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: My sincere condolences. It's never easy to lose someone you love but you can take some comfort from the fact that you were her team captain all the way. She was lucky to have you by her side. All the very best.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Hi JayDee I think you're entirely normal! Whether it's one year or 10 since diagnosis and whatever our rational brain says, we all dread the recurrence of cancer. Yes we suppress that from ourselves and others but scan time is when it surfaces.  Wishing you a great outcome Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Scanxiety

Posts.Content: Welcome (temporarily) to the seroma sisters. JeanieB's has fixed itself and I'm not sure about Marmalade as she doesn't seem to come on here any more. I've been feeling a bit lonely lol. Inconvenient but it's good news! Most people's seromas seem to go away within a couple of months so don't be too concerned. I think I've mentioned that I'm a fluidy person - I think that's why mine's hung around. The plus side is that with the seroma, it looks like I still have a cleavage. Mine has shrunk a bit in the last week or so, mainly as we've been lying around a resort in Bali for 11 days now. No doubt it'll regrow as soon as I get home and start doing normal things. However, if that's the worst that happens to me, I'll be very happy.  Hugs
Posts.Title: Firm swelling of 'breast'

Posts.Content: Hi ronstar It may well be a seroma. I have one. It's very hard but has flesh and skin over the top. I can't exactly remember when it appeared, definitely not directly after my mastectomy, but possibly a couple of months later. I've had it drained several times (about 5 or 6 I think) but it comes back within a week or so. It's almost like a boob but a bit too high - right up level with my armpit. To be honest, I've given up worrying about it. I'm due for a surgeon's check up in April so I'm trying to hold off till then without getting it drained, so she can see it in its full glory. Last time I had it drained, the radiologist asked me twice if I was sure that I didn't have an implant. (Did he think I'm stupid? - possibly) It doesn't appear fluidy cos it's hard but it is full of fluid. Don't panic too much - the doc will probably just want to ultrasound it so s/he can see what's going on. Let us know how you get on. Best
Posts.Title: Firm swelling of 'breast'

Posts.Content: Hi Had enough  I second what Carolyn28 and mistymoley said. I was very breathless during chemo but put it down to expected side effects, and I have to say neither my onco nor the chemo unit seemed particularly concerned. I got to the point where I could hardly get to the toilet, and getting up to open the front door was a major exercise. Fortunately I had to go to the GP for something else. He immediately swung into action - within a couple of minutes I was on oxygen and half an hour later I was in an ambulance. I had pulmonary embolisms, which nearly killed me (respiratory failure and a coma for 3 days). Bless my lovely GP for spotting it! The moral of this story is yep it could be expected side effects like possibly low red blood cell count, or it could be something way more serious. I don't mean to scare you but it really is worth keeping on at the docs and go to A&E if it gets any worse. Best
Posts.Title: Breathlessness

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone but dammit I forgot to mention the drain for 13 weeks lol. Gonna have to edit it.  Love to all  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: Just to add my thoughts, although it looks like you've made your decision RoseKen1 I originally had a silicon implant and ended up with a very attractive perky boob that made the other one look positively tired and old. However, I had problems during chemo and accumulated a lot of fluid all over. Eventually it went, except in my reconstructed breast, which was like a football on my chest. After many consults and much physio surgery was the only option left to fix it. I was so sick of the whole business that I opted for a full mastectomy and I haven't regretted it for a moment. Yes I'm lopsided Lizzie but I'm very comfortable with that. I don't feel damaged or less feminine and the scar is a nice fine line. I think I'm much happier this way than I would be with an implant.  One other point that doesn't seem to have been mentioned (apologies if I missed it). It can be better not to have an implant if you are to have radiotherapy. Implants can make it more difficult for the radiation beams to be targeted correctly and the radiotherapy can cause what's called capsular contracture, where fibres grow round the implant and squeeze and distort it. If that happens the implant has to be removed.  Hope it all goes well for you.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Don't be too hard on yourself Rosemary. It's a big decision that people have to make at the start, not when they know more. It is all overwhelming but don't worry too much; soon you'll be an old lag who understands exactly what's going on and able to provide support to others.  Chemo can be tough but many people don't find it too bad. You tend to hear the horror stories but there are plenty of others just getting on with it. Do have a look at the monthly chemo club thread. You'll find loads of tips for getting through chemo and people who're going through it at the same time as you that you can chat with.  May your side effects be minimal.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Maria. Clear margins means they got all the cancer in your breast with a margin of healthy tissue around it. That's the point of having surgery.  Chemo has a different purpose. It is designed to kill cancer cells wherever they've migrated to in your body. If there are just a few cells, they will be too small to be picked up on a scan. HER2+ BC is a more aggressive type, making chemo and Herceptin more important. The oncos always recommend chemo and herceptin if you're HER2+.  If you had no evidence of spread to your lymph nodes, it's less likely any cells are circulating round your body. But not guaranteed. Indeed, there was someone on a thread today who said they had no lymph node spread but have a small spinal metatisis.  Radio is different again. It's designed to give some heavy duty treatment to the area near where your cancer was found, again to prevent recurrence. Your onco will be able to explain all this at your appointment. I suggest that you make a list of all the questions you want to ask him/her as I guarantee they'll go right out of your head on the day lol. Can also be helpful to take someone along with you - four ears are better than two. Wishing you all the best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: so I have had the operation

Posts.Content: louis7. I was told by my radio-oncologist to stay out of the sun or cover up with eg Tshirt for at least a year and to always wear spf 50. Mind you I always do as I'm fair skinned and live in Australia where the sun burns right through you. After radio, I used the spf 50 for babies as I figured it would probably be the mildest available. Didn't have any problems. Everyone should be sunsmart, regardless of having had radiotherapy - use spf 50, cover up in the height of the day, wear a broad brimmed hat. Even in England when the sun is shining (hahahaha) but certainly if you travel to the Med for example.

Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ February 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Reading this thread has actually made me very cross. Too many GPs are telling us it's "normal" to have low moods, anxiety etc. and then expect us to go away and get on with life with no treatment. Wrong! There are treatment options available eg anti-depressants, counselling, CBT. Quite possibly people may choose not to have treatment but that's different from not being offered. I suspect it's much the same for women going through menopause, without the added burden of tamoxifen.  OK rant over. Several people on here and others I know have found help with venlafaxine. It's an anti-depressant but also helps with hot flushes etc. Those of you who are suffering anxiety and low moods might think about raising this as a possibility with your doctor.  Big hugs to all that are suffering.
Posts.Title: Constant Anxiety

Posts.Content: Hi Bazzy. It must be a difficult and worrying time for you. That's completely normal - after all, getting a cancer diagnosis is one of the scariest things that can happen to anyone. I can assure you though, once you get your pathology results and have a treatment plan, things will settle down and you'll just put one foot in front of the other and keep going until you come out the other side.  You said you don't have your HER2 results but do you have any others? Do you know the stage and grade and was it hormone (ER and/or PR) positive? Also, have they told you whether there was any (armpit) lymph node involvement? All these will contribute to the treatment plan they come up with.  If your tumour was HER2+, they will definitely offer you chemo as chemo plus herceptin plus pertuzumab is the gold standard treatment for that type of BC. If it was hormone positive, you may not be offered chemo as that's not necessarily the best treatment. If it was what's called triple negative (ie HER2 and hormone negative) then you will be offered chemo as that's the only effective treatment. So you can see why the onco needs to wait till he gets the full pathology results.  In the meantime, try to relax and take the time to recover from your surgery. The cancer is now gone so a week or two here or there makes little difference. My advice would be not to think too far ahead. but take it one step at a time. Try to avoid Dr Google as you can frighten yourself badly and much of the information out there is unreliable or out of date. If you must research, then stick to the well known sites like Macmillan and Cancer Research UK.  Finally, you're right to write your questions down. I found my mind went blank as soon as I walked in the doc's office. Make notes of what he tells you too as you won't remember it all later. Do feel free to come back to this group and ask as many questions as you like or just have a rant. There are lovely supportive people here who'll help you through.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Worries.

Posts.Content: It might be worth a sleeping tablet just for a night or two. You can buy anti-histamines over the counter that are targeted at sleep and do a pretty good job. I use them for flying. Best Lynn
Posts.Title: Tried and scared

Posts.Content: Hi JMC04 Welcome aboard. I'm sure you'd rather not be here but we're a good bunch and you'll find all sorts of help, tips and support as you travel this rocky road. You will find that treatment takes over your life but it does end eventually. At the start my onco said, give me a year of your life and I'll give you 20. That stuck with me and now I'm out the other side, fit and happy. You'll have lots of questions as you find out more about what's going on. Don't hesitate to ask - there are loads of very knowledgeable people here.  Wishing you all the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: If your tumour was hormone receptor positive, you should be taking tamoxifen or similar. I'm not sure how it all works as you're pre-menopausal but please ask loads of questions. Forgetting you simply isn't good enough.  I'm on a different aromatase inhibitor cos I'm post-menopause but frankly after the first month the side effects have been minimal, just getting hot now and again - I wouldn't even say they're hot flushes.  The stats strongly support taking AIs to reduce the risk of recurrence and metastases so don't close your mind to it.  And finally, think about complaining long and loud!!! All the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer 2014

Posts.Content: Congratulations. May there be many more!!!
Posts.Title: It's been a year and I'm in the clear!

Posts.Content: Let's hope you get your slot soon. The sooner it's done, the better.  I was born in Beckenham in Kent, although I think that's considered to be part of London these days. It certainly wasn't in the 1950s! I still have an uncle and quite a few cousins in the SE, and an aunt and more cousins in Scotland too. We don't have Macmillan here but we do have specialist breast cancer nurses, funded either by private hospitals or by a Foundation. They perform a similar role to Macmillan nurses.  I was diagnosed in May 2015 and finished all treatment in September 2016 so I've been clear for over 3 years now. Long may it continue!
Posts.Title: Reconstruction or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab Your surgeon sounds great - actually thinking about what's best for you rather than just putting you through the production line. And very good news on the chemo results. Reconstruction isn't an easy decision - risks and benefits with all options. Did he mention that there can be problems with radiotherapy if you have an implant. Firstly, the implant makes the actual radiotherapy harder to plan as it gets in the way. Secondly, the radiation can cause your implant to harden or can cause capsular contracture, where bits of tissue grow round the implant squeezing it. In the worst cases, the implant has to be removed. The only reason I mention this is because no one told me until I had my first radio planning appointment and then the radio oncologist just kept going on about it. As it turned out I had to have my implant removed and a full mastectomy before radio (for other reasons) but it was definitely a serious issue for the radio oncologist.  Hope it all goes well, whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Strange as it may sound that's a pretty good result Bazzy. If you're HER2- then you may not have to have chemo. You might want to ask about the oncotype dx test if your oncologist suggests chemo (if HER2-). It's a test to show how much benefit chemo would be to you. There's some good info about it here.

Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: You can have herceptin at the same time as a taxane but not at the same time as the EC. So the usual practice is to give you the doses of EC first and then start T and H at the same time.  Take the PICC - anything that saves your veins is a good thing! Best of luck with it all. Lynn
Posts.Title: Having chemo and herceptin

Posts.Content: That's pretty scary news for you taylor0428 Big hug from me. It just shows how much no one really knows about cancer and how it spreads.  I can completely understand your need to know what you're dealing with and 2 weeks seems a terribly long time to wait. Not much you can do in the meantime except try to keep yourself occupied as far as you can.  Wishing you all the very best. Keep in touch. Lots of love Lynn xx

Posts.Title: Anastrozole leg cramps and tonic water. Information please.

Posts.Content: Hi operahappy - I have peripheral neuropathy too, caused by the taxane part of my chemo (paclitaxel or docetaxel - I had the former). It started about 4 weeks in to a 12 week weekly treatment schedule, with a tingling or slight pins and needles sensation but over the weeks it spread from just two fingers on each hand to my whole hand and my feet (club like feeling is an accurate description). My onco initially reduced the dose of paclitaxel by 25% but after week 9, he cancelled the rest of the treatment. He told me that mostly it fixes over time but if you have actual numbness or if it spreads beyond your hands then it may be permanent.
Posts.Title: Loss of sensitivity in feet and finger tips.

Posts.Content: Just thought I'd clarify the MUGA scan/Herceptin/heart issue for everyone.  The LVEF (left ventricle ejection fraction) is a measure of how much blood your heart pumps through on each beat. The normal range is 55% to 70%. Herceptin can affect your heart so the docs keep a close eye on it during Herceptin treatment. The NICE guidelines specify a scan before you start, to get a base measurement and then every three months after that. It can either be a MUGA scan or an echocardiogram. Your LVEF can drop during treatment and if it drops 10 percentage points or more from baseline and to below 50% then treatment will probably be suspended. Often the heart will recover sufficiently to allow treatment with H to resume.  Just to illustrate: my LVEF was 68% before I started H. Over the 12 months it dropped to high 50s. Six months after finishing it was back to 69%. So, some impact but not enough for the docs to be concerned and then a full recovery pretty quickly.  Best
Posts.Title: ER+ and HER2+

Posts.Content: Hi pipchick. It's never ever a waste of time to get a lump checked out. I'm sure any doctor would rather see a false alarm than a cancer patient. Make that appointment with your GP and insist on another referral to the breast clinic.  In the meantime, try not to let the worrying take over.  Hope it turns out to be nothing to worry about.
Posts.Title: 2nd armpit lump

Posts.Content: Hi Louby. It may just be your body getting used to the oestrogen deprivation. If so, the pain should ease off. Take pain killers if you need to.  Are you pre-menopausal? If so, tamoxifen can cause some bone loss. Do mention these symptoms to your doctor as you may need bone strengthening treatment. If you're post-menopausal, tamoxifen actually helps with bone strength.  Cheers
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen & bone aches

Posts.Content: Hi emj. Bad luck that you got a positive diagnosis but excellent luck that it was caught early. It sounds like you have no spread and aren't HER2+ but are hormone positive. I know this is all pretty scary and a bit of a whirl but things will settle down. Once you have a full treatment plan in place, you'll find that everything becomes a lot less daunting and you just keep going. You're very lucky if you don't have to go through chemo as that's the worst part of the treatment in my view. I found radio to be a doddle by comparison. The worst part was having to go every day and find parking at the hospital!  Make sure you either take someone with you to the onco appointment or write things down as you go, as I guarantee you won't remember much that you're told. If you have questions between now and then, make sure to make a list as they'll all fly out of your head as soon as you walk in that door lol.  Do stay in touch with this site. We're a great bunch and so many people can offer support or useful tips as we've been there!  Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: New to the group and Not quite sure what I should be feeling?

Posts.Content: I can't really add much to Jane's excellent post but I wanted to let you know I sympathise. I had a L mastectomy too. At first I was very reluctant to be seen lop-sided but I started radiotherapy 2 weeks ago and the base of my bra is uncomfortable directly afterwards. So I thought who's going to see me between the cancer centre and home, except other cancer patients, and started not putting my bra back on. A week later, I simply don't care about being lopsided. It's a bit like being bald, and I was out and proud with that! I guess what I'm saying is that you naturally get more accustomed to it and it becomes not such a big deal. Just remember why you had it done!
Posts.Title: had left sided masectomy last week, so sad today

Posts.Content: Hi taylor0428 That must be so worrying for you but at least you're on to it quickly. I have a lump near my mastectomy scar but it turned out to be scar tissue. Was worrying there for a while though!  This probably doesn't help much but do remember that a local recurrence or a new primary isn't as serious as distant metasteses. Nasty yes, but fixable.  Push for an early appointment!!!!!! Best Lynn
Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi mumof3abitlost Venting is ok. We all need to do it!!! Trouble with having had cancer is that if we get a random pain, our minds turn naturally to cancer. I developed pain in my hip a few months back when I was away on holiday in Bali. Happens every time I go as the beds are far too hard (Asian style) but this time, I was convinced I had bone mets, especially when the ache persisted for a while after I got back. I was waiting for my next check up to mention it (scheduled for about 6 weeks after I returned) but guess what - it had gone by then. Going again in a couple of weeks so no doubt I'll have the same problem lol and will go through the same thought processes. It's good though that you mentioned it to your hospital and GP. It's always better to mention something and be told it's ok than to not mention it and spend ages worrying and possibly delay treatment if it were serious. If the pain persists then mention it again.  In the meantime, some gentle exercise may help to loosen up your body. Do you like swimming? It's very kind to the body as the water supports your weight.  Wishing you all the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: tension aches and pains

Posts.Content: I used to hate people telling me I looked well, especially when the colour in my cheeks was from the flush you get with doxorubicin or epirubicin.  Now I don't mind so much, because I know I look and am well. However, I do still find it tiresome that people need to make the comment. It's almost as if they're constantly surprised. I don't ever take issue though cos I know they mean well sigh. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Your cancer wasn't bad then....

Posts.Content: Don't you hate the nagging! I'm overweight and used to smoke (gave up when I got pneumonia a few years ago) but quite frankly the nagging from doctors just stopped me going to see them, unless desperate. In 20 years I only went about 3 or 4 times - to get antibiotics. That is until I found my lump and that changed everything. Now I seem to be visiting a doctor every couple of weeks, even though my treatment has finished. AND my oncologist has started nagging me about being overweight grrrrr. Mind you none of them nagged while I was being treated, which is a good thing.

Also, is it possible that chemo has shrunk your tumour? There are several explanations so do try not to over-worry. Best wishes  Lynn
Posts.Title: mri

Posts.Content: Hi CTopaz The waiting is awful isn't it. Seems like everyone thinks that's the worst part. I guess we're all the same and all worry and look on the dark side at some stage.  It does sound reasonably hopeful though! However, even if the news is bad just remember that whatever it is has been caught early, which means you'll have a very high chance of recovery. Also, just identifying the lump is the first step on the road to recovery. Try not to let the worry take over - do something you love doing, go out with friends, a bit of retail therapy, whatever you fancy to take your mind off it. Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Waiting for breast core biopsy results and reading too much into available...

Posts.Title: Hair cuts for cold cap?

Posts.Content: Hi Sharkay. You're not Robinson Crusoe believe me. The pain does go away eventually and your family and friends will get a grip. I found that saying the word cancer out loud in a completely natural way helped me and them come to terms with it. It's a funny thing though - I have a friend who had BC nearly 5 years ago and still can't deal with the word cancer - she got really upset last week when I said I was going to the Cancer Centre after seeing her. Well it's called the Canberra Region Cancer Centre so what else was I supposed to call it! She suggested to just say hospital but I think that's more worrisome as it's unclear why you're going there.  And as for the drain. Most inconvenient but doing it's job. I had one for 14  weeks and only had it removed cos I cheated and convinced the community nurse that I wasn't leaking any more. You've still got a way to go - chemo and possibly radio - but you will get through it and you will find reserves of strength that you didn't know you had.  Wishing you the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: had left sided masectomy last week, so sad today

Posts.Content: I think it would very much depend on the type of gardening you do. Weeding, light pruning (with the good hand/arm), even lawn mowing didn't cause me too much trouble at first but I was unable to do anything heavy like carrying bags of prunings or fertiliser, let alone digging. Also, as chemo progressed I got more and more fatigued and had less and less strength. As for the infection risk, in some ways you're probably less at risk in the garden (not mixing with people and their germs) but of course there's a high risk with cuts, thorns etc. Perhaps those leather gauntlet gloves that go up to your elbow? I use them for rose pruning but I have to say my hands don't have much fine motor movement while wearing them. To be honest, gardening doesn't really sound like a viable proposition during chemo and while recovering from surgery. If you end up having full or partial lymph node clearance, you'll have to restrict your arm work for a while during the healing or you'll expose yourself to the risk of lymphoedema. The Macmillan helpline is very good for advice about claiming entitlements during treatment. Their number is at the bottom of the page and they are open during business hours and till 8pm.  Wishing you all the best from a very amateur gardener.
Posts.Title: Chemo and working and a gardener

Posts.Content: Great news CTopaz. We're smiling for you Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Waiting for breast core biopsy results and reading too much into available...

Posts.Content: I understand where you're at LittleWren - it's not easy is it?  I originally decided to have a saved skin mastectomy with immediate reconstruction and duly had it, with a permanent implant fitted. It was a lovely boob for about 3 months but then I got seriously ill from chemo and as part of that put on a lot of fluid (about 10 kg worth), including in the reconstructed breast which turned into a football sitting on my chest. Eventually the fluid went away - from everywhere except my reconstructed breast. I was told it would sort itself out but it didn't and I ended up with what they call septation. This is basically where fibres grow in the fluid so you end up with something like a sponge with lots of pockets filled with fluid. Also the fibres had grown round my implant, squeezing and distorting it. Had to be fixed surgically. By that point I was so sick of the damned football that I told my surgeon just to chop it off, in other words a full mastectomy. It healed beautifully except I have a seroma which I have to get drained about once a month. I'm happy with wearing a knitted knocker though and don't care that I have no boob.  Clearly I'm a fluidy person so I'm reluctant to undergo reconstruction, in case it sets a new chain of problems in motion. I may change my mind later.  As far as I know there are different kinds of reconstruction, which seem to have different healing times. One I think takes fat from your tummy, and another takes muscle from your back and there are others. Both of these seem to take much longer to heal than a straight implant. One other thing to watch is whether you are to have radiotherapy. Implants before radiotherapy are discouraged because they can make radio more difficult and there can be problems with the implant afterwards. Having said all that, the majority of people in this group who've had reconstructions are very happy with them. Hopefully some will respond to your query. In the meantime, you might like to check this out.  https://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/information-support/facing-breast-cancer/going-through-treatment-breast-cancer/surgery/breast-reconstruction  Best Lynn xx

Posts.Title: August chemo club. Multiple pulmonary embolisms.aids in house

Posts.Content: Hi sharma Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I'm sorry to see you here but you'll find plenty of help and support.  As for those lymph nodes ... unlike you I'm not in the medical profession, but I'm pretty sure they get zapped if you have radiotherapy, that is if they haven't been removed as part of a WLE or mastectomy, so any nasties there would get dealt with one way or the other. I had a mastectomy and then I had radio - the target area for that included both my sternum and the supra clavicular fossa area to get more lymph nodes. My radio oncologist told me they targeted the expanded area as I had an aggressive type of breast cancer. I think it would be well worth raising your concerns with your surgeon first of all.  It will be a long 7 days but do try to not let the worrying take over. Keep busy, treat yourself and above all be kind to yourself. Shopping therapy works wonders. Hope it all goes well for you.
Posts.Title: ... started my journey today

Posts.Content: I spent a month in hospital during my chemo (long and boring story) but I made sure to tell every female staff member to make sure they regularly examined their breasts. I was REALLY surprised that a lot of the younger nurses (not those in the cancer ward) did not undertake breast self-examination. There have been loads of ad campaigns here over the years but seemingly they're not getting through.  All we can do is keep preaching!
Posts.Title: How to make others aware

Posts.Content: Hi Smiffy. This all sounds rather scary - hope you're bearing up! Also sounds like you haven't had the best so far, what with needing to buy your own CT scan and having an offhand onco. Also seems strange to me that they won't investigate the "shadows" a bit more - perhaps think about asking for a PET scan.  Of course we all hope that the "shadows" are nothing to worry about but remember how far treatment has come in the last 20 years. That's especially true with HER2+ (which you clearly are as they're going to give you trastumazab).  I'm also HER2+ with a nerdy neurotic husband who has done heaps of research on this. There are other drugs in the pipeline for HER2+ (Neratinib and Lapatinib are showing a lot of promise) so there will be plenty of options for you going forward. Wishing you the very best with your treatment and hoping the shadows are nothing. Lynn xxxx
Posts.Title: mri

Posts.Content: Hi Sharmer Sorry to hear your news and I'm not at all surprised you're shellshocked. A cancer diagnosis is one of the most scary things that can happen to you. Bear in mind though that breast cancer is highly treatable, with well over 90% surviving; and many of those that don't make it were either very old, had something else wrong with them as well or were diagnosed too late. HER2+ cancers used to have a worse outcome but the so-called wonder drug - herceptin - has changed that. Be careful looking at Dr Google as some of the survival stats still include people who didn't get herceptin. As time goes by, the figures get better and better. They now give pertuzumab as well as H, with even better results. I agree that the only way is to take it one step at a time. Focus for now on your surgery and healing from that. If you can, it would probably be useful to prepare some freezer meals for when you're not up to cooking. If you don't use them after surgery, I'm sure you will during chemo. From now till surgery, eat well and try to get plenty of exercise so you get yourself as well as possible to deal with the surgery. Wishing you all the very best.
Posts.Title: ... started my journey today

Posts.Content: You're not stupid Aliasdj and neither are you a fraud. A cancer diagnosis and major surgery is tough for anyone so it's not surprising that you feel a bit vulnerable. Let others do the supporting for a change - it should be a two way street with the people you love, shouldn't it?  Chemo may well be the next step but in the meantime, take the time to let yourself heal both physically and mentally. See your doctor as you shouldn't be taking anything that causes a reaction. There are plenty of different antibiotics and I'm sure your doc can find one that works for you.  Hoping you feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Why am I being so stupid.

Posts.Content: Hi Carol - there's a thread today about chemo leaking and causing burns. Another good reason to go for a PICC or other longer term solution. I have a PortaCath which sits under my skin ie nothing showing normally. The nurse has to put a needle in for each treatment, but it's only a short sting and I can live my life normally for the rest of the time. The only downside to a PICC is that you have a thing hanging off you all the time.
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: Yes I'm in Australia but it might be worth asking about a port. Best of luck with everything.
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: Hi Jdlp Welcome aboard the roller coaster. So glad you have found us as there are heaps of lovely people here who have plenty of knowledge to answer your questions and listen if you need to rant. Your treatment plan sounds almost exactly like mine, except I had 5 weeks of radio, perhaps because I had a mastectomy so didn't need the "booster" radio direct to the breast area. Whereabouts do you live? Am I correct in thinking that you're not in the UK? The only reason I ask is that UK people usually have a slightly different treatment plan (EC rather than AC, and 3 weeks radio). They also call a lumpectomy a WLE rather than lumpectomy. I'm in Australia but this is the best most helpful site I've found.  It sounds like the AC treated you reasonably well. I hope the paclitaxel does too. There are plenty of tips around to help with side effects. Do keep visiting Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Letrozole or other AIs reduce the risk of local recurrence AND metastatic tumours elsewhere in the body. I imagine whoever told you it 'shrinks other tumours' meant metatases. As far as I'm aware it doesn't have any effect on completely unrelated cancers.  I too am HER2+ as well as hormone positive. I was originally put on letrozole but I did struggle with the aching and with hot flushes so my onco changed me over to anastrozole. His view is that they're virtually equally effective and it's important to be comfortable with the treatment or else you won't continue.  You might be interested to know that a paper was presented at the recent cancer conference in Chicago detailing the results of a study of letrozole over 10 years rather than 5. It demonstrated a further 34% (I think - can't remember exact number) reduction in the risk of recurrence. My onco has already said I should stay on it for 10 years. Sigh Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: And if you change brands and it still doesn't work for you, get your onco to change you to another AI. I started on letrozole but found it very tough going so I switched to anastrazole (aka arimidex), which suits me much better. There's also another one but I can't recall the name of it right now. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: Oh Cartwheels you poor thing. Shingles is horrid. I had it a few months back (long past chemo). Did they give you anti-virals? Acyclovir is the one I was given. If not, then rush to your GP and get some as it makes a huge difference. Mine was cleared up within a week; otherwise it'll hang around for about 6 weeks. Perhaps your onco might give you a prescription???  I think your BCN was a bit off not recognising it - shingles is very distinctive as it only affects one side of the body - nursing 101!
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Congratulations and enjoy your time away. I thought about a disabled sticker but the form asked a lot of really intrusive questions and I decided I didn't want that info to be on my driving record. I know my GP would've endorsed it but never mind. I never have that much trouble parking anyway. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Chemo's finished !!

Posts.Content: I prefer not to wax full stop as I get terrible red blotches. I'm also scared of shaving my underarm on my affected side as I have no nerves and worry about cutting myself. Fortunately, I'm not that hairy but the few that are there I get rid of with hair removal cream. Works a treat. Cheers L
Posts.Title: Underarm Waxing

Posts.Content: I agree with Jane Jives68 about the antihistamine. I still have herceptin by infusion so I get given an antihistamine as part of that. I'd ask your BCN or chemo unit. I was offered the option of swapping over to injection but declined cos I'd heard of side effects like yours and didn't see any point in taking the risk. If the swelling persists, you might want to think about talking to your onco about having H by infusion instead. It only takes 30 mins and isn't a drama. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Herceptin injection site swelling.

Posts.Content: Hi JMC04 Once in the chemo club, always in the chemo club. I don't think it ever quite leaves you. I finished in Jan last year but I still have very clear memories - and occasional fatigue.  Hope your surgery goes well next week. Big hugs
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Gloria - I had a portacath and loved it. It worked perfectly for me for the entire 16 months I had it (including having Herceptin by infusion). However, one of the nurses did tell me that 'they all take, but only some give'. In other words, it's not uncommon for them not to be able to draw blood from a port. I mostly had my bloods done by needle in the vein as my veins don't give any trouble (thank goodness). Jenny - fatigue. I had the most awful fatigue you can imagine. I spent the days sitting down or in bed the entire time. Sometimes it was a mammoth effort just to get up to answer the door or go to the toilet. I could probably walk about 20 paces and that's it. However, at the 4 month mark, they discovered I had pulmonary embolisms (clots on the lung) so it's highly likely they were the major contributor to the fatigue. I wasn't nearly as bad for the first month or so, just a bit tired here and there so I suspect the clots started developing in month 2.  I was fine on T - not much energy but not the same level of draining fatigue that I'd had before - I was able to shower, cook, go out for coffee. The one thing I couldn't do for ages was change the bed - I found putting on a new duvet cover just completely overwhelming. Fortunately hubby was happy to do it.  No one knows how badly fatigue will strike you so just roll with it. My best advice is to drink plenty of water or other fluids - 3 litres in the 24 hours following chemo and 2 litres every other day (that's what I was told) and to get as much exercise as you can - even if it's only a 5 minute walk down the street. There's a fair bit of research coming through that shows that exercise reduces the severity of side effects. The other thing is to report side effects to the chemo unit and your oncologist - don't think you're making a fuss, they need to know. I think I downplayed my SEs (fatigue, breathlessness) so much they took a while to pick up on the clots. Best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi again Jdlp I'm doing really well thank you. Fit as a fiddle, nearly 2 years from diagnosis. Whereabouts in Australia? I live in Canberra but come from Adelaide. Best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Yes it can be dangerous Cartwheels I was "lucky" I had it across my chest (good side) but of course that meant that initially I thought it was BC related. Still as I was pulling my top down for him to have a look, my GP said That's shingles so he was on to it immediately.  You may get your chemo delayed by a week but please don't pretend it's ok if it's not as the onco needs the facts. I finished Herceptin last September. Main side effects were drippy nose and flaky nails. The drippy nose is long gone but my nails are still crap. I thought I was feeling fine all through it but I definitely had an upsurge in energy once it was finished so overall I'd say it made me feel a bit below par, but not ill at all.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Firstly, welcome aboard the roller coaster jojo1969. It's good that your team is on to it so quickly! Things will start to settle down mentally for you now.  The first chemo is probably the most daunting as you've no idea how you'll feel or react. By the end of that session though you'll feel that it's not as bad as you thought it was going to be. The important things to remember are to drink lots of water beforehand to plump up your veins so they can get the cannula in easily, drink at least 2 and preferably 3 litres in the 24 hours following (to flush it through your body), take a few snacks and a cardi or wrap as you may get cold. I found my Kindle invaluable for entertainment (I went through a lot of trashy historical romances as I couldn't concentrate on anything more serious).  If you haven't had an introductory session with the chemo nurses, they'll probably give you one. That's about what actually happens, the anti-sickness meds to take home, watching your temperature, giving you a contact to ring if any problems and so on. There are heaps of tips from people who've been through it in a file linked at the bottom of crystaljuju's opening post on this thread.  And finally, bear in mind that chemo is very do-able, you just have to look after yourself. Many people get through it with few problems and it's the minority that post here because they are having difficulties.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi again 1BB My SEs did get worse as the AC treatments went on. I was a bit like the energizer bunny runny out of battery. Not the same with T - then I just felt a bit meh the whole time. I had quite bad SEs but not everyone does. You might find you stick at the 'bit meh' level all the way through.  Best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: JennyEm I'm a massive fan of manuka honey for all sorts of things. My brother had a lingering ulcer on his arm after a car accident. It was about the size of a pound coin. Nothing the docs gave him did any good, but then he tried a poultice with manuka honey. It was healed in about 6 weeks. I didn't use it for mouth problems but I can't see it doing any harm.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: My onco told me not to try to diet while on chemo. He said everyone either loses or gains weight and few remain the same. His view is that there are more important things to worry about. Having said that I still have to try to control my bgl. My appetite has reduced by about 90% and I don't feel like eating most of the time so I've lost over 3 stone (every cloud has a silver lining!). I find I want to eat mostly in the morning so I make sure to have a good healthy protein rich breakfast. For the rest of the day it's whatever I fancy. Hot chips are a favourite and there's a baker near me that makes the best apple crumble slice - I'm addicted! So I say go for the milk shakes or cheesecake, just don't have too many. PS it's still a revelation to me that I can eat chips and cake and still lose weight - I've been fighting my fat all my life.
Posts.Title: MacDonalds milkshake?

Posts.Content: Interesting thread! I have always been completely open about my BC and treatment as I figured it stopped the whispering and gossiping. However, when I was in hospital my husband sent regular email updates on me to my friends and family. I was horrified when I found out later the level of detail he'd gone into - made me feel somehow exposed to everyone. I had to bite my tongue though as I know that writing those emails was therapeutic for him and in no way did he want to upset me.  I agree with Carolyn28 that the real problem here is not your friend but the nosy bloke. I expect he put your friend in a position where she felt she had to share the info with him. Blame him, not her. And watch him. Odd people can be unpredictable. Best
Posts.Title: Am I being Oversensitive?

Posts.Content: Hi 1BB Sorry to disappoint you but your hair's not really likely to grow back during T. Some people get some wispy peach fuzz but hair really starts showing a month after chemo finishes.  Hope your side effects aren't too bad. How are you feeling so far?
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: I'm afraid sore mouth and achy teeth can be SEs of tax. I suggest the bicarb mouthwash - just a tsp of bicarb in a cup of water, used as often as you like. It'll help with the soreness and the lack of taste.  We don't have a public holiday this weekend but it's a lovely day - 19C after an overnight low of 2C. I've been out in the garden fixing up my irrigation and rock garden edging. Both of them got squashed by a digger that we had in to dig a trench for a new sewer pipe - over 2 years ago, shortly before I was diagnosed. I wasn't up to any gardening for ages and the weeds were a higher priority lol.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Bedy I do hope letrozole works for you. Try changing brands every couple of months until you find what works best for you. There is a third AI - exemestane - so if you can't stand the letrozole after a few months of trying then ask your doctor about whether you can try that.  I am taking Arimidex (anastrozole) as that works better for me than letrozole and I have also been told by my onco to take calcium/D3 tablets.  I find I'm not too bad with the aches now but keeping the weight off is a challenge.  Hope you find something that works for you
Posts.Title: Letrozole V Femara

Posts.Content: I have calcifications on my spine. When I was in hospital during chemo, some radiographer decided they were bone mets and set hares running, worrying my husband immensely. Silly thing was that neither my hubby nor my onco nor anyone else for that matter told me. I guess they didn't want to upset me. However, I'd already had a CT scan of the area and knew it was only calcifications!!! That same CT told me I also have arthritis in a different part of my spine. Moral of the story - x-rays show up all sorts of stuff so don't panic yet! I know the not knowing is the hardest bit so hugs. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Bone mets

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry to hear your news Laura, but as Gay said, there are several treatments that can stabilise the tumour(s). Do you know the pathology of the tumour (hormone positive or negative, HER2 positive or negative)? Also, I know you said you didn't like the idea of a line in you but, believe me, once it's inserted you can't feel a thing. A portacath is better than a PICC line for longer term as there are no bits dangling outside your skin - it's just inserted in your chest and then they use a needle to access it when needed. They can give you local anaesthetic so you don't even feel that needle going in. If you have to have any more chemo, I'd strongly recommend you consider asking for one. Usually I don't recommend internet searches, but have a look and you'll see how straightforward it is.  Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: How much more can they throw at me??

Posts.Content: I had a portacath in my chest that was there for 16 months (chemo and herceptin with a bit of a break between parts 1 and 2 of chemo as I was ill). I thought it was wonderful. No pain, no busted up veins. I'd strongly recommend if offered.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi meashmosh Welcome aboard the roller coaster and I'm glad you've found us. Even if you don't post very often, there are plenty of tips here to help you get through. Lots of very knowledgeable people too if you do have any queries. How was your first FEC?
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Excellent news Judyr58 The more of us that have the opportunity to contribute the better.  Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Opportunity if you didn't like Brave the Shave campaign

Posts.Content: Hi Lujay13 I agree there doesn't seem to be a standard. I'm in Australia so it's different anyway but I get seen every 3 months, by the surgeon and medical oncologist alternately. I think it very much depends on the doctors involved and the type of cancer you had.  You can feel a bit as though you've been cast adrift when suddenly you're not in their rooms all the time. It's quite scary at first, as though a prop has been taken away, but you'll gradually normalise and get back to your regular routines. The most important thing is to know your body and be alert to any symptoms - lumps, unusual pain that doesn't go away, breathlessness, headaches and so on and if in any doubt, get yourself checked out.  Can I recommend After The Treatment Finishes - Then What ? by Dr Peter Harvey This is a fantastic article that explains so much of what you feel after treatment. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Whats the normal follow up after treatment finishes.

Posts.Content: Hi Aneesa1 - welcome aboard. Your wig lady might have been lovely but it's seriously unhelpful to be spreading misinformation. I'd be furious. Are you going to mention it to her when you see her? You have stage 3, which is primary and therefore curative, not stage 4 which is secondary and not. Please don't be put off by this. I was diagnosed with stage 3 HER2+ and hormone positive BC nearly 2 years ago and I'm fighting fit now. By the way I found all 4 doctors (GP, surgeon, medical onco and radio onco) to be very open and straightforward throughout my treatment. I did learn, however, that you need to be assertive and make sure to ask if you're not clear about anything. Wishing you all the best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: Don't judge him too quickly Aneesa1. A lot of blokes find it very hard to deal with their partner having BC and can react in odd ways. My husband explained it as a sense of helplessness, as blokes are normally "fixers" but they can't fix this. Some react by being a bit distant, others by being over-fussy, and many other ways. I was very fortunate in that my hubby was there for me every step of the way (he's clearly in the over-fussy category), even though he was difficult at times. Others have not been so lucky but still have their relationships Carolyn28 comes to mind.  All you can do, I think, is be honest and open with him, but don't waste any emotional energy - you'll need it for yourself. Another hug Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: Hi 1BB Welcome aboard the roller coaster. It's hard to know how chemo will hit you and how much your taste etc will be affected. It's hard to avoid losing your hair though, although some people have had great success with the cold cap. Are you going to try that or just go with the hair loss? As far as tips go, may I suggest that you have a look at the list tagged at the bottom of Crystaljuju's opening post on this thread. Just click on it and the list will open. This is a composite of all sorts of info collected from people here so it's a good starting point.  For me, I found the loss of taste very difficult and didn't want to eat much. I lived on tinned tomato soup, cherry tomatoes, grapes, scrambled egg and fresh orange juice. That's all I could stomach. Even water became difficult but I found that a slight flavouring like Ribena, orange squash or a squeeze of lemon or orange helped a lot. It's very important to drink heaps of water. At least 3 litres in the 24 hours following each treatment and 2 litres every other day. I used to fill 2 or 3 750ml bottles each morning and drink them through the day so I could keep track of how much I was getting into me. NB tea and coffee don't count but fruit tea, soup and similar do.  Also, I highly recommend bicarb mouthwash, used as often as you need to. I was given it by my chemo unit but there are plenty of easy recipes on the internet.  I hope it all goes really well for you Best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Sorry to disappoint you bougiecat but 10 years is getting more and more common. My onco has already told me that I'd be on AIs for 10 years. Probably by then it'll be 15 lol, but if it stops the cancer coming back I'll live with it. Best
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Thanks for the suggestion Cocopops1 We're on to it! The monthly radiotherapy club should be live in the next day or two. Such a great idea. I hope everyone supports it as radio is an important part of our treatment. Crystaljuju
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi maxinem2 Sorry to hear you're feeling below par. I was only given dexamethsone by infusion and had some tablets to take home as well. I also had metoclopromide given to me as tabs but hardly needed them. I think most other anti-nausea medication is given by tablet too. I expect the reason you feel wiped out is the cumulative effect of 3 doses of FEC. It's tough stuff and feeling like crap is pretty normal - my chemo nurses called it the red devil. However, do keep a close eye on your temperature, and watch out for breathlessness. Ring your BCN if you have any worries with side effects.  Rest as much as you need to but try to get a little exercise, even if it's only a walk to the corner of your street, as exercise really does help with the fatigue.  Best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: You are so not batty 1BB. I hope by now you've managed to get to sleep and don't read this until the morning. If not, then just think how much worse you'll feel in the morning if you've not slept. Tomorrow or the next day may be dreadful, but they may not. It's too early to tell how you'll react to chemo and anyway, you'll still be feeling the steroids, which make things seem a bit better.  Try to live in the present (such a cliche I'm afraid) rather than wondering or worrying. If you don't feel too bad right now, celebrate that. If you start to feel bad at some point, deal with it then. Don't waste the time when you feel ok with worrying about feeling not ok later - that's pointless. Let's hope your side effects aren't going to be too bad.  Big hugs
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: The lack of taste is awful isn't it 1BB? Mine was made even worse as I was unable to eat anything spicy because of the diarrhoea/constipation issues I also suffered with. I found that cherry tomatoes and grapes were delicious - like a burst of sunshine in my mouth - and fresh orange juice too. Other than that, I lived on scrambled egg (doesn't taste of much anyway so it tasted fairly normal) and tinned tomato soup.
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Sorry to disappoint you bougiecat but 10 years is getting more and more common. My onco has already told me that I'd be on AIs for 10 years. Probably by then it'll be 15 lol, but if it stops the cancer coming back I'll live with it. Best
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: You're right anncg - my mistake. I have a nasty habit of not reading things carefully enough. 100 lines for me. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Maxine Glad to hear the tax truck hasn't hit you (yet?) I actually found T much easier than the AC I had to start with.  I too had the one-off injections - Neulasta or pegfilgastrim - with absolutely no problems at all. No pain, no aches and no mood influence so hopefully that'll be the same for you.  Best
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Yes. HER2+ is aggressive and we have to live with that! My response has been to take every treatment offered so I've had surgery, chemo, Herceptin, radio, hormone therapy and Denusomab injections so far (Denusomab is a bone strengthening drug but also offers a significant reduction in the risk of bone mets) and I'll take anything else on offer! I'm way past child-bearing (and rearing lol) so that wasn't an issue for me. I've never really liked children much so I doubt I would have worried, but I know I'm unusual in that. I guess it's worth freezing eggs, so at least you have some option in the future. You're better off than I was though, if your nodes are clear - I had a full clearance and 14/30 were cancerous. As a result of this, I had extra radiotherapy in my supra-clavicular area (near the collar bone) as that's the next point of spread. I had a whole body CT scan and bone scan and also had an MRI of my spine as there were "suspicious calcifications". They turned out to be just calcification thank goodness. I can see no reason why you shouldn't get married this year. You should be done with chemo in time for a lovely summer or autumn wedding to celebrate your health. If your fiance sticks by you through this then he's a keeper; if he doesn't then better to know now that he's a git, rather than a few years down the track. I'm now healthier than I've been for years and loving life, so there is hope after an HER2+ diagnosis. Hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: I forgot to mention, it might be worth asking why you've been diagnosed as stage 3 if you don't have spread to lymph nodes or elsewhere. That's usually a classic symptom for stage 3.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: Oh Laura89 I was so sad to read your story - it almost made me cry. I can't imagine what kind of hell you've been through, and are still going through. I've seen people on here have some of the problems you've had but not all of them together. I had a pretty terrible time with chemo but am very fortunate that healing after surgery was straightforward for me. I had a portacath so finding veins wasn't an issue. I'm in Australia and here it's standard practice for everyone who needs chemo to be fitted with a port, or at least a PICC line. I think it's wrong that they don't do so in the UK - probably a funding issue.  It sounds like you're healing now - I do hope that continues and you can eventually put this behind you, for the sake of your children.  May I ask at which hospital you're being treated?  Wishing you all the best, with a big virtual hug
Posts.Title: How much more can they throw at me??

Posts.Content: Mine felt more like a malteser. It was over 7cm but I can't recall the exact measurement. It was right under my boob so I didn't pick up up earlier unfortunately. Best
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: I had paclitaxel instead of docetaxel but, like you, my onco stopped treatment after 9 out of 12 sessions, as I had peripheral neuropathy. He told me that if it's confined to the hands and feet it's usually temporary but if it starts moving up the arms, it's more likely to be permanent. Now, 20 months after finishing, both my hands and feet have recovered, except I have a bit of tingling in my little and ring fingers of one hand. Nothing that affects my dexterity though.  I wouldn't be too concerned. It sounds like you're on a pretty normal treatment path.
Posts.Title: Stopping Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Yes you're right, everything does taste awful, except you'll probably find a few foods that are nice. For me, I lived on tinned tomato soup, scrambled egg, cherry tomatoes, grapes and fresh orange juice. Hot chips with gravy were pretty nice too but I tried not to have them too often.  Do try the bicarb mouthwash (1/2 tsp bicarb in a cup of water) before you eat as it briefly washes away that oily nasty feeling.  The other tip I was given is not to eat your very favourite foods as they'll taste wrong and may it may ruin them forever for you. I certainly came close to never eating mashed potato again. Fortunately, I've recovered from that sad situation now.
Posts.Title: Everything tastes awful!

Posts.Content: Hi Mark You shouldn't get too much with Herceptin. Apart from possible lowering of your LVEF, side effects are minor. You should already have had a MUGA scan or echocardiogram to check your LVEF and should have them repeated every 3 months. Mine dropped from 68 to 54 over the 12 months, which is still in the healthy range. You only have to worry if it goes below 45. The docs are very aware of this problem and usually monitor you closely.  The main side effect I've had is a persistent drippy nose. Not like a cold, just water dripping unexpectedly out of my nose. Minor but occasionally embarrassing. People here have also mentioned achey muscles. I have that but am not sure whether it's the H or the aromatase inhibitor I also have to take. It's not unbearable though.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: JeanieB Radio made me very tired indeed. I had my appt about noon each day then came home and slept for a couple of hours and still got a full 8 or 9 hours sleep. It was genuine tiredness though, not at all like chemo fatigue. Be reassured, I was feeling heaps better within a couple of weeks of finishing.
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: Can't say I've ever been a dreamer Buddha7. If they're vivid, I hope they're fun dreams not scary ones. L

Posts.Content: What a horrible position to be in Laura. I was also about to suggest that it might be time to get a second opinion. Whereabouts are you being treated? Is there a major cancer centre within reasonable travelling distance? The table at this link is a performance scorecard for all NHS trusts. You might find it useful, although it is by trust rather than individual hospital. I'm sure plenty of people on here would be able to recommend good treatment centres if you're inclined to look elsewhere. In the meantime, remember you have rights as a patient and if you're not getting the treatment or explanations you need then you could contact the PALS team at your hospital/trust. I don't really know  how that works (as I'm in Australia - it's different here) but I know other champs do, so I've tagged a couple Carolyn28 Dreamthief - one or other should be able to help.  Stay strong

Posts.Content: Hi Pennymoon  I was very ill in hospital during chemo. During that time, my husband solved the 'keep everyone informed' problem by sending a circular email to all my friends and relatives every couple of days. At least that way, everyone was included and got the same information. And of course, it was much easier on him than having to deal with constant inquiries. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Welshmakem Congrats on getting through chemo.  Let me say first that we all worry about cancer returning. However hard we try to put it out of our minds, it's lurking there ready to jump out at the slightest opportunity.  I don't think your surgeon would recommend a lumpectomy unless he was confident that it would deal with the problem but I do understand the feeling that you're safer if you chop off your boobs. I'm not sure that's strictly true however. Firstly, a friend of mine had a full mastectomy and when she went back a year or so later for a reconstruction they found a very small cancer. She was told that they don't necessarily manage to get ALL the breast tissue.  Secondly, recurrence of cancer in your breast is horrid but isn't nearly as bad as return elsewhere (lungs, liver, bones, brain mostly). A double mastectomy won't solve that. It's something you'll have to live with.   I'd suggest talking it over with the surgeon. He can take you through the relative risks. From what people have said on here, surgeons seem to leave the decision up to you but subtly (or maybe not so) push you in the direction they think is best. Be guided by the expert.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Last chemo and approaching surgery

Posts.Content: Hi rmjd. I hope chemo has treated you reasonably kindly and continues to do so.  I didn't have high calcium but my bloods were all over the place during chemo, mostly not serious and they settled down within 6 months of finishing. I think that's pretty normal. At least your medical team is on to the high calcium and you should be able to get an answer from your oncologist as to whether it's a serious problem.  Hope the rest of your treatment goes well for you.

Posts.Content: One of the "good" things about having had a whole body CT scan when I was first diagnosed was that it showed that I have arthritis in my lower spine and my left hip. Both are definitely worse since starting anastrozole and made even worse by sleeping on hard beds. It'll take me a couple of weeks to recover from the hard beds in Japan! Unpleasant and sometimes needing pain killers but not life threatening. Don't let your mind run away with you Snowys Mum - remember worry doubles the burden! Hope you get good results from the tests. Big hug to keep you going.

Posts.Content: Hi AntsNest I too have flaky fingernails which I blamed on chemo but, although I finished chemo end January, they haven't improved. I never thought it might be the Herceptin. I've been putting nail hardener (just a supermarket brand by Sally someone - it's made in England) which has really helped hold them together, although I keep them short. My drippy nose stopped about a week ago.  As for cramps, I get dreadful cramps when my magnesium levels are low (there is some benefit in all those blood tests) so I now take a magnesium supplement. They've gone for now.  Best Lynn xx

Posts.Content: It must be very frustrating not to have any answers Lelotron. I confess ductectomy is a new one on me but Dr Google tells me it's not uncommon. There are actually a few reputable scientific articles, which seem to suggest it's a good diagnostic tool.  Hard to know how painful it'll be so get the docs to give you some serious pain killers just in case.  I know that some people find even the biopsies quite painful, although I had no pain at all. Posts.Title: Ductectomy - what should I expect?

Posts.Content: The white blood cells won't go back to normal levels within 3 weeks but should improve enough for you to have your next chemo treatment. I too had neulasta when I was having the AC part of the treatment and my white cells increased very significantly.  I'm struggling to remember the details now but I think that your white cell count is at its lowest about 10 days after the treatment. For me in Australia the minimum level to get the next treatment was 1 (normal is 3+ I think). Trouble is I can't remember the unit of measurement so I'm not much help really. Don't forget that after the first treatment you'll be starting out with a low count so you are likely to drop into the neutropenic range very quickly. Best of luck with your treatment. Lynn
Posts.Title: Blood Cell Count

Posts.Content: I managed to avoid colds during treatment (but I've had 4 since finishing 10 months ago so I've caught up). The only advice I can give is to watch the paracetamol as it can mask a high temperature. I'd ring your BCN and check that paracetamol is ok to take. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: the common cold

Posts.Content: I asked the oncology registrar about R1 and R2. He'd never heard of it but said he'd look into it. I decided not to raise the subject again as I don't want them to tell me NOT to use it. I've been using it every day and for me it's been brilliant. I've had 12 sessions so far and my skin is only just pink. (I've always had a bit of a problem with being told what to do lol) Interesting about the aqueous cream. We are given tubes of aqueous cream by the hospital and told to use only that - perhaps the formulation here in Australia is different.  Best to all Lynn
Posts.Title: Confusion over R1 and R2

Posts.Content: Hi Confusedbear  I don't think I've seen you posting before, so if this is your first time welcome aboard the roller coaster. Or as someone else said, welcome to the Hotel California. You know - the one where you can check out but never leave. It sounds like that's exactly the case for you.  How long is it since you finished chemo and radio and Herceptin if you had it? My oncologist told me that fatigue can linger around for up to 2 years from the end of treatment. I finished chemo proper in January last year, Herceptin in September, radio in May, I felt that I was pretty ok 6 months after I finished chemo, then I got another burst of energy when I finished Herceptin. However, I do still get really exhausted if I overdo it - I then crash badly. I don't sleep very well either so I'm sure a lot of the problem is that. But overall I feel really well so I'm not too bothered.  Bottom line is that you may well still feel fatigued so don't worry too much, unless it keeps getting worse. I'd mention it to your onco or GP whenever your next visit is. Best of luck
Posts.Title: Fatigue after treatment has finished

Posts.Content: I had chemo (AC and paclitaxel) and herceptin through my port. No problems at all. It's also pretty standard here in Australia as it causes way fewer problems for patients. Go for it! Best  Lynn xx

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky. I forgot to mention that my oncologist was quite satisfied that 9 paclitaxel was enough to have "done the job". He said that there's a lot of debate about how much is enough of any chemo but many centres give docetaxel or 3 weekly paclitaxel only 3 times and that works. You will feel well again soon. It took me about 3 weeks after the last paclitaxel to feel really different and what a fantastic feeling that was! Best  Lynn xx

Posts.Title: Confusion over R1 and R2

Posts.Content: Hi alli1970 Sounds like you've been through the mill!  I had a saved skin mastectomy with implant in June 2015. All was fine for a few months then I got really ill from chemo. This included putting on about 10 kg of fluid. Eventually the fluid went from everywhere except my new boob, which was like a football on my chest. That in turn caused capsular contracture. The physio tried everything to get the fluid to shift but nothing worked so eventually surgery was the only option. By then I'd had enough and decided to get my boob chopped off. That was in March 2016. At the time I didn't want a reconstruction because of the fluid issues. I still feel the same - why run the risk? I've been using knitted knockers ever since and am quite happy with them as you just pin them inside a regular bra. Everyone I tell says they can't tell the difference and my hubby doesn't care. I'm lopsided Lizzie at home, but that doesn't worry me either - I'm alive! The only negative for you that I can see is that it's an additional surgery. My current view is to avoid surgery wherever possible lol. Merry Christmas Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Implant removal

Posts.Title: Hair loss or otherwise on Docetaxel

Posts.Content: HiCocopops1 I had side effects more or less immediately. The worst was diahorrea, which usually lasted a couple of days. I also used to get indigestion/reflux but that was more likely around day 3-4 and I still had some fatigue, but not nearly as much as with AC. Probably the most serious side effect was peripheral neuropathy, which didn't start for a couple of weeks. It just got worse over the weeks. In the end my onco stopped the paclitaxel after 9 doses, as it was quite bad in my hands. It then took about 6 months to go but I'm fine now.  Hope your SEs are really mild
