Posts.Title: More unnecessary tears...

Posts.Content: You poor thing Puzzle - lymphoedema can be very sore. However, it does seem to be a very early diagnosis. Normally breast lymphoedema (BL) isn't diagnosed for several months after surgery so it can be distinguished from swelling/fluid retention relating to the surgery. BL is tough to deal with. I have it - sometimes it feels like I have a football hanging off my chest - and it makes me wish I'd gone for a full mastectomy rather than a skin saving mastectomy. Little pain though as I have no nerves left in that area - grateful for small mercies! I was referred to a lymphoedema physiotherapist who has been great. Treatment is a combination of manual lymph drainage (gentle massage), taping and compression. I have to massage my breast and chest for 20 mins twice a day and wear an elasticated band around my boobs (like a Victorian corset) for as much time as I can bear. The physio is also going to strap it with kinesio tape next week, although that will make showering impossible, which isn't so great in the Aussie summer! I'll do it though as I have to try to reduce the BL before I have radio.  You're right that there isn't much out there about BL. There's quite a good article on cancer.org - the American cancer society's website but that's all I've found other than ads for compression garments. I have discovered though that up to 70% of people who have breast surgery do get BL. The only other advice I can offer is to say keep up with your exercises. They're really important.  Let us know how you go - I'll be open to suggestions too! Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Lymphoedema in breast - need advice

Posts.Title: Prosthetics without a bra

Posts.Content: I chose a saved skin mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. At first it was wonderful - I had a lovely pert boob and you couldn't tell with my clothes on. However, during chemo I got really really ill and put on a lot of fluid (about 3 stone's worth) and blew up like a balloon. Eventually the fluid went - from everywhere except my breast. For 3 months I was told it would go away by itself. It didn't and I ended up with what they call a septated seroma (aka a football on my chest). This is essentially where the breast fills with fluid and then fibres grow through it, making it like a sponge. It's impossible to drain cos the fluid ends up in loads of small cavities. I also had capsular contracture, which is fibres growing round the implant and squeezing it. To cut a long story short, I ended up having the breast removed and I'm much better. My radiooncologist also told me that it's harder to get a good result with radiotherapy if you have an implant (hard for them to get to the chest wall behind the implant). If I had my time over, I'd go for a full mastectomy.  Best of luck with whatever decision you make. Lynn xxx

Posts.Title: Preparing for chemo

Posts.Content: Hey Julia. I'd say the cost of cancer treatment is a lot more than 30 000 pounds. My (ever so nerdy) husband worked out that my treatment was close to A$700 000. Leaving aside the cost of my stay in hospital, it would've been around $300 000 - that's about 185 000 pounds - for surgery (2), chemo, radio, herceptin and appointments with the various doctors. Apart from anything else, I had 4 Neulasta injections - that's $24 000. The cost of Herceptin for a year is US$70 000 in the USA but here in Aust, the govt has managed to negotiate the price down to around A$50 000 (c 31000 pounds), so I guess a similar price would apply in the UK. Scary isn't it but it shows just how blessed we are to live in countries with a good public health system. Like in the UK, the public health system here in Australia is showing the strain, with ever more millions needed to prop it up. The government keeps trying to impose different small charges to try to stem the rising costs but people are naturally resistant. I guess we all believe good public health care is a right, but I'm not sure it can go on forever increasing. Mind you, I'd hate to live in the US where many people cant afford chemo drugs and the biggest cause of personal bankruptcy is medical bills.  Off my soapbox now
Posts.Title: Concerned about recent news

Posts.Content: I didn't lose my nails but they did go flaky and pretty cr*p. 9 weeks post chemo and I can see the healthy regrowth. I didn't lose any but I did have to keep them very short cos of the flaking. I was told not to use a commercial mouthwash but I was given a baking soda based mouthwash at the hospital. It was wonderful - I had no mouth problems at all. There are plenty of recipes for it on the internet.  Really the best advice I can give you is to drink heaps, especially directly after your treatment - I did 3 litres in the first 24 hrs and then tried to stick to at least 2 litres the rest of the time. I found weak Ribena was easy to tolerate.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky SpicedTea I had peripheral neuropathy, mainly in my hands, when I had paclitaxel. I had numb fingers and tingly palms. My onco said it was usually temporary if it didn't spread up your arm but if  it spread further than your hand, it could be permanent. In the end, he stopped the chemo after 9 sessions as it was getting too bad. That was end January. Now my right hand is pretty much ok but my left still tingles, especially the ring and little fingers. Not badly enough to prevent me from doing anything though. You'll find it's going to be slow to recover cos nerves take ages to regrow.  I would at least ring your onco's rooms as they do like to keep an eye on neuropathy.  And no need to feel guilty. Everyone has something and that's just the way it is.  Best Lynn xx

Posts.Title: Silly radiotherapy question -

Posts.Content: I too had a really negative view of radio as I have very fair skin. I admit I wasn't that thrilled about the thought of being blasted either. However, both my radio-oncologist and the radio nurses were very kind and explained things very clearly.  I've now had 5 radio treatments (20% through yay!) and I have nothing to show on my skin at all so far. It's a bit red immediately afterwards but that goes within a couple of hours. The worst part for me is the discomfort of having my arms above my head and head turned to the right and having to keep absolutely still for 20 mins or so. I find my shoulder joints get locked and my neck aches. I have resorted to having a stash of neurofen in my bag and taking a couple as soon as I finish. That seems to work! Radio does reduce the risk of local recurrence quite significantly and with an aggressive cancer (HER2+) I went ahead with radio as I want to do anything I can to make sure it doesn't come back. Best wishes for your future treatment.

Posts.Title: Treatment finished :-)

Posts.Content: Oh LondonLass we're all praying, lighting joss sticks and leaving offerings for a good outcome for you. The very best thing would be that you've worked yourself into a stew over nothing. What can you do on Tuesday to dislodge the worry, even if only for an hour?  Now about those drugs ... You know very well that aromatase inhibitors are very helpful so I don't need to emphasise that. You also know that the side effects vary with each person so it's wrong to expect you'll definitely be badly hit by them. You will need to do the assertive patient thing again if the doc suggests an AI. Firstly, make him/her take you through the pluses and minuses of each of the three and genuinely discuss which of them would be best for you. Secondly, kick up the world's biggest fuss to make sure you get prescribed the patented version ie Femara, Arimidex or Aromasin. You, like me, would have read enough complaints on this forum to know that most people seem to find the patented version much easier than any of the generics. Personally, I find Arimidex perfectly OK - a little stiffness if I sit for too long eg in a movie or on a flight, but it goes within a minute or so of moving around. That's all.  Finally, I fear that you're in danger of talking yourself into horrid side effects. Nothing I can say about that, except beware and try not to. Maybe you could try talking yourself into it all being ok???  I'm really sorry if this sounds hard, I don't mean it that way. Think of it as tough love. Big hugs and I hope it all goes well tomorrow.
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi Peanut. I too found water hard to take during chemo. I ended up drinking weak Ribena, which I normally can't stand. Orange or lemon squash were ok too. I went right off coffee but did manage some tea and found herbal teas with rose hip in them to be very tasty. Also, I used to make up ginger tea by slicing a whole finger of ginger and soaking it in boiling water. Then I kept it in the fridge. Makes a really nice cold drink and has the added benefit of keeping the nausea at bay.
Posts.Title: Drink

Posts.Content: Hi wonkyboob Sorry to be late replying. Everyone on here would say the waiting for results is the worst time, as your imagination can run away with you.  I don't think you need to worry that your local hospital wasn't sure what was going on. The main thing is that they referred you on to a specialist centre who do. I know Carolyn28 is having her treatment at the Royal Marsden and is very happy with them.  Even if you have a "teeny tiny cancer" that's good news in a weird way. It means you've caught it very early and it should therefore be curable. The survival rate for BC is over 90% overall and for early cancers even higher. Finding it is the first stage of recovery! Wishing you all the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Radial Scar in left breast

Posts.Content: Hi Booth1986. Welcome aboard the roller coaster. I'm not surprised you're worrying - it's completely normal. The early stages of diagnosis are awful as you are thrust into a new scary world and don't understand much of what's being said to you. And that's before I mention the waiting, which gets to us all. I can assure you though that once you have a treatment plan in place and start grinding through it, things will settle down and become far more routine.  It's good news that your lymph nodes have tested negative. That means the cancer is most unlikely to have spread as the lymph nodes are the first place it spreads to. They will re-test when you have surgery but even if they do discover some cancer cells, it's still unlikely there's been any further spread. It's the role of the lymph nodes to catch any escaping cells so finding a few just means the nodes are doing their job.  ER negative means that your tumour isn't fed by oestrogen. The consequence of this is that you won't be offered tamoxifen or one of the other hormone suppressing drugs after your surgery as they won't be of any help. You are also more likely to be offered chemo as this is a more effective treatment for hormone negative cancer. They will also test your tumour to see whether it is HER2 positive or negative. If positive, there's a different drug regime again. All this testing helps the docs work out exactly which type of breast cancer you have and what will be the most effective treatment. While they do biopsies before surgery, the best information comes from testing the actual tumour after it's been removed.  When you see your surgeon after surgery, you should ask him/her to explain the results of the pathology testing - and keep asking till you completely understand. I'd suggest you ask for a copy of the pathology report too. You can also ask here as there are plenty of knowlegeable people who'll be able to assist you. In the meantime, kick back and wait for the surgery. There's no point in getting ahead of yourself.  Hope it all goes well.
Posts.Title: Pre op today can't wait to get it out

Posts.Content: I had thyroid problems, which the endocrinologist put down to having too many scans ie too much iodine contrast dye in a short period. Smart man probably saved my life.

Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: I'm so glad you weren't offended. It was definitely meant kindly xxx And I do understand about the drugs - I think I've mentioned before just how many I take these days. The only benefit is that I take so many, I never forget to take them lol. It's a public holiday here - ANZAC day, roughly like Remembrance Day I guess, when everyone salutes our fallen soldiers. Australians are very militaristic and very jingoistic too. I think it's rather tiresome. Anyway it's 12.40 pm and pouring with rain so I can't even get out in the garden. Therefore I have wasted the entire morning - haven't even washed up from last night lol. Hubby the same - he's been lying on the sofa watching TV since just after he had breakfast. Must get my A into G.  Now try for some sleep or at least think nice thoughts. We used to go to a lovely hotel in Bali, which unfortunately has closed for renovations. Every day we'd lie in the same spot right by the pool, on banana lounges under a frangipani tree. Some of the happiest times of my life so that is my "happy place", and I try to visualise it whenever anything horrid is happening eg lying in the MRI machine or when I can't sleep.  Just to the left of this pic Hugs
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: I'm in Australia and it works slightly differently here. Drug funding is managed separately. Drugs are either listed as open or restricted. If open, the GP can prescribe what they want and it'll be paid for. Restricted drugs have to be separately approved. That's usually cos they're expensive. Neulasta is in that category - to get approved you have to prove that you need it ie that you go neutropenic. In effect, it means you don't get it for the first treatment but do for later ones. I guess that's a cost saver in itself but I'm kinda ok with it, given that it costs over $2000 per shot.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: Hi knicnic What a crap thing to happen just before Christmas, or at any time really. Just remember that the main thing is that your mum found the lump and is doing something about it. That's the first step in getting fixed up! It ma;y or may not be breast cancer - no one knows till the biopsy results are in, but what I do know is that spending the next weeks worrying about it will do absolutely nothing to change the diagnosis. Do try to park the worrying if you can. Distractions can be good and there's plenty of scope for that round christmas time. All the while bear in mind that breast cancer is very very treatable and the vast majority of people survive. In my city, 96% of people who have BC survive for at least 5 years. I think in most places it's over 90%.  Try to help your mum through this by not over-worrying, helping her with stuff, doing research for her, and contributing whatever you can to making it a really good Christmas for your family. Wishing you and your mum all the very best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump over 50

Posts.Content: Statins are generally very safe and half the Western world takes them! They slightly elevate the risk of developing type 2 diabetes but then I developed it from the steroids I had with chemo! My experience is that most weird things happening in your body can be pinned down to the horrible chemicals that are/have been pumped into you. I have taken the view that there's nothing I can do about that side of it, so I'd best go with the drugs that improve the situation with the various weird things. Do the research (ahhh Dr Google ...) but personally I'd go for them as they do really work.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: I'm HER2 positive too. My onco said it's a nasty aggessive type of cancer but now we have Herceptin survival rates are similar to other BCs. He thinks there's no reason I shouldn't live to my 80s.
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Sounds like your head is in the right place Grannie - that makes such a difference. Enjoy the cream cake and best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 2nd chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi TootsBess Fatigue sucks. I found that it took me 6 months before I was really on top of things and I still have episodes of fatigue if I overdo it (13 months since I finished chemo). Both my onco and GP have told me it can take up to 2 years. By coincidence, I was just looking over an old thread on this very topic. You might find it interesting https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_experiences/moving_on___post_treatment/f/738/p/117453/936529#936529 Best
Posts.Title: Post Chemo Fatigue and Hair!

Posts.Content: I've got 4 knitted knockers that I made myself. I actually made 6 in the end but the first two were too big. Two are 'aqua knockers' to go inside my swimmers - they're filled with shower scrunchies rather than fibre fill so they dry quickly.  Lynn
Posts.Title: 2nd chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: "The other thing is why give one pill...Aromasin...and then give another to counteract its effect....Zometa?" It doesn't work quite like that Nicola. The Aromasin is to reduce the amount of oestrogen in your body as your kind of cancer needs oestrogen to grow. Unfortunately one of the consequences of reduced oestrogen is the potential for thinning of your bones or osteoporosis. The Zometa is to strengthen your bones. The good news is that Zometa and similar drugs have an anti-cancer effect, reducing the risk of bone mets.  None of us like having to take drugs (oh goody an extra pill today - I don't think so) but each step in the treatment is designed to reduce the risk of your cancer recurring or spreading.  Wishing you all the very best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy & Hormone treatment positive lymph node

Posts.Content: Hi Acidomoduso Welcome aboard. I'm so sorry to hear about your mum. It can be really hard when you're not part of the conversations with the doctors and are trying to piece everything together. Is there any chance your mum might let you go with her to appointments? It's pretty normal practice to do a head to pelvis CT scan when cancer cells are found in the lymph nodes. This is to check for spread of the cancer to other organs eg the lungs and liver. The bone scan would be to check for any spread to her bones. It's as much about ruling out any distant spread as anything. It's quite possible the earlier CT scan didn't cover a wide enough area. There's a handy table here that describes each grade and stage. Wishing you and your family all the best.
Posts.Title: Confusion about stages and grades

Posts.Content: Brilliant news. Time to celebrate
Posts.Title: Phew!

Posts.Content: I went without a bra most of the time through radio, as it was too uncomfortable. I did find that any fabric, other than cotton, irritated my skin (eg the one time I wore a Tshirt of a cotton/polyester mix). Mostly for me, it was the elastic around the base of the bra that was uncomfortable. I was lucky that it was winter so wore Tshirts and very loose sweatshirts - it was hardly noticeable that I only had one boob. Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Bra for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I too had bad sleep initially. The best advice I read was on either Macmillan or a similar site. It said - if you can't sleep at night, sleep during the day. As for how to get to sleep. The person who could work that out would be very rich indeed! I try to empty my mind and every time it wanders I tell myself to relax. It's a variant of the old hippie mantra thing, only my mantra is "just relax, just relax". Surprisingly, it works about 90% of the time. If it doesn't, I just read for a while. I have a backlit kindle so I don't have to have the light on, which is also conducive to sleep. Best of luck, I know it can be awful. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Sleepness nights

Posts.Content: Hi Scotland. I'm same as you - surgery, chemo, radio, herceptin, aromatase inhibitors. I was naturally nervous before my first chemo but don't worry, you soon become an old lag. The most important thing to remember is that you're trying to give yourself the best chance of fixing this. Even if each treatment only lowers the risk of recurrence by a few percentage points, in the end they add up to a very strong survival rate. Keep your eye on that prize! Best of luck with your treatment. Lynn

Posts.Title: Happy news....

Posts.Content: Strange how our minds work, isn't it? I thought I was cool and confident for my first annual check up, particularly as I feel so good and am fitter than I have been for years. I was totally calm through the mammo and ultrasound but then ... when I went to pick up the film and results letter the next day I was a quivering mess. I sat in the car for about half an hour not wanting to open it. Great feeling though when I plucked up the courage and got the all clear! I guess we all worry in some way! Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: First year follow up mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Islanikita I don't have big boobs (or one now at least) but I have had many of the same problems as you. When I had my first surgery (saved skin mastectomy with reconstruction) I was a size 24 and do you think the hospital had any of them - of course not. I was given one that was about 3 sizes too small round the back and about 2 cup sizes too big. It wasn't till I was able to get out to a specialist shop that I found anything that even fitted. And I can't say that they were in any way attractive! A long and sorry story which I won't bore you with resulted in my new boob filling with fluid (ultimately they got 3 litres out of it), the implant getting twisted and having fibres growing round it. In the end surgery was the only way to fix it but by then I was so over having a football on my chest that I just opted for a mastectomy to put an end to it all. I do not regret it at all.  Once that had healed and radio was finished, I had to do something about bras. I've dropped 2 dress sizes in that time so I thought it would be easy - how hard can it be to get a size 20C bra. Tried heaps but wasted my money. In the end, I decided to take the underwire out of my favourite moulded bras from before and do them up on the first row of hooks. They work well and look great. Lord knows what I'll do when they wear out. I have 4 but 2 are looking tatty! As for knitted knockers, I love them. It took me 4 goes to get it exactly right for me but now I've knitted 4 (one for each bra) plus a couple that I've filled with bath scrunchie stuff for swimming. The blessing is that I've now been able to match my other boob pretty exactly and also I can pin them inside my bra or swimmers so they never move. Highly recommend but you do have to fiddle a bit initially till you're satisfied with the look.  As far as the mastectomy goes, as ronstar said, I do have a positive view. In a funny way, it's actually made me feel more feminine, along the lines of "you can take my hair, you can take my boob, but I'm still a woman". I haven't hidden it from my husband or my friends - everyone's had a look, even my 16 year old nephew! (That's because he's about to have major surgery and was really worried about the scar, so I showed him that scars aren't that bad). Most of the time at home I don't wear a bra, never have, so I'm lopsided Lizzie and I don't care! I'll happily open the front door, talk to the cleaner and so on. I've even been down to the shops, but only in winter time and with a loose sweatshirt - I'm more embarrassed about how saggy my one boob is than I am about not having one on the other side. When I had radio I used to put the R1 cream on in the changeroom at the hospital and not wear a bra to go home. Didn't care as I figured everyone around had something to do with cancer so they'd be tolerant if they in fact noticed.  I guess everyone eventually finds their own solution. I hope you find yours soon. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: I decided to be out and proud and didn't bother with the cold cap. I cut my hair shorter and shorter. I found my hair painful where it rubbed eg against the pillow so eventually I shaved my head (or hubby did actually). I don't have a wig or scarf but sometimes wear a hat - in winter when I was cold and now in the sun. The up side is that I've found that people are really kind plus I get great service in cafes and restaurants! Being bald doesn't bother me at all now.
Posts.Title: Cold cap & some hair loss

Posts.Content: That's completely crap Peartree Let's hope it all turns out to be lumpiness and not a recurrence. You know the drill - you can't change the outcome so try not to worry about the results. Easy to say but hard to do I know.  Big hug and I truly hope it turns out well for you Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Please....not again

Posts.Content: Fourteen out of 30 of my lymph nodes were cancerous. All 30 removed. That was in June 2015. Now I'm healthy and fitter than I have been for 15 years and definitely loving life. I rarely think about it these days. Of course I occasionally have dark moments but these are getting less and less frequent and I prefer to just get on with my life.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Worrying again

Posts.Content: My view is drink it if you fancy it - there's so much that is horrible! I drank Ribena and orange squash.  I'm not a believer in artificial sweeteners. I don't like the idea of the additional chemicals; after all we've had enough pumped into us. Best
Posts.Title: Can i drink lucozade on chemo

Posts.Content: You're hot today George Dreamthief  But seriously, Yogijo if you're sore then I wouldn't be shaving. If your skin is ok then try hair removal cream. I only use that now as I'm a bit nervous about cutting myself as the area is totally numb. Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Armpit shaving!

Posts.Content: Hi Jess. I used manuka honey skin cream. It's fabulous but be careful as there are lots of fakes out there. Buy only from a chemist or reputable health food shop. Best if made in New Zealand. For my face, I was lucky enough to win a pot of Guerlain face cream a few years ago which I'd never used. However, it's really expensive to buy.
Posts.Title: Body lotion

Posts.Content: Hi KiwiCardi I had bolus too. It was laid across my chest area. I too had a mastectomy so maybe it's related to that. I know they're intended to modify the depth or angle of the radiation beam. Occasionally the technicians will make a personally shaped bolus for big breasted ladies. Not applicable to you and I though lol. I used r2 on the weekend - usually managed 4x per day as I didn't have to scrub for treatment. No need to use the R1 but it's nice and cooling if you feel you're burning up.  Best
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy questions

Posts.Content: Hi Evie - every journey is different but I can assure you that no one gets all the SEs and most of the nasties are not common. If you're having the usual 8 treatments, by tomorrow night you'll already be 12.5% completed!  I hope you've packed your goodie bag for tomorrow. I used to take boiled lollies, things to do (kindle, knitting, puzzle book) and a wrap. I was treated in a private hospital, which was really good about providing morning tea and lunch plus loads of drink choices, but some people take additional food and drinks as well.  Drink lots of water tonight, tomorrow morning and in the 24 hours following. Try also to take some gentle exercise. That way you circulate the chemo to where it needs to be and then flush it out quickly.  Wishing you all the very best - you'll soon be an old lag. Let us know how you go. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 1st session

Posts.Content: Hi all. My story is a bit of a tale of woe but I'm healthy so that's the main thing! I had a saved skin mastectomy with immediate implant in June 2015. Neither the surgeon nor the radio oncologist was concerned about having the implant before radiotherapy. I healed well and everything was rosy until about September, during chemo, when I got really sick with atrial fibrillation and PEs. Around that time I also started amassing fluid everywhere - ended up being about 10kg (almost 2 stone worth of fluid). Cutting a long story short, eventually I lost the fluid - everywhere except my reconstructed breast. By Christmas it was as if I was carrying a football on my chest, despite having been told it would eventually go and having lots of physio and binding.  I finished chemo end January and had my radio planning appointment but the fluid was so bad the radio oncologist was reluctant to go ahead. An ultrasound showed that the fluid, which by then they were calling a seroma, had septated ie grown lots of little fibres so the inside looked like a sponge rather than a balloon filled with water.  Also, the fibres had grown round the implant causing capsular contracture, ie squeezing and distorting it. Surgery to fix it was the only solution. By then I was so sick of the whole situation I opted for a full mastectomy and havent regretted it. The surgeon managed to drain 3 litres of fluid, which she said was "spectacular". I had a small seroma for a while but that's now healed and I've had my radio too. I may opt for a reconstruction at some point in the future but I'm reluctant at the moment as I don't fancy any further fluid problems! Apparently this whole situation is really rare - neither my surgeon nor my radio oncologist nor my medical oncologist had ever seen anything like it - so don't fear this happening. The only advice I'd give as a result of my experience is watch the fluid. You will be told that seromas eventually fix themselves but don't believe it - some do but many don't. Just keep on top of the situation. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: That sounds like a terrible day overall nannanap, although it does sound like your surgery was successful, which is the important thing.  I hope your daughter is OK - you never stop worrying about them do you? And as for the Japanese flag - I'd never heard that one before and it took me a couple of minutes to work it out lol.  Hope you managed to get some sleep and that today is better for all of you. Remember the surgery might have seemed easy but it still has a major impact on your body and you do need to rest. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Just another day - Again!

Posts.Content: It may be a sleep problem rather than a bladder problem. We all program ourselves through our life to have a wee if we wake. I do, even though sometimes it's only a tablespoonful! I think it would be worth talking to your GP.
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy -Dehydration, waking at night etc.

Posts.Content: I've just seen your second post about the infection risk. It exists of course and some people do suffer badly. I had no problems though. I stuck to the pregnancy diet - no shellfish, blue cheese, deli meats (except prepacked from the supermarket). We also had bottles of handwash everywhere and I was meticulous about using them. I also cleaned the kitchen bench each time with spray n wipe before preparing food. Importantly, I was given bicarb mouthwash and used it several times a day as the mouth is an open entry for infections. I had to give up my volunteer work at an aged care facility as my onco was very concerned about antibiotic resistant bacteria but that was the only real sacrifice.  Get a digital thermometer if you don't already have one and take your temp regularly. This will enable you to take early action if your temp rises. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 1st session

Posts.Content: I started getting cystitis during Tax - repeated bouts but no evidence of infection. Eventually I worked out why - I had started using the exercise bike regularly and was having what one might call friction issues. I got a gel seat cover and have had no further problems.  Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Chemo side effects once chemo finished

Posts.Content: Same same but different. I started on Letrozole but was switched to Anastrozole as the hot flushes and night sweats were unbearable. Better so far ... I have been stiff and creaky on both but it's worst if I stay seated for too long. If I keep moving around and get plenty of exercise my body loosens up and it's quite bearable.  Best of luck! Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Anastrozole to Tamoxifen then Letrozole

Posts.Content: OH dillybub how horrid for you!!!!! I had a similar experience a couple of months ago. I went for my annual mammo and ultrasound (3years) and the US showed a "nodule" in my good boob, near my nipple. Had to wait a week to get an MRI and another week for the results. Very scary. Fortunately it was all clear. As I said at the time it was pretty frightening but looking back, it did show that my team was on the ball and I couldn't have asked for more support and assistance. That's reassuring.  I'll be thinking of you and hope everything works out well. Big hugs
Posts.Title: New Lump

Posts.Content: Thanks candytop Big hugs to you. You'll get there. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: Yes Pollyp I lost 38 kg, which is about 5 stone I think. However, that was mostly because i was so ill during chemo. Not a diet I'd recommend but a very pleasing side effect lol. EXCEPT very few of my clothes are wearable - they hang off me and look terrible, even my favourites. I don't want to buy too many though as I need to lose more. Never satisfied! Love the idea of just taking one underwire out. I might try that. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: I can't promise you'll feel improved maxinem2 but I strongly suspect you will. All power to you.  And to tag ... just type an @ symbol and start typing the name of the person eg @kacang and a list of suggestions will magically appear. Click on the correct one and you've tagged that person.  Best
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: I'm sorry I can't help you on this one. Suggest you ring the doc's office and ask - just to be sure. Best of luck with it.
Posts.Title: Like zoladex but not zoladex

Posts.Content: Hi Emi. You are not broken - just a bit bent out of shape perhaps. The worst part of this whole journey is the early bit where you are bombarded with tests, words you don't understand and appointment after appointment. Eventually it all settles into a rhythm and before you know it, you're coping.  It is gruelling, sometimes painful and sometimes scary but most of all it's do-able. Everyone's journey is different but we've all had good bits and bad bits. You'll find great people on this site who are happy to help/chat and who have been through the same thing. I've found it invaluable.  I second the advice already given - try to get them to give you a portacath or at least a PICC or Hickman line before you start chemo. While the portacath is the gold medal winner, they are all better than having chemo through cannulas. Make sure to be kind to yourself - you don't have to be a martyr. Family and friends will want to help - let them! Welcome to the club none of us wanted to join and I hope you're feeling calmer about it all soon. Best wishes  Lynn
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed with HRE2+ AND ER+ breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi GrandmaRob It's lovely of you to want to help your aunt. She may think she can manage by herself, but it will be hard for her so anything you can do will be appreciated I'm sure. Apart from anything else, having some company can make it all feel not as overwhelming.  As others have said, the ban on lifting is the most important and yet probably the hardest if you live alone. I was told to lift no more than 3kg (7lbs) for 3 weeks, nor to do any activity that required heavy duty use of my arm eg digging, vacuuming. I would say that shopping and putting the rubbish out are the two most difficult tasks. Shopping's ok if you only have one bagful, that you can carry with the other arm but I had to rely on my husband to put out the bins (still do lol). Also, for the first few days she won't have much energy, so perhaps a few meals cooked for her? In addition, the hospital I was in won't let people go home as early if there's no one there. She might be kept in a bit longer, or is it possible you could stay over one or two nights? You haven't mentioned follow up treatment but if she has to have chemo or radiotherapy, then lifts to and from the hospital will be appreciated, even if it's only sometimes.  Wishing your aunt all the best.
Posts.Title: Care after Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1 The first time I found a lump, about 15 years ago, I ignored it completely and it sat there until I had my mastectomy last year. But when I found the second one last year, I think I knew it was BC and was at the doc's the next day and yep sure enough ... we all try to ignore/procrastinate/decide it's something benign at some point.  I don't have anything to add to the good advice and kind words that people have already given but I wanted to say hi and that I hope it turns out well for you. If not, then do stay connected with this group. The people here are great and have helped me through some tough times. Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: I had a mammo and ultrasound of my remaining breast and an ultrasound of the chest area on my affected side. That's the standard here in Australia. If you don't get offered ultrasound, I'd push for it.  I'll share some wise advice from my onco, which might help ease your anxieties. He said that recurrence or mets are never without symptoms - lump, unusual pain, breathlessness, headaches and so on so the most important thing to do is to know your body and be alert to any changes. This is more effective than any scans as they only reflect a single point in time.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Screening after bresst cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Dee KiwiCardi How irritating - just when you thought you were getting over it all!  I haven't had arm lymphoedema but I did have the 'football' on the chest fluid problems. The physios tried manual lymph drainage and taught me how to do it - gradually stroking across from bad side to good side etc - have they shown you that? I was also told to keep my arm elevated whenever possible.  I was also told to do arm exercises with light weights (not more than 1kg) but I think that's not universally accepted as a good idea - some say lift no weight - even shopping - with that arm. Anyway I do some exercises with light weights and haven't had a problem so far.  Someone has had success with kinesio taping - I think it's Crystaljuju but she's away at the moment.  Best
Posts.Title: Possible to reduce lymphodema in arm?

Posts.Content: Great news Mattyg. You must both be so pleased.  Dreamthief posted details of a great article about recovering from treatment. Unfortunately I can't remember the details and I don't know how to tag him (sorry) but it's worth a read if you can find it. The essential argument is that it takes time and there are several phases.  Have a fabbo holiday and all the best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: All over, thank you x

Posts.Content: Yep Batfinkcaz I had a strong sense that I was going to have a health 'train wreck'. I thought it would be a heart attack as that runs strongly in my family. One good thing coming out of having BC is that I now know my heart is strong as it's been checked and re-checked.  I think at some level your body knew it was unwell but you didn't process it consciously - I don't believe you bring it on either.
Posts.Title: Feeling old and tired before diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi KiwiCardi I do hope the MLD works for you. It should do some good. When I saw the lymphoedema physio, she said that firstly you need to 'give the lymph somewhere to go' so to rub my good armpit about 10 times in a circular motion, then stroke from the centre across the top of my right breast about 5 times, then across my left breast area from armpit to centre 5 times, then up the arm, repeat until bored, or for at least 10 minutes. This apparently gets the fluid moving to where you actually have nodes to deal with it. Only very light strokes as it's all just under the skin. Might be worth a try.
Posts.Title: Possible to reduce lymphodema in arm?

Posts.Content: Hi again Mattyg. The article I was referring to is: After The Treatment Finishes - Then What ? Dr Peter Harvey Help with understanding emotional feelings of what you have been through when all the appointments end.
Posts.Title: All over, thank you x

Posts.Content: How annoying for you. A week seems a long time to wait for your results to me and of course it's always an anxious time. Try not to let it take over. Lots of love  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: In a right tizz now!

Posts.Content: I have a couple of Pilkington glass pieces Kerry, that my grandmother bought there for me (I'm a bit of a glass nut lol).  The Glassworks here is just for art glass. It was originally a power station so has massive ceilings. I'm sure down by the furnaces it would be dreadfully hot but at least in the spectator areas it's fine. Beginners only get to use bunsen burners so I'm in no danger of extra hot flushes lol Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Who am I now? Answers on a postcard please.....

Posts.Content: Great news Dee. Would be terrific if you can dump the sleeve most of the time.  Best
Posts.Title: Possible to reduce lymphodema in arm?

Posts.Content: Hi Mom74 Which part of chemo are you having first - the T or the AC? The reason I ask is that not everyone loses their hair with T, but hair loss is virtually guaranteed with AC.  Don't worry, it doesn't all just drop off, like taking off a hat. You may notice some on your pillow, as mentioned, or that your hairbrush has more hair than usual. Another key sign is that your hair starts hurting, rather like a too-tight ponytail. That can become unbearable and that's when most people shave their hair off.  I had my AC first and started losing my hair about a week in. As soon as that happened, hubby and I sat down with a bottle of champagne while he shaved me. That was recommended by my GP lol.  Hope you're not finding the chemo too awful.
Posts.Title: TAC and hair loss

Posts.Content: Hi Tray41 Breathlessness is a curse! The most common cause is low red blood cell count making you super tired but it can also be caused by heart issues or more seriously by blood clots in your lungs. I struggled on for weeks being breathless with neither the nurses nor the docs really worrying about it. Then one day my GP said I think you have a clot. He was right! Clots are unusual but not unheard of with chemo. However, I'd make sure you mention it to the nurses or your oncologist next time you see them.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 2nd T this week. How is everyone else doing ?

Posts.Content: I too have read a lot about the benefits of cannabis oil. However, I find it very difficult to move past the links between cannabis and serious mental illness in vulnerable individuals (schizophrenia, bipolar, anxiety disorders to name a few0. I respect everyone's right to choose but I'm afraid it's not for me and I could never recommend it.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: I too had terrible problems with the steroids (dexmethasone in my case), although my problems are physical not mental. I am half way through the 12 week weekly paclitaxel treatment. My onco wouldn't let me have it with no steroids - he thinks it's important protection against the possible allergic reaction. He did however cut my dose right back to the minimum (4mg) when I think the normal dose is up to 20mg - and I don't have any dex tablets after the infusion. I've been fine on that regime. There are a couple of other possibilities. The cancer research UK site suggests abraxane instead as you don't need the steroid. It's usually only used for metastatic BC though. There's also an article from the US NIH which seems to suggest that you can discontinue pre-meds after a couple of rounds if you don't get the allergic reaction.  I suggest you do a bit of research and go back to your onco with questions.
Posts.Title: Psychotic reaction to chemo steroids

Posts.Content: The best thing I found to take away the nasty mouth  feel was bicarb mouthwash. 1 tsp dissolved in a cup of warm water. Swill it round your mouth as often as you like, warm or cold. I used to use it just before eating anything, to give the food the best chance of tasting ok.  You can add a couple of drops of peppermint essence to it if you fancy mint flavouring but I never bothered. Best
Posts.Title: Metalic mouth

Posts.Content: Hi Lamg There are basically two taxanes - taxotere (or docetaxel) which is normally every 3 weeks with 3 or 4 treatments, and Taxol (or paclitaxel) which is weekly for 12 weeks. The weekly regimen is a lower dose and usually easier as far as side effects go, and some people who really struggle on docetaxel are swapped to the weekly paclitaxel. It sounds to me like you're having the docetaxel but with accelerated treatment - fortnightly instead of 3 weekly. That's a tough regimen. May I suggest that you have  full discussion with your oncologist next time you see him or talk to himso you're quite clear on what is being given to you. You might also want to ask why fortnightly and whether you should switch to paclitaxel weekly.  It sounds like you didn't do too badly on the first lot - was that EC or its cousin AC? My purely speculative observation is that a lot of people who do ok on EC find T tough and vice versa.  Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: Taxol (do not know the full name)

Posts.Content: Hooley dooley Mom74 that's a tough chemo regime - I've never heard of that before. I had 4 cycles of AC fortnightly followed by 9 out of an intended 12 paclitaxel. I had the weekly paclitaxel rather than the 3 weekly docetaxel. Do look after yourself and don't worry about your hair - you will know when it starts to come out. Best
Posts.Title: TAC and hair loss

Posts.Content: The risk with having an implant and then radiotherapy is that of capsular contracture. This is where fibres grow round the implant and squeeze it so it becomes mis-shapen. It also makes radio more difficult as they have to plan the beams around the implant spot. I was told that your skin takes a year to fully recover from radio and my surgeon doesn't want to do a reconstruction till a year has passed.  Best of luck Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Am I being too trusting?

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo. Good to hear from you and great that your doing so well. Just make sure you keep that work-life balance and don't slip back into old habits. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: There's a lot of stupidity out there - lemon, coconut oil, and a hundred others. Unfortunately my sister-in-law believes it.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: POSTCARD FROM AUSTRALIA Who are you now KerryCake? A tough capable woman who has been through a whole lot of sh*t and come out the other side ready for the rest of her life. You go girl! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Who am I now? Answers on a postcard please.....

Posts.Content: Hi Sue. Everyone's chemo journey is different and we all experience different SEs. I had few problems with nausea, vomiting, taste or mouth ulcers but I got the bad SEs instead eg pulmonary embolisms. Chemo is a horrible experience but as my onco said, they're not trying to kill you! You will get through it and come out the other side stronger. Radio then is a breeze, apart from the inconvenience of going every day.  Best wishes for your treatment. Try not to over-worry. Lynn
Posts.Title: About to start chemo and so worried

Posts.Content: I finished chemo at the end of January. Most of my hair is about 4 cm long now but it is shorter on top and that definitely took longer to get growing. I was told that's normal.  I haven't had a haircut as such but I have had my husband shave the bottom back to a no 4 so my hair now looks like a deliberate style rather than an unkempt mullet! As for the sticky out bits - I just stick them down with product. Not entirely happy with it but it's way better than no hair and lots of people have complimented me. Rocking the Judi Dench look! Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: 1st haircut after vhemo

Posts.Content: I always wanted to be able to draw and paint KerryCake but I'm afraid I'm talent-free! I clearly remember a school report from when I was about 14 - I got a C for art, with the comment "Lynn tries", which just about said it all. However, I'm much better at craft and am going to sign up for a glass making class. We have a fabbo Glassworks nearby with everything from beginners making beads through to mastercraftspeople  making amazing stuff. I had to wait till I got my holidays out the way but am signing up for the next class.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Who am I now? Answers on a postcard please.....

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha. Sorry to hear you have to have a mastectomy. Am I reading your post right that it's both breasts? I had a left mastectomy with implant in June 2015. I gained a lovely pert boob, alas no nipple. The surgeon had to take out my lymph nodes as well but she went in through the cut on the underside of my breast so I had one single scar under the breast, close to the chest wall. Healing for me was really fast. I had the wound covered with plastic for 10 days and when I peeled that off, most of the scab came off too. If I recall correctly, the rest of the scab was gone in a week. I was given arm exercises the day after surgery and did them religiously to recover full movement in my arm and shoulder. No pain at all.  As it happened I was very ill during chemo and put on about 10kg of fluid, which eventually went from everywhere except my new boob. This meant eventually that I had to have the implant removed and I decided not to go for another one, thinking that I'm vulnerable to fluid problems. However, don't let that put you off - what happened to me is very rare.  I don't know if your surgeon has mentioned it but radiotherapy can be problematic with implants. Firstly, getting the angles right is more difficult as there's a silicon blob in the way. Secondly, people occasionally get what's called capsular contracture, where fibres grow round the implant, squeezing and distorting it, as well as causing pain. The only solution is to replace the implant. I'm not certain but I think that you can have temporary implants, some of which can be left permanently if all is ok, or else they're replaced later with permanent implants. May I suggest that you make sure that your surgeon fully explains all this, including all the risks and benefits.  Hope it all goes well for you.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy,

Posts.Content: You've definitely done the right thing helsbels18 - and it seems to be looking positive which is great. I wouldn't tell my hubbie either as he's so neurotic! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: Hi JJ I've just re-read this thread and thought I'd share my rehab with you. 6 months ago I was in hospital for a month, including 2 weeks in the ICU. My onco wanted me to do in-patient rehab as the majority of people over 60 never fully recover from a stint in ICU. However, I waited for a week for a place in a private hospital and in the end couldn't stand being in the cancer ward any longer so I went home. At that time I could just about walk 20 metres, as long as there was a hand railing, and couldn't climb stairs. I had to use a wheelchair to get to the car to go home and then be helped by my husband into the house. There was an 18 week wait for out patient rehab so I decided to do my own.  I religiously did the exercises given to me by the physio at the hospital and also bought an exercise bike. When I first started I could only do one minute on the easiest setting. I have stuck at it and now do 20 mins daily with interval training, including a bit at the toughest level. A cycling coach whom I know said it's not necessary to do more than 20 mins as long as you do intervals.  Six months later ... I'm fitter than I've ever been, I can walk longer than most of my friends (except the exercise nut) and feel better than I have in 15 years. It sort of crept up on me and I still can't really believe it. But it is great. If you can buy, borrow or dig out of the garage an exercise bike I'd highly recommend it.  With very best wishes for a complete recovery. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Back from hospital after DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi. Sorry to hear you have a recurrence - not the news you wanted! I had a full node clearance in June 2015 with my first surgery. I had a second surgery in March 16. I still have a seroma from the last surgery but no sign of lymphoedema. I've even had an infection in the hand on that side but nothing.  I have been religious with the arm exercises since the first surgery and still do them. I have full shoulder movement and no pain. I do carry things but try to avoid heavy lifting - that's all I avoid.  And just to reassure you - I'm very overweight too, although I've lost quite a bit since being diagnosed. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Terrified at the thought of axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi JJ - you poor tihng, sounds like you got the worst of everything! I agree with you that they don't give you clear warnings or maybe we just don't listen carefully enough. I had a saved skin mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. I swear I wasn't told about capsular contracture or the difficulty implants causes for radio therapy. Anyway I've had several problems with the reconstructed breast and 2 weeks ago had it chopped off. I don't regret it. Hopefully you will recover better now you are home. Best wishes Lynn
Posts.Title: Back from hospital after DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi Hides It's probably a bit of vein damage from the chemo. However, this can get serious if you get a clot. Please ring your chemo unit or whatever your contact point is to check. Remember they'd rather check than have something serious overlooked. If it suddenly starts hurting a lot or swelling more, then take yourself to A&E.
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Great post Julia
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: My husband has had a terrible time of it starting with serious anger and moving through fear to crazy levels of worrying. He's been depressed before and is on the pills - basically he's a nervy person. Of course it wasn't helped by me ending up really sick and in ICU.  I feel that he's coped with the whole BC experience a lot less well than I have. However, he's good now although he does still try to smother me still. I do feel though that I've had to "manage" him as well as myself and have some resentment about that (although I'd never say so) - for once it was about me and not about him. I can't advise you how to handle him, just a couple of things that worked for me. I made sure to let him feel useful as helpless feelings were one of his key issues - letting him cook dinner, bring me cups of tea, driving me to appointments even when I was quite capable of driving myself. Secondly I made sure not to bite or argue when he was fussing over me, even though sometimes it drove me mad. Thirdly I made sure we did "normal" things together whenever I could - lunch at a cafe, trip to the movies and so on. Also I tried really hard to be nice to him (this sprang from a comment he made - "you're lovely to your friends but horrible to me"). I wasn't dishonest though and there were times when I had to tell him to back off or shut up eg when he'd carry on about possible consequences - usually I'd put it in terms of him making a difficult journey more difficult for me. The plus side is that I have absolutely no doubt that he really cares and our relationship has remained rock solid - better than before if that's possible. Best of luck Lynn
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Hi LovelyTapir So sad to hear about your blood sugar problems. Sad because it's not uncommon and yet it doesn't seem to be something they consider when looking at side effects. For example, when they do your bloods or BP they could easily do a glucose test as well.  I had terrible problems with glucose levels during chemo. In fact, the endocrinologist is of the opinion that I was tipped into diabetes ie steroid-induced diabetes. This was discovered at the end of my AC chemo when I had heart problems (atrial fibrillation) and clots in my lungs too. Apparently it was all linked. When I was much improved and resumed chemo with T, I asked if I could have it without any steroids. My onco was very reluctant because of the possible allergic effects of T. However he did agree to reduce the dose to the bare minimum so I just had 8mg dexmethasone infused just prior to the T and no before or after tablets. Even so my BGL went up from an ok 6 or 7 to around 15 or 16 and took 48 hours to come down.  The moral of this story is that you need to talk to your onco about the dose of steroids you're being given. If you're not having too much nausea, they should be able to cut them back quite considerably.  As for food, I didn't want to eat much at all and I confess I didn't pay much attention to blood sugar levels at that time. I lived on scrambled eggs, cherry tomatoes, grapes, fresh orange juice and tomato soup. They were the only things I could bear to put in my mouth.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: For me it took 6 weeks for my energy levels to go up. I had a second significant improvement when I finished Herceptin. Now, 15 months since I finished the main chemo I'm pretty much back to normal, although I do crash if I overdo it, and crash harder than I ever have. My onco told me to expect it to take 2 years to be fully back to normal.

Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Well said manshill.  I am open to the concept of alternative treatments, and also of the placebo effect. I think everyone has to do what's right for them. What I find really irritating however is the pseudo-science. Grand statements that sound somewhat scientific - enough to suck in those that don't know - but really complete b/s in terms of the science. Unfortunately, there are several of these statements making an appearance on this  thread.  Personally I don't think it does McMillan any credit to let this run. They have a precious reputation for factual believable information and should do everything to preserve it.  Meantime, advice to anyone reading this thread - don't believe everything that's written here.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: I had horrible headaches throughout chemo. I'm a bit of a headachey person but they were way worse and longer than normal. My onco told me to use neurofen plus (ibuprofen plus 12.8mg codeine in each tab). They worked. However, as George said, you do have to be careful as they can be addictive so I saved them for the very worst days. Otherwise I used paracetamol and ibuprofen 2 hrs apart, which did help. Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Hellish Headache

Posts.Content: Sorry to disappoint you Flopsy, but I'm not on Tamoxifen. I'm on anastrazole (Arimidex). I'm pretty sure my nail loss was due to chemo as I watched it deteriorate right from the beginning :( It was only when we were in Bali and I was swimming a lot that it actually fell off - got too soft I think. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Nails breaking and coming away from Nail bed

Posts.Content: Hi Karen Lacomtekp Just want to wish you all the best for tomorrow. I'll be thinking of you.  Hugs Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Content: Hahahaha I live in Canberra (the capital, although few people seem to realise it). It's 3 hrs drive to Sydney and about 8 hours to Melb. We have been known to drive up to Sydney for lunch as there are great curries in Little India.   The Lebua will be cool and both beach places sound great. You'll have a fabulous time. xxx Carolyn28
Posts.Title: Can l fly Liverpool - Dublin after all Chemo's have finished ?

Posts.Content: Hi cuckoo As long as you're seeing someone, I don't think it matters who it is. After all, they all should be capable of finding any recurrence, dealing with minor problems or lecturing you about one thing or another. Are you on AIs or tamoxifen? If so, then you might need to see the oncologist if you're having problems, but best to raise anything with the GP or breast unit first. I still see my medical oncologist, surgeon and radio-oncologist roughly every 4 months but that's in rotation so I only see each of them once a year.
Posts.Title: 2 yrs post-treatment, should I still be seeing Oncologist?

Posts.Content: Sigh. It actually all started in Sydney (Captain Cook and all that). You're pretty close on the placement of cities but Melbourne is in Victoria. Canberra isn't in NSW either but we are surrounded by NSW. We are in the Aust. Capital Territory - a bit like DC.  People here have a different view of driving. I remember when we were living near Wimbledon and took a Sunday drive to Winchester. The people at work the next day looked at me as though I was from Mars! Mind you it used to sometimes take me nearly 2 hours to go see my grandmother in Belvedere, Kent if the M25 was bad. No one ever thought that was extraordinary.  Lynn xx Carolyn28
Posts.Title: Can l fly Liverpool - Dublin after all Chemo's have finished ?

Posts.Content: And just to add to this intellectual discussion, I saw this today: Noting that they are in fact drumhead cabbages, not lettuces, hence the relevance.
Posts.Title: Anyone for Cabbage (Radiation related)

Posts.Content: Hi Always Baking  Something else to worry about grrrr! At least they're on to it and it may well turn out to be nothing to worry about. I had a similar situation where some dumb ass radiologist thought he saw mets on my spine. I was an in-patient and very unwell at the time so no one wanted to tell me, including my oncologist. Instead my hubby, brother and mother worried themselves stupid. What they didn't know (but I did) was that I'd already had a CT scan of the area (ordered by my surgeon months beforehand) and it was found to be only calcification. If only they'd mentioned it to me ... So anyway I had an MRI and guess what - it was just calcification! Carolyn28 Lucky you going to Thailand - Koh Samui is one of my very favourite places. Bangkok is an experience too - great fun but noisy and smelly and hard to get round. If you haven't already booked your hotel there, try to get somewhere near the river as the river boats and taxis make life a lot easier. We like to stay at the Shangri-La, which is not only a fabbo hotel by the river but is also right near a monorail station and within walking distance of Silom Rd, one of the good shopping areas. When are you going to make it as far as Australia? We have a lovely spare bedroom and a pool. I'm hanging out for a visitor from overseas so I can take them on a road trip! Love to all  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Can l fly Liverpool - Dublin after all Chemo's have finished ?

Posts.Content: I've retired so I didn't have the work or not decision to make. There is, however, no way I could have worked cos of the fatigue. Some days I barely had enough energy to have a shower. Everyone's journey is different though so you might be fine. I did have to give up my volunteer work in an aged care facility though - the onco said they're a hotbed of multi-resistant organisms and the risk of infection was too high.
Posts.Title: Work during treatment

Posts.Content: Hi chris47 I just use a couple of safety pins to pin the KK to my bra, one at the bottom middle and one by the strap. I have found that moulded lightly padded bras work best as they give you a matching shape to start with. Then you just need to fill out those shapes. My husband and my best friends tell me you can't tell any difference. I also do the same with my bathers but I have a KK filled with shower scrunchy for swimming. It took me about 4 tries to get the KK exactly right for me - ended up with a C cup size but with slightly less padding than recommended.  Good luck with it.
