Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Baileybelle You've raised the age old question. One I think everyone who's had a mastectomy asks (or suffers from) at some point.  I refuse to wear a silicon prosthesis for several reasons - they cost about $400 here in Australia and there are no freebies, although you can get some contribution towards the cost through your private health insurance. Secondly it means you have to wear a pocketed bra or else you run the risk of the chicken fillet popping out to say hello. I'm told they feel really hot and uncomfortable in Australian summers too.  Anyway, I wear a knitted knocker - very light and comfortable and I can safety pin it to my bra so there are no surprise appearances. This means you can wear any bra. I've been through many many bras since my mastectomy and never really found a perfect one. In fact, my most preferred bras are ones I had before surgery that I have removed the underwire from. Don't know what I'll do when they wear out.  As far as reconstruction goes, my surgeon said she wouldn't do anything until at least 12 months after finishing radio. She's happy to do it after that. However, I don't want a reconstruction as I've had lots of problems with fluid and I don't want more.  I agree that more pretty bras should be available but I wonder about the size of the market for them as most people seem to have lumpectomies or reconstructions now. Wishing you all the best
Posts.Title: Mastectomy Bras!

Posts.Content: I finished chemo (AC followed by Paclitaxel) on 29 January. I only lost one toenail but all my nails became very soft and flaky and kept splitting and breaking. Only nail hardener kept them together but then sometimes the top would just snap off. Most have grown out now but my thumbs are still very flaky and I think they've got about another 5mm to grow. I've still got a couple of Beau's lines on them. Also on one index finger, the nail bed has retreated and I may still lose that nail.  My regrowing toenail is only halfway up so far. So yep it could still be chemo but if your nails were ok and then started being not ok, it may not be. I haven't heard that Tamoxifen does anything drastic to nails though.  I'm going to reward myself with a professional manicure when my thumbs have finally grown out. Can't wait! Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Nails breaking and coming away from Nail bed

Posts.Content: Hi Always Baking  I don't want to be a party pooper but if your last treatment is on 27 October, you'll have the usual fatigue, neutropenia and other side effects for at least a couple of weeks. Aeroplanes are full of germs so you'd be putting yourself at risk of infection if you travel immediately after your last treatment. If I were you, I'd wait at least a month. Sorry Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Can l fly Liverpool - Dublin after all Chemo's have finished ?

Posts.Content: Perhaps you should try manuka honey cream. Medihoney or othrers available in health food shops and the like. But beware of imitations - Tesco's finest won't do any good lol
Posts.Title: FEC T allergic reaction

Posts.Content: I didn't keep a diary, but I wish I had. I didn't think of it till about half way through and then I had no energy. I'm already having trouble remembering a lot of stuff, especially how I felt physically. I guess forgetting is a self-protection mechanism but I'd like to be able to remember just how bad I felt so I can compare it to how great I feel now. What I do have is details of most of my treatment. Doctors do like to write to each other and copy everyone else in and my lovely GP gives me copies. Unfortunately the gaping hole is my time in hospital so I'm thinking of putting in a Freedom of Information request to get that info so I have a complete record. Important in case we move.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: I actually had two planning appointments. The first time I had a football on my chest - my implanted boob had swollen massively. There was a lot of talk between the technicians, the radio oncology consultant and the radiotherapy registrar about how to deal with this massive boob. They took loads of measurements for making a special bolus (covering that brings the radiation beam target closer to the surface of the skin). They also made a back mould so I would be lying in an odd position that was easier to irradiate. And of course I had the scan and tatts. In the end the consultant decided she wasn't happy with the idea of irradiating the football and referred me back to my surgeon.  After a mastectomy, I had another much more straightforward planning appointment - measurements, scan, more tatts.  The only reason I've mentioned all this is that some radio oncologists get very thingy about doing radiotherapy when you've got an implant. This is for two reasons - firstly it makes getting the positioning of the beams harder and secondly radio can damage the implant. Many people with implants have had successful radio though so don't get too concerned.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy planning appointment

Posts.Content: JeanieB One guy was so frightened that his brother went in his place and it was only the fact that the particular radiotherapy he had needed a mould that has been made to fit the actual patient that they realised it was the brother It's impossible to underestimate some people
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy planning appointment

Posts.Content: Hi Pocket rocket That doesn't sound great. It's hard to understand why they didn't deal with it while they had you opened up. A similar situation happened to Carolyn28 but she's not really around at the moment - living it up in Singapore, lucky thing. However, I've tagged her so she's likely to get back to you soon. Best
Posts.Title: Another lump found

Posts.Content: I completely understand. I originally had a reconstruction but had no end of trouble so, finally, when there was no other option but surgery, I asked the surgeon to chop it off. I couldn't bear the thought of ongoing problems, with constant doctor and physio visits. Haven't regretted it for a minute. Not that I'm suggesting you do the same, but there must be a creative solution out there for you. Good luck
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy 5 years on

Posts.Content: Hi Debs. I don't know anything at all about looking after hamsters but I do have 3 indoor cats. I looked after them all through chemo, including changing their litter trays once a week and emptying the poo out daily. I wore rubber gloves and a paper face mask (to prevent inhaling any litter dust) and of course washed my hands thoroughly afterwards. Apart from that I had bottles of alcohol wash around the house and cleaned my hands with that frequently. No infection problems at all.  As for being by yourself ... I completely understand as I'm a bit of a loner. However, there were times when I really needed help. I was quite ill with side effects and very weak and fatigued. Changing the bed was beyond me as was any kind of heavy vacuuming. At times I wasn't fit to drive. I am blessed to have a supportive husband and some very good friends who all got me through it.  Generally I found that people really want to help but often aren't sure how to. I'd suggest letting one or two friends be part of your journey and then you'll at least have someone to turn to if needed. Wishing you all the best. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Living alone and having chemo

Posts.Content: Great post Julia
Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: Hi June. It's the gift that keeps giving isn't it? Firstly, congratulations on making the 5 years and getting back to your usual life. It sounds like you've been doing really well.  I presume the breast consultant has ruled out a recurrence?  I haven't had this sort of problem as I had a full mastectomy no reconstruction but sounds like you need to do something about it. Has your surgeon given you any info about the likely success of going down the liposuction route? Also, has he/she suggested any alternatives? All I can really say is don't agree to anything you're not comfortable with and do explore all the options.  Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy 5 years on

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. Have you seen the post yet about Macmillan making videos on hair loss? It's here.  Do consider participating - you might get a free wig consultation.
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I never had a night sweat or a hot flush with menopause. I only found out what the fuss was about when I first started on AIs. I did swap taking the pill in the evening for taking it in the morning. The night sweats immediately disappeared. The flushes during the day gradually reduced and after about 8 months - nothing. So hopefully there is light at the end of the tunnel for you.  I know you don't want to take any more drugs, so I'm going to suggest another drug hahahaha. Feel free to ignore me, cheerfully or otherwise. However, a lot of people with bad menopausal symptoms think that the anti-depressant venlafaxine is very helpful for relieving the symptoms. A friend of mine had it while menopausal. Then she got breast cancer and asked her onco if she should stop it. He said definitely no as it would help with the flushes from Arimidex. Might be worth asking about ... Friday is your non-work day isn't it? Do try to have a nap this afternoon. Makes the world of difference. Big hugs
Posts.Title: My Night....

Posts.Content: I don't wear button up shirts either, nor pyjamas. When I had my op, I borrowed 3 of my hubbie's casual cotton shirts. They were perfect! However, I found that after a couple of days I could easily pull on a loose top.  I originally had a skin saving mastectomy with implant but because of various problems with fluid, I had to have the implant removed and my boob cut off. Frankly, if I had my time over, I'd go for a full mastectomy immediately. It's not as bad as you might think and not noticeable when dressed!
Posts.Title: Having left sided masectomy without reconstruction in 2 weeks, please...

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl34. I was diagnosed in May 2015 - hormone positive and HER2+, grade 3, stage 3, 14/30 nodes were cancerous. 15 months of treatment (no pertuzumab as it hadn't been approved then) and lots of bumps along the way.  Now, I'm fit and happy and loving life. I guess it may come back but I'm not worrying about that. I'll deal with it if it happens. In the meantime, I'm living a full life and really enjoying myself. So yes there is life after HER2 !!!!
Posts.Title: 6 cycles of TCHP chemo finished But why am I worrying

Posts.Content: I use Guerlain Superaqua moisturiser. I was lucky enough to win a Guerlain pack about 5 years ago with about $1000 worth of cosmetics and skin products. I gave several away and had this moisturiser sitting in my drawer as I never used to use one at all. My skin went very dry during chemo so I dug it out. Wonderful! It's hideously expensive but one pot lasts nearly a year so not so bad. Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?

Posts.Content: Hi Buttermere fan  I had terrible headaches throughout chemo, but I'm a bit of a headachey person anyway. I found that only codeine plus ibuprofen really killed them. However, you have to be careful how often you use that so I had to save it for when I really needed it.  As for sickness, do ask for different meds - they have a whole arsenal. I found the best way of warding off nausea was dry biscuits - just a couple of ritz type biscuits really settled my tummy. I used to have them by my bed and carry them round in my bag. I found that when I couldn't drink water, weak ribena or orange squash were ok.  Wishing you the very best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Just started chemo

Posts.Content: Bras seem to be a never ending problem for us, whether we're big or small, fat or thin, one or two boobs. I ended up having a mastectomy after a reconstruction that didn't survive. During radiotherapy I avoided wearing anything tight around my chest area whenever possible so I was definitely lop-sided Lizzie for those 5 weeks. I've tried all sorts of different bras but the ones that work best are 3 old (pre-BC) preformed bras with the underwire removed. The look is positively normal! Dunno what I'll do when they eventually wear out. Best to all  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: scared to put a bra on after surger for lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Mira. Sorry to hear you're suffering! I've never been able to find any research that confirms what many of us feel ie that different brands have different impacts. There's plenty of anecdotal evidence (several threads on here for a start) but many oncologists won't acknowledge the problem. My own oncologist doesn't really believe in difference between the brands but he has been prepared to go along with me on the basis of the placebo effect. I was a bit cross that he didn't believe me but I got what I wanted so in the end it didn't matter. We can't all be wrong can we?
Posts.Title: Letrozole issues AGAIN! Need advice

Posts.Content: I was much the same Mira. I started on letrozole (a generic) but didn't know about the brand issue. It was awful, so my onco swapped me over to anastrozole. Similar problems but by then I'd heard of that changing brands could help. My friendly local pharmacist kindly gave me the patent brand arimidex and then when I next visited my onco I asked him to specific the brand. As I said he agreed but with some scepticism. I've been on Arimidex now for nearly 2 years and don't have much trouble at all - just a little stiffness if I sit for too long. I confess I've gained a bit of weight but I don't know if that's the Arimidex, me being a pig or just regaining some of the 40kg (88 pounds) I lost during chemo. I've been told it's almost unavoidable to regain some of the weight. I do get very hungry though.  I do hope you find a way to settle things down as it can be really debilitating.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Letrozole issues AGAIN! Need advice

Posts.Content: Hi Debs. I too had trouble sleeping during chemo. The best bit of advice I found was 'if you don't sleep at night, then sleep during the day'. It made me feel so much better and stop worrying about not sleeping! Cheers Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Living alone and having chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Susanne - I only managed R2 three times a day,  except on weekends. It was plenty  Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Bras seem to be a never ending problem for us, whether we're big or small, fat or thin, one or two boobs. I ended up having a mastectomy after a reconstruction that didn't survive. During radiotherapy I avoided wearing anything tight around my chest area whenever possible so I was definitely lop-sided Lizzie for those 5 weeks. I've tried all sorts of different bras but the ones that work best are 3 old (pre-BC) preformed bras with the underwire removed. The look is positively normal! Dunno what I'll do when they eventually wear out. Best to all  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: scared to put a bra on after surger for lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Best of luck with the scan MrsShep. I just had mine. I think we all get worried about it, even if we know it's not logical and I'm not sure they get easier as the years go by. Big hugs
Posts.Title: 2 yearly mammogram tomorroe

Posts.Content: No problems.  If stopping is a possibility, it would be worth asking the onco what percentage benefit (ie reduction in risk of recurrence) she thinks letrozole gives you. For some people it's only 3 or 4% but for others it's much more significant. That would help you make a rational decision.
Posts.Title: Letrozole issues AGAIN! Need advice

Posts.Content: Sorry I had the opposite of a long trek to radio - 12 mins, including walking to the car.  I used to put R1 on in the change room and then a very loose t shirt and sweat shirt (no bra).then i'd put R2 on at home. I never had a problem with it sticking. Someone said they put R2 on straight away - I think that's wrong. It's the R1 that's designed to cool the skin after treatment andR2 is the moisturiser. Best  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi BluesJK. Welcome to the forum. Posting in the chemo club is fine but if you want to start a new post, all you have to do is join the breast group and then you'll get a start new thread option on the right hand side. Most if not all of the people reading the chemo club thread will have decided to go for chemo. You might get a more balanced perspective if you started a new thread on the specific topic. To chemo or not to chemo is a big decision, especially given your age and potential compromise of fertility. I was in the 'throw everything at it' group but I understand why you might be reluctant. A bit of searching through the older threads in this group will find you lots of discussions about whether or not to have chemo - have a read as something might jump out at you that helps you make the decision.  I have to say that 41 on the oncotype test seems very high to me. I think you'll find that around 20 or 25 is usually the area where there's a decision to be made and higher than that most oncologists would definitely be recommending chemo. Mind you that's only my impression from reading threads here, as not having chemo wasn't an option for me as the cancer I had was HER2+. A 15% risk reduction seems pretty high to me too. I personally couldn't live with that level of risk although as I said, I'd pretty much do or take anything to avoid a recurrence. Hopefully someone will come along with the opposite viewpoint to me. I know there are plenty! Ruby Rose - It does seem unusual to have only 18 weeks worth of Herceptin. I don't recall anyone else only having that, other than toxophilite (whose treatment was stopped because of heart issues) but I do know that when Herceptin first came on the market, people in New Zealand only got 9 doses because the government couldn't afford to subsidise the full year's worth. I had atrial fibrillation during chemo but no problems at all with herceptin. I was closely monitored though, with a visit to the cardiologist every 3 months as well as a finger tip heart monitor to check every day.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ruby Rose - it's great the drugs are being tailored to suit you - as they should! I only mentioned the NZ situation to reassure you that there must have been some science to show that a shorter treatment than one year was effective. Your lucky to avoid FEC as that's well known for heart damage. Herceptin can do, usually temporary, damage to your heart, lowering the left ventricle ejection fraction. Mine went down a little - from high 60s to high 50s if I remember correctly - but not enough to cause problems. It was back to high 60s within 3 months of finishing H.  Your heart will be monitored but just make sure that if there are any signs of problems, you insist on a cardiology consult.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Mavi So similar to me!  I didn't have food poisoning but did have terrible trouble with my bowels during chemo - both ways. But what I really wanted to mention is that I have a Protein C deficiency, discovered when I had pulmonary embolisms during chemo. I'm on warfarin for the rest of my life. I asked about one of the more modern blood thinners but the specialist said that warfarin gives better control long term. The down side is that I have to have my blood tested once a month. The up side is that warfarin is reversible so if I were, say in a car accident, they could make my blood clot with a shot of Vitamin K. The other up  side is that I can't eat too many green vegetables - no more broccoli for me lol.  Also, on the question of port removal or not, I had a port but I had mine for about 18 months as I received my Herceptin by infusion (by injection wasn't available when I started and I was given a choice when injections came in). Afterwards I was given a choice of leaving it there or having it removed. I chose removal, mainly as they have to be flushed every 6-8 weeks. That would have meant a trip to the chemo unit every couple of months and I thought that would mean I'd never get away from being a patient. Not good psychologically.  All the best for the rest of your treatment.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Wink Mmm Busselton - a bit of a way from the major teaching hospitals lol but a lovely part of the country. Are you able to be treated locally? I came across one person on here who was from Charters Towers in Qld - she had to travel to Townsville (1.5 hours) for everything except the GP.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: My experience was of course different as I"m in Australia. Portacaths are used quite routinely here for anyone having more than a couple of chemo treatments.  I had mine inserted privately (not odd as I had my chemo at the same private hospital) and none of the nurses had any trouble. However, at one point I was very ill and was admitted to the tertiary public hospital. For some reason, they couldn't access my port - even the supposed port guru had several tries but couldn't get into it. I was also told at one point that all ports will take but only some will give - in other words it can be tricky to get blood from them. My take out from all of this is that ports, although they seem simple (just a drum that you poke a needle into), are in fact a dark art. I know you have to be trained but even then it's not easy. I think that's why some places avoid them.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ah Leolady56, I hadn't realised you are about to start chemo. I hope it all goes well for you. I had paclitaxel and didn't feel too bad through it, although I ended up with peripheral neuropathy so only had 9 of the 12 planned doses. Will you be having other chemo drugs afterwards?
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Katiepie Once upon a time I was a big drinker and I continued to drink quite a lot during my first lot of chemo (AC). However, I was hospitalised at the end of that for a month. That was an enforced break from alcohol. I went on to lifetime warfarin and was warned very severely about not drinking more than one glass of wine. Decided that none would be easier than one. That was in September 2015. Since then I've had 2 alcoholic desserts, one with sauternes jelly and the other with a calvados drizzle. That's it. And, while I acknowledge that I may have a drink now and then, I simply don't miss it at all. I think it was definitely easier having the enforced break in hospital though.  As for getting fit, I had to do self directed rehab when I got out of hospital (long story). I bought myself an exercise bike (or stationary bike at the gym types seem to call them these days) and gradually built up to 20 mins with intervals. A cycling coach I know told me that's enough for general fitness, as long as you do the intervals. I hate it still but do manage 5 times a week. The alternative was walking, but I hate that even more lol. As a friend of mine says, why walk when you've got a perfectly good car. But as a total non-exerciser for my entire life, I can assure you that a little bit of exercise will definitely help with the fatigue and WILL make you feel better. No need to go overboard.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi candytop What a dilemma and how irritating to have this happen at the same time. You poor thing. I think I tend to agree with Crystaljuju - lumpectomy, teeth, chemo. The main reason I think that is because bad teeth or gums can easily let germs in and are often the source of infection when your immune system is compromised by chemo. And infections are something you really will need to avoid if possible. I say lumpectomy before teeth so you can get rid of the little monster asap. Have they told you you're definitely to have chemo? It seems that, unlike here in Australia, not everyone is slated for chemo - depends on the risk of recurrence, type of cancer, whether it's spread to your lymph nodes and so on.  Despite what we all say, the main thing is that you should be guided by your oncologist. You need to be an assertive patient and press him/her until you get a full and satisfactory answer.  Wishing you all the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Dental verses chemo before lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Wow 2-3 months - that seems an extraordinary period of time to have to go without teeth! Is it just delays in service or do they want your gum to heal fully before fitting for new dentures. I couldn't have tolerated that kind of wait. Mind you the system's a bit different here in Australia - I haven't been to a dentist since I got the full dentures. I go directly to a dental technician ie the guy that makes and repairs them. He delivers new dentures in less than a week from the first moulds and repairs within 2 hours and is cheaper too lol. At least it will be winter in the UK - you can wear a woolly hat and scarf over your mouth and hide pretty well I should think. And of course it's perfect time of the year for soups and mashed potato. I found during chemo (when I had very little appetite) that tomato soup, fresh OJ and scrambled egg were among the very few foods I could actually get down. I lived on them plus cherry tomatoes and grapes for the entire period. I can't say I worried that much about nutrition as eating anything was a struggle - I relied on the eggs lol.  Hopefully you'll find enough soft foods that you can stand. Just think how great the first real meal will be after it's all over! Good luck with it all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Dental verses chemo before lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Never is a big word! I was told not to shave with a manual razor initially because the whole area is numb and it's too easy to cut yourself.  Are you having chemo or radio? My underarm hairs disappeared completely during chemo and haven't regrown on the affected side. On the other side, I have a few but nowhere near the forest I used to have. Best
Posts.Title: Under arm hair.......

Posts.Content: I understand helsbels18. My aunt died of pancreatic 3 years ago and a few weeks ago I found out an old friend has oesophageal cancer and isn't expected to survive more than a few weeks. It's crazy to say I feel lucky I had BC but I do and I'm so grateful for the marvellous treatment I've received and all the research that's been done into BC which puts us in a much better position today than many who get other types of cancer.
Posts.Title: Feeling sad but lucky!

Posts.Content: Both T and H can cause nose issues. I had a very dry nose, from which (ironically) liquid, almost like water, would pour out from time to time. Having no hairs doesn't help either. Mine didn't really clear up until I finished H. I moisturised a lot, poked Vaseline up my nose when it was very dry and used decongestant nasal spray when it was drippy.  Best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Sore nose

Posts.Content: Wow Leolady56 that's awful. I would certainly be on at them to make sure you get great treatment from here on. I had a port fitted - it's very common here in Australia. At the time I started, they were still giving Herceptin by infusion and everyone who was having H had a port because of the length of time. For me it was brilliant. Never had any problems with it and I have the tiniest scar - even I can't find it most of the time.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Leolady56 My chemo nurses called the red cheek look the doxy flush, short for doxorubicin. I guess epirubicin does the same.  Nothing to worry about. The only problem I found was that people thought I was rosy-cheeked and therefore healthy, which I wasn't. Stay strong and drink more water than you can imagine.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Wink Welcome to the forum. It must be very tough for you worrying about your kids while going through treatment but always bear in mind that over 90% of people survive breast cancer. In some parts of Australia, the survival rate is even higher. For example, in Canberra where I live, it's hovering around 96%, which is pretty amazing really. Whereabouts are you?  I had AC chemo followed by T but I had paclitaxel, which is 12 weekly doses, rather than docetaxel, which is 3 or 4 doses, 3 weeks apart. The A stands for doxorubicin (aka adriamyacin, which is where the A comes from). It's a close cousin to epirubicin, which is much more common in the UK. Australia seems to favour doxorubicin for some reason - I don't know of anyone here who has had epirubicin.  I had a hard time with the AC but found the T part reasonably easy. For some people it's the other way round and I have a good friend who sailed through both with very few side effects. You won't really know how difficult it will be until you get started.  The main advice I'd give you right now is to accept help when it's offered and make sure you have some back up for looking after your kids if you feel cr*p. Knowing they're ok will take the pressure off you if all you want is a doona day. Apart from that, drink loads of water - I was told to drink 3 litres in the 24 hours following chemo and 2 litres every other day - and try to get some gentle exercise. It really does help.  Don't forget we're here if you want to ask any questions or just need to rant about anything. I hope it goes well for you and your side effects are mild.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thanks for letting us know candytop At least you've got a realistic plan now. Sounds pretty sensible to me. How long before you can get dentures? When I had my teeth out, the dentures went straight in and I wasn't allowed to take them out for 3 days. That was many many years ago though.  Wishing you all the best Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Dental verses chemo before lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Interesting. I saw my oncologist before every treatment and have continued to see him once a month through Herceptin. It's just a check up. We mostly talked about side effects but he did also check for lumps every second visit. I also get weighed as that can vary the dose. Made me feel confident that I was being looked after. Lots of love  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Appointment With Chemo Consultant Halfway Thro My Chemo's ??

Posts.Content: Just adding my little bit. Surprisingly, I've found I'm ill less often since finishing treatment. Actually I didn't have a cold at all during treatment, for which I was very grateful, and I only had one last year, which was shortly after I finished herceptin. I have made sure to have my annual flu shot early though.
Posts.Title: Hello, I've just joined the forum today and was wondering if anyone...

Posts.Content: Hi Sharpie6 It does sound like you've been through the mill a bit. It must be worrying for you. But well done you for reading your notes and finding the problem. That just shows how important it is for all of us to be on top of what's happening.  Can biopsies be wrong? I'd imagine any procedure can be wrong, but the error rate would be pretty low. However, a biopsy is taking a sample of tissue and then the pathologist looks at the cells in that sample. It is possible for suspicious areas to be partly ok and partly cancerous. The main thing though is that your surgeon is on to it and that means they can treat both lumps if the second does turn out to be cancerous. I have tagged Carolyn28 as she had a bad time with misdiagnosis and she may have more to say. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Does anyone have experience or know of a core biopsy being wrongly...

Posts.Content: Oh Ruby Rose, I'm so sorry. Even if you think a loved one is close to the end it's still an awful shock. You've had so much on your plate recently, I'm not surprised you hesitated about starting chemo. But just remember YOU ARE STRONG and you'll get through it for the sake of your family. Just take it all one day at a time and take refuge in your lovely family. They'll be there for you. May your side effects be minimal.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I found T much easier than AC, but I did have the weekly paclitaxel. I've also had my 12 months of Herceptin, which didn't really cause any problems other than the drippy nose - without warning, water will just pour out of your nose. Keep tissues very handy at all times. Make sure you tell your onco or chemo unit if you have any trouble with T as the dose can be reduced or you can be switched to the weekly paclitaxel.  Hope it all goes well for you.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel & Heceptin Chemo

Posts.Content: Oh you poor thing! Something else to worry about. I've not heard of this problem so sorry I can't be more help.  I'd insist on at least a PICC line. Mind you it does seem ridiculous that they don't do portacaths grrrr.  Best Lynn xxx
Posts.Title: Lymph nodes in the mesentery

Posts.Content: Hi. I've nothing really to add to the good advice already given but I just want to wish you all the best.  Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: Dream kitchen - everyone should have one! My problem is when we had our kitchen redone a couple of years back I got a fabulous extra cupboard about 50 cm deep and 1.2 metres wide. I call it my toy cupboard. Problem what problem - it's now full cos I can't resist buying gadgets and pots and pans.  But for me the most luxurious thing about my kitchen is the lid drawer. Yes an entire drawer for pan lids. It makes life so much easier. Happy cooking all Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Is An MRI Scan The Best Scan To check If The B.C. Has Spread ?

Posts.Content: Seems like it's time to be assertive KiwiCardi especially if your onco was wavering. I don't see why anyone should have to put up with infusion by cannula - instruments of torture!!!  Mind you if you do have to have a cannula, make sure you drink heaps and heaps of water beforehand. Being fully hydrated really does help plump up your veins and makes it much easier.  Best of luck with it all Lynn
